My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Still a work of art to this day. 

Not much to say that hasn't already been said honestly, the level design is phenomenal, exploring black mesa is just a joy, the atmosphere is unparalleled, and Gordon's journey is exciting from beginning to end. 

There are a total of 18 chapters, the first 14 are all absolutely incredible fun, full of frantic fights and memorable set pieces. Yes even on a rail is good (although I admit it drags on for too long). The final 4 are the infamous Xen chapters, which on replaying them I don't think are nearly as bad as people make them out to be, but also I didn't enjoy them as much as the Black Mesa chapters. And the Nihilanth boss fight ended up harder than I remembered or expected now. 

I encountered some bugs here and there, mostly with AI behavior and flickering textures, but nothing that would really ruin the experience. For example the Gonarch got stuck in place while walking to the next arena twice. But for a 24 year old game, the fact it has so few issues on modern systems is impressive.

Overall though Half-Life is still an absolute masterpiece even with it's slight technical issues and later chapters. I would love to see Valve patch the game to fix some of the bugs, and maybe give it a remaster similar to the one Quake got, to really bring this timeless classic up to date.

Half-Life is a very unique game when it comes to its story-telling. Everything is experienced through the eyes of Gordon Freeman rather than told to you, the player, through any cutscenes. You're left in the dark about everything that's happening in Black Mesa and when the facility gets invaded, you experience and figure everything out first hand. This is especially powerful in the opening moments of the game when you're mostly defenceless and witness all the chaos around you.

The gun-play and difficulty are finely calibrated, the weapons are fun to use, the enemy line-up makes for a lot of unique combat scenarios and the game has a good amount of puzzles which halt progression. It is a remarkably solid game that feels very modern to play despite its dated visuals, it holds up very well!

The Half-Life series is (currently) my absolute favorite game series, with Half-Life: Alyx being on top, and Half-Life 2 and Episode 2 not far below. Still, Half-Life 1 doesn't need to hide at all behind its successors.

Run. Think. Shoot. Live.
This motto on the back of Half-Life's original packaging pretty much sums it up accurately.
The game can be quite unforgiving in some places, even on normal difficulty. You really need to be deliberate about your actions and strategy. (Quicksave is your friend!)
Once you are aware of that, the game basically turns into a combat puzzle game. 
The campaign and story are slowly escalating. You start off on a normal day of work that goes haywire. Most of the time, you are on your own, forced to adapt to the circumstances and prove yourself decisive in the bigger picture.

All in all, a classic that holds up after more than 20 years!

Note #1: Many recommend to play the original over the Source port. I myself played the Source version and didn't have any issues with it.
Note #2: You can also play this in VR! Just look up Half-Life VR by Max Vollmer.
Note #3: Black Mesa, the Half-Life remake by the community, improves upon the original in almost every way possible. Modern graphics, reworked levels, and great music!

[h1]They're waiting for you, Gordon.
In the [b]test chamber[/b].[/h1]

You can't go by as a gamer on Steam without knowing about the existence of [b]Half-Life[/b]. That is, of course, because Steam itself would not exist had it not been for the success of this game and the many others it spawned throughout the years. Counter-Strike, Team Fortress, Portal and countless other games and even more mods would all not exist if it weren't for this game in particular. For many years I had not gotten interested in playing the first Half-Life, despite thoroughly enjoying the second one and all the previously mentioned games as well.

On the 31st of August, precisely a week ago as of the time of writing I changed my mind and played through the game for the first time ever. It hooked me in so much that for a whole week, I could not put it down and by this point I had put [i]an unhealthy amount of hours[/i] into the game and had completed 15 playthroughs of Half-Life in a row. It is hard to recall a game that would've gotten me to do the same to this extreme extent, albeit DOOM and Quake being most probable exceptions, some of the most important games I consider my all-time favorite FPS games.
[b]Now I know which game I can confidently add to that list.[/b]

[b]Half-Life[/b] has been known to be described as a linear campaign experience, which is true - in return, however, it [b]is extremely well balanced[/b] from start to finish ([i]*khm*[/i] maybe with some exceptions, [spoiler]Xen[/spoiler]). Half-Life has intense speed and full-throttle action that stretches all throughout its campaign, while also filling the gaps between these encounters with map exploration, puzzles and environmental story telling, which compared to FPS games before Half-Life has not been the case and to "boomer shooter" fans might sound like a turn off - however, it is absolutely not!

After the game kicks off with the introductory prologue, the chapters are put together in the most varied and exciting way; so well that for 15 playthroughs (until the other half of some of the later playthroughs - we're talking a lot of hours and a human brain here after all) I hardly ever felt any frustration due to the pacing, as when there was action, it was intense and tough with the artificial intelligence being surprisingly mobile and smart, resulting in each combat encounter engaging and challenging, and when these fights would tire you just a bit too much, the game would gear back and give you breathing space, rewarding you with story elements of a somewhat clich√© yet as interestingly told plot as back then was possible (I personally love the concept of it and experiencing it first-hand each time), along with engaging environments and light-hearted but satisfying puzzles.

The movement and quick weapon switching also give you tremendous amount of freedom, as on top of the base running speed that is just as fast as it should be, you're also able to improve yourself with bunny hopping and long jump later on, and simultaneously if the story or environments so desire, the player can also slow down to walk and sneak, standing or crouching, with more possibilities than in most games before and even after it.

I personally, after so many playthroughs, mostly try to play as fast as possible and the storytelling and narrative, for the majority of the game and with a few exceptions, do not slow me down whatsoever. Although if I want to focus on those aspects with greater attention, I play slow and the experience is albeit moreover the same, obviously there is a huge difference in many different ways. This flexibility is something one cannot experience in many other shooters before or after Half-Life, and it gives a feeling of freedom that is unique and makes the game even better as it is up to the player how they want to enjoy it.

Technology-wise by now it does not surprise anyone that the game also runs and loads in lightning-fast, and due to its easy moddability and developer tools, the possibilities are countless and throughout Half-Life's almost 30-year-old existence, there were many people making their mark not just in the modding scene but in the grand video game industry as well because of GoldSrc and Source, later on, and Valve's accepting and encouraging policy regarding fan-made content.

[b]This game is a goldmine for FPS enjoyers and is really well put together.
[i]A timeless classic that influenced and still influences an entire industry and millions of people worldwide.[/i][/b]

There's still some life in this 24 year-old shooter. Anyone reading this probably knows how influential this game is, so this review will focus on my own experience as a modern gamer playing for the first time in 2022. To be clear, first-person shooters are not a genre I am well-acquainted with. In fact, this is the first fps campaign I have actually finished, so I won't bother comparing it with others like it. Instead, I'll attempt to meet the game on its own terms.

Starting with what I enjoyed, Half-Life has an intriguing story and a tense, creepy sci-fi atmosphere. You play as a physicist escaping from an underground research facility after a lab accident causes aliens to teleport into the base and wreak havoc. Where the aliens are coming from and why they are attacking is a mystery for most of the game, and the question of what exactly the creatures [i]want[/i] is only partially answered. The real intrigue is in the game's cutscene-free storytelling, which puts you in the protagonist's skin and creates a feeling of isolation. You don't just watch the accident play out--you conduct the experiment yourself, and are forced to deal with the consequences when it goes wrong. And so, you tear your way through the facility, blasting any aliens in your path and walking past dozens of dying scientists in the hopes that maybe you can stop this mess after reaching the surface--but for now, you just have to survive. This is complemented surprisingly well by some of the cheesier bits of dialogue, voice acting, and sometimes strange AI, which offset the creepiness by providing some welcome, if unintentional levity to all the chaos. This may sound like a backhanded complement, but it actually works in the game's favor; these lapses are often so well-timed, you'd swear it was intentional. 

Now, as the game tells its story through mostly uninterrupted gameplay, I'd be remiss not to talk about both aspects. In the spirit of playing a lone scientist surviving an alien invasion, the game keeps you peeking around every corner, often building a sense of dread by letting you hear enemies well before you can see them. But you can't always rely on this, as aliens may teleport in at any time. These surprise attacks are generally reactable, as enemies have distinct behavior patterns and character designs that the player will already be familiar with before getting ambushed. These patterns help you to quickly make informed choices about how to avoid damage and what weapons to use. And this is good, because the game's weapon arsenal is [i]massive[/i]. All in all, the game does a very good job at forcing you to think on your feet while still allowing you to make plans and play creatively. 

Unfortunately, not all aspects of the gameplay are as thrilling as the excellent combat. Platforming in particular is terrible. The game often expects you to walk on narrow ledges and make precise jumps quickly despite having no indicator of where your feet are, and jumping onto some higher ledges may require you to crouch mid-jump, which makes the less-awkward normal jumps kind of pointless. Additionally, ladders control as though the player is simply [i]walking[/i] up a vertical stretch, which can cause you to slip off the side of the ladder if you aren't careful. This is worsened by the fact that the level design sometimes forces you to combine all of these awkward mechanics, and the final stages of the game are almost pure platforming. 

On the more subjective qualities of the game, some players may be put off by the fact that the game encourages a very slow, defensive playstyle. This is not helped by the fact that the game makes save-scumming easy--and tempting, thanks to a jagged difficulty curve. The latter problem only gets worse as you near the end of the game, when stages become noticeably messier and more gimmicky, resulting in needless confusion and some cheap deaths. 

On the whole, I give Half-Life a modest recommendation to anyone interested in an immersive campaign with a chilling atmosphere and strategic combat. However, prepare to put up with a lot of frustration along the way. If you aren't charmed by 90s graphics, prefer quick thrills to slow build-up, or [i]really[/i] don't like difficult games, then perhaps this game isn't for you. Half-Life feels very much like two games in one, although, regrettably, that‚Äôs not a good thing. For the majority of its runtime, you have a nearly flawless romp that ebbs and flows from survival horror into full-on action, one that has aged wonderfully if you can look past the archaic graphical fidelity. However, as it reaches what should‚Äôve been a spectacular climax, it instead becomes a grind you‚Äôre almost happy to see end.

However, if the past twenty-five-ish years have shown anything, it‚Äôs that even the rush job that was Xen didn‚Äôt color people‚Äôs impressions of Half-Life. There‚Äôs a lot more good than bad here and a couple of, at worst, mediocre hours don‚Äôt ruin the overall experience. The original Half-Life is still a nearly flawless experience and one that every self-respecting gamer should play through at least once‚Äîthough there‚Äôs no shortage of extra content, from the official expansions to literally hundreds of mods and map packs, to expand your trip to the Black Mesa Research Facility.

If you haven‚Äôt played it in a while, go back and reexperience it all over again. If it‚Äôs your first time, then grab your crowbar and face the unforeseen consequences of your actions. Trust me when I say that life will be different.

[h1] Review [/h1]
[b] Summary - [/b] Half-Life is a series of first-person shooter (FPS) games developed and published by Valve. The games combine shooting combat, puzzles and storytelling. The original Half-Life, Valve's first product, was released in 1998 for Windows to critical and commercial success. Players control Gordon Freeman, a scientist who must survive an alien invasion.

[b] Story - [/b] Okay, well the story is pretty vague if i‚Äôm gonna be honest. I had many people recommend this game to me and told me that the story was a masterpiece, I must have been playing the wrong game. You don‚Äôt really get a mention of the antagonist. You just see him walk behind a wall or go through a portal. Not much screen time for the antonigist. All I knew was that you have to escape the lap and you end up facing the boss in the Xen (other world). The first half of the game was pretty good and I deeply enjoyed it. Once I got into that second half, my whole mood just switched. I did not like the second half, like at all. It was really repetitive and just boring. The other world was okay but didn‚Äôt bring my excitement back. It didn‚Äôt help that the last boss reminded me of the marshmallow dude from Ghostbusters. The story was a huge let down and maybe because I had high expectations (because everyone that told me about it hyped it up into oblivion).

[b] Gameplay - [/b] I will say that the gameplay is amazing! It‚Äôs fast and smooth and aged pretty well for a 1998 title. Only issues I had was that I would get stuck in some environments (clipping issues) and sometimes if I got to a checkpoint, I would be stuck completely having to load an old save to get back to the checkpoint hoping not to get stuck again. It‚Äôs an old game so I‚Äôll give it an excuse. The gunplay is really fun and you can use some really unique and fun weapons in this game. You can fight a ton of different enemies that require strategy and I love that difficulty. The atmosphere and environments are incredible and blows me away that this is a 1998 game. They did an amazing job in the gameplay/graphics section.

[b] Sound Design - [/b] The sound design is, well, average at best. The voices are so low and so hard to hear them, especially if the environment can be really loud at times. You don‚Äôt get any subtitles, which would fix the issue for me with the voices but no luck. Is there a voice audio setting? Nope! The audio is pretty meh I will say. The gun sounds are good though, so we got that going I guess. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Fun and challenging gameplay
	[*] Amazing environments
	[*] Incredible graphics for 1998
	[*] Tons of weapons and enemy variety 
	[*] Good and challenging puzzles
[/list]

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
	[*] Story was bare bones
	[*] Antagonist is uninteresting
	[*] The game balancing is a hit or miss
	[*] Game can be buggy (checkpoints can lock you in place)
	[*] Bad sound design
	[*] Second half of the game is repetitive
[/list]

How do you review a game which was one of the most innovative games of its time?  One of the best things I can say is that it still holds up as a great game even today.  Great action, great exploration and puzzle solving. A bit of good old humor.  A game rich in content and lengthy game play.  I've been playing recently on the steam deck.  It takes a bit of tweaking of the UI to get the controls to work well, but once you have a good setup the game plays like it did in the 90's.  It's the epitome of fun and I would recommend this game to everybody who enjoys great nostalgic games and appreciates innovative games of their time.

Half-Life is an action shooter (yes there's a lot of shooting, but there's autoaim for some guns don't worry) with an OK story and a fairly significant puzzle-solving element. And honestly, I had good fun playing it, despite the ancient graphics and audio. The closest I'd come to Half-Life before this was GMod, but that didn't make a difference. It's decently long, too, about 10-15 hours' worth.
Many parts of the game feel impossible (they're not) or like you're doing something the wrong way (if it works it works), which are both uncomfortable feelings. As is typical with older games, you kinda have to figure things out for yourself.
Nevertheless, I had a fair few hours of fun with this game. 8/10

Circa 2003 I had the luxury of being a 10 year old choosing between re-released boxed copies of Half Life and Deus Ex; I chose half life and it easily became my fondest game purchase. It's hyperbolic and cringey to throw 'best game evar' around and I dont think it is, but I do feel I should thank it for shaping my tastes for years to come and it is a classic for a reason.

Playing it again on the hardest difficulty with Re-Shade CRT filters, low res with chunky pixels and a bag of weed is some of the most fun I've had playing a game in a long time, and my fondness and appreciation for it has only grown.

The fact it still gets memes and fan animations to this day means it's never escaped my attention; I don't think a day goes by without one of those highly quotable scientist VA lines entering my head like "Have you seen my coffee cup?" If a game has that kind of presence in my life to that degree, it deserves to be near the top of my favorite games list, and it is.

OK so this may be one of the most genre shaping fps games of the 90's. Aside from DOOM or Blood this game focuses on a narrative that doesn't take away control from the player and incorporates little bits of puzzles and physics which make for some of the most memorable set pieces in games at the time. The game doesn't sacrifice speed and the combat is frantic and is in my opinion the best middle ground of modern and classic styled fps combat with an interesting arsenal of weapons. However there I one thing that I think prevents me from playing it again and thats all of the end game chapters. After Surface tension the game falls off for me at the end with encounters feeling more like a slog as it goes on. Thats to be expected given that the guy who made the hardest commercially released DOOM expansion worked on this made the worst most dickish levels in an fps and that's Xen. Xen on paper sounds cool but it just does not want you to have fun in any capacity. Fuck especially the xen factory and the final Boss the nyalynth or however you spell it. Xen is the decay constant in half life to put it in an esoteric sense and makes me not want to play this game. Still give it a play through and on the rare occasion you feel like playing it again use console commands to skip the intro.

I am not going to say what everyone has already said about the main campaign and so I'll do a short review of the lesser-talked-about HL1 multiplayer.

HL1 multiplayer is incredibly high-octane and chaotic with higher player count. Mechanically, it's very much focused on smooth and unrestricted movement, as well as playing to the strengths of your current arsenal of weapons. Movement strongly prevails over aiming in this game so the duels when both sides don't have instakill/overpowered weapons are stupidly fun. It's very enjoyable to play from time to time if you're an experienced movement shooter player (moreso if you've been playing GoldSrc + Source games for all your life) but your mileage may vary if you're not.

I recommend giving this OG of arena shooters a try. Despite the age and somewhat shallow playerbase, it's not completely filled with pros who have 10+ years of experience so chances are you'll stumble across a lot of casual players who are also here to screw around in a janky but oddly fun GoldSrc multiplayer game.

P.S. I highly recommend looking up crosshair and playermodel colour fix mods even if you don't plan on becoming a multiplayer pro as those provide reasonable quality-of-life changes without making the game look too exotic and non-native.

- Half-Life is the defacto standard by which all first-person shooters are compared to. And as far as I'm concerned, nothing has come close to it since then. Its influence is so widespread that you'd be hard-pressed to find a PC player who hasn't played it. It's a title that was ahead of it's time, and still continues to hold its own in modern day. It also served as the platform of being the most influential title for the modding community, give way to the likes of Counter-Strike, Day of Defeat, and Team Fortress to name a few. What is there to say, really? Half Life is a classic, and every true fan of FPS should play it. Yes, graphics and game mechanics are dated (and the GoldSRC engine has some weird bugs, especially after quicksaving), but it's a game from the 90's. Computers had a lot less to work with then. AI can be goofy too (especially when marines frag themselves with their own grenades), but enemies still pose a challenge.

I've always liked 90's shooters. Half Life is no exception. Half Life  blends strategy and fast paced movement. You are rewarded for planning ahead, using cover effectively, and utilizing your full arsenal (like planting traps with laser mines, or using the guass to bounce shots off walls or blast guys behind cover). Some of the Xen levels drag a bit but overall it's good fun.

All in all, this is a must-play. It all began here, in the halls of Black Mesa. Go hit some headcrabs with a crowbar.

P.S. As a Linux gamer, I really appreciate that Valve has made so many titles playable on Linux. Here's hoping to see even more in the future. :)
a true classic.

The year is 1998, a very special era in gaming history, Sony and Nintendo were locked in figurative War to consistently manufacture phenomenal games to captivate their audiences, (A feat they both outdid, and continuously bettered time after time). Quite a wonder then how a small, unheard of studio nobody had ever heard of made history with a debut release, simply known as Half-Life.
    There's nothing else to say other than: Iconic. Even when I didn't have a PC, The name Half-Life was always present in my head. after a long time, I finally decided to play Half-Life last summer after a friend gifted it to me. While I had played my fair share of icons and legends, games like Halo, etc. Even then this game surprised me. In Half-Life: you play as the famously muted scientist Gordon Freeman. blasting through droves of zombies and aliens felt fresh and unique, despite being almost like every shooter in existence. (other than valves iconic no-zoom) Everything about it was fresh and interesting, the phenomenal mix of shooter and puzzle, The strengths it had back in the day are the same strengths it has today. Its old, and its not a well kept secret, but that's an after thought. Half-Life captivated me. cruising through "on a rail" with Mathew wilder's break my stride keyboard solos playing through my mind, is a memory i will never forget, or sneaking through the environmental hazards of office will never get old. Each location felt realistic and believable, as if they belonged in an underground lab. 
    Now is Half-Life a masterpiece, No, Not really, despite the great game play and flawless build-up (not including Xen) it tended to drag on ever so slightly, especially if your opting to play its two expansions, opposing force and blue shift. But even with that, Half-Life is an undeniable must-have and must-play, even if just to see the nexus of ideas that revolutionized gaming as a whole. more than 2 decades after release, this game is nothing short of phenomenal, Luckily for fans, They wouldn't have to wait very long for more.

One of the best video games ever. Seamlessly combines Platforming, Puzzle and First Person Shooter to create a survival-horror (ish) experience like no other. A big contrast to how Valve operates today. If you have a PC, you NEED to pick this up, whether it's your first time, or you want to experience a big rush of Nostalgia. And the G-Man (He goes without saying)....

So you've probably heard of Half-Life before. Probably heard of it a lot, in fact, it's often touted as one of the timeless classics of gaming, a watershed moment that changed the way games were made forever. But the question remains: almost 25 years after its original release, does Half-Life hold up to that reputation?

The answer is yes, very much so! To begin, it still runs just fine on Windows 10, so unlike a lot of games that are nowhere near as old, Half-Life can be purchased, installed, and played without any further effort on your part. So, if that was what caused you any hesitation, don't worry, it runs just fine and is largely free of bugs and glitches. I never had any issues when playing.

Now, moving on to the game itself...

The Good!
-Half Life holds up. No questions asked. Modern AAA titles can't hold a candle to how good and complete and whole the moment-to-moment gameplay of Half-Life is. Combat is intense but not chaotic, exploration is easy and you rarely get lost, there's basically no cutscenes that break the flow and make the player a passenger to the experience.
-Tutorials? In game? lol. This is a good thing- the game expects you to pay attention to what it shows you, and remember it moving forward. No gametips on loading screens, no tutorials in the middle of levels, nothing. This makes it a rewarding and intuitive experience!
-Fairness. Half-Life is tough, but very fair, it is only rarely that I ever felt like a failure was beyond my control. Enemies all make noises, have well-telegraphed attacks, and all have weaknesses that can be exploited to your advantage.
-An actual, honest to god save system means that whenever things get sketchy, you can just make a save. If things don't work out, loading that save is free and easy and quick. This alone makes the game much less frustrating, as losing progress to experimentation and risk-taking is not an issue.
-A coherent story told through the game itself. Things the player sees and hears as they wander the facility do much more to tell the story than any cutscenes ever could.

The Bad, because even Half-Life isn't perfect
-Health, ammo, and especially armor can be a little too scarce at times. While the issue is eased by being able to break open crates for goodies, there were more than a few occasions where I felt pressed to do really weird and tedious things to scrape by.
-The Black Mesa facility is great! What comes after is... not. I won't spoil anything, but the grand finale the game builds to is a massive let-down, a result of very rushed development. There's no shame in turning off the game once you leave the facility.


The Ugly
-Half-Life has a lot of really cool sci-fi weapons it adds to your arsenal. Odds are you won't use them because the MP5/M4 (depending on what textures you use) is easily the best gun in any situation.
-This game released in 1998, and it shows. Graphics limitations hinder it when it should be at its best, something the fan remake Black Mesa fixes. This isn't to say you should play that instead, though it is very worthy of playing, but instead that Half-Life was built around its limitations and you can feel it.
-An emphasis on "show. don't tell" tutorials can result in it not being very clear what you're meant to do in a few levels. Normally I could figure it out after a few minutes, but don't be shy about looking up guides for some sections.

Overall, Half-Life is easily a 10/10 game not in spite of, but because of, its imperfections. Valve knew what they had and worked around it, creating a timeless classic worthy of 12-18 hours of your time to experience. It's not perfect, but what game is? This may be as close as we'll ever get to perfection in a game, and that, I think, makes Half-Life a game you should play. Fair warning, though: it's hard to respect a lot of modern titles after playing this. There's no going back from experiencing what a first-person shooter can be when it's nothing more than a game.

I originally gave half-life a negative review, but after finishing it and starting a second playthrough, I realized my problem was only a small part of the game. The storytelling is great - you can skip the entire story or you can stick around and listen to what people have to say. The combat is interesting as well, with several different weapons to use. My first problem lies in a series of three chapters - blast pit, power up, and on a rail. I could barely tell what I was supposed to do for most of these chapters, and I even got basically softlocked in on a rail with 1 health and enemies everywhere. I just used invincibility to get past that section. Every other chapter does a good job at telling you what to do, and they're all fun to play. We've got hostiles is a creative section in the fact that it's a big loop. The start was fun as well, where you're given just a crowbar and maybe a pistol. Also, I'm probably the only person in the history of the universe to say this, but I actually like xen. I don't see why people dislike it - All the levels are unique and fun to play in my opinion. Well, other than my experience with Gonarch - it was what I can only assume to be bugged, and I had to noclip to beat it. My second problem is that easy difficulty isn't actually easy. It's probably just me being bad at video games, but I've found myself dying several times on my first playthrough. This problem even persists in the expansions, and easy difficulty doesn't begin to be actually easy until half-life 2. Despite these problems though, I enjoyed half-life for the most part.
Rise and shine Mr Freeman, you have to play this classic.

I just completed Half-Life 1 for the first time. It was very fulfilling to do so. I usually get stuck sort of early on in the game, but this time I powered through and am very happy I did so. I recommend this game. 

The start is incredibly powerful and an absolutely iconic scene of Gaming. The following levels are equally strong, although as I am sure we all know, On A Rail can prove to be a very contentious level. I didn't mind it too much, but honestly just abandon the little traincart, making your way on foot is more effective. Otherwise, the levels after that were quite great. This game is difficult though, which I think is a good thing, but one should go into the game with the idea that at some points it can be as hard as Dark Souls. 

Xen is another iffy chapter of the game. Really slogged through it using the Hivehand because I hand no proper ammo. Quicksave is your friend. I prefer HL1 Xen over Black Mesa Xen, beause it lasts only an hour which I find a lot more tolerable than Black Mesa's Xen. The Nihilanth fight in HL1 kinda sucked because there isn't a clear aim, but die enough and you'll figure it out. Again, I quicksaved a bunch in this game and I'm not ashamed of doing so. 

To conclude, I think anyone and everyone should play this game, and I think it is a good game. However, I'm not delusional and it's clear that in some aspects the game has grown quite clunky. Got into playing it properly commited and willing to put in the effort, and you'll be rewarded with the wisdom Half-Life can give you.

This game has a very well crafted atmosphere. It feels like you are experiencing something nobody else could comprehend. The lab environment is almost other worldly, full of strange rooms and surrounded by locations that fill you with questions.
The idea of scientists accidentally unleashing alien creatures into this world is a great concept. But I have to admit, I was a bit disappointed when it was revealed they already visited other worlds and even experimented on the creatures before the incident. Gotta admit it would be cooler if this was for the first time they opened this sort of portal, maybe accidentally, or they didn't realize it could be filled with dangerous creatures.

The alien designs and their combat styles are great. I must say they spooked me through the whole game. One of the reasons is a perfect sound design. It really does sound alien and very uncanny, especially houndeye. Even when I didn't consider them to be very dangerous, they still made me feel uneasy just because of the noises they made.
I feel like this game did its best to be scary without trying too hard. Maybe the older graphics contributed, I do have to say I feel like the graphics just fit this game perfectly. I would say it's very ingenious design-wise, they knew what they could create and chose the best possible setting.

Gameplay-wise, there were some parts the game could get a bit challenging, but that's one of the best things about older games ‚Äì not expecting the player to be a total dumbass. Also, clearing the challenges was satisfying, because the story was interesting and I just wanted to see more. The aliens got progressively stronger, constantly bringing new enemy types, and I really enjoyed that. I do have to say I preferred battling the aliens than H.E.C.U. though. They just got a bit boring after some time.

There's a wide variety of weapons and I think they were all well-balanced as I constantly swapped them around. Getting some alien weaponry was cool as well. The hive-hand was super fun to use, even thought it sometimes murdered some guard I needed to progress.
I just really enjoyed this setting of you travelling through this giant mysterious facility, meeting random people from time to time, trying to figure out what's going on, resolving issues and progressively realizing you aren't just trying to save yourself from aliens, but from god knows what.

Ending it off in the alien world was a great finish. Once again, a great atmosphere, well designed otherworld. Meeting the big boss aliens like Gonarch or the Nihilanth was exciting, even though the final boss wasn't as hard as I expected. But it was still a great and satisfying ending, and I wish it truly ended there. Supernatural ending for a supernatural game. I played it for the first time two weeks ago, I cannot stop thinking about it, and I would rather pretend it doesn't have a sequel, which I played after.

Also, bullsquid is the best creature. Why there's no official bullsquid merch is beyond me.

Just to preface my experience with this game. I was not alive before this game came out so it really means nothing to me. No nostalgia, no real knowledge of why this game is considered so great.

             --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This game does not hold your hand. I made a new game and immediately realized that the game has no identifiers for things you can interact on. So, you have to look up what your key binds are in the settings. This is just flat-out poor game design. You have just loaded a new IP from a new developer, so you‚Äôll have no clue what the mechanics and nuisances of the game. They should have small pop-up notifiers to indicate that a button is pressable, a scientist is interactable, or that a door can simply be pushed open. Yes, this is a problem, you can‚Äôt tell whether a door wants you to push a button, push it open (by rubbing up against it), or wait for the sensors of automatic doors.

Dozens of times I sat wondering where I should be going, so I just end up wandering (and wasting resources). Sometimes this will lead to the proper areas, others not so much. Many times, there is a small hole in the wall, or a vent that needs to be bashed in order to proceed. These so called ‚Äúhole in the walls‚Äù do not look obvious, in fact they look like a clipping texture or a dev didn‚Äôt get the wall moved down just enough. 

Things such as tunnels have a pretty serious problem with you getting stuck on them. Even when your not in tunnels you could run up against something the wrong way and be trapped on it. This has resulted in probably a dozen reloads.

Hit detection was pretty abysmal, which I guess I should expect from a game made in 1998. But there was one instance where I unloaded a M4 rifle (all 50 shots) into a soldier‚Äôs head from point blank range. Believe me when I tell you that the crosshair on the center of the head and it did nothing‚Ä¶ 50 shots and none of them seemed to register. At that point, I knew to hop off the game for a little.

             --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

With all of my gripes out the way I must commend the games creativity. The Gauss and Gluon guns were really cool to use for the first time. In general the weapon diversity is pretty great considering the release date. The mob diversity would still put modern games like Destiny to shame. Each one has its own mannerisms that distinguish themselves from another.

Honestly, it‚Äôs worth a try at $0.99 USD. Just keep in mind that some of the game doesn't hold up to modern standards. It doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs a bad game, it just needs a little patience. 

Something I don‚Äôt have‚Ä¶

I wanted so badly to like Half Life. I really, really did. But I just can't. And it has nothing to do with the graphics, the clunky aiming, or the ridiculously loud audio. It has to do with almost the entire last third of the game.

The first problem: Helicopters. Helicopters are just the f*#$ing worst. They have high health, and deal SO much damage. And when introduced, they, for whatever reason, are put in a spot with minimal cover. AFTER you fought your way past a horde of soldiers which you likely took a lot of damage from and lost a lot of ammo dealing with. Every time a helicopter shows up, it is either in a small area with little cover, or a large area with no cover. There is almost no in between. And the first two or three encounters, they do not give you the rocket launcher yet. They only weapon that could effectively damage them. (Side note: When introduced, they are introduced in an area where you have to swim in a large pool of water with a shark alien thing. An area that give you no ammo for the crossbow, the only weapon that can hurt them.)

Problem two: Levels past the facility (as in the section just before you see the first 'copter) began to get cluttered with enemies, and the levels began to get... worse. It felt like Valve started to run dry on ideas after that point and just kinda slapped random levels together and dropped in enemies for the sake of not boring the player. They aren't repetitive but just annoying. The puzzles at times made no sense, enemies were in really annoying places, etc etc. 

Problem three: The entirety of Xen. There is not a SINGLE good thing I could say about Xen. But I can say plenty of bad;
One- They introduce a new enemy type out of nowhere. Flying aliens that shoot little balls at you. They aren't that bad alone, but for some reason, Valve decided to shove them in areas that are cramped and full of enemies. Or if they aren't cramped spots, they are in areas that have no way of dodging them. Like say a floating platform with no where to run to without losing all your health. They are often shoved in places full of vortigaunts, a high damage high range enemy. (There's a section that is a cramped, tiny hallway full of egg things that if shot, release heavy enemies too along with vortigaunts, which is a horrible spot and I hope whoever made it regrets it for eternity). Also they are floaty, and while their projectiles are slow, they often can't be focused on and will catch you off guard.
Two: The levels. The levels are just so stupidly laid out. They are frustrating, confusing, and overall unclear. A lot of areas are tightly compacted and full of enemies.
Three: The gonarch fight. Nothing to really say here. Confusing and annoying. That's it.
Four: The bossfight- The boss fight is horrible. There is no way around it. It is horrible. The boss (I am honestly not in the mood to look up the name) teleports you around to different areas. Areas with enemies that can waste your ammo. Killing it took me like an hour (granted, this is my fault. I didn't realise you had to destroy the crystals. I had just gotten off the anxiety trip that was the last like two hours so I wasn't thinking clearly) and once I did figure it out, it was still frustrating to deal with the summoning of the flying pricks constantly, and the never ending teleporting. It was one big shit show from beginning to end, and none of it felt rewarding. I wasn't glad to beat the boss, I was glad that it was over. I wasn't getting that bittersweet feeling of the journey coming to a close. All I felt was relief that this horrid anxiety filled hell trip was finally over. (Apologies if my structuring is wonky. I am a bit tired, and equally stressed, so a clear head is not exactly what I have right now)

Man, I just... Damn... wtf. I don't believe many people born after 1998 actually beat this game.

I say that because it just drags and drags and drags I don't get it.
The first 4 or 5 hours are great, they still cared about the horror aspect, you as a player still care about the environments which stay fresh and feel like there's more to learn about the incident, there are still friendly NPCs around, the enemies have manageable weaknesses. Here I understood why it was foundational, between the uninterrupted flow of gameplay and bits of narrative dropped in through NPC speeches, the vents everywhere peppering levels that loop back and contain (often player-triggered) dynamic events.

And then you hit this point, Ch8/9ish, where the game jumps the shark and everything just starts to feel annoying and pointless. Open, "military base" levels where they just throw everyshit at the fan in arrangements of sand, rocks, and concrete, use every enemy they have access to, put little bunkered down turret manning guys in spots with no vulnerabilities, they abuse the big grunts that are bullet sponges unless you have ammo for a few key guns and then have guns themselves that obnoxiously curve around corners and across cover. The war breaking out just feels braindead, the atmosphere and narrative cohesion of levels weakens.
We hit Questionable Ethics (11) and it's like okay? Cool? So they were [spoiler]experimenting with Xen aliens[/spoiler] the whole time? Yeah? Like I didn't guess? 12 we hit the big spectacle cliff-face and it could've easily ended there, instead we go BACK IN.

Lambda is fine. Back to intricately designed corridors with ambiguous science shit going on, yay.
I'm in the apparently rare camp who actually didn't mind Xen; I think long jump added a lot to skirmishes and lessened the pain points. Enough that had it been introduced earlier obviously the levels would've had to have been designed for it but at least 12 and 13 I would've had a lot more fun.
Nihilanth was a fuck though. Great, redirect me out of the high health boss that already includes a ton of downtime in jumping and falling to some contrived platforming rooms that completely break the tension of the fight and the pace of gameplay. I get it ammo but jesus. Cool design but like whatever.


All of this being said, while I probably won't try Black Mesa, hit that instead. 
I generally think this game's aged pretty well but I'd bet good money that the extremely ungenerous fall damage, very difficult to adjust to ladders, loading zones every few minutes, egregious lack of autosaves in combination with rare as fuck heals that led to a ton of save-scumming for me, and FREQUENTLY getting stuck in geometry by being next to it during aforementioned loading seriously held down my experience and were at least half of why I hated the pacing so much.

This game was a masterpiece at the time. The beginning of this game will forever be one of the best intros to a game ever... However, most of the game doesn't hold up today. The game becomes confusing and frustrating to play, even with a walk-through. The combat gets old after a while and the goals get muddled. The intuitive map design becomes maze after maze with annoying enemies and traps. The game's auto-save starts out really good, but about half way through the game becomes useless. It leaves checkpoints up to the player and so I saved at every turn. Resources become scarce, but it's in a way that becomes frustrating rather than rewarding. The movement is momentum based, and that leads to some trouble with some of the tighter jumps the game expects you to make. In summary, it's old. It doesn't have any kinda modern polish, but it also doesn't have that old game charm. It's a game that has been done better a thousand times since its release. It's not a game I would play unless you really want to be able to say that you beat Half-Life 1.

EDIT:
Actual Review. Half-Life is by far the best shooter I've ever played. The characters don't talk to you for 3 hours. There is no dumb exposition dump. It get's straight to the point on what matter's most to a game. Game-play and Story. Most games I play now, I just play them for like 1 hour a day. and then that's it. But when I play a game that has a lot of worth and really feels it innovates the genre. I play for 4 hours or more a day until I beat it. When I first played Half-Life I stopped playing 5 hours in. 

The Story is damn, how did they do this? They made a story where you can just speedrun everything and still get the story. It tells the story through environment and the scripted sequences. One moment Black Mesa is clean, the next moment there's zombies and aliens everywhere. You go down the stairs, you see this scientist calling help to the army man, and the next thing you know the scientist is killed by the army man. That right there is how you tell a story, not some guy talking to you for 3 hours saying that the man is bad. 

The Game-play feels so fluid and precise. Each section feels unique because it showcases a new idea and if it does not showcase a new idea, it incorporates multiple ideas and it's so seamless as well. It has rich sense of variety, One moment you'll be in the sewer, and in the next level you'll be shooting some giant spider in space. It has that 30 seconds of fun. Even after you think you've seen everything this game has to offer. You get your ass whopped by Ideas on top Ideas. There is always that freshness, that innovation. That keeps you interested in exploring further. It innovated the shooter genre and went above the stratosphere.

Half-Life is a legendary, must-to-play 1998 FPS game developed by Valve. To consider yourself a true gamer, you must have this game under your belt. A game strongly recommended for everyone and an excellent game for people that are starting to become gamers. Give this to your kids as their 1st game, you won't regret it and they will be thankful in the future. 

Playing a badass dude and a legendary gaming character named Gordon Freeman, Ph.D. in Theoretical Physics, which I guess Ph.D. gives you knowledge of every weapon you touch and just kick ass. Works for the Black Mesa and gets involved in an experiment that goes wrong and opens a dimension to another world called Xen. Through each fight and puzzle, you piece together the story in the game. Also, in the game, you will meet another legendary but mysterious character, G-Man. He plays a huge role in this game and the Half-Life sequels. Won't spoil them and the story. You should experience it all with a huge jaw drop and dilated pupils.

The game consists of 1 Training room and 3 modes, easy, medium, and hard.
The training room is strongly recommended for new gamers and for gamers that haven't played a Valve game in their life. Get to know how the game functions and its controls. If you skip it and act all tough, you will have big difficulties.
Now the modes:
1. Easy mode: Recommended for new gamers. Not difficult at all and not even a challenger. Great way to observe the game, it's surrounding and the story behind it without any fear of getting killed instantly. Difficulty 1/10;
2. Medium mode: Great for players that never played a Valve game before but aren't new to FPS games. It's the same as the easy mode, just with the challenging fights. Difficulty 5/10;
3. Hard mode: This mode is for veterans and people that enjoy pain. It's challenging as hell and keeps the adrenalin pumping. Difficulty 10/10;

Of the various weapons that are offered in this game, I must praise the most powerful weapon in this game. Equivalent to the Doom 1993 shotgun (not as powerful and impactful as the Doom 1993 shotgun), the 44. Magnum. Its amazing power strikes down all foes, no matter their sizes and the difficulty you will play on. If you ever feel endangered just whip out this bad boy and it will do the job. The best weapon in this game!

Personally, the worst weapon in this game is the HECU RPG, the bazooka in the game. Proved unworthy and cost my life many times. It has a guiding option to guide your missiles, and boy did they miss, a lot. It seems like it was a hit, but it goes through them. In hard mode, it barely does a thing. I prefer using the crowbar and the pistol over this thing. Almost always I barely use this thing, because the rest of the arsenal does a better job.

Multiplayer: After so many years, it's still alive and you can easily find a couple of good and full servers. The multiplayer is awesome and you need to check it out. You must experience it.

As someone with no nostalgic connections to this game, I have to say that Half Life lived up to the hype. Plays quite well for a game released in 1998 and you could see how it revolutionized the FPS genre and focused more on other things besides mindless shooting. In Half Life, you have to solve puzzles, rely on NPCs, parkour (rather extremely I might add. You are going to have a rough time if you don't know how to crouch-jump), and observe your surroundings.

The high point of the game for me has to be the NPC interactions with you and the environment. They react when getting hit, they talk to each other, they talk to you and are your primary source of story-telling, and come off as real people. Reminds me of older Halo titles where the NPCs would talk about their surroundings and actions to make the game world feel alive. Too many games simply put a name tag on their NPCs but I can say that Half Life does a great job in making their NPCs feel real, I always felt the need to keep them safe and was sad if they died.

The only downside I had with the game was the audio direction. There is this weird audio effect where sounds will play slightly after they played for the first time, giving this echo effect. At first I thought this was a glitch but it turns out this was intentional to give the feeling of noises bouncing off the walls in the cramp spaces of the Black Mesa Research Facility. After I learned this was intentional, I felt a bit less aggravated but I wish there were an option to disable it. There is a command to disable it although it resets back to the usual echo when you enter a room designated for the audio effect.

I have heard of this series my whole time gaming, however due to me growing up with mainly RTS games for PC and everything else on Xbox I never actually got to experience Half Life the "real" way. While I've played the PlayStation port as well as The Orange Box on the Xbox 360 when Hollywood Video still existed. It took me 10 hours to beat Half Life on normal now that I own Half-Life and Half-Life 2 with all the DLC packs finally. 

While granted I have watched quite a lot of videos about the lore, mechanics, speed-running and everything else to do with both Half-Life titles, that was because of how badly I wanted to experience one of the best game series ever created. I would 100% say that I used tricks and whatnot that I remembered while getting to explore and have fun with the famous momentum kink in the game engine.

Overall, I'd say this game lives up to the hype surrounding the series; The amount of puzzle solving I was doing mid-firefight was insanely fun considering one misplaced step while throwing a grenade, satchel charge and firing a rocket from the rocket launcher can completely kill your run and cause quick F7.

10/10 - Half-Life lives up to the word around the net as well as feeling somewhat refreshing compared to FPS titles currently being played. I honestly would call Half-Life somewhat of a precursor to the "Looter-Shooter" genre; At times I felt like I had to back off and sit in a corner to evaluate my ammo and how many enemies I could shoot to pass through an area instead of clearing the area. At one point I even recall long jumping through an entire section with (I don't know the enemy type) armored aliens that have flamethrowers. Basically I enjoyed this title because it was fresh and new to me while also providing me a whole new way to experience not only an FPS game, but also having it blended with puzzles and platforming as well as micromanaging your ammunition and any guards or scientists you're escorting since they love to just stop following you.

Half-Life is a watershed game in many ways. Story driven FPS games can be clearly divided as either pre Half-Life and post Half-Life because of its innovations in story telling, level design, and interactivity. Nevertheless, some of Half-Life's gameplay has dated it a bit, more than its sequel or even classic FPS like Doom or Quake. Still, Half-Life is certainly worth playing and is (mostly) a fantastic game.

PROS:
- Great storyline and experience
- Great enemies and impressive AI for the time
- Great weapons and variety
- Mostly great level design presenting an unbroken, linear narrative
- Expectedly great performance
- Decent value, taking around 9 hours on a first time playthrough

CONS:
- The final levels in Xen are notorious for a reason: they suck
- Some of the movement and clipping feels unrefined

* Do not get the Source version of this game

Prior to 1998, in the PC world, first person shooter games such as DOOM ruled the domain with an iron fist, legendary and infamous in its own right as it essentially was the father and creator of the genre. 

However this was all to change. If Doom was the father, then Half-Life is the son.

The late 90s essentially was the "golden age" of gaming. The SNES was phasing out, the N64 was ripe and the Playstation was dominating the market.  Pioneers and trailblazers such as Starcraft, Diablo and Age of Empires were being released, celebrated and played around the world, it truly was a time to be alive.

In November 1998, Valve Studios in conjunction with Sierra Studios published the game Half-Life, a game, that changed the perceptions of us Millennials from that day forth on PC games forever. This game essentially turned the tide of FPS and still reflects the fundamentals of games we play today in the modern age. A freakish evolution within the gaming industry, Half-Life itself has won of 50 game of the year awards, has been the cornerstone of mods, shown in the media, has overwhelming positive reviews from all gaming affiliated outlets and is considered the most influential and greatest game created in video game history.

One of the games creators, president and part owner of Valve and Steam Gabe Newell said "Half-Life in many ways was a reactionary response to the trivialization of the experience of the first-person genre". 

Its so famous infact, that one of the most played online multiplayer games in the world "Counterstrike" is a mod of the game, including its infamous remake "Black Mesa". The game also had two spin off expansion packs called "Opposing Force" and "Blue Shift". Both these expansions intertwine and give context to other characters and factions within the story.

In this story, you are the Theoretical Physicist Gordon Freeman, who works within a fictitious site known as the the Black Mesa Research Facility located in New Mexico. This Facility is absolutely gigantic and is the crux of the game, which comprises of an in depth railway system,  office complexes, laboratories and a dam to say the least. The facility shows a mundane, corporate work life but industrialized, dystopian with moving and advanced technological hardware. The Facility is imbued with cloak and shadow, being a military-scientific facility in research and secret experiments akin to the secrecy of area 51.

Without going in depth nor revealing any spoilers, during an experiment, you are faced with an alien invasion from a fictional place called "Xen". You must fight your way through the facility doing anything you can do to survive. During so you will come across friend being other scientists/security and foe, being the military, aliens and perhaps some covert ops. The game is broken up into chapters, there are no cutscenes so dialogue dictates the storyline along with scripted events. There is also no talking by the protagonist which gives an enigma like effect.

For the late 90's, the graphics were amazing, still to this day they hold up to the test of time. The environment is intuitive and interactive. including being able to be exposed to certain elements such as radiation, electricity and fire. You have at your disposal a range of weapons that come as the story progresses, but it all begins with the famous crowbar which manifests itself as a symbol. Characters can be interacted with, will help you and talk with optional dialogue punchlines. This also extends to some enemies who will give some scripted dialogue. Scripted actions will occur as you progress through the game, including interesting ways that lead to certain character deaths. Characters can also ragdoll and explode. Blood and gore was included for realism. There are also many traps in your travels and ambushes to be aware of and puzzles that need to be overcome in the face of overwhelming odds.

As you progress deep into the game, things will start to make sense about how and why, the game comes to a close as it does, but continues on through its expansions and its successor Half-Life 2.

In this groundbreaking FPS, you play as Gordon Freeman, an MIT graduate with a PhD in Theoretical Physics, who is employed as a Research Associate at the Black Mesa Research Facility. He is needed for an experiment that winds up creating the worst day at work ever. You know how in the original Doom, the UAC was doing experiments involving portals from Phobos to Deimos, and they end up having demons from Hell invading? Well, something kinda similar happens here: while experimenting with with a strange crystal, Gordon finds himself accidentally initiating a "resonance cascade," which brings aliens from another dimension to Earth, wreaking havoc in the facility. After sh*t hits the fan, its up to Gordon to find a way to close the interdimensional portal, while also dealing with a special unit of the United States military sent to deal with the aliens, as well as silence all Black Mesa personnel.

As I stated before, this was a groundbreaking FPS in the late 90s. Enemy AI is more complex than its contemporaries were, and thus you need to be more careful with how you progress in the game. Set entirely in first person, there's a strong narrative focus here, with NPCs being a somewhat important way to progress the game, along with various setpieces in each level. Oh yeah, and the levels are interconnected rather than pushing a button and moving on the next level immediately. 

The atmosphere of these levels are fantastic, and the puzzles will get you thinking. The combat meanwhile, is great, due to the weapons you get to use. While some enemies are frustrating, at the very least there is a variety of them, which means things will never get to stale in that regard. The soundtrack, whenever there is music, is incredible.

Overall, a great way to start a legendary FPS franchise, and one I can recommend as just a really good game.

The legendary Half-Life existed to me only as whispers and mentions on the bespoke wind. I had never played it or  thought I'd play it. 

Eventually I found it, bought it... and even though I have not come very far *at all*, I already find it impressive, I can understand why it's so esteemed, and I can recommend it.

In terms of FPS's, I am very inexperienced, so the best I can offer is this: Compared to the big-name FPS's I've seen clips of, Half-Life is (relatively) slow-paced. Big sustained shootouts are unlikely; this game is largely around picking and choosing where and when you shoot, rationing your munitions, and using the environment to your advantage.

In terms of story and lore-building, Half Life succeeds in an immersive way. Spoken word between fictipersons, announcements overhead, blink-and-you'll miss it sightings, big signs, visual context such as machines being present working correctly or incorrectly to various degrees, are used to make this odd sci-fi story was really happening around -and to - me.

In terms of cons, I can't think of many, largely because I have not gotten far. The most immediate that come to mind are that if you're looking for a hero, you won't find it here. The playable guy Gordon allows- and sometimes outright does- some very awful things in order to progress, by necessity. [spoiler]As an example there's a device that a scientist has cleverly perched upon to stay safe. He insists on staying there, which frankly makes sense considering the circumstances. However, that part he's perched on is conductive of lightning.

Instead of offering an option to help him off and help him find shelter somewhere else in the facility, the game requires us to intentionally reactivate the device, which will cause the scientist to be shocked to death. For me personally this was stomach-churning, which to be fair was likely the intention given the scary elements of the story and setting.[/spoiler]

There is much to discover in Half Life 1, and if anyone's interested in PC gaming history, I recommend it. Among other things it could be darn well worth it to see and even play for oneself the game that help launched Valve as we know it today - without which this platform we write and read and share and make history on and through which we can access more games than we could have ever dared imagine possible in the 90's, might not exist.

[h1]TL; DR[/h1]
This game has undeniably aged. It's still a good game, arguably a great one, by modern standards, but the fact that its influence is so vast and powerful means that most of modern games employ its techniques, and as such, most of the "surprises" in this game are staples of modern FPS design. Its shadow is greater than itself, and in parts, the game has turned into a history lesson more than anything.

[h1]They're waiting for you, Gordon... in the test chamber.[/h1]
"What makes a good game?"
This is the question that crawls in my mind when I sit to review this game. Should one take its historic context? Its lineage, its influence? Or should one just take its state as-is and review it like any other game of the present era?

Here's what I think: if you have any interest in the history of first-person-shooters, this game is a MUST. Its influence is one of the most reverberating of its time and its shadow looms over many classics of today, such as Counter-Strike, TF2 and Borderlands. Not only that, but for its era, it had a lot of impressive features such as dynamic storytelling and robust enemy AI.

On the other hand... well, look, it's not a bad game, not even by modern standards. Its pacing works well, its enemy roster is creative enough and the gunplay feels pretty good. But other than that, when played today, Half-Life is not that good. I mean, it's good, but it's not unmissable.

Due to the amount of influence it has, if you have played any modern shooter campaign, you kind of already played Half-Life in a way. Not only that, but its story, while somewhat mysterious and arguably intriguing, is still way too basic and non-specific to genuinely wow anyone. It has some great setpieces, and it also has some pretty boring sections. It's, you know, a normal game.

So... yeah, I do feel it gets a bit overrated at times, but not in the sense that it "was never that great to begin with", just that it has... aged. It was great, and now, well... it's just good.

[h1]Review of Half-Life[/h1] 
Revolutionizing the industry with a story about a simple man, who's late for work. Honestly, what could go wrong at Black Mesa? An ethically sound, well guarded, and secluded research facility. Surely no experimentation could cause a quantum destabilization that opens inter-dimensional tears bringing forth hostile denizens from a border between realities. An event of which would later lead to the downfall of Humanity. After all, the possibility of a resonance cascade scenario, is extremely unlikely. 

[h1]Redefining the First Person Shooter[/h1]
Before Half-Life, the FPS genre was defined by a series of separate arena maze-like levels filled with enemies, where your only goal was to kill any and everything that moved. What if.. there were a first person shooter that drove you through a seamless & breathing world. One where you'd live out the events of a story, like an interactive movie. Today, this might seem silly, but in the late 1990's, this wasn't the vision, or idea, of what an FPS was meant to be. Nobody cared about such things, I mean, you bought an FPS to shoot things from a first person perspective, right? The genre could be nothing more or less than that. Or at least, that was until the talented folks behind Half-Life's development wanted to try something new, and as a result, played a huge role in changing gaming forever. 

Half-Life presents a narrative to the player, not through cutscenes, pre-explained exposition (Which isn't a bad thing, mind you), or walls of text, but instead through NPC dialogue & world building. You learn the events as they play out on screen, and progress through a consistent & seamless world. Not cut together by levels and loading screens, but chapters that are connected one after the other. Tied by in-world loading disguised by hallways or corners. That keep you in the world, and make the environment feel like a real place. Never taking you out of the experience. It's not about getting kills, or reaching a highscore. It's about survival, and fixing the mess that was inadvertently your fault. 

In the beginning you'll be living out just another day at your job. When an experiment goes terribly wrong, creating a 'Resonance Cascade' that opens rifts allowing creatures from the borderworld; Xen to freely pour into Black Mesa, your only hope of safety is to reach the surface, and escape the facility. You have no idea just how bad the situation is outside the lower levels you're fighting through. If the situation is even being contained, or if it's spreading. It's through other scientists and security guards, that you'll discover a military unit is responding to the emergency. You and your fellow coworkers are rescued, all you need to do is find them. Of course.. this short lived hope is abruptly shutdown when it becomes apparent that the military is there to clean up. Including all facility assets. The entire narrative shifts 180 degrees, and instead of running to the surface, you're running right back down into the dark depths. Your new goal, to reach the opposite end of the facility, as it's said there's a plan to end this once and for all, in the Lambda Complex. 

The world of Half-Life is alive. What I feel is underappreciated is just how advanced the AI was for its time. Xen creatures have a complex algorithm of behaviors and reactions, these.. animals, will fight and eat each other. They're creatures from all corners of existence, not best friends. Beings that appear to have a high level of intellect, are reduced to mindless slaves, fighting for.. someone, or something. The HECU, or military that's present, work in squads. They'll retreat when wounded. They'll speak to each other. They'll search for you. They'll drop grenades when you're chasing them, or throw them to flush you out. They will fight the invading Xen army. The roaches that're no bigger than your toe will feast and scatter. Scientists & security will react to smells. It's incredible to look back at this game and see just how ahead of its time, it really was. Simply incredible. The only limitation is that the AI is only able to perform one action at a time. However it's so easy to overlook this with just how well it all works. 
I highly suggest MarphitimusBlackimus on YouTube, for his detailed analysis videos on the inner workings of this game. It will really open your eyes, if they're not already.

[u]Never Stale[/u]
The gameplay and environmental systems never overstay their welcome. You'll explore all kinds of areas, never spending too much time in any one place. Nor doing one thing enough times to annoy you. Clean and slick interiors of advanced sectors in Black Mesa. Dark, and rusted halls of portions that're in disrepair. A rocket test silo. The hot scorching sands on the surface. Scaling a sheer vertical cliff face. The bizarre and alien Xen. To name a few. 

Environmental puzzles stay relatively simple, with the biggest challenge being not getting lost in some of the chapters that have you searching about to activate or deactivate something. 

As an FPS, you'll have access to a sizable arsenal of weaponry across a playthrough. Every weapon is varied, and different. With most weapons having an alternative fire mode that provides advantages in specific moments. Managing your ammunition is crucial. You have to scavenge for it, find your way into rooms or pick it off dead soldiers. It's easy to run low on ammo. Health works similarly, as well as your HEV suits power. Both of which are definite non regenerating pools. This type of old school difficulty, is a great satisfying mix. Which for me, is important, since I pick up on artificial difficulty easily. Half-Life is almost completely free of such things. 

Visually, the game's textures and geometry are dated by today's standards. However, the palette used, and the style it creates, allows Half-Life to hold up better than its sequels, in my opinion. Add on the advanced & detailed AI, varied gameplay, and everything else - Most of which.. is completely gone in the franchises later titles, to make room for physics simulation. But more on that in a future review.

As it stands now, Half-Life is my favorite entry in the series. I believe it's timeless, iconic, and important to see for the legacy it created. My only complaints about the experience, are the chapter "On a Rail", a poorly paced chapter that can be easily walked through in a quarter of the time, and the "tentacle", because I'm salty and that thing is scary as Hell. I would love to breakdown this game in a monster sized review, but with Steam review character limits, that's just not possible. 

[h1]Conclusion (Pros & Cons)[/h1] 
Half-Life is no doubt already in your library. For good reason. If it's not, then I suggest you at least try it when you get the chance. Put yourself into a 90's mindset, and experience just how mind blowing this game really is. A first time player can expect around 10-15 hours for a playthrough. A returning player can finish as early as 4~ hours. 

They're waiting for you Gordon, in the test chamber.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Works perfectly on modern PC's
+Revolutionary title
+Advanced AI (For its time)
+Birthed some of the most popular multiplayer titles via mods
+Testament to how trying new things, can change everything
+A 'Ground Zero' story

[b]Neutral:[/b]
~Sensitive movement controls
~OST

[b]Cons:[/b]
-"On A Rail"

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
Thank you for taking the time to read my review. Please remember, that this is just my opinion. We don't have to agree, one thing I love you may hate, and one thing I hate you may love. Hopefully this gave you an idea of what to expect. 

[b]Review lengths have been greatly compressed due to the character limit.[/b]

A question arises in society from time to time: "What is the greatest ___ ever?"
Who is the greatest NBA player ever?
What is the best music ever?
Who is the coolest person ever?
And finally...
What is the greatest first person shooter ever?

I've got answers to two of the above questions. Who is the coolest person ever? Gordon Freeman. What is the greatest first person shooter ever? Half-Life.

No game has ever been as influential to the gaming industry as the one you have on your screen right now. Half-Life wrote the rules for all future first person shooters. Halo? Yup. Half-Life 2? Duh. Deus Ex? Mmm-hmm. System Shock 2? Abso-hecking-lutely.

This is the game that started it all. As the Valve Corporation's first game, Half-Life created an emphasis on story and player control that had never been seen before in a video game. In addition, this game has an... interesting multiplayer mode that is very exciting. 

Unlike other games, its motto actually tells something of value to the player. "Run. Think. Shoot. Live." These are all options. You can run away from your enemies. Most of the time, this works if you're good at it. You can think about how you will dispose of the man who accuses you of "Killing all my buddies." Do you use the satchel charge or do you throw a grenade? You can shoot everything you see. There's enough ammo. Trust me.

There are an infinite number of ways to play this game. Are you a serial killer on the loose who doesn't care about story at all? Have fun shotgunning scientists. Are you a pacifist who waits to be shot at before shooting? Don't shoot the alien slaves in Interloper. Are you a French literature major living in an apartment in New York? Listen, my dear sir, and weep.

This game is my favorite FPS and its story is impeccable. Every time I play this game, I am brought to my knees, shouting "WHY? G-Man, WHY'D you do this?!"

Classic. Amazing, seamless blend of platforming and FPS that makes your heart rate soar. It's pretty hard imo, but you can savescum as much as you like. The result is a playthrough that viscerally feels good; the unkillable Gordon Freeman dodges every bullet and grenade while doing parkour through deadly machinery and shooting at otherworldly horrors (and the speedrun elevates this to comical levels). Narrative and gameplay support each other in that I'm compelled by curiosity through every obstacle. The graphics have "aged poorly," as some would say, but I find the 90's low-poly style quite charming. I mean, the 5 or so recycled NPC models have names! Plus, the simple design lends itself well to the sterile, utilitarian lab environment. More games need to be made like this.

Half-Life, like a lot of the games from its era, is a powerfully 90s thing. Not so much in terms of aesthetics, as I feel like the game actually has a pretty timeless look to its art design. The technology powering the game, though, and certainly its design, are very much of their time though. That's not a bad thing, of course! It's still a masterpiece of game design, particularly for the period it came out in. This game doubles every technological advancement made by Quake a few years prior, and it feels extremely modern next to pretty much anything else that came out in 1998. 

It's a little clunky and janky, and it certainly shows its age in some places, but Half-Life is a great time nonetheless. If you've got ten bucks burning a hole in your pocket and you just need something classic to play, I can think of way worse games to spend your money on. If nothing else, it's a piece of gaming history that should be played simply for its historical value.
