Prior to Half-Life, first-person shooters were simplistic. You‚Äôd dash around settings such as a base on Mars infested by hellish beasts, or a giant castle controlled by fascist maniacs. The game‚Äôs box and manual offered a brief plot summary, and you were let loose into levels which were mostly shooting galleries, and amid the carnage finding keys or keycards to unlock doors.

The gameplay was adrenaline-packed and fun, however it consisted entirely of shooting whatever moved across level after level, occasionally finding a bigger gun, or a secret room with power-ups. After say twenty of these levels, you‚Äôd fight a big boss that‚Äôs more of a bullet-sponge than normal enemies. Once this monstrosity is killed, the game concludes.

Half-Life upends this formula in totality. The intro consists of standing aboard a railcar transiting a ginormous research facility. You‚Äôre on your way to work, and must spectate to get a feel for where you are. You hear security announcements, watch colleagues chatting and going about their day, see heavy machinery operating, witness life proceed in a sophisticated, high-tech setting.

In a matter of minutes, Half-Life delivered more world building and atmosphere than any FPS title ever had. That‚Äôs before you even start‚Ä¶before you play an unwitting role in a disastrous science experiment which leaves you fighting for survival across the sprawling Black Mesa research complex.

A detailed story develops through the game; events are explained, and we feel immersed in the world before us. Characters have names, dialogue and personalities, and progress isn‚Äôt divided arbitrarily into levels with a singular objective of completion. Half-Life is comprehensively designed; the scientific and industrial environment of Black Mesa feels engrossing and realistic, in spite of the violent events and encounters the player must endure.

The puzzles make sense, as they are presented as functioning parts of the facilities you explore. They‚Äôre much more than finding a red keycard to unlock a red door, then proceeding to get a blue keycard to unlock a blue door. Likewise, this environmental problem-solving surpasses the worn FPS staple of pressing a button which opens a door on the other side of the level.

In Half-Life, the enemies require imaginative strategies to defeat. The soldier AI was revolutionary for its time, with squad members mobilizing together against threats. On a few occasions, certain opponents can only be killed through ingenious operation of machines. Gordon Freeman‚Äôs signature crowbar works both as a destroyer of easier enemies and as a tool to break vent covers and debris, allowing progress.

There‚Äôs obvious thought in the pacing of the adventure. The game waxes and wanes between quiet puzzle-solving and discreet navigation, and intense, explosive, nerve-jolting firefights. The soundtrack emphasizes the dramatic changes in mood with a synthesized mix of softly foreboding ambient tracks and energy-filled, bass-heavy adrenaline-pumpers.

The player‚Äôs armory is gradually upgraded, and each weapon satisfies a logical role. Even the placement of certain weapons is sensible; ammo and guns are awarded by accessing security offices or fortified checkpoints, rather than the secret rooms of earlier shooters. Your movement, health and armor are overseen by a futuristic hazard suit you don early in the game.

Here in the 2020s, what I‚Äôve described in this review are bare essentials of story-driven first-person shooter games. In the late 1990s though, Half-Life was a groundbreaking effort hitherto unseen and scarcely even imagined. To this day it inspires narratives in videogames, it has received both official and unofficial expansions, plus the excellent fan-made Black Mesa project which expands and graphically revamps the game in the Source engine.

Half-Life is a part of videogame history. It elevated first-person shooters from jaunty, arcade-style distraction to a serious art form; an equal to literature and film.

Man I really often have to remind myself, this game was made in 1993, refined by 1998. Back then, PCs used floppy disk storage, had under a gigabyte's worth of HDD and RAM, and ran on the ugliest screens there could be.

This game is revolutionary, and it would've been more than a tripleA in its time, it's a founding father. It was years ahead of its competitors, going a completely different route than DOOM, straying away from Nintendo's family games and being years before other older FPS games like Halo, yet still made by some of the same geniuses who made DOOM, ID Software.

This first piece of work that Valve made on the Source Engine would go on to create an environment for their future games, multiplayer and singleplayer alike. Back before all of their achievements, this stood by as a root and erupted into what Valve is today, it blew up.

Valve has had great achievements, but within the sheer success of their platform, the innovative design of their servers and engines, the choices of launcher, hardware and OS/software, nestled within it all are the games they make. Everything about them reeks a sort of awareness and precision that no other developer has ever mastered as well as Valve. They toy with the player, analyse every possible perspective someone could have and strings along a story and atmosphere that this mind could traverse and feel immersed in.

AI's reactions, pre-written events, environments, interactions, Half Life kinda has all of them. There are moments in Half Life where I can't help but notice little gimmicks that make it feel so alive, which I never see repeated. There are moments in the story where things happen, and they tie into the game's atmosphere. As of recent, seeing alien encounters slowly ramp up higher and higher, the game had just put me through a combat-heavy section against the human task forces. Now I see them fighting among eachother as I stand back and watch. I really felt like a battle was ongoing, as tides slowly shifted and radios began broadcasting panicked cries of "Forget Freeman, we are retreating!". I've not fought a single human since then, but I hear them down these corridors shouting in their walkietalkies still. This game has me invested in a way I can't describe. I want to run with these people and flee. The world's looking redder and redder, there are tendrils and monsters I haven't seen before surfacing. Bumping into scientists running and scattering, saw this police officer once at the top of a roof pull his gun on me for a second thinking I was a taskforce guy before putting it back down and saying "Ah, hello". I haven't seen any others react like this, and I feel like the developers put him here to show me a mirrored image of myself. I was just as scared and startled as him, and I was seconds away from shooting em back. The relief of a friendly face I soon probably won't be seeing again. The way I'm talking about it in this manner, almost as if I'm mentally living Freeman's life, is giving me chills as I write it.

This goes with everything Valve makes, and it's so noticeable in their very first games. Where less focus was on graphics and all was on how they could use every other field in their favour to grasp the player's attention. Games aren't considered art because of their visual directive or their sound design; it's how they play with a player's viewpoint, it's how they interact with our perception to create a free and dynamic yet deliberate and coherent canvas which we paint our experiences and memories upon. And with developer commentaries, you will begin to realise a dozen more things that you never even previously thought of. Things as little as the colours of the environment, or the starting area and sequence, add up to this image of what you perceive and feel playing it, it's the true art and craft of making a game. They've thought every last pixel of it out over years of collective and collaborative effort.

Portal and Half Life, in my opinion, are masterpieces. They are pure works of passion that extract the essence of what a game is meant to be, and Valve has nailed that vision. They deserve the spotlight of being featured in a museum somewhere, discussed in some louvre, just to make a point.

And yet, instead of being hung up behind bulletproof glass for you to gawk at from 5m away? You're here buying it and enjoying it to its fullest extent for a f***ing dollar.

A revolutionary game that changed the gaming industry and the FPS genre as a whole forever. You should absolutely buy and play this game if you're into first person shooters.
However, it was my first "boomer shooter" ('90s shooters like Classic Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D), and my first playthrough (circa July 2021) had some problems I accidentally caused myself.
Don't let this happen to you. Here are some tips and stuff that you should know in general:
[list]
    [*] Play in OpenGL if possible. Mixing software mode and widescreen (a requirement if you want to play on a modern 1080p monitor) breaks the game (just trust me, it does) requiring launch arguments to fix.
    [*] I'm not someone  that tries to 1:1 replicate the 1998 experience (I just told you about widescreen, that wasn't in the original, after all), but please turn off the "HD" models. They do not fit in with the game and are a downgrade.
    [*] Planning on buying the expansions (Blue Shift, Opposing Force, Decay) or Half-Life 2 and its Episodes? You should probably play this first. If you're already decided, check how much are the Half-Life 1 Anthology (Half-Life, its expansions except for the PS2 Exclusive "Decay" and Team Fortress Classic), the Half-Life Complete Pack (HL1 Anthology + Half-Life Source, a terrible buggy mess I'll talk about later + Half-Life 2 and its episodes) and the Orange Box (Half-Life 2, its episodes, Portal and the premium version of TF2, which you'll need plus a non-limited Steam account in order to chat in that game). [b] Don't get overwhelmed, though. Start with this one and see if you like it.[/b]
    [*] What about the Half-Life: Source remaster and the Black Mesa remake? Do not, under any circumstance, play Half-Life Source. Half-Life in Valve's former flagship engine sounds like an excellent idea in theory but HLS executes it terribly. It's a broken, buggy mess. You should play the original Half-Life and Half-Life 2 before playing Black Mesa, which is fine.
[/list]

I thought I'd show respect to the original after many hours of Black Mesa, and damn does Half-Life still hold up well.

Of course graphics are outdated but it doesn't even matter; I played on Hard, and while it was certainly frustrating at times, the gunplay and diversity of weapons just feels too good. I think I regularly used every weapon throughout the my 6.5 hour playthrough, which is kind of insane when in most FPS games one weapon is almost always the best choice. The level design is (generally) great and the spatial consistency of moving throughout Black Mesa feels amazing. It doesn't feel like I've just teleported to the next chapter, but of course the lab experimenting on alien lifeforms is directly connected to waste management. It just feels right.

There are a [i]few[/i] bad sections in Half-Life though, like On A Rail and Zen, that dampened by enjoyment‚Äîbut then right after I'm in a completely new location, with unique challenges to overcome that keep the game constantly fresh.

This is by no means a long game, but it sure is fun while it lasts... just don't pick hard unless you're somewhat masochistic.

Valve's 1998 debut hit Half Life is an extraordinary game, because it was set on innovating gaming as a whole.
For years the FPS genre had followed in the footsteps of DOOM and Quake, legendary games in their own right, and as a result FPS started to feel samey. But Valve refused to follow the trodden path and masterfully created a quantum leap in new technology, pioneering into new territory, and crafting a strong narrative in an industry where in the words of John Carmack, co-founder of Id Software, "Story in a game is like story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but its not that important"
And valve did it again with HL2, but now when you look at the Industry today, we see history repeating itself, AAA games are feeling samey and refuse to bring something new to the table. We need to relearn how to innovate from old games like these to move forward and create truly impressive titles in the modern era of gaming.

There's a reason people call this a classic.  Half Life changed the FPS genre so much and for the better.
   First off this game doesn't just drop your into combat and give you a single line explaining the bad plot that's just used to give you a reason for shooting people without mercy.  Half Life starts with a scene were you have no weapons or enemies, gives you an explanation for what is going on while also showing you around Black Mesa and giving you an idea of what is happening without it being told to you directly (one of the many examples of Half Life being amazing at environmental storytelling) and, giving the general mood of the game all while letting you figure out the main motion controls.
   Never forget that Half Life also had some of the most strategical gameplay of any FPS at the time.  Grenades, trip mines, satchels, and snarks are some of the most obvious examples being able to draw out enemies, time attacks perfectly without aiming, kill enemies without even being there, having other creatures do the dirty work for you, clearing out mine fields, and a million other uses but every weapon has unique uses.
   Of course the enemies are all different and interesting.  From long range attacks to being able to avoid your            weapons these bad guys are creepy, cool, and delightfully challenging to fight.
   You can't forget the incredible pacing in this game.  The story never seems to pass by super quickly or drag on to long (other than a few parts) and keeps you interested for the entire time.
   I don't have the time or words to express my love for this game so I will simply tell you to buy the game.  If you're anything like me you'll love it.

Half-Life is such a masterpiece.

It's an old game, but it's still absolutely great. It has received 50 Game of The Year awards, and is (in my opinion) one of the best games ever made.

Alright, it runs on the GoldSrc engine, which means that the graphics aren't exactly great; But I love them! The graphics have a charm to them that I don't find in a lot of other games...
The sound design is also brilliant. Whenever you're in a vent, all the sounds have a bit of a reverb added to it which is very immersive. The NPCs have conversations with each other (kind of), which makes the world and characters feel alive [i](that is until the 'incident' happens)[/i].

Since it is over 20 years old, you might think that the game is pretty dead. Well, you'd be wrong. I myself, as well as many others, are still mapping and modding for this game to this day. You can easily make a map by setting up the right tools which takes less than 15 minutes, and have fun for many, MANY hours.

The atmosphere is creepy, but somewhat relaxing. You can walk around for a while without meeting anyone (since most of them are dead), which made me feel extremely lost and helpless.

[h1]Go[strike]o[/strike]d Game[/h1]
I haven't finished the game as of the writing of this review, but no matter the rest of the game, this is, still in 2022, one of the best games I've ever played. 

I didn't know wut to expect going in; I mean sure it's Half-Life, ya' know? But is it "HL" for its historic novelty alone, or does it still hold up today as a game worth ur time? Plenty of older "masterpieces" I'd tried, turned out to not have aged very gracefully at all.

Before I jump in further, I want to clarify: It's not my nostalgia goggles speaking; I wasn't even born when this game was released and I started gaming much much l8r (less than a decade ago), well past the age of games like this.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Is the combat good? In principle.... n-noo? But it works. Whether it be thru level design or pacing or just careful attention to the design of the encounters themselves, it's stupid fun.

 To elaborate, pretty early on the game introduces an enemy type (that quickly becomes the staple) that does hitscan damage, almost always outnumbers the player, and takes a ridiculous amount of damage to go down without so much as flinching. In theory, this should just be an irritating fuckfest like COD4(MW), and my arsenal isn't too exotic either (actually their same weapons). Functionally tho, this plays more like a movement shooter (or some odd, super fun hybrid), the likes of DOOM Eternal (funnily enough), and not one encounter I've had has resembled COD4.

The game still has an impressive enemy variety with most of them being distinctly mechanically different.

[h1]Black Mesa[/h1]
This is an (Action-)Adventure game in the truest sense. Progressing thru the facility, completing mundane jobs in extraordinary circumstances, expanding ur arsenal, and coming across new threats, all capture that elusive sense of journey and adventure excellently.

The level and mission design here is phenomenal. The set pieces boast more player freedom and interactivity than most games do today, whilst the level design heavily leverages curiosity by employing secrets the player is meant and encouraged (thru, once again, subtle navigational clues embedded within the environment) to find. Everywhere one can expect to be a secret (underneath a dark staircase, thru a 'sus' looking door, behind the waterfall, etc.) the player will usually find one. The rewards are often not more than some extra ammo or armour, but it's an acknowledgement of the interest the players take in the game world.

Moreover, the level progression itself is fairly secret-y?-esque? Instead of the traditional linear corridor to setpiece/cutscene level design, the level progression here turns out to be just one of the many possible pursuits forward (the rest being secrets and the like), which also surprisingly never leads me to be stuck or get frustrated. 

No obj. markers, mini-maps, glowing interactable objects, contract-like quest systems, obviously coloured climbing elements, tutorials, pop-ups, corridor linearity to levels, and yet each time I felt like I was wasting my time going down a pointless tangent leading me to the dead end, the game threw an organic interaction or secret or, heck, the objective at me. This might have been Valve's first commercial project, but I've rarely seen level design this consistently good more than 2 decades l8r.

Each mission (of the ones I've played so far) is paced very well, with ample downtime, set pieces, new elements and environments, and variation to prevent it from getting stale or predictable. Furthermore, about halfway thru the game, the devs just decided (seemingly) to make a second game and attach it to the end of this one. A host of new weapons, new environments, new enemies are just casually dropped on the player. Different missions also bring in entirely different mechanics ([spoiler] rail cart, conveyor belts and acid vats, etc. [/spoiler]) and just as easily throw them out afterwards (tho not quite as game-changing as TF2, they still change mix things up enough).

The game's visuals, despite their age, still weave together an incredible ambience and sense of immersion, tho the Mesa part of Black Mesa is still a little hard to swallow. Inside the facility, however, the low poly count and dated visuals quickly fade as a detractor and are much easier to digest.  

[h1]Attention to Detail[/h1]
The introductory train ride may not work as well today, with its countable polygon dioramas, but the pre-fuck-up lab, with its player freedom and attention to detail, still astonishes me. So many little details have been catered for, and many elements of the game one would presume to be scripted, have an impressive level of dynamism to them.

The dialogue is also surprisingly realistic and genuine. In most instances, the game doesn't use more than a few short lines to make NPCs instantly likable ([spoiler]such as the guard u see at the start of the on the rail mission... or whatev it's called[/spoiler]). The grounded nature of the dialogue in this game is something most games continue to relentlessly fuck up even today (Horizon:FW).

As a testament to the attention to detail, here's an example. Right at the start (of the game) if u try and walk into the occupied bathroom stall door, the scientists will uhh... [spoiler]politely clear his throat[/spoiler]. 

[h1]Jank[/h1]
So there's a fair bit of it. It's a game from 1998 and it shows, especially in this regard. Angled surfaces, sometimes shoddy aim-assist, jumps not registering, awkward collisions, other utter bullshit, it's got the whole package and it bloody well makes use of it. But as much as it can make me pull my hair out at times, it has surprisingly not soured the overall experience for me. Ofc I would love if I didn't have to contend with the bullshit, but for a game as old as this, I mean I can't really get myself to complain.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Usually, I have a nice little wrap-it-up sorta note here, but I don't really know wut more to say. I could go on gushing about this game, but the bottom line is I haven't come across Xen yet; wut I have come across. however, easily makes this a masterpiece.

lemme just preface this: i have no nostalgic connection with this game. i didnt grow up with this, or half-life 2 for that matter, and only started playing this game fairly recently. as such, i had a lot more complaints that were less a problem with the game and more a problem with the time period this game came out in. i wont delve into that here, however.

this game is genuinely one of the few games from pre-2000 that i've actually completed. despite feeling dated in some regards, the gameplay is just plain fun. there are sections of the game, specifically towards the end, that just feel a bit too weirdly designed for me to enjoy them. i'd say the game kinda starts to trail off in terms of compelling level design after [spoiler]the military leaves black mesa, and the border world felt like such a chore.[/spoiler] this is pretty much the only negative, however.

onto the positives. my favorite aspect was easily the environmental storytelling that the game has. there arent really any cutscenes, and you can get a lot about the story just from observing your surroundings. this does lead to some slight confusion on the story if you just blazed through it, but for those with a keen eye, it's very compelling from a lore aspect. the overall setting of the game generally feels very realistic (well, realistic in the scenario that theres an alien invasion that starts in the science lab you work at). it's very easy to put yourself in gordon's shoes, since he's just a normal guy. no superhuman abilities, just pure skill that is completely inherited from the player who controls him.

in order not to ramble too much, i will cut this here. overall, would 100% recommend the game, even to people who dont like shooters. prior to this, i'd never really played a shooter and saw it through, and im glad this was my first adventure into the world of fps games. 

tldr: game is very good, albeit dated. if i had to rate it: 8/10

Valve makes good games. When they aren't flawlessly hosting a better games retailer than EGS, Valve is busy making couplets of games. Half-Life is one of said game couplets that has managed to weather the test of time and remains, to this day, one of the best designed, most engaging FPS titles of all time. The combat is incredible for a game that is >20 years old. The world design is top notch, arguably the best in the industry until the likes of BotW and RDR2 came around. The story telling is beyond what could have expected from a 90s title, much less one with a silent protagonist. The puzzles are rock solid, evidence that the Valve design mantra that has held through to modern titles was present from day 1. All that and the game on the OG engine was update 22 years after the game was released and replaced by a remake with an updated engine. Don't be scared off by the age of the game, pick up the entire Orange Box and give this classic a playthrough.

I look forward to playing Half-Life 2 when I have the time to.

Strong "cinematic" start is very impressive first time, but if you don't know english you are stuck and play it like a sierra quest (it's published by sierra, get it?). And every time you want to replay the game the "cinematic" 2 hours long intro is utter trash you have to suffer through. You already know the story beats, now you just want the gameplay.
First hour after the event was kinda weak in the 90s: without internet full of walkthroughs it is very easy to miss the crowbar and the first gun in all of the clatter and be stuck.

Then it's hours upon hours of pretty mediocre insane corridor shooter, where the most fun part is pressing buttons. Your legally blind nerd protagonist single-handedly destroys more army-men, tanks, choppas and giant enemy crabs than duke nukem or doomguy. You even have to fight hordes of sexy-time girl-ninjas. At one point you are even captured in a teerible trope of "now we take away your inventory". The army guys drag you somewhere looking at you while you are looking at them and leave you alive for no reason. Talk about dumb bad guys.
Once you start to get sci-fi and alien bioweapons you finally start to see that this is not a stupid shooter where all cool guns were replaced with stupid boring realistic military stuff with weak damage. This isn't the Wolfenstein 3D on a 3D engine. Bioguns were great then and they are great now. Even today there are still like 3,5 games that have them. One of which is called Opposing Force.
So okay it's a mediocre FPS with primitive gunplay where you can press E half as much as in the Duke Nukem 3D (but now in 3D) and it has some cool sci-fi and bioweapons you never saw anywhere else. You finally finished it and a science dude tells you to jump in a portal and win the game.

OH DAMN XEN! NOW THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST GAMES EVER! An alien world with extremely fun reduced gravity, now we are talking! There are some alien and sci-fi games. But it's always you invading a civilized space or defending human's colonies with civilized spaces, so same corridors slightly different skin. But this time you run around alien wilderness and then invade an alien sci-fi factory! The last boss is pretty weak. It's not as bad as in Quake, but it's still a stupid puzzle. It will take some time but it is possible to understand it without a walkthrough.

And then there is the multiplayer deathmatch. Quake 2 is absolute garbage without MP, and HL would not be the same without it too. You played with all those weird weapons and gadgets, half of which are utility tools with no use to them, and now you can finally place traps for fellow humans or rain aggressive naked rats into their hiding hole. You can run around with vacuum cleaner reducing live players into bloody chunks.

Amazing Xen and great deathmatch make this corridor game with bad gunplay one of the greatest games to this day.

AMAZING GAME!!! The campaign has a pretty good story for a game from 1998, has a lot of cool weapons, and has an ONLINE multiplayer! It even supports custom maps, making the multiplayer part so much better! First game I got on computer, and best game I got on computer. 10/10

I remember Half-Life was a big thing when it was first released (nearly quarter of a century ago now!), and no doubt had a huge impact on gaming and popularising games with scripted sequences and a story telling that wasn't confined to just being an FMV animation or a wall of text. Basically, the birth of modern "cinematic" FPS games.

You weren't the "only one against the world", but could and needed to recruit fellow scientists and security guards. You wielded an arsenal of (mostly) realistic weapons, such as Glock and MP5. There are many parts/levels, that other than the dated graphics, are still memorable and gripping, such as the fight against the Apache gunship. This game still oozes atmosphere.

But it's not perfect, and the big problems are the platforming sections (the bane of FPS games throughout their history IMO) and Xen, the "Gigeresque" alien world you get to visit in the latter part of the game. Put those two together, and you have a rather frustrating and unsatisfying "epilogue" to an otherwise great experience.

But overall, I feel it is a game that can still be very much enjoyed, even without through rose-tinted glasses of nostalgia. And for those of us who played it back in the day, it will no doubt bring back lots of memories of a certain "golden era" of gaming.

As a lifelong Half-Life fan (or at least what has felt like my entire life up to this point) I am ashamed to admit I never played the original until now. I played a bit of HL: Source while I was ignorant to its issues and I played Black Mesa, but I never sat down and just beat the original. Having now done that, I can say that those that are looking to get into Half-Life or those who are like me and loved Black Mesa, HL2 and its episodes, and even Alyx, I wholeheartedly recommend you play this version. It is shorter than all of those other games, but it packs a nice punch. I will be sure to replay it again in the future!

I've heard that this game hasn't aged well. At first glance, I expected it to hold up as well as I had heard. I've played games from this era in the past, on emulators or otherwise, and they've never not been underwhelming. I know I should probably curve the opinion I form when I play games from this era, because I wasn't around when games of this era came out, and I didn't grow up with them, and I don't have nostalgia for them, and I don't have their frame of reference for what the cutting-edge was when they came out. But I also don't really give a shit. Personal experience is the rawest and most valuable material you have to make a subjective opinion on something. 
With all that being said; this game is a fucking banger. The game lacks polish and can still be refined, sure, but the core gameplay and story are still an incredibly strong foundation for a game.
I can't really speak to the gunplay, movement, or puzzles too much. I didn't spend my adolescence getting a fucking master's degree in learning how Source engine works or designing FPS games. With that in mind, I think the core design of the game still holds up today. Each area feels different and realized while having a tight grip on the themes and story being presented. In Black Mesa, you'll be crawling through tight air ducts while trying to stop fucking alien headcrabs from biting your head off while trying to not shoot your pistol too much. The corpses of scientists and security guards pepper the hallways, and you will see people being fucking ripped apart and brutalized. You'll finally get to the surface and then immediately have to deal with the entire fucking U.S Armed Forces while on like 26 health (I'm probably not very good at this game don't make fun of me). You have to launch a fucking rocket into space for some reason while fending off a leviathan creature with just 8 grenades. Every moment, you're trying to figure out how in god's name you're going to make progress while fending off threats from all sides while managing all of your ammo for your guns and your health. Once the game finally tells you there is a light at the end of the tunnel, it immediately puts you in a literal alien world. You're overwhelmed, it feels hopeless, and a lot of the time you don't even have an idea as to the effects of what you're doing, but still you move forward and do what you can; that's the beauty of Half-Life. It's always aware of what it's trying to say on the whole while providing unique, moment to moment experiences backed by gameplay that still feels solid today.

I enjoyed this game after having played Black Mesa first. I wanted to see how good it compares backwards rather than forwards to see if it offered a more unique perspective on the game

Honestly this game is great, I can see how it became such an industry changing title the second it released.

However, Black Mesa is just a better game. Before any pitchforks get raised at me, let me just explain that Black Mesa spent years in development, finely recreating every single part of this game into a wholly optimised experience. Black Mesa also had 2020 technology to build its game on, and this game didn't even have 2000 tech. Half-Life 1 just cannot compete with Black Mesa, and tbh that's not necessarily a bad thing. It's amazing that we got two great games out of this, but when it comes to which one someone should play, honestly I'd say Black Mesa. 

The only reason I recommend Half-Life is that if you want to see just how important this game was, keeping in mind this is a game from 1998, absolutely DO play this game. It IS worth your time. But if you just want to play a fun game and have a good time, while you can find that here, you'd have a better time in Black Mesa.

Edit: Also I played the whole game on hard difficulty. Turns out the game isn't all that hard, people probably just suck. Pro-tip: Use more than one weapon. Don't be afraid to use the magnum even though you really like your SMG/M4.

Overall:

Half Life is a game changing, FPS that led the genre into a new era, with its immersive, realistic environments and storytelling. In this context, it's a fantastic game, and at its core, it still holds up as a fun game, instead of a mere historical curiosity. However, as many transitory pieces of art which redefine genre conventions, many of its aspects, both design and technical, have dated as well as milk, making it a quite frustrating experience.

7/10


The good:

One of the innovations that Half Life brought to the table was its commitment to seamless storytelling and realism. Its levels flowed into one another without interruptions, and without ever taking control away from the player. All the story was conveyed through character dialogue and scripted events, never using non interactive cutscenes. It basically took the complete opposite approach to storytelling to Metal Gear Solid, a game from the same year. The entire game is viewed through one seamless take from a single camera, Gordon Freeman's POV. This is something that games boast and market themselves on, like 2018's God of War, and yet Half Life did it very effectively 20 years prior. It's very immersive, and it helps the player really inhabit the character, who is appropriately enough of a blank slate, for players to express themselves freely through him. Black Mesa is a very interesting environment, being realistic enough to be believable but fantastical enough to allow for clever and versatile level design. There's also a surprising number of memorable, distinct environments, given that most of the game takes place in a single location. The pacing is very good, switching between exploration and resource gathering, to combat, and to light puzzling often, without it becoming tiring. The enemy AI is very sophisticated for the time, and holds up fantastically to this day. The human soldiers are especially impressive through their use of squad tactics, and grenades. Gordon's weapons arsenal, while not the most balanced (the assault rifle is pretty OP), is quite satisfying to use, and allows many different approaches to each situation.

The meh:

The game's commitment to realism also translates to its level design in a very impressive way, but it also creates problems. Often, the way forward is not communicated very well to the player, and I stumbled around a lot looking for how to progress, often relying on a walkthrough. This obtuseness however, can simultaneously be rewarding. Thinking of the environment in imaginative ways is the name of the game, and it can be surprising to see what the game expects you to do to progress. I found myself thinking that I had found an exploit, or a bug, only to realize that I was following the intended path all along. In a way it reminded me of my first experience with Super Metroid, or the final stretch of Portal. Fantastic highs, and super frustrating lows. Some enemy attacks, especially those with hitscan weapons, are pretty cheap as they deal massive damage very quickly. While that adds frustration, it also helps put the player in Freeman's shoes. He is up against an alien invasion, and an entire army, of course it's not a fair fight. You have to survive using your wits, employing on the fly guerrilla tactics, and your luck. Also, the game's mysterious unresolved ending can be quite underwhelming, or add to the game's vibe, depending on the player's engagement with the story, and the subtext about the hubris of mad science. 


The bad:

My frustrations with Half Life are mostly centered around one thing. Platforming. The game designers lean heavily into platforming segments during exploration, which the controls simply aren't built for. Gordon Freeman runs too fast and has a sense of momentum in controlling him, which combined with the first person view makes for a very janky and imprecise platforming experience. This is further exacerbated in the game's final stretch [spoiler] in Zen, where platforming is emphasized even more, with the addition of space gravity and a long jump ability. During the final boss, I often found myself jumping into the air only to find myself dying from the fall damage. [/spoiler] Also, climbing ladders in this, and other Valve games, is straight up garbage. Other than that, the bosses are pretty bad, either being complete pushovers or frustrating as hell. Finally, the most surprising thing about the game that annoyed me, were the bugs. From getting stuck on terrain while crouching, to broken scripted events, to audio and music tracks stopping abruptly, there was a significant number of times where I had to load a previous save to restore the game to working order. Considering that this is Valve's first game, and one of the hallmarks of PC gaming history, and that it's on Valve's own platform, where it has been patched multiple times over the years, this is unacceptable.

Half-Life made an effort to ground its game world in realism in contrast to other shooters of its time, and that decision still pays off well twenty years later. Black Mesa is memorable setting, and its distinctive sights and sounds help reinforce that. However, this was Valve's first commercial product, and that shows in various ways. It's no secret that the game's emphasis on set pieces was to make up for its fairly mediocre combat, and while the enemy AI is impressive, the emphasis on hitscan and otherwise difficult-to-avoid enemy attacks does sting. The boss fights, though few in number, do also tend to be some of the weakest parts of the game.

Still, to write off Half-Life as a historical curiosity would do it a great disservice. It's still a fascinating world to explore, and even if the game's age turns you off, there's also the remake Black Mesa available as an alternative.

This was not my first time playing through this game; however, it was been a long time since my last play through and I have mixed emotions towards this game. While yes, I do recommend this game and it is one the most revolutionary games to date, that's not to say that it is not without flaw. The bad. Many times I found myself frustrated on the lack of clear directions, as well with how "slippery" the movement felt. This made moments in the story that required precise jumping and movement annoying to deal with. On top of that, the amount of times I died to random environmental events, as well as glitches where my player was stuck has become too many to count and that also frustrated me. The good. The story, atmosphere, and world-building of the disastrous 'Resonance Cascade Event' was amazing. I love the Half-Life franchise and the way Valve managed to truly bring the scope of this event to life was amazing. The 'run and gun' type game play is very fun and satisfying at times, the game makes you feel at the center of the action.  Overall, I would give Half-Life one an 8/10, highly recommended.

One of my favorite games, an instant classic. This game follows the intense survival of one Dr. Gordon freeman, a scientist working at black mesa. After an accident in the test chamber, its up to you to save yourself and anyone else you can from an onslaught of aliens and even other humans!

After playing this game I can see why it gained the "classic" status it has.  The game is a product of its time when the term "Run and Gun shooter" was literal.  You run around killing anything that walks and to top it off the story is fairly interesting too.  I enjoy the DLC expansions that show you different perspectives of the Black Mesa incident.  

However, my main issues with the game are two things.  1) I found myself getting lost a couple times while playing the game, resorting to the internet to help me.  Sure, I could've figured it out on my own I guess, but it was a tad annoying.  2) Near the end of the game the platforming does get troublesome, however, I suppose it wasn't that big of a deal.

Anyway, at the end of the day I really enjoyed this game and will revisit it in the near future in the form of Black Mesa.  Off to play Half-Life 2 I guess.

Half-Life is highly enjoyable for a game of it's age. Despite being 24 years old at the time of writing this review, it still remains an enjoyable and sometimes genuinely frightening game to play. Valve did a great job making the environment of the game, as details can be seen sprinkled lovingly around every corner. Everything from the sound design (as crunchy and compressed as it is) to the scripted sequences is executed in a way that gives the game a lot of depth. I certainly found myself enjoying the dark humor that the game presents you with. 

The shooting is pleasant, albeit a bit dated in execution. The movement and platforming feels a bit loose; it's easy to miss a jump, slip off the edge of a broken walkway, but that's to be expected of any game from Half-Life's time. All in all, this is a classic example of Valve's quality game-making capability. For a game from 1998, Half-Life is an impressive and enjoyable game.

I recommend this game, it's worth buying. I rate this game a solid 8/10.

If DOOM made the FPS genre and QUAKE refined it, then Half-Life added world and life to it. The story of Half-Life is remarkable to say the least while still maintaining a fun gameplay loop. It still has the mechanical elements of 90s FPS but it branched off through its story, creating a truly unique experience at the time and one that's really only been topped by Valve themselves through the sequels. The steady delivery of story between, and sometimes during, action helps to keep the player engaged with what's going on in the story while not spending too much time on it and taking away from the fun. I'd say the best way to enjoy Half-Life is to go in blind and just enjoy the ride; pay attention to the details 
 and just experience it. It really is hard to find games much like Half-Life these days.

I've just recently completed what many consider one of the all time first person shooter classics. This game, like DOOM and System Shock before it, refined the model for modern for fps's. The gameplay is very well made and enjoyable. I did, however experience one major glitch during my game. Every time I  would start the game from my desktop, I'd receive a warning that steam cloud failed to backup my saves. I thought nothing of it until one day near the end of the story, I discovered half my saves (the most recent half) missing. I solved the issue by using console commands to load the level I was really on. So I'm glad I didn't have to restart the whole game, but very frustrated that I had to go through the trouble. I really hope the same issue doesn't occur for Opposing Forces and Blue Shift. My other negative isn't much a negative as it is a lack of a positive. The story in this game compared to System Shock 2 and even the original System Shock, is extremely lackluster, leaving this game to rely almost entirely on the gameplay. I won't say any more except that I hope the DLC and/or sequels improve on this aspect.

First thing's first; Definetly buy this instead of Half-Life: Source.

Pros:
- It isn't broken
- It's constantly being updated
- This game is marketed for what it is (The source version is not a remaster like they said it was).
- Way more mods available for this verion than source.
- Settings are easy to change and gameplay is reasonably challenging
- The mechanics combined with the great story work great unlike the source version
- Multiplayer is better than source
- Can be used to play Half Life: Decay
- Great music score created by Kelly Bailey
- Soundtrack is free

Cons:
- Water doesn't look as good as it does in the source version.
- No ragdoll physics like in the source version.
- The source version has a chapters menu and animated backgrounds unlike this verion which requires the console to load in a chapter.

This game is a solid 9.8 if you like retro shooters like DOOM. The constant updates from Valve keep it relevant and very easy to download, install, and get to playing the game.

The long half-life of radioactive materials has presented a fundamental challenge to generations of scientists, politicians, and national and global communities alike. With a half-life of up to 4.5 billion years for uranium-238, the legacies of nuclear tests, uranium mining and radioactive waste management linger. It is Australia‚Äôs intimacy with the nuclear that Ian Lowe hopes to untangle in his new book Long Half-life: The Nuclear Industry in Australia, his latest contribution in a series of endeavours to enlighten the public on Australia‚Äôs ill-conceived pursuit of this industry.

The perplexity that surrounds radioactivity is central to Lowe‚Äôs work. Early in the piece, he quips that the long half-life of uranium baffles politicians as their ‚Äòtime horizon[s] rarely extend ‚Ä¶ beyond this year‚Äôs budget or next year‚Äôs election‚Äô (p. 1). But it is not just long half-lives that induce trepidation. Lowe notes that meta-data on the effects of radioactivity is lacking and scientists have never been able to confidently agree on its degree of danger. As scientific opinions differ wildly on many aspects of the nuclear, confusion reigns. In response, laypeople ‚Äì minimally informed and bewildered by the mixed messages ‚Äì fall in the middle of the mess. The tendency has been for ‚Äòpeople to choose the one [opinion] they would prefer to be right‚Äô (p. 27). This, Lowe implies throughout, has been the case since the dawn of the nuclear age in Australia, guiding arguments both for and against the nuclear industry since its emergence in the 1950s.

But it is nuclear energy, rather than the nuclear industry writ large, that most concerns Lowe in this work. Despite nuclear energy presenting itself periodically as a ‚Äòcleaner‚Äô and ‚Äòcheaper‚Äô alternative to fossil fuels since as early as the 1950s, its use was (and is) indivisible from other uses of the nuclear. Lowe argues that the ill-fated British nuclear tests held in Australia (1952-63) ensured that questions of the viability of nuclear energy were entwined with desires for nuclear weapons (p. 42). Such intimacy between energy and weaponry persists. Lowe evokes this by placing this debate in its contemporary context: earlier this year, the Doomsday clock moved the closest it has ever been to midnight in response to the determination that the biggest threats to humankind in 2021 are nuclear weapons and climate change (p. 186). Lowe shows that nuclear energy sits at the nexus of these threats, as it always has.

But, further to this, and from the beginning of Long Half-life, it is clear that Lowe does not believe nuclear energy is economically viable. This will come as little shock to Lowe‚Äôs target audience: an already environmentally-conscious and presumably anti-nuclear one. Lowe uses Long Half-life to platform renewable energy as an alternative to the physically, environmentally, and financially damaging nuclear option. In doing so, he weaves together arguments against the nuclear with a call (to the Australian Government especially) to do something meaningful about climate change. Lowe draws upon his expertise in physics and environmental science to assure his reader that, while it once may have been, nuclear is not the answer to Australia‚Äôs current problems.

By placing our nuclear past in conversation with the current threat from anthropogenic climate change, Lowe provides insightful social commentary. However, it is easy to forget while reading Long-half life that it has been marketed by the publisher as a ‚Äòhistory‚Äô, specifically a ‚Äòsocial and political history of Australia‚Äôs role in the nuclear industry‚Äô. While reading, I was struck that the chapter on the development of global nuclear politics and the beginning of the Cold War was afforded seven pages, and only three endnotes. On the other hand, contemporary debates in South Australia regarding the disposal of nuclear waste are generously given nearly thirty. Yet there was little acknowledgement of the historic efforts of activists to overturn previous dump proposals in South Australia, most notably the 1998 National Waste Repository floated by the Howard Government.

Lowe deals with the contemporary politics of the nuclear in Australia in some depth (albeit omitting key scholars on the nuclear such as Wayne Reynolds and relying a little heavy-handedly on former-diplomat Richard Broinowski‚Äôs Fact or Fission? for historical analysis). However, the lived experience of the nuclear is markedly absent. In Long Half-life the human element of this story is mostly limited to the male politicians and scientists integrally involved in policy. Those most impacted by this policy dilemma are unfortunately lost among reports, scientific debates and statistics, with only vague mentions of the various communities who have pushed back against the nuclear, generation after generation.

This is not to say that Long Half-life is not a worthwhile book. Rather, it has been potentially mismarketed. To sell this book as a ‚Äòsocial‚Äô history is a disservice to what Lowe has done within its pages, chiefly in illuminating the debates surrounding the nuclear industry from the perspective of someone intimately familiar with it. I agree with Monash University Press‚Äô assertion that Lowe is ‚Äòuniquely qualified to tell this story‚Äô. His status as a ‚Äònuclear expert‚Äô is undeniable. And, as one makes their way through Long Half-life, it becomes increasingly clear that it has been written from the perspective of someone who fears for the consequences of his generation‚Äôs actions on those to come.

Ultimately, Long Half-life is a treatise on how to consider the adverse effects of our actions. Indeed, Dave Sweeney and Peter Garrett endorse this volume as a ‚Äòcautionary tale‚Äô and a ‚Äòclarion call for sanity‚Äô. And so, in keeping with its overall themes, Lowe concludes Long Half-life with a powerful call to arms: ‚Äò[o]ur decisions are creating the future in which our descendants will live. I believe we should be working to give them the legacy of a clean and secure future, not one clouded by radioactive waste and fear of nuclear war‚Äô (p. 208). Effective social history or not, it is hard to argue with that.

As a person who generally doesn't enjoy the FPS genre, Half-Life is a wonderful game that has aged phenomenally for the most part. From a basic but intriguing premise, to fun and interesting environments, to some really funny voice acting, Half-Life has got it all. It does have a few issues IMO, such as the game not being exactly clear on what you need to be doing at all times, as well as Xen not being as fleshed out as it could be and the final boss being a bit lackluster. I won't hold that last point against the game however, as it's the only boss in the game so there wasn't really anything to compare it to. So overall, Half-Life is a wonderful little game with a few flaws, but not enough to make a big difference.

This game is one of the best single player games I've played. It has a lot of action in the game. 

Graphics and audio

The audio and textures aren't as good as they are for newer games obviously because this game is old but its good for the year it came out.  9/10 (for its time)

Gameplay

This game took me 10 hours to complete and in those 10 hours I had a whole lot of fun.  Tons of weapons and enemies. Good storyline 10/10.

Bugs

There are some bugs you might encounter such as the second last boss getting stuck (which is what happened for me) but they are mostly easy to fix just make sure you keep a lot of normal saves and not quick saves just in case it bugs out.

Overall this is an amazing game and for $2 it is worth it!

this game has lots of shit moments, but the ideas are so good, that it gets you going, how many games out there have so many different encounters like this one has? every single level of this game has a great replay factor, which is good since this is an hellish, unforgivable shooter.

The thing that sticks negatively with me is the combat, yeah cool that you have all this nice ideas and a great script for the gameplay, but if your shooting sucks so bad that you can't even have the pleasure to try to approach levels differently with the guns, why would i have fun? it's just the same thing over and over again, but this time there is a catch! 
The movement is sloppy as hell too, and even tho this is a shooter, you need to platform several times, and it sucks so much to try to control Freeman's buttery feet.
I could go all day talking about how the combat isn't good and how the fun of the game is on the new ideas and encounters, but it's a thing that only you can understand when you experience an encounter where you are spamming three soldiers with your rifle and it takes about 4 seconds to take one of them down.

If the gameplay wasn't as dated and the shooting wasn't as unpleasant, this would be a perfect fps, but as of right now it only stands as a classic for me.

This was my first play through of the game as an adult. I never played it as a child either but I watched my older brother play it through and I have little recollection of it. It's an old game but I can understand why it's still gold!
Here are my thoughts on:

Graphics:
Good for a game from 1998! Although the rendering of humans in Half-Life isn't very good; the environment and the creatures are quite believable. After about an hour, you brain will adjust to the graphics and fill in missing details. There were a few stages where the graphics clipped through objects but nothing too bad. 

Gameplay:
This can be a little frustrating to a modern gamer. I forgot how direct and linear older games tended to be, so there was less hand holding than modern games and more "you figure it out", it took only a minor psychological adjustment and it's not difficult to solve puzzles and tactics. 
The game employed more than just 'puzzle solving' too; there were several stages as a platformer where you had to leap from platform to platform. These sections were frustrating to play because the controls were a little too sensitive. So for example jumping from one platform to the other, landing teetering on the edge and controlling you character to move forward a bit, only to have him take 3 strides and now you're dead.
I'd like to suggest to save the game regularly so as to avoid needing to do painful jumps all over again in case you die. 

Story:
Not much goes into a narrative but a brief understanding of "scientific experiment goes wrong, opens portal, government conspiracy and interdimensional aliens". 

Extra Notes:
Take care of your health and ammo when you quicksave. There are many spots in the game where ammo is scarce and health is also scarce. 
Has some replayability as a fps.

This game absolute rules. It's genuinely impressive how much of the game still holds up today. The puzzles and exploration are where this game shines. I loved searching every inch of Black Mesa and finding extra equipment to aid me. The weapons are also pretty fun to play around with. Despite the game's age, I did not have too many issues with the allied AI either. The enemies are generally fun to fight against. I preferred the human enemies personally.

Performance wise, the game runs smoothly but the loading areas can be pretty jarring. I thought the story was pretty nice. It wasn't anything too crazy or mind-blowing, but it was pretty solid.

The game does fall off in the endgame. The alien world is such a slog and it was frustrating at times. I thought the aliens were cool and mysterious from a story standpoint, and it's a darn shame the alien world was as boring and frustrating as it was. The platforming of this game is by far the worst part of the entire game. At no point was it fun to platform, but it could just be the game's age. The headcrab queen thing and Nihilanth were really tedious boss fights. 

Despite the Half-Life's faults and age, it is still a fun experience and downright impressive at times. I would highly recommend this game.

Half-Life consistently violates game design principles: bad platforming, unfair enemy placement, and occasionally, an unclear path of progression partially due to the low-detail objects and environments. Gunplay lacks the satisfaction of modern first person shooter titles and the setting loses its appeal after the first hour or so. The appeal of a fully 3D rendered DirectX 6-era game with lip-synced voice acting doesn't hold weight over 20 years later.

Well, I thought I'd write something about one of the forefathers of computer games... Half-Life, the "pioneer" for all coming story shooters...

Well, Half-Life is like any other game. Either you like it or you hate it.

[b]One shouldn't forget that the game is from 1998 and is therefore one of the really old games.[/b] 

Due to the age, it is of course absolutely not comparable with current games, even if they are retro games. Whether they are created from scratch and with a retro look, or are simply technically polished, a Half-Life will always play differently than "younger" games.

I'm a total Half Life fan. It's no secret and I don't make any of it.
This is probably due to my age and the fact that I played the game for hours after it was released. I even have the packaging with CD-ROM somewhere (if anyone knows what that is).

[b]What makes Half-Life so great is that without it, many of the games we know and play today wouldn't even exist.. [/b]

The Half-Life engine was then an "evolution" of id Software's great Quake engine and Half-Life is still rated 96 / 100 by Metacritic to this day and even made it into the Guinness book as the best-selling first-person shooter.
Half-Life was [b]the first first-person shooter to have a story, scripted cutscenes, and an AI.[/b] 
If I remember correctly, the Gordon Freeman story was inspired by the Stephen King novel ‚ÄûThe Mist‚Äú, but I'm not entirely sure.

I know some who have tried to play the game and I can understand some saying "great game, I just can't play it because I don't like the control / gameplay".
If you're not used to it or don't know it, then it's an absolutely strange feeling, I'll admit that. 
I just recently played all the sequels again and it's really a weird feeling at times. You can say that, yes.

Half-Life and Gordon Freeman, for me, an absolute cult classic that you should definitely have played if you can.
I can warmly recommend [url= https://store.steampowered.com/app/362890]Black Mesa[/url] to anyone who wants to immerse themselves in the Half-Life universe, but doesn't get along with it in the original way. 
Black Mesa is really fun, looks better and plays a little differently and is definitely worth checking out.

Half Life is a great game. An amazing game. I would even go as far as saying that it belongs into videogame history and you should absolutely play it.

Half Life is a Game about 27 year old Gordon Freeman, who experiments with some crystal accidentally opens a portal to another dimension while doing so. This causes havoc because aliens start teleporting into the facillity and not only that - The U.S. government comes in to help by cleaning up this mess [i]and everyone that experienced it.[/i] Freeman has to fight his way through the facillity and completes countless of tasks to stop the chaos and manages to defeat a giant baby called [i]the Nihilanth.[/i]

Look mate, I never played Half Life before. The only game that I played that was kinda similar was probably Bioshock but I think I have to say that I adored Half Life so much that I'd say that Bioshock isn't as good as Half Life. As soon as I started it and as soon as I got into the suit and the music started playing I was super pumped up and addicted. It only gets better and better from this point on because you collect weapons, kill aliens and go through the different areas while totally feeling badass.

The Writing is basically very weird but I don't think it's a weakness. The player mostly has no idea why the fuck you are getting swarmed by aliens or why the fuck you have to launch a rocket and it really adds because that's how Freeman probably actually feels ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

The game keeps being cool and badass until you arrive at "On a Rail". That is my first tiny problem with the game. It throws to many enemies and you, it gives you too little health and expects you to keep up when you are getting shot at from four sides with 20hp. Look mate I normally like hard games. I'm in love with Dark Souls and I went into the choosing the "normal" difficulty thinking that it probably won't be that hard. I was so wrong. I died countless of times because of stupid stuff and there were times were I felt like I was doing a no hit run :I

On a Rail wasn't even that bad. It gets bad once you get out of Black Mesa and wander around the New Mexico deserts. It's stupidly difficult from that point on and don't get me started on fucking Interloper... I played the game normally until then but I couldn't fucking take it anymore. I used god mode to get to the final boss because I was basically trapped in a giant room with 4hp getting shot at from all sides.

Half Life is fun but I should have chosen easy mode for it to not be frustrating at all. Maybe I just suck but I don't think actually think that I'm bad at videogames. -1 for the absurd difficulty.

Also a small thing: I encountered some annoying bugs like on time where I was just stuck in a pipe so also -0,5 for that.

All in  all: Half Life is an amazing game with interesting areas, perfect combat and a huge difficulty spike. I love it.

[b]This game was, unironically, one of the worst gaming experiences I've ever had.[/b] I've tried this several times, could never get into it that much. This game while it sure was phenomenal for its time, now it's just garbage, because nothing that was impressive at the time, still is. Most of the time spent is just wandering around not knowing where to go, or what to do either. I can't name a single thing that's good about Half-Life, best parts about it are average at best. It feels like a chore to play, and that's because it is.

[b]+[/b] Gameplay - mostly due to the engine, but enemies are well done, and aside from that, movement is kinda fun, gunplay is just average.
[b]-[/b] Weapons - while it does have variety of weapons to choose from, they're extremely imbalanced, you're only gonna play with 2 or 3 of them, since most of them are trash, and some of them are broken.
[b]-[/b] Story - would be average at best, but it's worse than that because of how much stretched this game is, 90% of the time nothing's going on.
[b]-[/b] Level Design - absolutely horrible, you can almost never know where to go or what to do, hardly anything makes any sense, it's mostly very confusing.
[b]-[/b] Bugs - it's not that big of a deal, but there are bugs than can be really annoying, some of them can even block your progress.

Overall Score: [b]2/10 (Very Bad)[/b]

Half-Life is an action-adventure first-person shooter set in the bowels of a mountain in the US state of New Mexico. It is there, according to the plot, that the federal research center of gigantic proportions, bearing the name "Black Mesa", is located, and it is there that a number of top-secret studies are carried out. The main character of the game is a young talented researcher Gordon Freeman, who works in the laboratory of anomalous materials.

An average-cleared scientist is unaware of the dangers of the work ahead. One morning, Gordon is sent to the test chamber for routine crystal analysis. The consequences of the experiment, however, are disastrous. The explosion of the crystal breaks a gap between the dimensions, from where alien forces begin to attack the Earth. Gordon, caught between the aliens and the US Army, seeks to get out of the complex before he is found and destroyed.

I never enjoyed this game and I honestly struggle to truly understand why. It left such a mediocre taste in my mouth that it took me 8 years to get around to the rest of the franchise - Which I now love. It's for this reason that I wouldn't recommend this to new players, yet I strongly enjoyed Black Mesa (a modernised remake). I would recommend buying that instead as it does what the rest of the franchise does well and adds a bit more of an atmosphere. I can't write too deep a review as it's been 8 years since I played it, but having remembered parts through Black Mesa I would say that conceptually it was fantastic and anyone looking for an old school shooter without any modern visuals should go ahead and buy this over Black Mesa. Honestly a true technical marvel of it's time, but it just didn't resonate with me in any way.

Just finished this game and it took me way longer than i expected, partially because i finished portal in a couple of hours and expected the same of half life. 

I think its a fun game, graphics, bugs, weird movement, dialogue volume too low compared to environment noise in certain sections i can excuse to it being an old game/ being an fps. 

I haven't played an fps before and maybe that's why i struggled with this game a bit but on several occasions i had to load last save a ton of times in order to get a section done or clear enemies with enough health/ammo (this holds true especially for the later sections). 

Some parts took way too long but that was sometimes because of me missing an interactive button or lever. Or not knowing that there was passage through that particular area but that's okay. That's what exploration is about.

The later sections were really hard for me and I had to look up a walkthrough for the final three sections due to not being able to figure out that i could destroy crystals/struggling with a fight/again not know that there was a passage in a particular place.

The story was a bit hazy for me since we travelled a lot and things were very diverse from what we originally started with.

Overall i don't know I give this game a positive or a negative but I think its worth trying out anyway. Gunning down enemies is always fun.

Half-Life, I‚Äôm my opinion and I‚Äôm sure in many others opinions half life is one of the most important games ever. Up until the release of half life in 1998 by valve corp and published by seria studios, games were just spawn and shoot; not really any story. Half life added an entire story with a fun multiplayer that you could play for hours. The story has an amazing storyline and very fun puzzles. One of the games from the past that holds up EXTREMELY well today. The gameplay is pretty good, though sometimes can be...don't play on hard mode basically.
Graphics are fine, temper your expectations, it's literally from another century, but the way they are made, set up an atmospheric style that is really effective at some points.


For a cons section, the default fov is pretty garbage, I'd recommend bumping it up by like an extra 20 ("default_fov 90" is the command to change it). Also, at certain points I started getting...nauseous? If you start playing for extended periods and start getting a headache, GET OFF! At least for like an hour or two because that nauseous feeling is pretty bad, I've never had that happen with a game before. Lastly, there are some glitches, geometry being number one, but they're few and far between, just make sure to save often as the autosaves in this game are pretty hit or miss.

All in all, a worthy purchase if you're going in with the right mindset, I personally bought the Valve-whatever-the-fuck-bundle, and I'm getting a pretty good mileage out of it.

One of the best games I have ever played it is practically a MUST play game. You should consider playing the whole Half-Life franchise before, you grow up.

 As you're playing you'll realize how open and wide the environment is while still having a clear idea or path of what you should do (in the game) without indicators like a mini-map with indicators or anything like that, It is fairly straightforward and simple what you should do and where you should go, etc etc, As well as the more you immerse yourself basically all the early VALVE games the more you realize literally so many other game industries have "copied" (got inspired by valve games) half-life 1 - 4 has the same vibe as games we have now but they feel original the feel raw and basic yet so empowering 

-Portal 1,2
-half-life 1
-half-life blue shift          (we don't mention the green one) [we don't talk about that]
-half-life 2 and other episodes 
-Left 4 dead 1,2
-Counter strike franchise 
-Gary's mod
-TF2


These games all hit hard and have so much orgasmic wholesomeness to them, They all possess mostly the same vibe in gaming although each game has its special feeling, Portal being Eire and lonely making you strive on completing objectives with music and sounds that fit your situation with amazing writing and storytelling with a deep thought of lore, half-life being completely original and deep lore that ties with portal making it way more diverse and incorporating rich gameplay and Puzzleish combat. They were one of the first games to introduce 3D zombie combat (mutant creatures) and a set goal (don't wanna spoil), And finally counter strike arguably the most famous shooter game there is, It has basically inspired counter-strike, valorant, and other games it was one of the first shooter games and a game that managed to incorporate strategy in-game vs other players it was originally a half-life 2 mod just like Garry's mod WHICH IS THE BEST SANDBOX GAME THERE IS gmod holds many precious memories of mine and I've had countless funny nights playing gmod with friends and having fun all around as well as having a wholesome community gmod is the best sandbox game period. Moving on to team fortress 1,2 Those games basically inspired Overwatch and valorant in terms of many features and genres as well as mechanics as you can see VALVE keeps coming up in every genre there is and having a big spot in each genre even serving as foundations in some genres like sandboxes and single-player storytelling.

VALVE is great and their games are getting they never get old people have adored them for ages and sadly those days are coming to an end with the valve being relatively quiet and not living up to expectations on recent game "innovations'. So I urge you to play and experience all the VALVE games, all of them. GIVE THEM A CHANCE.

Here's the thing: if you're interested in the Half-Life series, this isn't the place you HAVE to start. Honestly, starting with the next installment, Half-Life 2, it does a decent job basically creating an entirely different storyline. If you're a big fan of getting ALL of the in-jokes and references, then yes, plot-wise you could start here for sure.

It's fairly short, about a ten hour romp. It's the oldest game I've every actually played and finished, and I have to admit I think they were still in the midst of figuring out how to scale difficulty back in 1998 (you can save anywhere so it's not a big deal, but there were plenty of times I'd be reloading a save like a hundred darn times).

Overall it's a very fun shooter with lots of atmosphere and action and comedy and everything you can ask for. You can see how this short little escape from a strange scientific facility became the starting point for one of the biggest names in gaming.

I was drawn to Half-Life by its place in the history of video games, and its reputation as one of the greatest games of all time. Though it was certainly important for its time, I would not strongly recommend it for anyone looking for an extremely engaging experience, especially if they are more interested in story than (undoubtably good) gameplay. The atmosphere and plot are exciting at the beginning, but the game progressed at a very slow pace, and lost its wonderful creepiness after a while. By the final scenes, I was expecting to be rewarded for many long hours I had put into Freeman's battle, but I never found the epic climax I was hoping for. I must admit that due to some 'technical issues' I was not able to reach the very end of the game, so I will be charitable and say I probably missed something. In the final analysis, I think this game is a bit overrated, though I am sure there will be many who disagree with me.

if Doom is the grandpa of the FPS genre, Half-Life is the Father. Half-Life bridges the gap between old school shooters like Doom and Wolfenstein with modern shooters like Halo and that other one that refuses to die. 

For it's considerable age Half-Life has aged tremendously well, it's fun, frantic and engaging, the game definitely dips in quality by the final act, starting at Xen, which even Valve acknowledges, personally I'd recommend just throwing away your dignity and putting godmode on so you can blaze through it and get to the ending, it's not the most respectable way, but it's better than putting up with the atrocious design of Xen. Everywhere else however is amazing, the game has its moments of difficulty that reaches a little too high in my opinion, Surface Tension and On A Rail jump to my mind, but generally the game is very fair, unforgiving absolutely, but fair. 

Gordon Freeman is a mute nerd with a shotgun, but I like him more than somebody like Doomguy because Gordon is a nerd, he's no soldier, he's just a man trying his best to survive with what little he has so he can go home and watch Gundam Wing probably. The game has you slowly become the super soldier, and personally I find that a helluva lot more engaging than starting the game a badass. 

Half-Life is fantastic, it's aged fantastically and the majority of the game is fun, don't forget to pay your respects to the daddy of the fps genre... no wait now that I say it like that it doesn't sound very good at all does it?

I love the take on aliens having headcrabs that attach themselves to humans and take control of their bodies nerve system to make them move and be "zombies" it is a refreshing take on zombies, without actually being zombies in what we have come to know as zombies since George A. Romero's zombie takes in movies from the 1960's.

Now I remember back in 2005 when I first played Half-Life it had DirectX 8 support and now with VALVe pushing Linux support and removing DirectX 8 from the Gold Source engine video games adding OpenGL support to the Gold Source engine video games I keep getting OpenGL errors every now and then and some freezing issues, which I do not remember ever happening with DirectX 8.

VALVe please add DirectX 8 support or at least a more up to date version of DirectX 9 support which supports 64-bit, which is DirectX 9.0C I believe?

This game is rather dated. It's one of the those rare games that it's attempt at what we know as the modern fps format was legendary at the time, but has caused it to be left in the dust as time moves on. That being said I played it without accessing the console whatsoever, so i didn't noclip to get out of spots where i'd get stuck in the wall or if there was a bug or anything. Played it totally vanilla. And If that's how you choose to play it then my rating should be Not Recommended instead. That playstyle truly reveals how much wrong there is in this game. And I think the overall world and story was worth playing, pretty neat. But I won't be playing it again, at least not in this format. I am excited to move on to the second game as it will be my first time seriously playing that game all the way through.

tldr; Great game for the time, but it's dated of course. Lots of bugs... Don't repeat my mistake and just use the console if you end up getting stuck or run into a game halting bug.
