Strange how this game is often recommended as one of the greatest games of all time, I didn't like it very much at all. I missed it on the first go around back in '98, and thought I'd give it another shot during the pandemic. Ironically I don't actually mind the graphics, it was a simpler time, but the game-play just isn't that engaging. You don't walk across the land, rather you "skate," often overshooting your intended platform to your death. You don't climb off a ladder, but hurl yourself in the opposite direction usually to your death. You don't fire precision shots to kill the enemies (who are the military and space aliens) but spray about a hundred bullets from a pistol (which makes an insufferable noise) or assault rifle, or wizz-bang alien weapons; while they all can kill you in around five hits. The plot is pretty boring as well. Maybe that guy in the blue suit you see at the start of EVERY scene has something to do with the invasion? Crack job detective. 

Again, I'm not quite sure why this game is so popular. If you're looking for games with a bit more substance which came out in '98, check out Grim Fandango, Baldur's Gate, Spyro the Dragon, Thief all on windows xp, (haha). But if you just can't get enough Half-Life, check out "Sabrina, the Teenage Witch: Spellbound." It's basically the same game as Half Life, but expanded to included a science fiction fantasy element that's as powerful as it is riveting.

Half life 1 is truly a masterpiece for it's time. Even when the Ai can be a bit goofy and a bit messy, The game truly fasincates me with details, even if this game is 20 years old you can still discover new and amazing facts with the series and the games as a whole (HL2, BS, OF, etc)


But for this game in particular, this game is special when it comes to details, for a game in 1998 theirs literally bugs that move around and little fishes that attack Gordon in a few areas. Another thing worth to note is how the game transforms slowly overtime as the Disaster goes on, Military losing hope, Scientists and Security slowly getting less frequent to see at the final few chapters. It shows how high scale Black Mesa's incident was and how horrifying it really was, especially in the DLC's with blue shift and Opposing force. Both have amazing storytelling without markers on a screen telling you where to go. 

The levels in the game (I sorta call them chapters just like HL2 does) Have amazing design, You may get stuck for a bit in one level if you're not aware of the map layout (especially on your first 1-10 playthroughs you may forget the layout or what to do entirely) without checking a tutorial. Can be annoying but its manageable if you try.

The Soundtrack is amazing, Questionable Ethics is by far the best song. The buildup, The action, The finale shows how much care and effort valve put in their game. Half life 1's Beta was entirely scrapped and made an entirely new game. And it really shows in the release.

The guns and weapons have some unique designs, each one feels different when you hold it. The Magnum Revolver deals heavy blows to enemies, especially more bigger and dangerous enemies, The crossbow is like a sniper and can pick enemies from far away. Each weapon has a different variety to it that makes them fun and rewarding to pick enemies off with.

I really enjoyed Half-Life. I was really excited to finally play this game and it did not disappoint for the most part. The one thing I really loved about the game is that it's very much one big seamless experience. Loading between different areas is done in a mostly non-intrusive way (at least as much as technology at that time could allow), and all of the "cutscenes" and dialogue are integrated into the gameplay. This, coupled with the eerie music and ambience allows you to really get immersed in the world, like you really are Gordon Freeman going on this journey. The combat feels good and the problem solving to get through the different areas and challenges is really satisfying when you finally get it right. There were some parts of the game where it was a little confusing on what to do, and its easy to occasionally get lost, but for a game made in '98 it holds up surprisingly well.

A 40/60 split of good/bad respectively, I'd say. When it it's good it's good but more often than not it wasn't, just tedious and frustrating instead.

Pros:
- Surprisingly immersive and interactive world considering the year it was released.
- Rewards caution and sharp senses, the tools and hints you need to succeed are there if you take the time to examine the situation... Usually.
- It's got charm, I cannot deny.

Cons:
- Gordon controls like a drunk with brain damage made of flubber caught in an oil slick at all times. Makes already frustrating first-person platforming so much worse. Even just trying to move with any sort of precision can be all but impossible sometimes.
- Rife with artificially difficult trial-and-error sections and/or portions which call for quick, precise movements that the control your given only technically allows for, if ya know what I mean.
- One of the worst final bosses I've ever had the displeasure of having to slog against.

Honestly the DLC's were better (even Blue Shift.) Better level design with more reasonable challenges.

While this game may be ~22 years old, it is pure enjoyment even today.  Personally, I enjoy the late-90's/early-00's era of graphics as it still left a lot to the imagination.  Now and days everything is so polished and detailed that it's a lot to take in, and I personally find it mentally taxing and overwhelming to play many modern games.  However Half-life is very enjoyable in 2021, and a basic linear game, without *too* much repetition of textures.  The AI can be a little dumb and non-responsive at times, but that's common with games of this era - I find it a nice nostalgic reminder of how far gaming (and computing in general) has come, if nothing else.  Highly recommend to anyone!

It started it all. With the release of this game began the saga of a game company we now know for its award-winning titles and franchises.

Half-Life's great. With today's standards, probably not the best, since it was a 1998 game and the textures and sounds are... well... 1998..., but it did revolutionize the FPS genre at the time. Nonetheless, fantastic story, mechanics, gameplay, voice acting, etc.
Can get difficult at times but maybe that's just me; I'm not a [i]huge[/i] fan of the FPS genre. I got this game, as well as HL2 and the Episodes, [i]partly[/i] because I loved the Portals.
This occasional difficulty spike meant that I had to save like, every few seconds to ensure some progress. It sadly did detract from what was otherwise a fun and enjoyable experience. Fortunately, this was not present in HL2 (but I haven't played that on the hardest difficulty, so I don't know if that would be [i]as difficult[/i] or more).
If you're good at FPS games then you will likely not face the same problems as me. But if not, then here's a warning: it's hard.

So do I recommend it? Yes if you're really into first person shooters, and/or would like to get into the Half-Life-Portal universe story, and/or are feeling the '90s nostalgia. While you're at it, be sure to get HL2, as well.

I was one of the few people who never got to play classics such as Half Life, Fallout or DOOM until recently, and I honestly never thought much about them. I knew that Half Life was critically acclaimed and formed the backbone for not only Half Life 2 (considered by many to be the greatest game released by Valve), but also its successors, and the wide scope of the company, allowing it to release anything from consoles, to VR headsets (and VR games, as we found out).

Without spoiling too much, you play as Gordon Freeman, a scientist who studied for a PhD in Theoretical Physics at the MIT. (In other words, super-duper smart guy). He works in a top-secret research facility that works on teleportation gear, and ways to connect to other hypothetical dimensions. These experiments worked, but - as it turns out - worked too well, and creatures from a different dimension come seeping through the facility. Your goal is not only to seal this rift, but to ultimately survive.

The game employs the use of puzzles, which for the most part are extremely straightforward. While there are lots of visual hints available, such as outright signs, you will most likely not need any. Use your intuition, in 9 out of 10 cases, it will be right. The shooting is pretty good, all things considered, though the AI can get annoying even on Normal difficulty. Somehow I still managed to get across though.
The graphics are poor by today's standards; they are very low-poly, but that does not stop the game from setting an atmosphere. If anything, I appreciate the color palletes used, and on today's computers, the game changes levels instantly. It's also a nice change of pace from modern games; whereas modern games can draw you in with their visuals, this game draws you in by making you imagine its potential - and boy it is huge. You needn't look further than Half Life: Alyx.

Overall, really enjoyed it. Can recommend. 8/10

This was the first proper single player shooter I ever played as I did not grow up playing them. I played it for the first time a few years and ago and it was my gateway to loving linear, single player fps games. I found the environments and the simple story incredibly immersive. The combat, especially on hard, requires you to plan ahead for each encounter. The entire arsenal you have access to is useful. The soundtrack is minimal but memorable when it appears. The enemy AI is actually really fun to go up against as you learn their quirks. 
I feel this 20 year old game holds up extremely well. The graphics are dated, but they have a charm and simplicity to them that keeps them a bit fresh. Honestly, I think you are missing out if you haven't played this.

[h1]Dust Up[/h1]

[u]Half-Life[/u] is a game that created a world and encapsulated story within it, unlike anything else at the time. It still holds up today - remarkably well, along with it's successor. This game is a mountain in creative endeavour and a journey of timeless proportion. Game play elements largely range around FPS combat, of which there are numerous weapons and consequent strategies to employ. It makes for enjoyable variation and persistent novelty combined with the changing level environments and enemy encounters. Speaking of changing environments, the game takes place at a research facility called Black Mesa and your ventures will take place here. The atmosphere that both the visuals, ambience, and music evokes help to enhance the experience and memorability. Perhaps it's also important that the game flows without any cut-scenes with the only gaps being load times between areas. That is probably one of the most notable praises and for good reason, it succinctly keeps the immersive qualities of the game within a consistent state and thus allows the player to stay in a flow with the game and the elements that make it so great to begin with. Overall, the experience can be described as brilliantly potent and immersive.

The music also adds a lot to the overall atmosphere. For the most part, the game remains on ambience and an assortment of sound effects to fill the noise but sometimes the soundtrack kicks in and it's incredibly potent. Ranging from dark ambient soundscapes that envelope the world, as well as harder industrial and techno tracks for the more pumped up moments of combat. The whole OST fits the environment - hazardous and isolating atmosphere of Black Mesa.

Half Life is (in my opinion) one of the top 5 most important FPS ever. If Wolfenstein and Doom started the genre, Quake started to use real 3d and Call of Duty is the peak of multiplayer FPS, Half Life is the first FPS to create a deep lore and story. For a 1998 game, Valve made it solid enough to be enjoyable for years and decades.

Story is really good developed and well designed, enough to create one of the most beautiful lores in the videogame industry. Basically you play as Gordon Freeman, a scientist who, because an incident, has to escape from Black Mesa facility while fighting aliens to stop the invasion. 

Gameplay is really well made even for a game made 24 years ago. The HUD looks clean, with the weapon selection well chosen and good mechanics: refilling the HEV suit's shield, using a lantern (this was one of the things I didn't liked, but it's forgivable since it's one of the FPS pioneers and neither Wolfenstein/Doom, Quake or Duke Nukem had tried to include it), and the puzzles might be hard sometimes, but it's the fun of the game, I guess.

Graphics are not horrible. It might look really outdated even using the HD models, but I don't blame Valve. GoldSource was the peak of game engines in the 90's, but nowadays it might look clunky.

Story is really good (SPOILER ALERT). Gordon Freeman starts his job in Black Mesa facility trying to make a spectrometer, but it goes wrong and aliens invade the facility. Later, the US Army arrives and the scientists have hope that the soldiers will control the invasion, but the true reason the marines are there is to kill everyone in Black Mesa. Finally, Gordon finds a way to stop the aliens using a portal to Xen. Discretly, a suspicious man is watching Gordon around Black Mesa.

The game itself it's long for 8 to 10 hours long, although sometimes it can be much difficult because puzzles or moments when you have to think too much every action. 

If you love FPS, play Half Life. If you love videogames, play Half Life. If you want to play a good story, play Half Life. Definitely this game is a must-play if you are a gamer.

I played the PS2 version of Half-Life 1 a while ago, but I quit the game after a while after not really finding it fun. I bought the Valve Collection recently and playing this game again, its quite fun. There are quite a few differences but I want to state why this game feels so good to play.

The engine and the weapons play with each other really well. Just smacking head crabs with a crowbar feels fluid in some sort of way and running around shooting things is just plain fun.

I've not really been a big fan of N64 era graphics and the first steps into 3D but the game has some weird charm to it that I can look through. When characters talk though you can tell the game is dated.

The story is ehh.. alright. Its exciting and more action packed than most games but it's completely lacking compared to the other games in the series. In my opinion.

Overall, get it. Its still a fun game and there's so much replayability that you can see why its one of Valve's most prominent game series'. This title will probably be a 7/10, a good start for the series.

I felt the need to write this review almost immediately after completing Half-Life (which was a very enjoyable 2 days, which is about the same amount of time as has passed in the game itself, funnily enough), and I would like to say that in spite of being an over 20 year-old game, Half-Life holds up well and is worth playing, and I'm very pleasantly surprised  and impressed with it.

While the clearly dated graphics, interface as well as the somewhat bare feel of Half-Life's setting may be offputting and do show the age of the game, I believe it also gives it a distinct charm. I have a list of points on which I'd like to remark upon:

GAMEPLAY
Having already played several Source games, and having no experience with non-Source FPS games, I was excited to see how Half-Life really worked... which is rather good, actually (with some notable exceptions)! I very much like how your character moves noticeably faster than in the Source games, and it definitely makes the game more fast-paced. This, I believe, is similar to older games such as those from the Doom or Quake series, which came out somewhere around the same time (and the games are obviously related, and it's nice to get a feel for how games of that era played). Generally speaking, Half-Life is also very pleasant to control.

The shooting worked mostly well, although sometimes it's hard to tell whether or not you're hitting an enemy. The Hivehand weapon was especially confusing to use. I was also surprised to see the physics (such as the gibs from smashed boxes), which I wasn't even aware was possible back in 1998.

A significant problem was getting stuck on objects, and an even greater problem was the completely broken nature of pulling objects, done by pressing the USE key and moving backwards. This always sent the object careening away by what amounts to several metres to the left or right with teriffic speed, and I suspect that it's a bug.

SOUND
The sound design, apart from the mostly very poor quality, adds to the gritty yet incidentally humorous and exaggerated atmosphere along with the flawless soundtrack, a great portion of which you will recognise from Half-Life 2. During my very first time playing I found myself walking continuously back and forth on the metal grates of the training course, then stopping and absorbing it along with the look of the map, as it turned to total silence... strangely amazing feeling.

Hearing complete and utter silence only interrupted by footsteps I also found quite fascinating, for some reason. This atmosphere of outdatedness and simplicity, even desolation, is something I can appreciate. With regards to the soundtrack, I especially enjoyed hearing "Drums and Riffs" during the rocket scene (I'm of course being vague to avoid spoiling it completely, but hey, this game is literally decades old), which had a particularly defiant and bold feel to it, so to say.

One genuine complaint one could make is the lack of consistency with the general sound quality, as well as the overuse of "stingers", the socalled short, suspenseful pieces of music meant to highlight the dark nature of a certain scene, also featured in Half-Life 2 (I believe I heard the same stinger at least 3 times). I also noticed that the music keeps going after you die or load a save file, which was quite awkward.

SETTING
By far one of Half-Life's biggest strengths is its setting and atmosphere. With tons of intriguing and wildly different maps, Half-Life is full of variety. The Black Mesa Research Facility, with its incomprehensible size, gives off a feeling of openness, and not once did the world feel boxy, claustrophobic or awkward. It felt very natural, with virtually no invisible walls to speak of. I enjoy the setting being in a barren canyon-type environment, conveying the sense that you're somewhere important to be held secret. Getting to explore it further and journeying down the deadly cliffs was also fantastic. I think it's a great setting for a secret lab, and a game in general because of the lack of anything important aside from ourselves and the characters and action immediately before us.
It does hurt the setting that the quality of the skyboxes is so extremely low.

The main setting also contrasts very well with the chaotic and macabre Xen. Overall, I think the environments and the game itself is very memorable and unique in terms of design.
The setting in the final scene is also a great callback to the beginning, in several ways, and its bizarre nature adds up to a great ending.

STORY
I appreciate the kind of story that poses questions and unsolved mysteries, and especially stories that don't need a backstory or long-winded introductory cutscene, but instead throws you right into it. Again, the datedness and simplicity of Half-Life works in favour of the game here. It's a very subtle way of introducting the player to the world of the game, and it's a recurring theme with a lot of Valve's games, especially the first Portal game, where it's done masterfully. In Half-Life, you get to piece the story together yourself without any metanarrative interruptions. It makes you feel like you're really there, in a way. Simplicity is the key here. Half-Life shows and basically never tells, which is what makes the universe of the game so captivating.

Half-Life can tell a story with a lot of mystique using very little, and the best example of this is the G-Man and his supposed associates. I would say that his puppetmaster-esque role and the power dynamic it poses is maybe the most interesting thing about the Half-Life universe. It also makes us ask even more questions about who your character, Gordon Freeman, actually is, considering his interactions with the G-Man.

OVERALL
As someone who originally played Half-Life 2 about 8 years ago, I'm glad to have played Half-Life 1. I look forward to play the extra levels from Opposing Force and Blue Shift next, and I'm very happy to have gotten all of these on sale! Half-Life is very much worth experiencing in spite of its age and I completely understand why it has had such an impact. It's been a pleasure to experience such a big part of video game/software history and I strongly recommend it.

Half life is a old classic that fundamentally changed the world of FPS games. I decided to see if it has been improved over the year. Indeed some of the very nasty bugs that caused games to crash or stopped your progress have been taken care of. In the very early versions that was a huge problem. Also the textures have been updated so it's more consistent. I did found some glitches that are probably related to the original game engine. Mostly they are graphical bugs but there are also some where you can glitch out and take no damage from enemies or even big bosses. How exactly to achieve this I shall leave for everyone else to discover. Over all it is fun to play and relive the memories.

Half Life. What is there to say about such an influential game? This game - although not as important as Doom was for FPS games (in my opinion) - changed how we see and play the games of today.

As we all know by now, thanks to the opening sequence alone games today have a story to tell you with the environment around them and with cut scenes... But I don‚Äôt believe anything has been done as well as Half Life and its opening sequence. These days we have unskippable cut scenes giving you a complete dumb of information, at times being too much to handle for someone who just started the game but Half Life lets you discover the story for yourself, the opening shows you a LOT of what‚Äôs happening in Black Mesa but without completely overloading is with everything going on - it is really a teaser for what‚Äôs to come. Again, nothing like this (as far as I remember) has been done after Half Life - sure they changed the format of games, but as I said, they dump info instead of letting you the player figure it all out.

The game is a little rough around the edges, this is a game of its time still, although the story and the environment is fun to play around with the AI can be a bit messy. Although the AI can be smart and look for alternative methods to take you down, they‚Äôre still very predictable and at times can break - for example, the G-Man later on in the game glitched out for me and wouldn‚Äôt move even when I was right next to him, it did break my immersion but these moments are far and few in-between.

The character interaction must be a highlight these days, again I may be remembering wrong but there aren‚Äôt many or any games where you can interact with almost every character. Even after the shit hits the fan, the leftover scientists and guards react to the current situation and talk to each other - a limited number of dialogue can be heard but again, that‚Äôs a lot more than what we get for today‚Äôs games.

And the ending, oh my god the ending, although not as impressive to look at now, the introduction and explanation of why there was a blue-suited man following you around Black Mesa is amazing and a great way to end this weird adventure.

Based on the information provided, can you guess what game this review is for? What's it about? What kind of game is it?

Point is, these reviews are completely interchangeable. I bet if you took this exact review, and copy and pasted it to every game in your library, you'd get the top review for half of the games you put it on, even if you didn't change the check marks to fit each individual game.

In my opinion, the Steam community should stop encouraging this format and instead downvote them all into oblivion. Maybe it's just me, and I guess it's not THAT big a deal, but for someone that puts at least some effort into the reviews they write, it is a little disheartening that the steam community prefers lazy checklists that ultimately don't say anything specific about the games in question. Plus I don't see how they could ever actually influence someone's decision to purchase a game or not when so little information is given.

Anyone agree or am I the only one that wants to read legitimately helpful reviews for games I might be interested in?

A lot to do and relatively entertaining. The puzzles are great and the action feels just right. The only problem is that the management between health, armor, and ammo can become very tedious. So much so, that I had to quick save and load every 5 seconds when I took the slightest bit of damage just so I could feel confident through the next area. It also did not help that Vortigaunts spawn behind you as you are clearing the playing field in front of you and instantly hit you with their unavoidable hit-scan electric attack which removes a good bit of armor and drains your health. Other than that, it was pretty fun for 13 hours worth of content. Playing this game requires a lot of knowledge about video games in general. If you do not know much about the language of video games, it will force you to learn through trial and error. It teaches you a lot of valuable skills that can be transferred over to a lot of other games.

This game has aged poorly, Firstly the control is floaty and freeman bounces off objects way too frequently too ever have any precise movement especially on narrow ledges. Secondly the ladders are garbage there's no real way to tell if you have actually grabbed the ladder until you move which then 2 things will happen you die from falling or take a retarded amount of damage falling or you actually climb the ladder. Third is the weapon roster which 99% are useless once you have the magnum (damage) and MP5/M4 (workhorse) other than those the weapons get out classed by these 2 or are just gimmick weapons that will only get you killed. Lastly the game has really nice set pieces but that's really all it has Half-Life now today has no substance the enemies are sponges the game has terrible pacing and the roster of enemies is VERY small, Once you hit Surface Tension you've pretty much seen all the game has to offer, because after that is the sections leading up to what EVERY half-life fan says is the worst part of the game "ZEN". I know that half-life pioneered set pieces and storytelling in games, but there are other games that have done the same AND kept the game pacing and story engaging. Pick it up if its on sale but I don't see why this is STILL heralded as TOP PC gaming.

I wasn't born when Half-Life came out. I didn't experience the hype surrounding this game or how it changed the industry but two weeks ago I decided that it was time for me to play this legendary masterpiece.
And... yes I can DEFINITELY see why this was such a big deal. And for the first five hours of my playthrough I really had a lot of fun. So yeah, I think that this game deserves the hype and yes it is one of the most important game ever made. It's weird because I love this game. I love what this game has done to the gaming industry. But at the same time I think that the mechanics have aged very well. The story is still really good(I googled it:)) but the mechanics aren't. I was expecting that. I mean if the mechanics of an over 20 year old game would still hold up today there would be something seriously wrong with the modern standards for games. Because of this I don't blame this game for not holding up. In a lot of ways it's still great. The weapon and enemy variety is still great but the gunplay and the movement, oh god the movement, have aged very poorly. It's sad because these two are the things the ruin the whole experience. Everything else is still fine. Even the graphics are not too bad.
So in conclusion: I don't think that you should buy Half-Life in 2021. I've heard that the remake Black Mesa ist very good, so go play that game while still appreciating what this game has done for games.

Going back to a 1998 game can be challenging. There‚Äôs no eye candy in Half-Life, but it has something most modern titles lack. Valve‚Äôs original hit has passion and original intent.
Half-Life is a first-person shooter that thinks outside the box. It mixes science fiction components with spine chiller and endurance awfulness for an entrancing tale about a puppet believing in his own freedom. 

You play as an experimental scientist, Gordon Freeman. The situation is the puzzling, underground Black Mesa research center. Furthermore, the story is about you, getting away from the office, when crap hits the fan. 
Under New Mexico's desert, Black Mesa is overseeing research with problematic morals. You're not a huge piece of it, however; you're simply a traveler. 
The game begins with Gordon Freeman awakening on a train cart. The truck traversed the lab while foreboding music swirls all around. Voices from the speakers invite you to the exploration offices, which you get to see for around five minutes. 
This fantastic arrangement then, at that point, inclines when Gordon Freeman takes part in a risky trial. An "mishap" opens up an entry to a different universe, permitting outsiders to slither into Black Mesa. 
You, as Gordon Freeman, must escape to the surface.
The brilliance of Half-Life is its ongoing interaction, and I can't discuss the interactivity without further growing the story. Both go in hand with each other. 
The game occurs during 18 episode, each bringing new interactivity mechanics, riddles, weapons, and difficulties. 
There will never be a dull for a second or a monotonous fragment. The interactivity continues developing and hopping between elements of horror, science fiction, and all out action. 
The game's visuals, albeit obsolete, were progressive when. It runs on the GoldSRC engine. Two or three years after its introduction, it developed into Source, which runs every one of Valve's games until 2013's DOTA. That incorporates several Counter Strikes games, the Left 4 Dead establishment, Portal 2, Team Fortress, Team Fortress 2, and so forth

There is no need for reviews for this game, you will always find someone talking about half life. Moreover counter strike games are just developed mods for this game, such is its greatness.

You have to let this person do it. Valve Software is a startup, a relatively unknown company with no trail and no real business to make such a powerful game. But it's powerful and the best single player shooter I've ever played. For some people -- especially those who haven't played the game -- it's hard to pinpoint exactly what everyone's talking about. There's nothing special about the engine - it's a heavily modified version of Quake by Id Software. Its genre, first-person shooters, almost got beaten to death. Its design couldn't be simpler: grab a gun, run, shoot, jump; there's no tedious cutscenes or dislocated RPG elements here. The weapons aren't spectacular either, just your usual assortment of realistic modern guns and some alien gadgets with some new twists. The creatures are fairly standard in a way, and many of the levels have been done before. Personally, no particular element of Half-Life stands out more than others, and nothing makes or breaks the game.

Gets even worse when they bind literally every weapon to exist in game to keys and then spam these in absolutely idiotic patterns like shotgun - RPG - MP nade within few ms.
Percentage of people using weapons that actually require some kind of skills like prediction, trajectory calculation, or just really good aim (examples include handgrenades, hivehand (secondary attack), satchels (no spam + blocking + camping), snarks (no brainless spam as well), RPG without laser) is close to zero. So, shortly: if you're looking for healthy strategic competition that doesn't consist of flat gauss - crossbow - shotgun pattern while all the most sweet features are rarely ever exploited, you won't find it here. Move along.

This game is amazing. Literal masterpiece, a must play for anybody out there. I wouldn't be afraid to say that this is probably one of my favorite games EVER. And here's why you should buy this game.

1. The Story. While playing the game I fell in love with the story, the characters, and the lore in general. The story is probably the most important part of this game. The mysteries, lore, characters, and story really make this game stand out from others.

2. The Combat. What else can I say, the combat in this game is very smooth and satisfying, The guns in this game feel loud and powerful to shoot, and give the player a sense of power while in combat.

3. Level Design. While it can be bad sometimes, for the most part the level design in this game is excellent. You can tell the developers put a lot of time into setting the mood for every area in the level. Which transitions to my next point:

4. The Atmosphere. This game's atmosphere is great. The developers definitely put in a lot of time perfecting the lighting and environment for every area in this game. 

Now there are a couple things wrong with this game, it's not perfect by ANY means.

1. Level Design. I know I just praised this game's level design but sometimes it really sucks. Like in chapters such as 'On a Rail' and especially the last 4 chapters, 'Xen', 'Gonarch's Lair', 'Interloper', and 'Nihilanth' being definitely the WORST part of the game.

2.Graphics. I know this game was made in 1998 but the graphics don't hold up well. If you wan't better graphics, check out 'Black Mesa' on Steam. Other than that, the game comes with HD models from one of the games two expansion packs, "Half-Life: Blue Shift". Apart from the HD models looking ugly, they just don't fit the game's style well. There is one way to remove them, which is by going into your game files and deleting the "valvehd" folder.

Half-Life is a great game, and just because there are some things wrong with it doesn't mean you should not buy this. Like I said, this is a must play and one of my favorite games ever. 
I give Half-Life a solid 9.5/10.

[b]Introduction to Half-Life[/b]
Half-Life is about a scientist named Gordon Freeman who has to survive aliens and military soldiers after an experiment goes horribly wrong, transporting various types of aliens to several facilities that Gordon will visit during the course of the game. This is the general, simplified plot of Half-Life.
The story for this game isn't told in traditional cutscenes, instead being presented through NPC dialogue and part of the gameplay as well. The story in general is interesting and stays solid throughout the campaign.

[b]Half-Life's Gameplay and Features[/b]
The gameplay is definitely the best part of this game though. The gun animations are solid, each weapon feels right, and they are mostly balanced. Though I have to say, the magnum and crossbow are some of the more OP weapons. Each type of enemy AI is easy to learn and can be taken out with almost any weapon Gordon has on him, but certain enemies later in the game can get a little annoying to deal with at times. 
Gordon can also encounter scientists and security guards, both of which can follow him around as allies, but they aren't of much help, so most of the journey is done solo. Scientists aren't really good for much else than opening up a locked door or two. Security guards have the same ability as scientists and they can attack enemies for you, but they only have a pistol. Gordon's allies aren't very durable either, so don't expect them to last long in a fight.

Aside from the gunfights, this game also has platforms to cross and puzzles to solve (Platforming in an FPS of all games, sounds crazy doesn't it?) You don't see that in FPS games nowadays. Most of the platforming sections this game throws at you aren't all that bad and can be jumped easily, though there are some parts that will require some more precise movements. Puzzles are also fairly easy to solve, but there was a couple that stumped me for a good while. While they were unexpected, the platforming and puzzle sections in this game give Half-Life a unique sense of identity, making it more unique than other games in the genre.

[b]The length of the original Half-Life[/b]
One playthrough of Half-Life's singleplayer campaign will take an average of 12 hours to complete. It's shorter than most games out there, but honestly, I thought the campaign had a decent length. Not too short to leave me unsatisfied, but also not too long to feel dragged out. 
There are mods for this game that can extend the playtime for those who want more out of a game over 2 decades old. Regardless of Half-Life's age, you can't go wrong with that enticing $10.00 price tag.

[b]Rating: A Half-Life worth experiencing.[/b]
To sum up, Half-Life is an innovative FPS with platforming and puzzle sections included. The story is compelling, and the gameplay is without a doubt, the best part of what this game has to offer. 
This game is a must buy for anyone with a Steam account. If you don't already have it, I strongly recommend you do get it in order to experience a classic that builds a fascinating world which is expanded upon in the sequel and Half-Life expansions: Opposing Force and Blue Shift.

Would I recommend Half-Life? Does a bear shit on the pope? The answer to both of these questions is: You bet your big ass. I was a wee boy when this and Rob Halford came out. Heck, I don't think I'd heard of it until first playing it in 2006. I loved it then and still do, having just beaten it, and this game too, in 2021 as of typing this. You play as Morgan Freeman, a silent scientist dude entering a research facility, where shit quickly hits the fan and aliens invade the place. You know how it is.

Armed at first with the iconic crowbar, you must escape, along the way fighting these aliens, and marines also jumping in to hunt you down. It reminds me of Rambo, in that you're a one-man army blasting your way through all these blokes with their machine guns and grenades and helicopters and whatnot. There's a nice selection of standard weapons for you to pick up. The explosives are my favourite. They blow things to bits. And then there's a few alien weapons.

Where it really shines is with it's immersive feel, using a seamless narrative viewed entirely by the player's point of view, and scripted events, all of which were revolutionary for the time and have inspired countless games that have also used these features. Here's looking at you, Call of Duty. Exploring teeny areas like vents and tunnels and solving puzzles is pretty satisfying too. Although the infamous Headcrabs (crawling vaginas with teeth and claws) tend to hide round corners in those dinky places and jump at you. They're bitches. And quite scary at times. Especially when they're latched onto a now-zombified scientist, coming after your ass.

Graphics and special effects have of course come on leaps and bounds in the last 23 years, but these were bum good for back then, and not too distractingly bad to look at now. At least not for me. I'm not down with the kids and their 4Ks and their 60fps thingymajiggies. There aren't many character models in it though, and you'll see the same Chris-Whitty-and-Albert-Einstein looking-ass scientists throughout.

The last section, where you exit the facility and teleport to the alien world of Xen (spoiler alert) is probably the weakest and disjointed part, with awkward death defying platforming (I died A LOT. Thank G-man for autosave) and a boss called Gonarch, who is a giant crab thing with a massive ballsack and shoots cum at you. Anyway, I haven't played the finally-finished fan remake Black Mesa yet, but if it goes on sale you can bet your Big Billy Bass (that's Louisiana slang for Ass, probably) I will get it.

Quite honestly, this was one of the most enjoyable experiences that I've had with a video game. I'm new to gaming, and being stubborn and an overachiever at times, I decided that beginning this game on hard difficulty was the way to go. That was a regrettable decision. Nevertheless, the game was still immensely fun. 

The story itself is not particularly deep, but the seemingly deliberate ambiguity of the plot left me thinking. With regards to the gameplay, I have no major complaints; in fact, the only objections I might have are sticking in place while turning valves in-game (which is rather sad for the "Valve" game development company) and having trouble climbing ladders, but otherwise I never had a bug. The graphics are not top-of-the-line, of course, but that said, the environment still feels real and immersive; the lighting in this game is particularly good. All in all, I'd happily recommend this game to whoever wants to start gaming with the classics: it's fun, fast, and still pulls its weight after twenty three years. Good job, Valve! I look forward to trying your sequel.

Being a relative noob to PC, I just finished my first playthrough of Half-Life. I usually play on medium difficulty but even so this classic proved challenging especially in Xen. The aforementioned problems with the game don't take away too much from the game other than being frustrating on occasion, but usually rather add a little charm to let you know that this is a pretty old game. I thought that the story was enjoyable and did a great job of environmental and spoken storytelling. The weapon and enemy variation ensured that there was never a dull moment. The puzzles were generally fun and the overall gameplay had enough variation throughout the different levels that kept things fresh. The soundtrack provided a brilliant atmosphere when trying to make the air uneasy or make the action intense. In conclusion, I think that the fact that most components of this game still stand the test of time is reason enough to give it a playthrough for its low price.

Half-Life is an amazing title in many ways. Not only has it been influential to gaming as a whole but it made developers and players rethink how stories in that kind of media could be told. Half-Life plays into gaming's biggest strength, being interactive. Everything experienced in the game is first hand, it doesn't make you feel like your playing as someone, it makes you feel like you are that someone. Gordon Freeman is silent allowing for the player to think on their own and discover the story for themselves as it pieces together. It makes this game immersive in a way that even in present day, I hadn't experienced before. Every bit and piece of the story is seen and experienced by you first hand, no third person dialogue, or even cutscenes. This game tells a compelling story of a scientist who's experiment has gone terribly wrong and is now just trying to escape Black Mesa Research Facility with his life. The story is full of mysteriousness and twists and it's something that any gamer must play at least once in their life. The gunplay is extremely fun and holds up still today even when compared to modern day shooters. It amazes me how I became so attached to a silent protagonist but yet I did,  and after I finished the game I was ready to start it all over again. Half-Life spawned many games like Counter Strike and for that I am very thankful, as Counter Strike is one of my favorite games. The multiplayer in this game as well is so much fun, especially with some friends. It is replayable and addicting and I would definitely recommend it. The only real fault in this game for me is the final stage on the alien homeworld Xen. This stage felt rushed and lacked content. I really wish they had put just a little more effort into Xen, as that would just be the cherry on top. Other than that however, Half-Life in my opinion is one of the greatest gaming masterpieces of all time. I give it a 9.5/10

Half-Life came out in 1998, and yet its still one of the most entertaining and original games around, with new mods coming out every day.

There's just something so un-quantifiably nostalgic and beautiful about the dingy corridors of Office Complex. 

I would credit this game for my appreciation of all things Wabi-sabi, being able to explore abandoned buildings and find beauty in the schadenfreude of urban decay.

I also credit this game to getting me into the mod scene, hammer editor taught me the basics of level design.

All said, Half-Life is a large part of the person I am now, and has stained the glasses I use to view the games industry.

I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone who has a computer and a few bucks to spare.

Really good game. I never really played a lot of story FPS titles but this was a pretty sweet experience. I look forward to playing more titles from this series in the future, especially seeing how (I imagine rightfully) beloved it is. The gameplay is quick-paced and keeps you on your toes a lot of the time (hallways collapsing, enemies spawning right in front of you to try and shoot you down) and incorporates another thing I really like in video games: parkour (and also didn't make it hell ;w;). If you like fighting human soldiers, aliens AND zombies, guess what? This game has all of those out to get you. Not only that, but the friendly NPCs make the levels feel a lot less lonely, and help you out when you're in a pinch. In terms of sound design, most if not all sound clips in this game convey something clearly -- explosions sound like explosions, a scientist screaming means there must be some kind of level hazard or enemy ahead, etc. Visual design is also, while mutually outdated, pretty damn good for a game that came out only a year after Sonic R. The people look like people, and the aliens look like aliens. Soldiers look like soldiers, and aren't easily confused with Black Mesa's guards. All in all, I give it a solid 10/10 especially because the manual save system can make up for so much pain.

TL;DR - Overall, I like this game. I really, really, really hate most of it, but I do recommend it. I think absolutely EVERYONE should play this game at some point in their "gaming career."

I want to start by saying that I'm sorry. I'm sorry that after 10 hours of slogging my way through this game, although I DO recommend it, I can't say I enjoyed myself.

Most of my issues with the game stem from the fact that it feels like Gordon is TRYING to get himself killed. What's that? You fell 10 feet? That's 15 health, down the drain. Did you step in a puddle of radioactive goop that you couldn't avoid, no matter how hard you tried? Sorry, that's 10 health that you've just lost. There are far too many instances where it feels like you're forced to take damage, and it only makes the experience more frustrating as a result. There's slippery terrain, radioactive puddles, lightning shooting out of the walls, pipes spewing hot gas at you, and giant green claw-things that are a nightmare to get around. For how strange and slippery Gordon's movement is, there sure are a LOT of instances of movement being needed to progress. Jumping segments, walking across tight pathways that are way too easy to fall off of, trying to jump across a gap but falling into it instead, falling into water and other dangerous liquids, etc.

Controls aside, I didn't enjoy the combat that much either. Shooting the enemies, namely the soldiers, feels actually pretty great, but they'll almost always gun you down before you can even fire off ten bullets, unless you're willing to sacrifice a third of your health while you shoot them. The headcrabs are hard to hit, the snipers and sheltered turret-soldiers CANNOT be killed unless you have explosives, the tanks vary from imposing to laughable, the minefield segments make me want to break my hand, and overall there are just so many instances of having to save preemptively, before proceeding to die 20 times before taking out every enemy and saving again not even a minute later.

However, although I did not enjoy most of this game, I do think it is great for what Valve had at the time. The most fun I had with the game was listening to the goofy voice acting and watching the unique animations for particular points in the game. I have heard about Half Life for so, so long now, and I can say that I am glad to have played it, not only to see what the hype was about, but also to add it to my library of "gaming knowledge."

So many modern video game tropes and gameplay features can be attributed to this absolutely fantastic and influential title which is more than worthy of its title as the greatest first person shooter of all time. So much of the video game industry was possible because of the breakthrough innovations made by this game. For god's sake, this game practically invented storytelling in a video game! I would say I am largely a Half-Life novice as I never played any of the games close to when they came out and I have spent the better part of COVID trying out some of these games to a lot of surprise and joy while questioning how it took me so long to play it.

I totally understand why Half-Life is so revered and I am glad I was able to experience it without knowing much about it beforehand. If you are on the fence, you definitely won't regret playing this game and it is actually really cool to see the groundwork for where so many Valve properties started.

(For context, this was my first playthrough of the game, and also one of the first games I've ever played using keyboard and mouse).

Half Life was released in 1999(?) and it definitely shows. The graphics are quite archaic, but remain serviceable nonetheless. The gameplay was the most interesting part for me personally, because it was far more strategic than what I'm used to. While this game is still viewed as one of the defining titles of the FPS genre, I think Its affect on the industry has lessened over time. Not many games uphold this tactical type of gameplay, which does suck, but helps prolong the seldom seen uniqueness of it. I struggled with this game and its many quirks a multitude of times over my entire playthrough because not only does it utilize such a rare form of gameplay (as I mentioned before), I also have not gotten used to keyboard and mouse controls. So this game slowly became a learning experience for me, and that is quite endearing. I'm absolutely more in touch with this control scheme than I was beforehand, and I will always have this game to thank for that.

Honestly, the story is told rather cryptically and any plot elements are either vague, or non-existent. exposition is also rather sparse, which I did appreciate . . . for the most part. I went into this game knowing nothing except Gordon Freeman, G-man, Headcrab, and weird baby I didn't have any context for. I left knowing pretty much the same stuff as before, along with a few smaller details such as Xen, and Black Mesa. I do hope the sequel has a better knack for storytelling than this one (from what I've heard, it does), because this just didn't do it for me.

The design and atmosphere was VERY well done. I was blindsided  by the sudden alien race quickly consuming everything, and I had not anticipated how horror focused some of the chapters are. the earlier chapters were more centered on the grotesque question of "What is happening?", with the latter half forming into disturbing wonder at the answer. but it manages to uphold the sci-fi horror tone the whole way through, and I was a big fan of it.

Overall, the game has without a doubt been hampered by the sands of time and the marching forward of its industry, but it still is very much worth playing, and I for one am glad I chose to do so.

Half-life is what started it for me. Yeah, sure, I could say Doom is what started PC gaming for me (and of course you can't forget Quake, Wolfenstein, Redneck rampage, etc) but Half-Life is what locked me firmly in place.

I still think of the times back then when I used to wake up at 6am on a Saturday to play some Half-Life and Starcraft and watch Pokemon. That feeling is something that I can't replicate today. Perhaps its nostalgia but that carefree feeling of being a kid and enjoying such an insane game is one of my fondest memories of growing up.

Not only was the single player insane to my ten year old mind back then but the countless mods that spawned because of this game and the fun times I had.. Some that immediately come to mind:

Pirates, Vikings and Knights
Vampire Slayer
Battlegrounds
The Specialists
Brainbread

The list is long and goes on and on. Yeah yeah, don't worry. I didn't forget about CS. That's reserved for it's own review. I still have floppy disks filled with updates, skin packs and bots that I downloaded from csnation. Any of you remember counter-crap? RzE? Rizzuh? Lungfish? The infamous [myg0t] cheating clan that'd you'd occasionally run into? :P

I recently cycled through some of the older games like Deathmatch Classic, Team Fortress and Day of Defeat. I was pleasantly surprised to see people still playing them. It just goes to show you that Half-Life and any of its mods will continue to stand the test of time.

Its a classic for a reason!
The Story follows Gordon Freeman, a scientist from the Black Mesa Facility who becomes a part of a science experiment that goes wrong and must try and survive the Aliens that have invaded Earth. The characters in this game are used to move the story along while having their own unique, funny moments. The inclusion and mystery of G-man was very well placed has has immediately become my favourite character in the game. As for the story, its simplistic but effective and the game never breaks away from it throughout its play time. As mentioned before, the mystery of G man and that whole scene that it takes place in gives Half-life more intrigue and leaves players with a greater impression. 
The setting of the Black Mesa Facility and Xen are really well thought out and fully detailed, making the player want to explore everything in front of them, however sometimes i did find myself lost at some points when trying to move to the next area. 
Graphically, even though it may have been the the best for its time, its retro style really gives it a classic feel and is just satisfying to look at. While there is an option for there to be HD textures and reworks of some skins, i would have it in its original state for anyone wanting to get the full experience. 
Sound and Audio are a mixed bag as there will be weird moments for the soundtrack to kick in and kinda takes away from the experience, however the audio choices for the guns, aliens and voice acting in general work really well here, adding that immersion for players to sink themselves into. 
In terms of gameplay, this is some solid, satisfying FPS action that loads can enjoy. You will be mainly be fighting off the aliens which i must say the variety of them is so vast, its impressive for a game like this. There are also human enemies that can pose their own challenge and is a great selection for the player to combat against. The weapon variety as well is amazing ranging from pistols to machine guns to the Tau Cannon which is really fun to use and gives players that freedom to overcome the obstacles that they face. There is also the H.E.V suit that can be charged up to give Gordon more armour against enemy attacks or protecting him from toxic waste which was a nice inclusion. The only problem i really faced was moving into a different area could cause Freeman to clip into the wall and makes the player unable to move, meaning that they would have to restart their game, however due to this being as old as it is, this issue can be put to the side. 
Overall, Half-Life is an amazing experience and fully deserves the cult following that it gained and i would recommend this to anyone who really wants to play a fun first person shooter!

Half-Life... Where do I start with this game?

Half-Life 1 was the first game in the series I got my hands on, and my favorite. Guess I'll start off with the obvious.

1. The Approach: Half-Life was unique to FPS games like DooM, Quake, and the Build Engine trilogy at the time. It took time at the start of its campaign to build the characters and the feel of Black Mesa. 
Taking two chapters (Black Mesa Inbound and Anomalous Materials.) To focus on character development, and getting the player into the world that Valve had set up for them. Like watching scientists in the distance run around, getting their work done in the iconic train ride.

2. The Gameplay: Valve wanted the player to feel like they were trapped in a scenario they couldn't control. Like they were just some guy who was in the wrong place at the wrong time. Hence why the first Headcrab you encounter is so early you don't even have the Crowbar yet.
Ahh, the Crowbar, the only melee weapon you get throughout Gordon's entire adventure through Black Mesa. This was to enhance that feeling of 'Shit's hit the fan, time to get outta here.'
Moreover, the player's health caps at 100, no higher, no lower. Again, you're not a super-soldier, just a scientist trying to survive.
And most notably at the time. Fall Damage and Reloading. Quake went full 3D. Half-Life went full realism. Reloading was such a novelty at the time, I can think of one other game that had reloading for all of its guns. Marathon.
Fall damage was also a rare thing. The Build Engine had it, but it was negligible. In Half Life, a full 3D game unlike the Build Trilogy, had fall damage make its presence known. Take Blast Pit for example. The map's mostly vertical, and you can't jump from the top floor to the bottom without tanking some large damage. Or right after that chapter in Power Up. There's a pipe before meeting the Gargantuan that can't be lived through on low health, unless the player lands on the table with the medkits.

3. The Story: You should know it by now. You are Gordon Freeman, a Theoretical Physicist working for Black Mesa. A top secret research facility in the middle of the desert in New Mexico.
One fateful day, after being late for work, Gordon begins the usual experiment using an Anti-Mass Spectrometer and a crystal specimen from Xen, the border world. But things go wrong, causing a Resonance Cascade, ripping open a portal to Xen, allowing alien creatures to spill through.
Gordon survives the Cascade itself and fights his way through the facility. Going toe to toe with both the Xen forces, and the HECU, a highly trained group of soldiers sent to kill everyone to cover up Black Mesa's existence.
Gordon finally reaches the Lambda labs, and is sent to Xen by the surviving members of the Science Team there, and slays the Nihlanth, the being holding the portal between Xen and Earth open.
Afterwards, he has an encounter with the G-Man. Whom he had been seeing since his train ride to work when this whole mess started.
Being sent to a recreation of said train. The G-Man offers Gordon a job under his employers. Gordon accepts and is sent into stasis until the events of the second game.
This approach at story through the eyes of someone in the middle of the event was something the gaming idustry had never seen before. Usually it was reading the game's manual, or through on-screen text that lore was presented.
But Valve changed that, and made the game that would shape the way FPS games were done to this very day.

That was a wall of text, but long story short, Buy Half-Life if you haven't already. It's a great game, Immersive and fun, a great experience overall. It has its negatives, (what game doesn't?) But those negatives are outweighed by the positives. Now, "Have a safe, and productive day."

Here, let's make an actual review for this thing instead of just saying "it's good".

Half-Life is a short, yet extremely sweet game I could, no, I have played over and over again and still have fun. 
The combat in this game is extremely fun - weapons all feel good and there's some pretty unique ones. Firing the mp5 in this game is better than an orgasm (well, at least if you're not using the HD pack.). There's not really any peashooters in this game, and a few weapons have fun alt-fires that increase combat strategy. I suppose the amount of weapons could be overwhelming late-game, but that doesn't apply to many of people.

Movement is always fast paced and feels good to this day, but this isn't just a run&gun. If you don't think out where you're going, you can get screwed quick - unlike what was seen in previous games, for the most part.

The map design in Half-Life is very intuitive. Many chapters feel very intertwined almost like a zelda dungeon, and the setpieces for battles are for the most part, great. Specifically the chapter "Surface Tension" (slight spoilers, sorry), has many different unique battles and setpieces where you can make use of your pretty good sized arsenal at that point in the game.
Not all maps are perfect though, you might've heard of the chapter "On a Rail" being annoying. Which is true for most people, atleast the first time around. Once you understand it well, you won't be caught up in the confusing navigation and are able to enjoy each of the pretty damn fun fights. 

Music in Half-Life is incorporated into the gameplay extremely well, always keeping the horror sci-fi atmosphere, while always giving hope and peace at times as well. Some pieces in this are also extremely unique, specifically "Hazardous Environments", which of course went on to become the Valve theme. 

Half-Life set the standard of actually including a story in FPS games - but the game never spends too much time focused on that, prioritizing gameplay. And there's only a single cutscene in the middle of the game where you actually lose control of Gordon Freeman, and it's like 20 seconds long. It's awesome.
The graphics in this game look pretty damn good - for a 1998 game. I don't know if I'm really weird or something, but I still think the game on the proper settings looks nice. If you don't play old games because you can't stand old graphics, I can only tell you you're missing out [strike]and shallow[/strike]
For the best graphical experience possible in Half-Life 1, turn off HD models, use your native resolution (which should be 1920x1080p if you're normal), and set the fov to around 90-115 in the developer console using the "default_fov" command. (adjust to your preference, but going higher than 115 will result in screwing up viewmodels).
To give the game it's intended look in terms of lighting, type these into the dev console :
Brightness 0.5
Gamma 1.8

PvP in Half-Life can be fun every once in awhile, but It's very unbalanced and outshined by it's mods and the still very much alive sequels of these mods : Counter Strike, TF2, etc.

The replay value of Half-Life is pretty insane. My motivations for replaying are going faster, and dying the least (though there's a few parts that bug out and make that last one a pain). It remains fun pretty much every replay, and it's not like I'm some replay junkie. I need to wait months before playing the same Zelda game again.

A warning though, the final section of Half-Life and it's final boss are underwhelming and nothing special, though what comes after always is nice. 
The ending was rushed and very unpolished - but it can never change how amazing the rest of the game is. While it's arguable whether it's bad or not, as some parts can be interesting and fun, it was never a part I seemed to get to playing during my daily replays this summer. I won't "spoil" it I guess, but for reasons it's very easy to just associate the ending with something else and void it out of your picture of the game. But that's a minus for Half-Life, you shouldn't have to do that with a **perfect** game.

And finally, if you don't know if you should buy Half-Life over Black Mesa, or already have Black Mesa and are unsure if you want to play Half-Life, you most definitely should. Aside from being the original experience, many aspects of Half-Life are considered better than in Black Mesa by quite a few people, including myself. Specifically the HECU, which are a key component of Half-Life were made way less fun to fight in Black Mesa. 
But that's also just my opinion - I would recommend checking out this video if you want to hear more about it : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_eZASMjHxuA&t=657s

Anyways, I hope this helps <3

Nearly a decade and a half ago, I overheard my cousin talking something about shooting terrorists on a video game. That is the exact moment I got hooked on Half-Life because computers were already fascinating to me, let alone playing adrenaline inducing games (for the time at least half life was adrenaline inducing lol) I had a very hard time imagining how much entertaining it would be to engage in shootouts with terrorists in virtual world. That was the Half-Life demo, I think, where you constantly kill terrorists until you see G-Man watching you from on top of a scaffolding. Anyway, we were playing as if there was no other thing to do in this world. Recently, I got into it again and finished the storyline for the first time. It was entertaining and enlightening at the same time, because when you were playing the demo, you wouldn't know what the hell is going on; the game is just another hack/slash for you, not any different than DOOM. The story is, how can I say, legendary. A straight ten. At least from my perspective because I love the abandoned laboratory concept a lot. Being as objective as possible, you may see a lot of flaws but there are things that should be taken into consideration before becoming way too judgemental about it. First things first; the game is fucking 23 years old. This simple fact is enough to start praising this game. Anyway, my point is that when it's half-life; you don't take its age into consideration. It's like GTAV where the game is older than most industry-leading games nowadays but it doesn't stop it from being better than them in most of the aspects. To compare Cyberpunk 2077 and GTAV would suffice to support my take. Long story short, depending on when you play it, it's a life changing experience or a duty to play. Duty, because this is undoubtedly a classic. You should definitely play it if you haven't already. What are you waiting for?

Half-Life 1 is ancient, being the bedrock of countless design conventions that we take for granted today. Despite this, it's exceptionally fun to play, ESPECIALLY after playing a few more modern takes on the FPS/adventure hybrid that this series pioneered. The game never takes control away from you, most of its expository scenes can be skipped (as in, walked right past) for repeat playthroughs, and because this is still a shooter from the 90s and isn't concerned with presentation nearly as much as its successors, most of the development resources went into creating a game that feels really good to play, once you get the hang of it.  You move really fast, the guns (especially the MP5/M16) have a satisfying kick, and the AI is noticeably more intelligent than I'm used to. There are a few bangers in the music department, the voice work is effortlessly charming, and the quality of the game's pacing is legendary - it's hard to put down, and perfects the balance of action and quiet moments with satisfying platforming segments and the like. It's easy to run on practically any machine, it loads incredibly fast, and did I mention that it feels REALLY GOOD to play?

I should also add that I have no nostalgia factor going into this - I was playing console games throughout my childhood, long before I discovered the Half-Life series.. which is a true testament to the game's strengths, considering how visibly dated it looks. I love this game, and I think that it's better than Half-Life 2 in almost every department.

If you haven't tried it yet... well then, get to it!

[h1]Revolutionising the landscape doesn't suddenly make this game a masterpiece[/h1]

[b]Masterpiece:[/b] a work of outstanding artistry, skill, or workmanship.

Half-Life is not a masterpiece. It's not a bad game, however it is not particularly good either. Nostalgists won't hesitate to tell you that this game is what shaped the modern FPS landscape, as if that suddenly means we should ignore the shortcomings just because it did something different.

I started off this franchise by playing HL2, and I really want to try Black Mesa, but I decided I would have to play the original first for the full experience, and oh boy what a mistake. I have heard that Black Mesa is very faithful to the original, so apart from graphics I have a feeling it is going to annoy me just as much.

Let's talk about what this game did well:
[list]
[*]As a Half-Life game the world is engaging and it is easy to follow the story.
[*]Wide variety of weapons
[*]That's it... Nothing else really wowed me.
[/list]

Let's talk about what missed the mark:
[list]
[*]Infrequent auto saves. Maybe I am just so used to HL2, Halo, CoD, etc. but the auto saves seemed to set me back up to 10 mins of progress, which was beyond frustrating. One small mistake (jump, 1 hit kill enemy, or even put in a situation where my health is just too low for me to survive) is all it took and yet it would send you back so far to the point where it made seemingly simple things tedious.
[*]Trip mines are stupid it's easier to just headshot a soldier with a revolver than to try and strategically place these. Soldiers also seem to see through walls as they will be very aggressive if you suddenly don't have a gun in your hands, so they will charge you and you will lose health trying to switch back.
[*] Getting lost or really stupid paths. No this isn't a complaint about "On the rail" (albeit I do have complaints about that chapter). I have played HL2, and had no issue finding my way there, but I found myself getting lost over and over, I don't know if it is the dated graphics making the lack of detail cause everything to look similar or if the devs just didn't make it clearer where you were supposed to go. I frequently found myself consulting a YT walkthrough to find out where I am supposed to go.
[*]"On the rail" is an experience, but controlling that machine with the same controls you use to move was awful. I frequently ran into traps because I kept moving when i tried to slow down or I accidentally released control of the mechanism causing me to just walk off. The chapter is actually very linear, and yet I found that jumping off the machine and just walking made it redundant and 10x easier, so not sure why it existed in the first place, because jumping off and walking skips entire sections.
[*]The game doesn't even tell you the controls anywhere. I had to find out how to long jump using Google. Thankfully as I had played HL2 most of the other controls were easy to figure out, but someone new to the game would likely be very annoyed and frustrated to have to consult options every few seconds. Also why doesn't the weapon selection menu go away if you choose not to change weapon? You have to press M1 to make it go away, so this meant I might cycle through, change my mind and unlike HL2 it would stay there making me waste time switching back to the weapon I was using.
[*]The shotgun sucks even at point blank. I guess this is to balance the ridiculous amount of reserve ammo you get, but I found myself using the revolver and crossbow for 90% of the game (once acquired) because I could just kill everything in 1-2 hits (normal difficulty). Whenever I used the shotgun it just didn't pack a punch even at point blank, and even with the alt-fire. HL2 handled this gun much better.
[*]The Assassins are so unbalanced. You will kill them, but your HP will be so low by the end of it, that you will just die as soon as you hit the next section. It's so annoying to simultaneously handle an enemy that dodges so efficiently while also being very aggressive.
[/list]

Neutral Points:
[list]
[*]Graphics are okay, nothing that will blow your mind
[*]Enemy design is tolerable given the era. You have your basic monsters, zombies, soldiers and 1 hit hazards, I can imagine that because of how focused Valve were on world building that these enemies would be considered "meh" in that time period.
[/list]

[b][u]Overall:[/u][/b]
You got this in "The Valve Complete Pack" just like I did. Put this in your "hidden" list and forget it exists, just not worth the effort. Read a short synopsis if you care to know the details of what happened that badly.

Edit:
I forgot to mention my absolute top pet peeve, doors in this game require you to WALK INTO THEM, yes unlike any normal game you don't press the "use" key you just walk into them. This is such a small detail and yet it drastically affects so much.

I'm 22. About to be 23 in a few months. Here's my story.

When I was 14, I got struck down with depression. This led to me missing a lot of school in highschool and ultimately finishing 9th grade with a single credit.

I spent the rest of my teens trying to play catch up, finally receiving my high school diploma by age 19.

But when things seemed to be going well at 19, I was attacked and nearly raped. By the same relative who molested me my entire childhood. I became suicidal and was diagnosed with PTSD a year later.

At age 20, my mom died from cancer. She was a single parent and raised me all on her own since my deadbeat father left when I was 1.

I was now suffering from daily flashbacks due to my disorder.
Grieving the loss of the only parent I ever had.
And sobbing regularly thanks to the horrific things my father said to me while my mom lay dying in her hospital bed.

At 21, I dropped out of university.
I spent the rest of that year taking odd jobs at factories to pay my bills.

When I turned 22, I thought for sure it was my time to shine and begin living my life...

And then COVID happened.

I turn 23 on Dec 11.

I know I didn't waste my early 20s since I was suffering from so much traumatic ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in the span of a few years that others experience over a lifetime, some never at all.

But as I begin my 23rd year. I feel lost.
My PTSD has been in remission for over a year. And I've healed from the loss of my mother... but I'm struggling to shake the feeling that I lost so much time, and will always play catch up with others in the same life arena.

I don't really know why I wrote all this down, but I guess if there's any other lonely soul out there who happens to see my comment, I just want you to know that you got this.

We didn't choose our life circumstances.
We didn't ask for our lives to go off plan.

But we are alive
We're healthy
We've been blessed with another day

If you're the same age as me, our lives are only just beginning.
If you're older, you too can realize your dreams, escape the rigid safety found in your daily routine, and live the life you thought could never be possible.

If you still got a pulse, God still has a purpose.

If you're still hurting, talk to someone about it.

If you feel bored, get lost in a good book.

If you feel lost or confused, reconnect with that inner child and find time to spend doing the things you loved so much as a little one.

I hope to revisit this review in a few years, perhaps before my 20s are up so I can update how my life has gone since then. Til then...

The atmosphere, the story, the scripted scenes (no cutscenes!), the puzzles, and the level design were all incredible and truly stand the test of time.

These days, [i]Half-Life[/i] will most often be obtained through purchasing a bundle, so it may not be the game that people purchase to play. But regardless of how you acquire this game, it is absolutely a must-play!

One of the most iconic games of all time, and for good reason. Even to this day this game proves to be very fun and an overall enjoyable experience. Mechanics and concepts are well explained and many taught through situations instead of directly telling the player about them. There are some bugs (not as many as HL: Source, thank god), but this is to be expected running a 1998 game on modern machines. Graphics are very dated but this is only really noticeable at certain points and the controversial HD models for the weapons, items, and NPCs can be turned on at any point if you so desire (some prefer the HD models while others prefer the original ones, so my best recommendation is to try switching between the original and HD models to see which ones you like better). Overall, Half Life is one of the best games of all time and continues to be a fun experience for series veterans and new players alike.

Half Life is a good game.
 It is certainly imperfect, but it's more than decent. Sure, the visuals have aged like milk, and some puzzles were too confusing to my tiny brain, but it was good.
If you're looking at this thinking "should i buy this?" I'd say so. Personally, i got it for a sale (about 2 bucks i think), so even if i stopped playing, it wouldn't have been much of a loss.
Also, the Xen levels aren't as bad as people say. Sure, they aren't great, but they're not bad.

QUALITIES: 
- Although the graphics haven't aged well, the sets and maps are pretty decent. 
- It's a good length, although I like my games short.
- Some parts are a great adrenaline rush.
- The weapon loadout is varied and- honestly- really odd (in a good way)
- The scripted sequences and its way of storytelling was insane for its time, and it still holds up pretty well.
- Surface Tension is a great level, although it's a little long for my liking.
- The voice acting is ever so slightly stale, and it's amazing.
- Good morning Gordon

THE BAD PARTS:
- Some puzzles straight up don't tell you what to do, so you may need a walkthrough, especially for On a Rail and onwards.
- On a Rail is the worst level. It's tedious and long. Feels like watching paint dry.
- Speaking of- the first 6 or 8 hours i put into this game ended up being of no use when the save file for that level corrupted. Worst experience I have had in gaming.
- The boss fight at the end was complete ASS. Look up a walkthrough for this one. 
- A lot of parts are very tedious.
- (this one is for the arena shooter players) DO NOT GO IN GUNS BLAZING. THINK ABOUT WHAT TO DO BEFORE YOU DO IT AND SAVE YOUR GAME A LOT.

The pros JUST outweigh the cons. Go play it, you *probably* will not regret it. Then get the second one, cause that one's supposed to be a lot better. 
RATING: 7.4/10
COMPLETED IN: 13-15 hours.

I want to like this game. I adore Half-Life 2 and its episodes, I adore Half-Life Alyx... yet this game is simply not fun. Backtracking is frequent and torturous, chapters cannot be picked and you cannot change difficulty midway through the game, so when the difficulty ramps up it's easy to get softlocked dying in one area. The bugs are extremely common; floating headcrabs, getting stuck on geometry after loading into a level, AI simply stopping altogether... and the placement of the loading zones is ridiculous. They'll often be put in the most awkward areas near enemies, which leads to easily the most immersion breaking thing in this game; enemies despawning after loading zones are encountered. Not to mention there's a loading zone every minute, whereas in Half-Life 2 there's a loading zone every 15-30 minutes, and in Alyx there's one every 1-2 hours.
