[h1]Half-Life is a wonderful fps game with a rich story that does not rely on cutscenes but has the story unravel as the player progresses.[/h1]

[b]If I had one criticism for the game, that would be most of what you're doing in Half-Life is simply walking around, looking for a button to press or looking for a passage you haven't noticed before to go through. And it's not really exciting or fun most of the time.

No doubt about it, the game is immersive and tense, but it tends to depend the user experience a bit too much on the atmosphere and not enough on what the player has to do. I can't say the game goes stale because every new objective feels different, but when you get down to it, you are looking for a button, going back and pressing one final button to complete an objective every time. This would lead to me getting bored from playing the game quickly, and most of my sessions at most lasted 30 minutes.

The game is most enjoyable for me when I'm battling it out with enemies, especially the military, but I need to time my shots and take cover often, since my health goes down easily.

You have to understand this first: I do not play shooters. My combat skills are laughable at best and freakishly abysmal at worst. My ability to platform correctly is not much better. 

I played this on Easy mode and, as one can expect, it was exceedingly difficult for me. But this game's ability to make me feel things is unmatched. Even with the 1998 graphics, I really felt like I was Gordan Freeman, living through the events of the game, experiencing his fear, horror, frustration, and exasperation. 

My creative writing teacher, in my freshman year of high school, had one rule (besides "shut up and do your homework") and that rule was "Show, don't tell." Unlike many other games I've played, this game excels at executing that principle. There are no minimaps or destination markers. There are no questlogs or tutorials. There is only you and Black Mesa (and any friends looking over your shoulder saying "Oh no, don't do that!") Everything you do you must figure out yourself, and I love that. It makes the game feel more real than any graphics software can.

I should have hated this game, and there were times that I did. But I've sort of fallen in love with it as well, because it can tell a story beautifully. If you haven't played it by now, I highly recommend checking out this classic PC gaming gem for yourself.

After playing through Doom I and II, I decided to pick up Half-Life. I enjoyed a lot of the games story and how it all played out. I have a good portion of problems with the game but most of them just boil down to GoldSrc ageing poorly. There's a mod called Half-Life: Restored that basically restores cut content from the base game.

A couple things I have problems with is the AI, combat, and level design. The enemy AI is amazing. I love how well done the soldiers are. The Spec Ops can go suck my nuts though, those guys are annoying to kill. The team AI is the problem I have. They annoy the shit outta me. For example, lets say one of the guards are getting attacked, they just stand there and shoot at it. They don't even take cover just stand there right in the line of fire! Idiots! The combat gets really annoying at times. Freeman reloads way to slowly, like, sure Freeman, take your sweet time reloading that shotgun while you're being pelted with machine gun rounds! Taking cover doesn't always work and after mid game, just move around more. The level design gets really annoying late game. You get the long jump way too late in game. Xen is really linear and promotes no exploration at all. The last problem I have with the game is how vague the story is. I still don't understand what the hell a Resonance Cascade is. And whats up with G-Man? I know he's some inter-galactic being that can travel space and time and he's always watching the player (even in Opposing Force, Blue Shift and Decay), but he never really does anything except adjust his tie and talk to you at the end of the game. 

Over all, I give Half-Life a 7.2 out of 10. It's a really good game and I recommend you check it out. I had a lot of fun playing Half-Life and I hope you do too!

‚Ä£ Final notes: The very first and original Half-Life is a monument in video gaming. Everyone who has ever played this game will probably praise it. And I do agree that this game is legendary and has to be played at least once, however I think some of the gameplay things you have to do have aged poorly. For example movement and platforming can be frustrating and some level layouts can be tricky to maneuver. But the story telling is great and honestly everything that happens in this game is memorable. Combat encounters still seem enjoyable and the graphics even though clearly horrible still have that nostalgic charm. Overall I had good and bad moments with this game, but I still think the good massively outshines the bad.

As much as this game is a piece of history for the shooter genre as a whole it is extremely dated and doesn't feel great to play in my opinion. I'm going to first go into what I liked about the game and then break down what I didn't. As a side note I played and beat it on the hardest difficulty so some of what I say may not apply for lower difficulties.

-Starting strong, I really enjoyed how; for most of the challenges the game throws at you, there are multiple ways of dealing with them, whether they are intended or not. The freedom to choose how to deal with the situation allows you to be creative in your approach, which allows for a more enjoyable time all around. And if you're good at manipulating the game's physics engine it just opens more ways to play. 
-I also love how since the game is old and not very refined, a lot of unexpected things can happen involving entities. In my play-through I saw quite a few headcrabs clip a box I was pushing while lunging and just get catapulted, and it was amazing whenever they did.
-And lastly I enjoyed how I was allowed to murder all the scientists I wanted without worrying about the game really stopping me (most of the time). I had my friend watching me play since he loves the game and his reaction every-time I drew my crowbar when a scientist was talking was great.

I really struggled thinking of what I liked about the game but I wanted to at least include something so it didn't seem like I was just hating the game. I really came into it wanting to know why it was so well regarded. Now let's get on to the negatives.

-Most of the guns in the game are just bad, having either pitiful damage or horrible fire rate (Sometimes both) or ungodly spread. Reload speed is also a big problem I had, I believe it takes like 4-6 secondes to reload the crossbow and the shotgun reloads a single slug per second I think. It might be more like .7 but that's still pretty bad.
-Most enemy has their on bullshit that tends to just be annoying. Human enemies love spamming grenades, Vortigaunts like to hide in dark places and fire their hard hitting blasts at you that does 35-ish damage while you're trying too deal with another enemy and they'll just sometimes spawn in right behind you, the grunts have a homing weapon that fires slow so the tracking is really good and they always come is groups, bullsquids will just spit at you from across the map, and so on.
-As soon as you are spotted by the enemy they all know where you are and the human enemies have hit-scan weapons almost guaranteeing you'll take damage.
-The story is told through random npcs that you may just run by without realizing they were talking in the first place.
-Dialogue is delivered super flat paired with bad audio.
 -The bosses are barely bosses. Until you get to Xen they are literally just, lead boss from area A to area B and hit button. That's if you even decide to fight them because you can just run past most of the time.
-The movement is really floaty which is why you can abuse it so much, but for a casual player who isn't abusing it, it's just annoying and sometimes you'll just walk right off the ledge.
-For half the game you're inside a boring foundation that get's old real quick.
-And finally, the range on explosions are deceptively big, pair that with the human enemies spamming grenades it becomes a bad time.

I'm not saying don't ever play this game, I'm just saying I think people get to hung up on the nostalgia and claim it's better than it is. I'd have to give it like a 4.5/10 as an actual game.

I often have a hard time picking favorites, but I'd be kidding myself if I didn't think Half-Life is my favorite game ever. I played it for the first time in 2007 - well past the point when it was new to the world - but that didn't stop me from being absolutely blown away. The intense action, unique aesthetics, measured storytelling and killer soundtrack all made for a package that resonated so strongly that it helped solidify not only my preferences in games, but even media in general.

Even upon replaying (which I now do pretty much every year) the ambiance is still as gripping as ever, and the gameplay remains fun thanks to an expansive arsenal of weapons, plus a varied roster of alien and human enemies to fight; both of which, as an aside, I always felt were slimmed down just a bit too much in the sequels. Some parts are undeniably jank by modern standards, but nothing is so bad as long as you're patient, or even the least bit accustomed to older games.

Review update:
I finished the game (normal mode, I don't think I could handle hard psychologically), and it has to be the worst good game I've ever played.

So many cool ideas and moments overwhelmed by real bad design choices and glitches. Half of my time I was having fun killing enemies, solving puzzles and following the intriguing story told by the environment, the other half I was fighting with my character getting stuck everywhere (Gordon's a fatty apparently) and countless glitches. I guess they made for occasional funny moments but most of the time they were frustrating. At some point I wasn't even able to continue the game because no matter what I did I would get stuck into a pipe (in surface tension) in between loading zones. 

I might recommend at least checking out half life, it's cool in terms of ideas, but I'd never recommend playing this version on steam, especially if you do not like unpolished games. There are updated versions like Half Life Source and the fan remake, Black Mesa. I never touched those, this is my first approach to the series, but they came several years later and are supposed to improve a few things.

I'm honestly excited to dive in HL2 now, as I'm told it has improved so much and is far more polished, which is truly the one thing this game lacks.

Some pros and cons I found

PROS:
-Innovative for the time
-Plenty of good ideas in terms of level design and storytelling
-Fast paced action 
-Many secret areas reward exploration with lots of pickups and new weapons.
-Mostly fair despite some big bs moments (like enemies spawning inside of you)
-Good variety despite the limited assets
-Oddly enough there were more details and interaction options in here than most modern games

CONS:
-Movement is mheh, platforming is super slippery and not fun.
-Audio is not good, you can't hear voices most of the times and the reverb fx is really messed up.
-Some parts or entire levels are pretty bad, especially the final part which everyone seems to agree on
-Too many glitches and inconsistencies, I spent so much time re-doing parts due to glitches, at some point I had to save every few steps to avoid wasting more time.
-A tad too many blind guesses.
-Final boss is a long lame battle, had way more fun with the first "tentacles" boss in the burner room.

I played and finished the game on hard mode over the course of a week, and overall I'd say I enjoyed the game a lot, But man, it really starts dragging during the last few chapters of the game.
Also know that I intentionally avoided all media about the series as a whole outside of a few ads made for the games and the unintentional occasional nugget of info; so my slate is as clean as possible for such an old and well-perceived series.

So... at the start of the game, I was immediately engrossed from the first "cutscene". I put quotes around that since it's really more "showing off" while simultaneously giving you an idea of where you are and how advanced the technology is, as well as you can move during it (which I didn't know until accidentally hitting a movement key). I like it. But afterwards, it did take a long time to start get through story stuff and get to the action. The first weapon you get, the crowbar, felt very powerful. It swings fast and I used it to kill a guard early before he could shoot me back, which I then I got a gun for. But when past that, the crowbar took way too long to do any meaningful damage, or they are headcrabs... and the crowbar does not work well on headcrabs.

But most of the other weapons feel pretty good. I don't like how the crossbow feels so stiff to use, but it's super powerful and silent, so I forgive it. You move pretty fast in this game too, which I first thought would be counter-productive to the game's seemingly slow pace. But after a short while, I grew to appreciate it. I also like the puzzle-combat style of the game (is that even a style? idk I kinda made that up just now). You can use a variety of weapons and strategies for almost every situation, some better than others of course. It reminds me of Metal Gear a lot, and I really like Metal Gear.

I was having a lot of fun going through the game, using minimal saves and only dying a few times (except that really hard invisible agent fight. That had a lot of dying before I sat back and outsmarted them). And I then I got to the rocket. I honestly felt like that was the end of the game for a while. It felt like I accomplished the main goal (stop the aliens from teleporting in) and you got to the surface. I though the game was broken when the credits didn't show up, and I didn't find an obvious way to progress. So, with a lot of hesitation, looked it up. You had to backtrack a bit to continue. Fine, ok. Not too big of an issue and it doesn't happen a lot in the game before nor since.

But after the rocket, the game started to drag. Right afterwards is a water section, which I hate (esp because I get motion sick super easily). And this was also the start of some bullshit enemy teleporting. You are on a narrow walkway that is slippery, causing hard to control sliding. The pool of water below has a tanky, very hard to deal with, pretty fast (also scary) alien fish thing that eats your legs in less than 3 chomps. You have to jump across the gap while sliding on the puddle. You start running across the water, ready to jump, then an alien spawns behind you, zaps you, and since i was at low health, dies. That was pretty frustrating, but no huge deal. But this kept happening. Not very often, but enough and at the most annoying moments, causing it to be frustrating.

And not too long after that chapter, the game introduces these bulky armored aliens that have a "bee" gun. They shoot homing bees that hurt pretty badly considering they shoot out of the bee gun pretty quickly. These destroy the "run, think, shoot, live" slogan to "run, see bee, shoot, die, reload save, use boring strat, live". You can't tell when these guys show up, so when you walk into a room to assess the situation and plan an attack / escape and one of these guys notices a slight disturbance in the force, they turn around and shoot you with 8 homing bees which usually cripple you down to 30 or lower health. You can counter them effectively when you get your own bee gun, but you need a lot of bees to kill one, they come out slower, and their homing capabilities are severely neutered. You have to shoot them within what feels like a couple of feet of them for them to home onto. This leads to a lot of long sessions of hiding behind a wall, poking the armored alien with bees, hoping he doesn't walk too much (which either lets him see and shoot you, or makes your bee-poking angle not viable), and sitting there for upwards of 20 seconds to finally play the game normally again. They only start showing up more and more, killing the strategy element of the game for me. Atleast the bee gun has unlimited ammo, which is nice since you run low on ammo occasionally (and melee isn't much of an option).

I feel like the bee gun and the shitty "teleports behind you" enemies really start getting annoying when you reach the reactor... which doesn't help since the reactor is more "go here and press button" than most other puzzles, especially since the puzzling was replaced with combat. And the combat usually has 2 or 3 bee guys, and I hate bee guys since they kill the game's pace and encourages a dumb cheese strat.

But the levels were what kept me playing. They either have great puzzles (my favorites being On a Rail and the Invisible ninja fights) or have breathtaking atmosphere (the Xen planet and the areas during Surface Tension for instance). Even the reactor level looked nice and felt like it made sense, on top of a really good teleport sections.

There are a fair share of annoying bugs though (mouse settings resetting and constantly getting stuck on those flying enemies and inside pipes mainly), but being an old game, I can forgive it for a few bugs here and there. I think It's worth playing game due to it's legacy on it's own; but if you want to play this game purely for it's own merits, I'd still think it'll be a fun ride. If I wanted to be stubborn, I'd stay stop after you launch the rocket. But you will be missing out on some of the best levels if you stop at what I think would've been a great stopping point. Plus maybe the bee guys are not nearly as much of an issue on easier difficulties.

6/10, really great game, and I'm looking forward to the famously incredible sequel. If it weren't for bee guys, it's be more of a 8/10; yes, I hate them that much. They kill pacing, are a pain to deal with more than 1 of at a time (which is almost always the case), and probably single handedly the reason for 75% of my saves and deaths.
A legendary game that defined the development of the genre. Thank you for it!

Half-Life is an amazing game for like the first 80% but then the last 20% is bad at best and horrendous at worst. Like for a game 1998 it has aged gracefully if you ask me, almost everything holds up really well except the sound quality is not all that great a lot of the times but for the rest i really did enjoy myself a lot.
If you want to know what my pros and cons are for most of the game then keep on reading buddy.

For my pros:
+ The entire game is a grand adventure that keeps on getting better (till you hit Xen) wich is really fun to kinda start small and you notice how big of a problem it is actually becoming.
+ Graphics still look kinda decent honestly (I was running it on OpenGL).
+ It's very atmospheric, I found myself getting sucked up into the world and not knowing how much time has actually passed.
+ All levels look and feel different wich is kinda incredible for such an old game that is 10 hours long.
+ The sewer/factory level was really fun honestly. Also the level where you have to ride a little train cart was made me feel like a little kid on a theme park ride.
+ All weapons also feel and sound unique from one another. Maybe my only complaint with the weapons might be the shotgun wich feels kinda weird to use since it has a smaller effective range than i'm used to but it after a while i got used to it and it also more than makes up for it with that earshattering noise.
+ The story is told through visual storytelling, there are no moments (except maybe 2 or 3 times) where the plot and what is happening or what you should do is told through dialogue. 

One neutral point that i have is that the combat is really basic but the sounds of the guns make it feel impactfull.

Now to the cons:
- Sound quality is not all that good, mostly the voices sound like they were recorded with some crappy mic.
- Gordon feels clunky to control in the platforming sections.
- When i quit the game it doesn't close properly and keeps running in the background, either i had to end it in  task manager or when it didn't show up i had to end steam.
- There's a real lack of music to be honest, it could also be that it was glitched on my end and that certain tracks wouldn't play because of it.
- I got stuck on terrain more than a few times so i had to reload a previous save.
- Sometimes the enemies are placed just around a corner with a shotgun wich you can have no idea that he's there.
- While we are talking about shotguns, the enemies with shotguns can shoot it way faster than you ever could wich is kinda bullshit.
- As last, this is probably something everyone already knows and that is that the final levels in Xen are just horrendous to play through, there's nothing fun about it whats however. Even made me enable noclip at certain parts because i got so done with platforming certain parts.

Summary:
Overall this is a great game and i would recommend everyone to play through it at least once on the hardest difficulty because then you have to manage ammo sometimes. I think it's priced pretty good but for the most people i'd recommend to wait for a sale. So an amazing game with a few bullsh*t parts but that's okay because the rest is f*cking superb.

I haven't played this game in weeks, and I can't get myself to. So now I'm writing a review, and I'm just going to honestly try to figure out [i]why[/i] I don't want to play it.

I just [i]could[/i] not enjoy this game, and [i]trust me[/i] I tried. A lot of the elements are surprising, nostalgic, recognizeable if you're familiar with the "Half-Life Expanded Universe", but there were so many times where I just scratched my head and thought "Man, this would really not hold up in today's game industry". Call me an entitled Gen-Z gamer who can't appreciate 'true art', but I did not have fun with this one, and I couldn't even finish it because of how tedious the fucking Gonarch is. I'll take the fact that I'm shit at this game and that I need more handholding to my ego, and go back to Team Fortress like the impatient endorphin-addicted pleb I am.

If you like playing this game, a sincere 'good for you'! I'm honestly happy you could have fun with something I don't see the value in. But if you're looking to get this game because you want the "full Valve experience" like I did, don't keep your expectations high. I don't think this game either A. is as 'timeless' as the community makes it out to be, nor B. holds a candle to newer games. 
If you're gonna do it for the lore, there are countless videos on YouTube going into more detail in a shorter time than playing through the full 25 hours-or-so of Half-Life games. If you're doing it for the gameplay, sure, why the fuck not, it's like half a cent - but  don't let yourself be disappointed if it's not for you, and go play Factorio or Titanfall 2 instead

I have learned something while playing Half-Life, I don't like First Person Shooters. As much as I like Metroid Prime and shooters like Resident Evil 4, there is just something about Half-Life's platforming and shooting that doesn't resonate with me nearly as well. 

The story is interesting for a bit, but just kinda ends up going from horror themed adventure to action adventure that, while realistic, didn't really pull me in. I will agree that I probably just suck at this game, but there is a number of difficulty spikes throughout and a lot of the puzzles can feel very obtuse and make you wonder if you're going the right way. More often than not I was either getting killed a lot for the rapid gunfire from enemies or from platforming around trying to figure out where to go to next, sometimes both. A lot of the soundtrack just tended to blend into sound effects, and I had to actually look up to make sure the game indeed had a soundtrack, and while it is there, I'd argue it's not very remember-able. Add all this together with a very annoying final boss fight and outdated graphics really makes me wonder how anyone saw this game as a classic. I'll agree that a lot of the charm is lost through time, but largely I feel very apathetic with my time with Half-Life.

Half-Life is a game where you run and gun everything.
That's what i would've said IF Half Life was that.
You play as Gordon Freeman, Gordon is a physicist. So in this game it makes sense to think like one. Each enemy encounter requires some sort of strategy, whether it's hiding from alien attacks or lobbing grenades at army marines to distract them, strategic combat is all key, running in and simple shooting will most likely kill you.
The map of this game as well seems huge.
Exploring an underground facility is fun and challenging. I found each area to be fair (except for that train area) and I always knew where to go. Each act usually had one or two puzzles, these ranging from using a 
Thruster to clear a path, or simply turning on a flooded generator. each puzzle isn't too hard and challenging, it also put the game to a slow pace and it may also involve combat, keeping you on our toes to expect anything.
The AI in this game is also impressive for 1998.
Marine AI is amazing as they too use strategies, such as using grenades to smoke you out of your hiding place, most of them carry a standard automatic rifle, which is both balanced in short and long range, meaning that you'll never have an unfair disadvantage.
So to fully summarise my review I would have to give Half-Life a 9/10, one point taken away for the graphics and the occasional glitch.

When this game first came out it was such a cultural shock for the gaming industry and shaped a mould for the modern first person shooter genre......

As a genius once said, "Story in a game is like story in a p*rn movie, it's expected to be there, but it's not important.". He may have been right, but before quake the first person shooter wasn't a genre but mere DOOM clones following the same format, but when quake came out this solidified the first person shooter as a gaming genre here to stay.

Before  Half-Life FPS games had a narrative but it was just there as it was "...expected to be there...", Half-Life was one of the first FPS game to take its narrative seriously and do it in a way that makes it a great game to play even to this day, I don't know if it was the first FPS to take it's narrative seriously, but it was the first one to do it well enough to create a huge movement towards story based FPS games and slowly distance itself form the balls to the wall, bad-assery that was DOOM. 

Without spoiling the narrative of this game here's a small summary of the story...

You are MIT graduate Gordan Freemn working in the Black Mesa facility, you're late for work and after a failed experiment a link between two worlds is created causing mass panic. You must do everything it takes.

This game does a great job of making you feel weak, one man against an unstoppable force of aliens.

Half-Life isn't afraid of questioning the morality of Gordan Freeman, it's never said to you directly but if you think of it, if you weren't late for work none of this may have happened, you also indirectly kill thousands of innocent people and you can kill friendly NPCs including guards and scientists without any repercussions on the story or progression.

A quick note is that this game is very unforgiving and doesn't allow you to mow through aliens like the DOOM slayer, your just a a MIT graduate against a whole army of aliens. The game also drags towards the end and i was just hoping for it to end by the time i got to around chapter 15 out of 18 and the last part of the game is easily the weakest part of the game from chapter 15 onward.

This game still rocks and you should pick it up the ending doesn't ruin the game at all but it is something you should be wary of, this game is timeless, Not visually.

HALF LIFE
So, basically... i bought the Valve Complete pack during the summer discount 2021, cuz I always wanted to go deep into the Half Life series... thinking it as "old" or "obsolete", i started playing the first chapter without any desire, but then... oh, boy!
This game just got me! It's still amazing, even if it's a bit old! I will explain now why I LOVED and I ABSOLUTELY ADVICE it!

STORYLINE:
Now, without making any spoiler, I believe the story is the main reason why I decided to keep going with the game. The plot catch you, you just start the adventure don't knowing what is going on, and you keep going realizing than nothing you expect actually happen: you think the facilities are over, but then you go in a completely different area, when you think enemies are over, you fight them again...
It's not a boring or foregone story: You'll see... you start thinking about getting out of the lab and you end... well... in a very enigmatic way...

CHARACTER:
I think Gordon Freeman actually got a place in my heart, even if he never says a word. He just know what to do, in the right moment and in the exact point.

TECNICAL OVERVIEW:
There are no cutscenes. You'll see everything in-game, throught Gordon's eyes, without true cutscenes.
Still, you'll be able to see very memorable moments, like the game's intro, when you are in the train and the woman on the microphone speaks to you...
Also, there are no actual levels, but more like chapters that separate the story: interesting choice, cuz it actually seems like you are in the Black Mesa facility, and not only playing a game...
Sadly, graphic it's not so modern: textures are pixelated, and sometimes some weird bugs and glitches can occur, like when you make a jump, and, instead to land, you just freeze in the place and you must kill yourself in order to get free.

GAMEPLAY:
The old graphic is, though, perfectly compensated by the gameplay: there is a lot of stuff you can break, secret areas, you can infiltrate actually breaking with the crowbar into the vents, and a lot more!
Also, I.A. is very smart: guards have a precise aim, enemies are difficult to face... even cockroaches have a smarter AI than Cyberpunk 2077!

PERSONAL RATING:
It's a really good game. If you, like me, are playing the Half Life series for the first time, I believe it's the right choice to start with the original Half Life.
Trust me: you won't regret it! 
Still a solid and modern game, even if it comes from 1997!

Alright. I've seen the memes. It was like $3.  Had to give it a go.
This review is happening in 2021. 

Pros:
-I ran into zero game breaking glitches.  Or... no real glitches at all.
-I went in blind and only used a guide when I couldn't figure out what to do.  Which... was more than I would have liked.  Like not interacting with something (generator switch) cause it looks like a light bulb... and you assume when you do something, the light will come on.  But it doesn't, you are supposed to interact with it.
-The difficulty was there.  I didn't find the overall combat to be too tough but the platforming and environment are a real challenge.
-Last boss was a bit tough.  I kept try to do stuff instead of just pumping him full of ammo.
-I had such found memories of my N64 days come rush in.
-The few times the soundtrack came on... it was absolutely bumpin'


Cons:
-Tough to look at man.  Just throwing it out there.  It is a product of its day and it looks that way.
^ in defense, I like that the graphics are unchanged to preserve the original, its just tough to look at in 2021.
-Certain weapons seemed completely useless.  I used the auto rifle for ~80% of all enemies.  Then revolver for anything at distance covered another 10% of enemies.
-Lots of platforming.  A lot.
-Xen environment at the end has different gravity values and its extremely annoying to adjust to.

Game was basically free.  Time investment was worth it.
-Final

Wake Up and Smell the Ashes...

Last time we left Gordon Freeman, the unlikely scientist-hero from the first Half-Life, he was traveling. Yes, just traveling. The mystery was where he was traveling to and why all of the incidents at Black Mesa had happened (not to mention why the game was rife with so many horrific jumping puzzles towards the end). Half-Life 2 begins with Gordon arriving via train with the G-Man teasing his mind with sickly whispers of warning. The last stop of the arriving train is City 17, a bastion of the alien Combine forces, yet another mystery themselves.

For the rest of the story, you'll have to play the game yourself. I'm absolutely dedicated to getting through this review with your chance at an untarnished gaming experience intact. That means no spoilers. Suffice to say, there are lots of twists to curl your brain along the way, some a bit more predictable than others, but all welcome and interesting.

While the writing and plot points will act as fly paper to your attention, the real winner here is the way the story is presented. Through the eyes of Gordon Freeman, you'll experience roughly 17-20 hours of consciousness which tests your senses and captures your mind. The simplicity and style with which this story is presented are perhaps the most graceful maneuvers of the many that Valve has carried out. From the moment you take your first steps off of that train and into the station at City 17, you'll begin to be tutored in the ways of this bizarre eastern European city. Public service announcements, private conversations, and the actions of characters around you, whether part of the Combine or simply waylaid citizens, create a stifling and threatening feeling that City 17 has become some sort of elaborate prison preaching the chance for freedom and opportunity without choice or desire.

While I was ultimately left a little bit frustrated by the open-endedness, the journey to get to the end of the story was assuredly interesting and opened up the doors to many more possibilities. It's easy to start speculating about this or that, just don't let it drive you nuts. The deeper you get, the darker and more intriguing it becomes until you get to the end... which you'll have to see for yourself.

Pure silence, it was strange. So I then decided to forcefully close the game using task manager. Restarted the game and it began playing normally in the train sequence just like how I remembered.

After playing a few hours, I went to sleep... woke up the next day and went to work where I talked with my friend / co worker about Half life. He talked about a half life 2 beta which was really strange and creepy, containing these weird and eerie sounds. I was interested and downloaded the beta when I got home, I opened it up and saw the menu, seeing how still and static it was with no sound. I hit the training room and entered a facility with kleiner. Eventually playing that level I started hearing these weird sounds and saw Gman apparitions with a weird moving wall.........

Assuming that the game wanted me to progress in that direction, I pressed onwards, forcing Gordon Freeman to pass by shifting walls of metal, their dull hues contrasting the bright red error signs surrounding them. I heard the background noises fade out, until it was just Gordon‚Äôs steps against the concrete floor.

Suddenly, the HUD disappeared from my screen, leaving nothing but a long concrete corridor and the sounds of footsteps, slowly getting louder. Entranced by the endless corridor ahead, I pressed onwards. I could hear my crappy PC fan whirring unusually fast. I took my finger off the W key just to turn on the desk fan I kept nearby to cool it off. When I looked back, Gordon was still moving towards a door. I tried to press pause, but nothing happened. Gordon just kept going forwards into the door. It slid open, revealing a pure black room with sonic.exe within. I heard gordon's crying reverberating through my empty bedroom.

I'll recommend this mostly if you like retro FPS or you want to see for yourself an important piece of video game history. In my opinion the right way to play this game is using the half-baked software renderer in a low resolution, the whole game gets a much tighter feel and ambience.

Unlike many of the older FPS games, the way half-life tries to be fun is not in the killing itself, but in its elaborate set pieces, which makes this game share more with Duke Nukem 3D than the Quake it inherited its engine. The most shocking thing to be found here is the ammount of levels that served as inspiration - or have been outright stolen - by the games that followed it.

It's a very cartoon nerdy game, the story is told by characters in game without cutscenes and without subtitles, which was rather new at the time. But even today that isn't too common, for good reason, because you might miss or mishear certain bit. The level design is a lot more fun once you've played it a first time, because there are parts that appear to intently be opaque as all hell.

The enemies don't get more interesting than the human soldiers where Valve did put a lot of effort into the AI. Either aliens, machines or human enemies they all feel rather bullet spongy, and the shotgun just doesn't pack enough damage or a clear enough spread to be a good weapon. Seriously, this game can take a lot of the blame for the death and disappearance of shotguns in FPS for a long time. Oh, and beware, this game ends with an old school really poorly aged floating and horrid boss battle.

OK, Half Life is from 1998, so it's pretty old - I'll try to keep that in mind when writing this review.

It's not brilliant, I'll be honest. The sound design is the same loop and when other sounds are playing, it becomes a horrible cacophony of noise. If you like tinnitus - this is perfect for you. 

The graphics are old, yet very good even today. They really do set the mood of the whole game. The enemy design is also brilliant, every enemy is very different from the other and so you always have to learn how to counter every new enemy. 

In combat, things fall apart. You are always the weaker enemy, which is partly the point, and bullets are scarce so really count if you don't want to take loads of damage. Combat is, however, the dominant feature, and you have to fight endless enemies that you have already met. It becomes almost a chore towards the end of the game, and it spoiled the experience for me. 

Half Life is a long game. It took me about 15 hours to beat the game on my first playthrough (on normal difficulty). At times there were long parts (one up to 2 hours) that felt like fillers and that didn't need to be there. There were puzzles that gave you no help to solve so you're stuck trying to solve the puzzle until you randomly get to the answer. 

It's not the best game ever, it's old and I got really motion sick at times. The thing that made this game enjoyable for me is the moments that aren't bad. If you stick with the game, there's so much it does right and these moments really make the game enjoyable and massively outweigh the negatives in Half Life.

Overall, I'd probably give this game a 5/10 - not the best, but not by far the worst I've ever played either.

A First Person shooter classic. Set in the Black Mesa Research Complex, the game provides a very exciting setting for a shooting game. The level / environment design is the game's strongest suit since most of the levels have a high degree of internal believability and feature a lot of interconnectivity. The game also makes use of very varied combat environments filled with combat setpieces and puzzles so you're rarely stuck doing just one thing. The audiovisual design still feels like it holds up with great action soundtrack used at exciting setpieces, weapons and the industrial machinery sounding what one would expect. My main criticism of the game was that some enemies feel VERY bullet-spongy meaning that even if you surprise them you're going to take a lot of damage which is fair enough. The conclusion of the game was in my opinion far weakest part of the game in terms of combat, aesthetics and especially the final combat encounter didn't function very well. Still, very enjoyable game and a worthwhile experience.

Half-Life is one of the most timeless 90's PC games, at least gameplay-wise.
The game follows the adventures of Gordon Freeman, a 27 year old therotical physicist who works at a mysterious scientific research facility called "Black Mesa", located deep within New Mexico's rocky underground areas. The game starts with a monorail ride that gives the player a look at the ambience. The soundtrack that plays during said ride gives chills up the spine and feeling of dread to any first-timer. After finishing the sequence, the player arrives at Sector C, where they have to start rushing toward the testing chamber, not before getting a Mark IV HEV Suit to put on as a security measure.

I won't spoil much of the rest, and I don't want to make the review a 20 page long explanation of the lore, so I'll get to the technical and gameplay side of the game. First off, you may have noticed the visuals are a bit rough. This is usually something most players can get over quickly, as with any other old-school 3D first-person shooter. 

However, if you really think the graphics are affecting your experience, but you're still eager to play it, you may also try Half-Life: Source, an official Valve port of the game to Half-Life 2's signature engine, Source, or you could also play Black Mesa, a full-on remake of the original game on a brand-new engine that not only massively improves its outdated visuals, but also has some gameplay changes and expansion of certain chapters and maps. 

Anyway, getting back on topic, Half Life seriously made the entire gaming industry rethink the purpose and possibilities of a story-driven FPS title. After all, shooters back then were thought to be short, fun and chaotic experiences, like Wolfenstein and DOOM. Half Life however, while still keeping gunplay a priority, gave space for a story and plot. Story-driven games did exist, but they were usually RPGs that required really long dialogs and walls of text to explain the lore, and included primitive (or none) gunplay, like the first Fallout for example. Half Life however, needed no more than a few hundred voicelines and implicit story telling to deliver a plot, which is quite the achievement event to this day, where first-person shooters still struggle to deliver stories in a meaningful and interesting way.

In short, great game, and the first shooter I ever played that got me hooked on its lore. 10/10 would beat zombies to death with a crowbar again

Half-Life is an FPS with survival-horror elements that was released in 1998. It revolutionized the world of not just FPS's but gaming as a whole. It was an immersive experience like no other and has set a lot of trends in how games tell their stories that are still commonly used today but just because a game revolutionized gaming doesn't mean it hold up today. However, Half-Life doesn't just hold up but remains one of the best games of all time and is my tied favorite game of all time. 

Half-Life has a somewhat cliche story however the story manages to stay interesting due to the way the story is told. You never leave Gordon Freeman's perspective throughout the entire game and you remain in control for the majority of the experience with only 1 exception I can think of. Set-pieces are commonly used to great effect and help tell the story in a natural way.

Where Half-Life shines is in it's fast-paced but methodical game-play. There are 2 main types of enemy. There are aliens which appear in a select few chapters throughout the game. They are pretty interesting as there are a lot of variants and they are all unique. They provide a nice survival-horror theme earlier in the game but ultimately leave a little to be desired. The second variant of enemy are the soldiers. Soldiers are my favorite aspect of this game. A lot of people complain that their weapons are hit-scan and that it can feel unfair while others complain that firefights can turn into you and the enemy just unloading your rounds into each other. I disagree with both of these critiques and believe that this was intentional by the developers to create more strategical game-play. Soldiers can not shoot and run at the same time so a lot of the game revolves around you trying to outsmart the enemy. Remember, you're a theoretical physicist not a doom-guy. Each weapon has a unique purpose and there are a lot of weapons in the game. Throwing grenades make enemies run away giving you a chance to unload into their back-side. You can shoot explosive barrels and move wooden boxed to make cover. Little tactics like these add up into a strategical, fast-paced, run and gun experience. 

10 euro is not a lot of money and I have played this game 4 times (currently on my 5th play-through) and have sunk 50 hours into this masterpiece so far so you can probably imagine that I highly recommend you pick up this game. But before that I suggest you watch a video titled "Why Half-life 1 is so unforgiving" made by 'Leadhead' on Youtube. They do a fantastic job of outlining how Half-Life 1 should be played for the best experience. All I have left to say is I hope you have as much fun as I have and will for hours on end.

Played through it twice, both times on hard difficulty. The first time, I played it for free, and I was thinking, ehh, a bunch of other games I play were sort of based on this game, so why not? I purchased it in a bundle for my second playthrough.

It has a nice jump-scare factor, it's a game of many hazards, and the storyline is really fun to follow. This is by no means a light play, not some casual shoot-em-up game. Every step you take, and every corner you peek around, could be your death (if you're not careful). It didn't take me long to start saving the game constantly. On rare occasion it's just downright unfair with the surprises, but a load game will always fix that and you know what to expect at that point.

This game is not for everyone, but if the above sounds appealing, and you like a nice fun FPS challenge, then this is for you. It also has lots of variety: many different guns, different aliens, different approaches you'll have to take to win each battle, different environments and controls in each environment, and so on. This helps to keep the game interesting. It's all very well scripted, in both senses.

I also recommend Half Life: C.A.G.E.D., which is a free (once you own HL) prison escape game that's much like Half Life (without aliens) and is pretty fun.

This is definitely a good game overall, especially if you're a big fan of classics, but it's definitely nothing cutting-edge gameplay wise(which makes sense, considering how old it is. I don't blame the wonkiness, its a little charming sometimes when you're not clipping into the floor when loading a new area). If you're in for the story and don't mind either 1) replaying the dumbest areas over and over because of unlucky enemy placement, or 2) going the easy route and cheating into the next area somehow, this is a really great game. The story is phenomenal, the world building is very very fun to find out about and play through, and the game is just fast-paced enough to keep things interesting without dunking you head-first into things. For a classic, this game is really fun- and while there were levels I loathed to play through (anything with the military, honestly) it was still a really nice thing to get to sit down and play. It remains one of my feel-good games that I sit down and replay whenever things get stressful and I need something easy and familiar, and the other content packs you can buy with it are also really fun. Blue shift is one of my favorites. 

TL;DR: Overall, good game. Old gameplay makes it a bit wonky at times and the later chapters can be frustrating, but it's still very fun and extremely worth it. I'd rank it about a 4.5/10 for gameplay, 9/10 for story.

Half-Life is certainly a great game and playing through it over twenty years after it‚Äôs initial release only strengthens that for me. That being said it is far from perfect. It‚Äôs story; characters; world building and presentation are ground breaking and still worthy of praise. It was a pioneer in not having any cut scenes and keeping you in Gordon Freeman‚Äôs shoes. It also managed a great feat in that it Valve chose to communicate the story through side characters you encounter and through announcements. Having Freeman be a mute could have been a terrible choice but they pulled it off. The presentation  of the game was fantastic. In that I mean things like the intro train ride setting up the facility and little things such as Gordon‚Äôs locker giving him some backstory. The characters of Barney; G-Man;  and the scientists all cemented their place in gaming history. There was a good selection of weapons that had many good and memorable choices. The difficulty curve of the game felt a bit off though with some sections feeling extremely easy and others feeling almost sadistic. The enemies were varied and all had little differences that made them unique as well as have slightly different strategies for. The graphics were good for the time. I wouldn‚Äôt say they were the best of 1998 but certainly top 5. The reload sounds and animations of the guns were varied and gave them extra character. I will now get to something that brought the game down for me from possible all time great to just great: the physics. Half-Life has by far some of the worst physics I have ever seen and to top it off it is compounded by having brutal levels of fall damage. The worst part of the physics for me was interacting with ladders. Going up or down would be an exercise in patience as it was all to easy for the game to think I wanted Gordon to leap off of it. Other times I would climb up the ladder and it may shoot me up in the air a bit having me lose half of my life in fall damage when I hit the ground. The fall damage and poor physics made some of the platforming very frustrating as well. Some of the issue was timing the jumps while others were seeming to slide a bit after landing. I had these issues years ago when I first played the game and they‚Äôre still there now. There are health kits scattered about as well as medical stations scattered as well. You can‚Äôt carry any med kits with you though.

	I played Half-Life on Linux. It never crashed on me. The game ran great which given the age wasn‚Äôt a surprise. There was an option for V-Sync but not any graphics options. The game seemed to be locked to 101 FPS regardless of if V-Sync was turned on. I will say that voices felt a bit muffled or with an echo at times. I also had one time where I went through a platform and got stuck making me have to reload my previous save. There were also textures that appeared black and others that would flicker. I could manually save whenever I wanted and there seemed to be no limit on number of saves. You can also just let the game auto save if you want to. You can‚Äôt change the difficulty after starting the game.

[h1] An experiment that cost humanity everything[/h1]
[b]Half-Life[/b] is one of the best games ever made by man. A game with a huge universe, which is much deeper than it might seem at first glance. This is not just a shooter. And this is not just a story about one late-come scientist wearing distinctive glasses. The Black Mesa incident is just a prelude to what humanity will have to face in a matter of days. And Gordon's journey through the entire complex is just one of many destinies that are being decided right here and now. And Freeman is clearly not the kind of person who gives up in the erupting nightmare, where your next step can be the last. And the story of Gordon Freeman is an example that there are no impassable obstacles, no matter how insurmountable they seemed. A simple scientist with a crowbar in his hands and wearing an H.E.V 4th model protective suit with a basic military expertise. What this particular person could achieve by the end of this longest day of his life? But he achieved a lot. He survived in this seething hell from unseen before aliens and exactly the same people but in a soldier's uniform, who came here with one goal - to clear the complex. Literally. Including him. Against the background of Gordon's survival, we see the fate of other people - not only the same scientists, security officers, but also the soldiers, the very ones who came to "cleanse" us. Half-Life is, first of all, the tragic story of the fate of many hundreds of people who became the first, but far from the last victims of this criminal experiment, whose result was known for a long time to that very man in a business suit and administrator Breen. In 48 hours the history of the complex will come to an end. Towards the end, which will be the beginning of an even greater nightmare that will befall the entire planet and its population. Most of the Black Mesa personnel will die, as will many of those who were sent to clean it up. But those who survive will devote the rest of their lives to trying to turn things around. After all, from the waste of Portal Storms, a force will come, which will open a new chapter in the history of the Earth. The darkest and bloodiest.

Half-Life is definitely a game-changing FPS, inspired by the classics but also genre-breaking. The levels are linear but it follows a coherent story, there's puzzles to solve outside of the shooting - sometimes optional to get some ammos and/or health but usually they are actually needed to continue onto the next area or level!

So gameplay-wise it's your standard FPS. You have a full set of various weapons - everything from a regular 9mm to an RPG. There's also some experimental weapons you get later on. The enemies are... I'd say kinda hard. Health is generated by either health packs or health stations, so no re-gen here. Ammo are in certain areas scarce and there's several enemy types that are bullet sponges, especially later on in the game.

Has it aged well? I don't know, it's playable but at the same time it's quite rough around the edges. Perhaps Black Mesa is the better version these days?

It's overall good tho and I had a fun time with it, although I do have to admit that in certain areas... I had to "turn off" my health. It was a bit too hard for my taste otherwise and I had no real interest in re-playing certain areas over and over.

The Half-Life game series is arguably the most influential in the PC gaming industry. It starts in 1998, most of the popular games at the time were Quake and Doom. In those games you play as super soldiers. Super hero-like characters with powerful strength. When Half-Life came out, you literally spawned playing as ‚Äúman on his way to work‚Äù. It was a new concept compared to any other game, and even more relatable to the player. You didn't have super-strength, you didn't have mind-control. You were a normal scientist with a hazard suit. The suit, named HEV suit or Hazardous Environment Suit. It was the only real power that the main character, Gordon Freeman had at his disposal. It's a suit that's not meant for war, simply working in hazardous environments.

When you start the game, you are greeted with a long train ride to your workplace. You are Gordon Freeman, a man with a PhD in Theoretical Physics. Along the train ride, you witness the advanced AI. You see NPCs (Non Playable Characters) at work, at break and interacting with each other. Having normal human conversations, such as ‚ÄúDo you know who ate all the doughnuts?‚Äù And generally complaining about work environments or equipment failures.

You work at Black Mesa Research Facility, a government facility located in the New Mexico desert. It's a top secret facility working on all sorts of super cool futuristic technologies. A massive underground facility with housing, amenities and even their own TV and news entertainment. They have a small security force that works all over the facility to protect it from any failed Frankenstein-like experiments.

When you arrive at your train stop, you are greeted by a friendly security guard who lets you out of your train and warns you that you are late to work and they are soon going to start a big experiment. Once freed from the train car, you enter the lobby of Sector C. You are then greeted by NPCs who tell you that you are late and must go to the test chamber. Once you have put on the HEV Suit and arrived at the test chamber, you begin the experiment. As predicted, it goes very wrong. You unintentionally create a portal to another planet prompting the native species to invade earth.

Fighting your way through the facility, you learn that the military has been ordered to cover up everything. They do this by eliminating everyone associated with the failed experiment. When the military fails, the CIA special forces are there to do the same thing. They are even ordered to eliminate the leftover military forces who originally failed. All while this is happening, the player is mysteriously stalked by a man known as The G-Man. A tall pale man in a blue suit carrying a black leather briefcase. Nothing is really known about him and how he relates to the main game, but it's speculated that he plays a major role.

A game that does shows its age in a lot of parts. Graphics are not amazing, but they have their charm and I'm sure they were very cutting edge when this game released back in 1998. Movement can feel great and then feel not so great. It's a mixed bag. Some of the design in this game can also prove to be frustrating. I had to turn on god mode a few times due to not having enough health and some parts being near impossible to go through without taking damage. Plus that final level is a just a barrage of enemies which proves very difficult, even on easier difficulties. I'm sure some of this was due to me being bad, but there were a lot of parts were enemy design and placement felt cheap.

However, this game has a lot of things that have aged very well. The music is fantastic and is always used very appropriately. There are also so many really cool set pieces. Every area I went through was not only well designed (level wise) but was also super memorable. The puzzles were also very well done and I was able to figure them out without the game ever spelling it out for you. The story is also simplistic, but very interesting and always had me intrigued. Plus it helps that the character of The G-Man is not only very menacing but is like the only one in the game to have decent voice acting. Lastly, the gun play still feels so rewarding and fun to play with a lot of cool weapons at your hands. 

So, it's definitely NOT a perfect game. But if you give the game a shot, I'm sure you will find a lot to love here.

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Gotta be honest, never heard of Half-Life until I became a PC gamer in 2012. Played Half-Life 2 about two years later after buying it to play Garry's Mod, which I loved. I knew enough of the story to get through the second game and loved it. One of the best games I've ever played. 

FINALLY got around to playing the majority of Half-Life 1 for the last couple of weeks. I've played the first 30 minutes on and off over the last 5 years. First 30 minutes is slow and boring IMO. But I pushed through. And dear god, I've been missing out. The game is not your standard FPS. You "could" go in guns blazing, but the game heavily encourages you to be at least a little smart about how you play. You get to a point where you actually enjoy reloading a save after scanning how many enemies are in a room, and blowing them up with trip mines and grenades. Then taking the rest out with your trusty shotgun. At one point I spent five minutes brain storming how to take out these soldiers in the generator room elevator in a creative way. I ended up setting a trip mine right in the middle of the elevator, pressed the button and laughed my ass off as they came down and exploded in a gory mess.

That's when I knew this game was special. The goldsrc engine isn't Source, I know. It's certainly not that impressive. But the creative gameplay mechanics makes up for it. You'll spend a lot of time in the first half playing the "where the f*ck do I go" game, but you'll get the hang of it. Don't feel bad for looking up Youtube walkthroughs though. IMO, if you spend too much time trying to figure out where to go, it gets boring and makes you want to quit. So I say go for it. 

TL;DR: This game is fucking awesome. Standard FPS players will take some time to get used to it. But it's worth it.

It's been over a decade since the last time I played this masterpiece of a game and it's just as I remembered it when first playing it. 

I can imagine it's pretty difficult for gamers nowadays to play (close to the original) Half-Life 1, considering that there's a source version as well as the superior Black Mesa version. That being said, there's something truly special about the vanilla version.

Having gone back after all these years, I have to say that I wasn't disappointed. The game still holds well even after all these years. It ran perfectly on my system, it easily supported 2k resolution and overall the game ran flawlessly, with only this weird echo in the game that's bothersome at first, but you get used to it eventually (never figured out how to turn it off).

Do I recommend this game? Yes, I really do, it's one of the games that enhanced story telling in games as well as improving the overall FPS genre. On that same breath, I understand that this game is pretty old now. If graphics is a bother to you, then perhaps consider playing the Black Mesa version. It's really worth getting into the game.

I don't really need to speak praises about this game, as aside from animations and the obviously dated graphics, this game holds up exceedingly well gameplay wise.  Also, while Black Mesa (The community based remake of this game) does exist, it also has changes made that while they are mostly for the better, they still aren't very faithful to the original. You should really consider playing this before Black Mesa so you can appreciate it better, but if dated graphics kill it for you then the first half of Black Mesa stays mostly faithful.

I can't recommend it for $10 as it nearly always goes on sale for $1 or less every other major sale, but it's still an absolute yes you should buy it.

I don't really know if i can add to the discussion of this game, because anything that could be said about Half-Life right now, has been said. I won't say it's a flawless game - it's not. Models haven't aged the best, NPC AI isn't exactly, well, intelligent, and certain chapters of the game (On a Rail, the Xen chapters) feel like Valve punishing the player for becoming too relaxed while playing the game. But that doesn't mean that Half-Life is a bad game - far from it. Not only did Half-Life introduce world-building and environmental storytelling never seen before in the FPS genre, it introduced a more tactical approach to FPS combat, encouraging smart and quick thinking as opposed to the common "Run into room and blow lead into every moving being". While this may frustrate first time players that are more used to the fast-paced unstoppable game play of, say, Doom or Blood, Half-Life's punishing nature encourages the player to think tactically and logistically, and use all available tools to overcome the challenges they must face.

Overall, Half-Life is an absolute must-play for any FPS fan that provides some of the most engaging and difficult game play ever seen in a video game.

[h1]HALF-LIFE... the game that started it all for VALVE Software and our voiceless hero, GORDON FREEMAN![/h1]

Ah the original game... played COUNTLESS times in my college life... a game that I used to play at least twice per year before we got flooded with so many games year after year. Honestly, I must have finished HL1 at least 20 times ever since 1998 (I still got the original box!!!) And now, I haven't played this vanilla version in TEN YEARS... so since I just finished BLACK MESA DEFINITIVE EDITION and HALF-LIFE ALYX, I was like... what the heck! Let's revisit the good old ones then get around HL2 while at it!

So what can be said about HL1? A masterpiece game. At launch, it was perfection. Now in 2021, it clearly show it's age. There's no doubt about that! Still, the game runs pretty damn well on modern system and even support ultrawide monitor 21:9 ratio without any issues. (Your aim cursor is pretty small though!).

Sounds, music, voice acting, level design (most of it), gameplay... everything is amazing of this game. 
No wonder I kept (re)playing it so many times!

The only gripes I got with this game... the "crouch-jump, the ladders and the strange "toilet sound" when underwater, the XEN platforming is irritating even today! Crouch-jump works mostly okay but at times, doesn't register properly. Never liked that mechanic ever since 1999 to this day in 2021. As for the ladders, you can easily fall down from it and at times, you seem glued to 'em. As for the toilet sound, it's mostly funny when you do hear that but get's annoying the longer you're underwater. XEN levels are much shorter in HL compared to BMDE but has annoying platforming. And the jump-module is triggered by the awful crouch-jump...

For the newcomers or those who never played Half-Life (which is a total BLASPHEMY in my PC Gamer bible), it is quite worth to play this original version. HOWEVER, you could simply focus your attention to BLACK MESA DEFINITIVE EDITION, which is an outstanding recreation of HL1. Main differences between the two games: cut down content in the "ON A RAIL" chapter and maybe a few other portions in the beginning of BMDE. Although, XEN is much MUCH longer in BMDE. It looks and plays fabulously AMAZING too!


[h1]So what's HALF-LIFE?[/h1]
[b]You're Gordon Freeman... and... well, everyone knows his story! He's just 27 (even if he's born in 1973), MIT graduate and earned a PhD in theoretical physics. He was employed to Black Mesa Research Facility as a Level 3 Research Associate Scientist.. even played hide&seek in the vents with his good pal Barney Calhoun! Gordon's a genius. He worked at BMRF for a while until one bad day late for work, the infamous feared RESONANCE CASCADE scenario occurred. That is when he get's to fight for his own survival at first but eventually, becomes a legendary hero for the Human Resistance war against the COMBINE...[/b]

[h1]I'd suggest you go read his fandom wiki page, very informative![/h1]
[url=https://half-life.fandom.com/wiki/Gordon_Freeman] GORDON FREEMAN[/url]


[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[b]+EVERYTHING?
Honestly, the game may not have good visuals today but at launch back in 1998, they weren't amazing either. They were good for the time since it used that good old reliable Quake 2 engine. The A.I. was impressive back then too. Gameplay and especially the story is where the game shines the most in my opinion.[/b]

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[b]-Crouch-jumping (just awful even today!).
-Ladder climb is quite edgy as you can fall easily.
-"Toilet-sound" when underwater.
-XEN platforming is annoying![/b]


[h1]OVERALL:[/h1]
[b]AMAZING FPS game worthy to revisit (for FPS old timers!) and even to newcomers. If you played BLACK MESA, give this original game a shot. I found it much easier compared to BMDE.[/b]


[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]OF COURSE! This game got my personal badge of honor! One of the few game that I can safely stamp MASTERPIECE all over it. HALF-LIFE is in my TOP 5 best games EVER. You can say that after eleven years, yeah I was due to replay it![/b]

As of by this review I have completed Half life for the very first time and all I have to say is ,this game is really revolutionary during 1998 it has done a lot of things that most fps games at that time didn't,it did something unique during the 1990's by making the protagonist not feel as if it were a bad ass already but a bad ass in the end of their journey.The interactivity in this world is phenomenal,allowing you to interact with NPCS,buttons,levers,turrets and etc.,well for NPCS,they do not do so much but following you for requesting them for specific tasks that Gordon Freeman can't do,it makes Gordon more like if he's part of the world,but not him as the world.During the Gameplay you can experience that not all NPCS are against you,HECU's for example are hostile against Gordon Freeman,black mesa personnel,and various aliens,this gives them much more room for creativity when it comes to level design.The atmosphere in this game at the time of it's release was unique and revolutionary it made you feel so small,and making some structures if it were part of the facility making fallen or destroyed debris a path because of the resonance cascade,however this game is a masterpiece in game design,but there are some flaws,the graphics of the gold source engine are really dated,that's why turning on HD content is really recommended even if it doesn't follow it's proper view,now I don't focus mainly on graphics unless if it disrupts the gameplay,so that's why I'm giving it a low deduction,now however when you reach Xen in the later part of the game the level design and platforming is a bit uncomfortable,being that there is zero gravity that means you really can't maneuver that much in the air,that's why when there are these jump pads in Xen you better angle yourself on which platform you want to land on,and sometimes when it comes to moving platforms in Xen yeah it can get a bit tricky at times,half life at the time of this game I really lowered my expectations about the soundtrack,but boy was I wrong,there were some amazing music whether it would be atmospheric such as "Vague Voices",and "Space Ocean",to the loud,impactful and adrenaline filled music such as "Nuclear Space Jam","Adrenaline Horror",and "Diabolical Adrenaline Guitar" to even the fun and enjoyful kind of music such as "Klaxon Beat",and "Credits Closing Theme".This game all in all is a massive achievement in gaming,it's a masterpiece from it's story telling and it's atmosphere,so would I recommend you this game?

Half life is a masterpeice,I love it for it's corny NPCS, for its focus on interactivity and story and Guns that are just magnificent, (Tau cannon should've been in 2) Balanced Gameplay. Varying difficulty settings, a training room, Deathmatch, Fun to fight AI that'll make you really think. It's nowhere near half life 2's balance but its fun to learn, it's very much enjoyable, Then theres Xen. Xen is like you got a fancy new suit, and spaghetti sauce just fell on it. Xen is okay, it's not as good as the rest. But it ruins the pacing. Highly recommend this game. After you play the full series, you'll understand why we so desperately want a finale. The finale leaves you thirsting for more gun play, especially with your newest toy you got (The Gluon gun) So you can head out for deathmatch where all your shooting skills get put to the test against other players in servers with varying player counts. I wish good will to those who helped make this game. In conclusion, Half life is a really good experience, Half life 2 is on a whole nother level. The fast paced marine AI, THE SETPIECES, THE PERFECTLY TIMED MUSIC,GORDON FREEMAN, THE HEADCRABS, THE INTRIGUING PREMISE, THE G-MAN, THE CROWBAR. It's all iconic.

Half-Life is a science-fiction story about Gordon Freeman, who is a scientist working in a research facility, and is the stories' protagonist. One day, when Gordon arrives at the installation, an experiment is scheduled. Assisted by his colleagues, Gordon joins the experiment.

The world is seen from the protagonist's own viewpoint.
During play, the protagonist makes a continuous journey through contiguous environments, which drives the story onwards. The protagonist may be moved to travel in all directions, on foot, through liquids, or by vehicles. The protagonist may also wear and carry items, mostly firearms, protection, and tools.
The environments are interactive, and have hazards that must be overcome. The protagonist may fail, but progress is kept safe and allows continuation.

The protagonist may engage with various actors, who may interact with the environment and with each other, by making use of ingenious dialogue, or by talking to, or mentioning the protagonist. This interaction between these characters is immersive.
The protagonist controls direct, immediate, and precise, which is practical for aiming, navigating, and avoiding hazards.
Half-Life is inspiring, and can be played with others and modified. Install [i]Half-Life SDK[/i] from the [i]tools section[/i] in the [i]Steam library[/i], to gain access to the world-editor.

I played Half-Life 2 and the episodes for as long as I had been actually playing videogames, when I got it on the Orange Box with the original intent of playing Portal 2. I loved how it encouraged thought and using the environment in new and interesting ways in order to get past the forces in your path. I loved the story despite the missing portion of the Black Mesa incident having never played the original game.

About three days ago I sold an item on the marketplace for about $10.00 and I decided that I would pick up this game which has been a gap in my experience with the series, and shooters as a whole. I did not, and never will, regret that decision.

Half-Life still holds up despite its date of release in 1998, but not in a graphical or bugwise sense. It brings to the table that wonderful thought-provoking gameplay that encompasses everything from strategic planning and resource management, to quick well-honed reflexes and snap decisions. The troubles you face while battling through Black Mesa rarely give way to brute force, but instead to cunning, rational reasoning, and even some of the most outrageous and ridiculous "Hail Mary"s I have ever had the pleasure of conceiving.

If you can manage to get over occasional confusing level design and the [spoiler] frustrating, boring, and slow-paced Xen levels, [/spoiler] I'm sure anyone with the desire to spend 10-15 hours on this game (or more for replays) will have an excellent time.

For the best experience, play blindly, with no walkthroughs, on hard mode. It will get frustrating, sure, but remember there is always a solution. Finding these solutions is a source of immense satisfaction, fulfillment, and excitement. You will not regret the experience.
