Half Life is one of the most known shooters of all time. Half life is a story game where Gordon Freeman works at Black mesa and fucks up and causes a Resonance Cascade. You cannot forget the world of half life, the enemies, the allies, the maps, and last but not least, the guns. You can run Half life on everything most likely, just ask your mom to buy you something that a homeless guy offered you for 300 bucks and you could probably run this game. While Half life is probably older than you and me, it still holds up as an amazing game and if you haven't played it, please check it out. The world building in this game is insane and has a great story if you pay close attention. The guns in this game are fantastic to use and there are 14 different weapons to use. The allies in enemies are unforgetable with the Scientists, the Security Guards, The Imposing force/MECU Soldiers, Creatures from Xen, and even the Black ops soldiers. The game can be hard and it's very unforgiving and you have to stay on your toes throughout the whole experience. The gunplay feels amazing and still holds up to this day. Though, all amazing games have flaws. The Xen part of this game is extremely long and boring and the graphics suck balls. The overall graphics of this game are shit but still good for its time. A few parts in this game like on a rail can seem extremely boring and tedious. And sometimes the game breaks and does random shit.

Overall I'd say this game is currently a 79/100 but for its time a def 95/100. If you cannot bear the graphics I recommend playing Black mesa.

One of the greatest and most influential FPS games of all time. When it first came out Half-Life revolutionized the FPS genre. And still to this day, you can feel it's effects on many FPS games. Before Half-Life there was DOOM, Wolfenstein. These games were just about running and gunning. Half-Life changed that formula. You can see that in the opening section in the game. Half-Life slowed down the gameplay and added more elements. In Half-Life, you have to be tactical. You can't rush into every enemy otherwise you'll be dead before you know it. You have to use every tool in your arsenal to get out of tricky situations. Half-Life was a huge deal back then and now years later playing it feels really good. The soundtrack is good, weapons sounds are great and gunplay is amazing. Level design is superb. There are platforming sections, stealth sections, creepy sections, we have lots of variety. The story is well written, characters are memorable. Mysterious G-Man, security guard Barney, protagonist Gordon Freeman, everyone has a charm to them. Enemy design is great. Headcrabs, houndeyes, every alien has a distinct feature and distinct behaviour. This game was ahead of its time, and it shows. It really is a masterpiece and better than most of the FPS games come out nowadays. If you are a FPS game fan and haven't played it, you definitely should play it. Half-Life is and always will be every FPS lover's favourite game.

Half Life is a solid game and I wholeheartedly think this game is worth your time

But that aside, I'd just like to take a moment and appreciate the fact that this game is still accessible today. Think about it, a nearly 23 year old game can still be bought through official means, and still runs perfectly on modern hardware without workarounds. I can't overstate how much of a godsend this is, especially considering how other games from around that same time can't even be played nowadays without older operating systems or even older hardware in some cases. Hell, even games that came out way after Half-Life still sometimes have issues with modern hardware. Crysis can't even run on Windows 10 systems without workarounds, yet Half-Life just runs out of the box. Had this game not have been easily accessible, it wouldn't have as big of a legacy as it currently does 

So thank Valve for keeping your old games alive, If only more companies could do the same...

This game saved my life.

I am 32.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

I made the mistake of playing this after Half-Life 2, believing it would be a less stressful experience without the auto-imposed challenge of getting the correspondent Steam achievements. And yet, it showed me the difference between this and its sequel, and why in the end the second one sets itself as timeless beyond any present flaws.

I'm always keen on playing older games, and having only experienced this classic game recently, I can say I don't believe it to have aged all that well. Not because of any visual aspects, but because the combat encounters and puzzles aren't all that engaging or polished, even knowing them to be revolutionary at the time. 

Combat is of its time, of course, and because of that some of its flaws can easily be excused, given what it created. But the enemies require too much fire to be dealt with, contrary to your character, which can get killed relatively quickly. Thus, each encounter gets a bit frustrating, as you spend the time figuring out how to exploit the poorly aged mechanics and physics, and not exactly planning any combat strategy. 

The puzzle aspects of the game ‚Äîmeaning, levels where you have to navigate and/or activate something to progress‚Äî sometimes take too long to go through, due to the "junky" movement mechanics and sometimes confusing level design. In my playthrough, I've gone back and forth many times in several areas trying to figure out the solution to continue, not understanding the particulars of what I had to do, an aspect I think was much better handled in the sequel, without any hand-holding.

As such, I come back to my first paragraph. Maybe I shouldn't have played this after the sequel, even if I didn't hold it to the same standards, obviously. But I can see clearly now how, maybe not inventing as much as this first outing, the sequel still remains honestly timeless to this day, even in its mechanics.
Being this a binary system, I'll still recommend the game with these reservations. Definitely experience it for the universe it started creating and as an important piece of videogame history...

... and then, go play Half-Life 2 and subsequent episodes!

While some may state that the game has shown its age and is no longer visually appealing and enjoyable, I genuinely felt a sense of euphoria while playing the game.  The pacing of combat, environments, and story come together in tandem with a sense of needing to use your brain at times. It's a groundbreaking game that all FPS fans should play at least once. The story may feel a little scarce, but it's the least of your concern. This game's highlight stems from the environments and the unique aspect of what Valve has created - the entire game perpetually propelling you forward as you enter unique environments and combat scenarios non-stop. It's incredible, and I can't get over how much I love that and other things about the game.

However, I noticed one issue in some combat instances where you are facing enemies at medium to low health with little to no suit charge. At times, completion of several combat scenarios may be impossible; even on easy mode, it was genuinely challenging at times should you be in low health from a previous altercation. While this may be my issue with being "shit" or "bad," I beg to differ. I wouldn't recommend this on hard mode. The worst thing about Half-Life is the chapters set in Xen by far. The level design is a trainwreck, it's visually unappealing, and it contains some sloppy platforming and boring boss fights. The entire game is golden, save for Xen. Usually, when I finished Lambda Core, I'd power through to Interloper and eventually stop playing. However, as I said, the entire game is golden - save for Xen.

All in all, I recommend this game to anyone into First-Person Shooters or even those NOT into First-Person Shooters. It's a must-play and a unique experience that will not leave you disappointed.

Gameplay: It's similar to Quake 1 (the game uses a modded engine of Quake) and It's fun.

Story: It's pretty basic, but not bad at all.

Optimization: The game is pretty optimized for the mayority of 2000's devices, but if your PC doesn't support ''OpenGL'' then you'll need to play on ''software'' for the best performance.

Lenght: If it's your first playthrough the game can last up to 10-12 hours if you play it non-stop.

Graphics: Good for it's time, but it can make a kid vomit nowadays.

Gunplay: Pretty good, especially on multiplayer.

Multiplayer: It's good and balanced.

Difficulty:   Easy: child's play       Normal: balanced      Hard: somewhat challenging

Bugs: Never found a significant bug nor a game breaking one.

AI: Enemy AI is basic and can be very fun to fight with, but the friendly AI can get very stupid at some points of the game.

Soundtrack: It's awesome, especially if you like rock and old electronic music.

Modding community: There are awesome mods in the modding community.

One of the best old-school games out there.

It's hard to recommend this game, but I think it's at least worth playing for it's story and to see the progression of the FPS genre, as well as the Half-Life franchise as a whole. 

If you take anything away from this, know that YOU SHOULD SAVE YOUR GAME WHEN YOU CAN. I was on easy mode (relatively experienced with singe-player, story-driven FPS) and I still was frustrated when I ended up having to redo an entire gauntlet again. Constantly saving manually may be a pain, but it'll likely pay off when the game resets you behind multiple challenges you've already overcame.

The first half of the game is simple, solid, and well-told. I want to make it clear that there is a reason I recommend this game. Learning what gun to use for a given challenge, seeing the aliens pitted against the military, and even the goofy spies are all really fun things that make the game stick out and will be pretty memorable overall.

As for the second half of Half-Life: it felt messy, even before the infamous Xen levels. Hard-to-kill soldiers camping behind turrets, tanks that are a long series of peek-and-shoot, and platforming that is less than ideal makes the game's second half disappointing as well as frustrating. As for the Xen levels: they do have a lot of visual and stylistic creativity, but they're certainly frustrating from a gameplay perspective. I really only felt the need to look up a guide once I reached the final boss. 

I feel like knowing what's bad about a game can mentally prepare you and allow you to overlook those issues, ultimately enjoying the game more. Some of the issues might be deal-breakers for you, but if not: I think there's still fun to be had in this decades-old game.

[h1]HALF-LIFE[/h1]
[b]Originally a side project to [i]Prospero[/i] and used to be called [i]Quiver, Triphammer and Belly of The Beast[/i]. Valve eventually settled on [i]Half-Life[/i]

Set in the Black Mesa Research Facility in New Mexico USA, You assume the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a 27 year old Theoretical Physicist. One morning, Gordon is running late at 8:47 AM for his job in Sector C Anomalous Materials. An experiment goes wrong causing a Resonance Cascade leading aliens from a border-world called Xen to invade Earth and Black Mesa. Gordon must traverse the facility and avoid death from the HECU and Aliens to make it to Lambda Complex to stop the Invasion and save Earth in the immersive and heart-pounding action-adventure story that set the stage for a generation of first-person shooters.

I'd like to preface this with the context that I'm not some kid who wasn't even born when this came out, or someone who was exclusively playing console games, either; I was there in the thick of the First-Person Shooter craze from the first time I played Heretic at a friend's house.  I played a lot of the old "2.5D" Shooters back in their day, like the Dooms, Heretic, Hexen, Duke Nukem 3D, and Blood.  I'd even played at least one fully 3D Shooter by then, because I was [b]completely[/b] obsessed with Turok: Dinosaur Hunter in 1997, before Half-Life even came out.  Not that it has any place in a recommendation for someone just looking to get into a game, but nostalgia isn't a factor here, either; while I had at least one friend back in the day who WOULD NOT SHUT-UP about Half-Life, I was never interested enough to play it back then, and didn't get around to it until this year: 2021.  This is supposed to be one of the most influential and revolutionary games in its genre, and I thought, "Alright; I can put myself back in 1998.  I'm totally disinterested in that upcoming Dreamcast thing, that weird 'Pocket Monsters' thing I read about a while ago is really starting to pick up some steam, and I'd finally gotten deep into that Final Fantasy 7 thing I'd wanted to play since I'd found out that my beloved 1, 2, and 3 were actually 1, 4, and 6.  Not the best days of my life, but moderately interesting times for video games, at least."

Well, boy, am I glad to be back; I don't miss this era of Shooters AT ALL.  Half-Life throws a lot of cardinal sins of the genre at you: weird ladder controls, lots of platforming sections, tiny ledges, "gotcha" moments such as the floor (looking like any other) falls out from underneath you, long underwater sections with limited oxygen, AN ENTIRE MINE CART [b]CHAPTER[/b], and when that all isn't enough, they start throwing clusters of these at you simultaneously while you're being harassed by an attack helicopter.  It's also from that early 3D era, where you're not sure if borking the momentum algorithm to get onto that weird ledge was a glitch win or the intended route.  Beyond even that, this game is extremely buggy; I'd sometimes be going through a pipe and when the next area loaded, I'd be in the pipe, but spawned slightly off the ground, so I couldn't move and had to reload an old save, and this happened quite a few times.  Thankfully, this is old enough that quicksave was still a thing, because you'll be needing it, not always through any fault of your own.  Equally thankfully, this is new enough that mouselook also existed; horrid as I found the level design to be, the actual controls were pretty good.  You can look around, run, swim, and even jump relatively smoothly; I would've liked a way to zoom in while shooting with more than just one weapon, and the ability to make [i]walk[/i] the default instead of being stuck on autorun the whole game, but that might speak to my being spoiled a bit by modern convenience.  The weapons could've used a little more balance, too - a lot of guns are so useful that I'm always hurting for ammo, or so useless that their main use is wasting ammo until you can reload something better - but that wasn't bad, either; the shooting part of this Shooter was just fine.

But Mooooooom, it's all about the story!  Well, admittedly, the plot doesn't mess around; you get RIGHT into it pretty early in the game.  I was pleasantly shocked at how quickly things escalated, and then... nothing.  There was one minor twist in the middle that was very believable and well-executed - a lot of newer writing throws them at you like crazy in an attempt to mask the fact that the underlying narrative isn't all that interesting, and then just leaves them hang - but there was almost no plot other than "go here; do this" until the end of the game after that.  The NPCs are also often lauded as revolutionary, but the most you'll ever get out of them is very poor cover fire (they even act all triumphant when taking credit for monsters that [i]you[/i] killed) or acting as keys made of meat.  Visually, it's a lot of gray underground tunnels, which fits the scenario, but is still boring to look at; things get pretty interesting toward the end, but that's not the majority of the game.  The character models are... well, it's 1998; they're going to look a little blocky, but these are pretty good from what I remember of that era.  The sound design is mostly fine; the audio is programmed in such a way that you should be able to tell where an enemy is by where the sound is coming from, and it's [i]usually[/i] close.  There's almost no music, and I know that's supposed to be atmospheric and immersive; it wasn't for me, but it wasn't a dealbreaker, either, and when you did have music, it was usually pretty good, even if it'd stop before it should.

Half-Life does some interesting things, and there are some pretty neat moments, but for what it puts you through, it just isn't enough of a payoff.  If you're looking to get into the series, I'd recommend just watching someone else play through it.  Or don't; I've just started Half-Life 2, and even though I'm not that far, the game has done a great job of telling me everything I needed to know about the first game.

I have a complicated relationship with this game. I first played it years ago and only got a few hours in thanks to my frustration with it and, honestly, the desire to play anything else. After trying to get back into it an embarrassing amount of times since that first encounter - Half-Life's historical value was enough to keep me going, but only for a while - I finally hunkered down and played through the game start to finish. And... yes, I see why people love this game. I am now on the Half-Life 3 hype train.
If you are interested in the series at all, I recommend you start with this original version of this first game like I did. Yes, play the game as it was in 1998, not through Black Mesa and NOT through Half-Life Source. The graphics are dated, but most other things either haven't aged a day (like the sound, level design, and "feel") or haven't yet been fixed in newer versions (mainly, some agonizing combat sections). Again, Half-Life is important piece in history that is worth seeing in its original format, non-HD textures and all. Once you have a good baseline for the series, go ahead and enjoy Source and Black Mesa. But make sure you experience this game in all of its old-school glory.
But back to my story. When I first tried to get into Half-Life nearly four years ago, I had almost no experience with first person shooters. Nowadays, I do have games to compare Half-Life to, for better and for worse. I see how the Halo was inspired by the AI and level design of Half-Life and how 90's twitch shooters inspired the movement and arsenal of Half-Life. These comparisons made me appreciate the game, though they also made me wish for the Halo sandbox and the fast pace of the modern Doom titles. So, duh: Half-Life feels old. That's not a revelation, but it is worth saying because I made the mistake of playing Half-Life like it was Doom or Halo.
It wasn't until I beat the game and watched a couple videos about it that I learned that I might have been playing Half-Life wrong. Again, the reason I kept falling off of this game was because I just wanted it to be more like Far Cry 4. I was and still am frustrated with turrets that kill you in seconds, the incredible movement speed that makes platforming more than tedious, and the onslaught of aliens that keep me up at night. Those things are still problems, but if you take a second and plan out your encounters before going in guns-blazing, you might die a few million times less. Half-Life is all about tactics, not mindlessness. I was playing with the assumption that I had to think and shoot at the same time, but things work out a lot better if you think first and only then execute your 10th level plan. So while I personally hate to say that there is any "right way" to play a game, I believe there is with Half-Life. And I don't like that about Half-Life. Sure, you can technically get your way through the game playing like Master Chief, but let's just say that you won't have nearly as much fun as you would when playing like Gordon Freeman.
But all of this is to say that yes, you should play Half-Life. At the end of the say, it's awesome. It's frustrating, somewhat-dated awesomeness with a fantastic story that is fantastically told. You just might have to have some patience to supplement the awesomeness. Hope you like it!

Text boxes, and cutscenes. 1997, nobody had truly taken advantage of the medium. Reading was the information delivery system of the book, and cutscenes, the movie. Both mediums were built to be mainly used in a 3rd person narrative, but the media of video games could be much more immersive. Then, E3 1997, an alpha was shown. Quiver, or Half Life. The scientists would talk to YOU, using their voices, coming from them. Never, ever, EVER a break from the 1st person perspective, entering a new era for video games. 
     "Welcome to the black mesa transit system". This era begins in a tram, showing you around the facility. Many today call this cliche, while in fact, this is the game that started cliches. All ready it shows the beauty of the GoldSRC engine, and the source engine to come. It allows for huge areas, and while today its easy to tell it's fake, even the faking of the entire black mesa facility is impressive. Unforseen Consequences and Office Complex provide atmosphereic horror, but We've got hostiles is the chapter that cranks the action to 11. Blast pit to apprehnsion gives exploration and puzzles. (Residue processing isn't that good haha) Questionable ethics and surface tension provide stunning set pieces, and show the lore get more and more complex, including a plot twist about the staff if you pay attension. Yeah, xens garbage. 
     Ok, get out the reviews. The game is ten bucks for Christ's sake! I got the entire valve collection on sale for 13$, so yeah, just buy it!

I've had lots of fun playing this game, and i feel i should go ahead and review some stuff about it

WARNING MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS!

Starting off with the gameplay,
The gameplay is really fun, with many enemies to fight or get around. Most of these enemies i really like, such as the Soldiers.

The Soldiers are really fun enemies to fight, they can run about, shoot you with Rifles and Shotguns, Throw grenades, Use Turrets, and come down from Helis!, alone they are quite weak, but working together while focusing on you can make them a tough threat!

There's also another enemy I really like in this game!

The bullsquid is a Xen creature that can shoot out projectiles and charge at the player, but what i really like is the way you can deal with them. Bullsquids have a odd mechanic that allows them to smell things like meat, they can also be distracted by it and go eat it, which allows the player a chance to go through them. I also like how they will try to kill other xen creatures such as the annoying headcrabs ( Which i'll get to later ) which shows how even though they are enemies in a video game, they will still hunt xen creatures like some kind of predator.


But there's one enemy in this game i got a few problems with,

The headcrab is one of the most annoying enemies i've fought in a video game, they will leap at the player and take a decent chunk of your health, and though they can be killed and avoided easily, the level design is what makes them such a problem. They commonly spawn in dark vents that you can't see in, and sometimes they'll be waiting behind some boxes, Hell they can even be teleported in sometimes at random, which is real annoying.

Weapons: There's a good amount of weapons in the game, that all can be useful. I usually reserve my pistol for headcrabs and houndeyes, and use my shotgun on the vorts, there's still plenty more weapons, such as the many kinds of explosives, and alien weapons that can be good to use against the enemies.

Levels: There's plenty of levels in the game, which are mostly good, except for some like On a Rail, which is quite annoying for someone who's just played, but going through it again isn't that bad. The levels all have a nice layout for players to go through, with many tight and closed up areas, with boxes or areas to get behind, along with some nice enemy placement.

However, the level design goes to shit as soon as you enter the final levels,

F U C K I N G X E N : Xen is by far the worst part of this game, the levels are large, and take advantage of one of the worst parts of half life..Platforming, it just doesn't work, not only do you easily take fall damage, but your character is really slippery, which is mostly fine since you'll mainly be in combat in the game, but when platforming becomes a main focus!?

FUCK

One thing i also dislike slightly is how they messed up some of the enemies here

The vortigaunts: These guys are a pretty simple enemy, they charge up a high damage attack that you can't be avoided in a open area, but the player can avoid it by going behind cover quickly, which is good to do normally, since most of the levels are in areas with lots of cover, but in xen most of the area's are open, so you'll just get hit by the vorts bolt.

Xen also has something else aswell,


BOSS FIGHTS: There is a " boss " more early in the game but i consider it more of a level that you have to go through rather then a boss.
But anyways, now onto the ACTUAL bosses, which i consider really annoying and bad

Starting with:

The Gonarch: This bitch is one of the worst bosses in gaming i have ever faced, and i'll tell you why.

The first stage is the most fine, it tells you what it can do, and you can avoid it's attacks with general ease

The second stage though is pretty annoying, since now there's a large hole in the way that you can easily fall into, and if you manage to get on a ledge there, A PISS SUCKLING HEAD FUCKER will jump right out and get eat a nice chunk of your health. Another thing i dislike about the gonarch, is that i don't feel like i'm ever doing damage to it, it feels like i'm trying to shoot a moving wall  that spawns mini headcrabs and occasionally hits me aswell as shoot jizz to attack


Then there's the third stage, which is almost broken.
The gonarch is supposed to jump down into a arena like spot, but instead that ballsacked bitch just stood there waiting for me to jump down, and since it was in a cave it could shoot its cum at me (Which btw, does a fuckton of damage) and hit me to K.O me. Due to this i had to load over and over again, until it finally got down.


Now onto the final boss, which is not as bad:

The nihilanth: A giant fetus with a metal butt plug up it's ass. Fitting boss i'd say for the end of the game, The nihilanth is a boss that is...OK

First you have to shoot some crystals so it doesn't heal(Which a new player probably wouldn't know, and just assume the crystals to be scenery) and then you have to shoot it a bunch until it's head opens up

The nihilanth has two attacks, the first being an attack in which it shoots a bunch of purple projectiles, 

And then there's the second, which i think can be annoying if your new.
The nihilanth can shoot a giant green portal, which teleport's you to an area, that you have to get out, this area includes some enemies aswell as ammo for your weapons. So, what's the big deal?
The problem here is that if you don't know you can go behind the large pillars to stop the green portal, then GOD FUCKING HELL it's sucks ass to go back to the same area's again and again, for fucks sake i want to fight the boss!

But playing through this again would likely be more easier, so it's not that bad,

Then there's the part where it's head opens up and you gotta shoot it, the problem here is that now you need to go on these floating pads, which can't decide if they want to shoot you up to his face, or up the nihilanths fetus ass. which is the one thing that i believe ruins the fun of the fight, but aside from all that, i think it's an okay boss ( Hell of a lot better then the moaning headcrab milf )


In general i think this game is really good, even though the last few levels kinda suck, and The gonarch is satans ballsack visuallised it's  a real good game!

So, I decided to revisit this game again after my last replay, 15 years ago. Now, I'm not going to describe my gameplay experience because we all know that this game is a classic that everybody should play at least ones. Rather I will focus on the technical problems that I faced with the game playing it on modern systems. I need to mention that the game comes in its final version with installed HD-pack, introduced in HL: Blue Shift. This means that the Glock, the MP5 and the shotgun are reskinned to Beretta, M16 and SPAS.     
 First, I couldn't start the game with the desktop shortcut after I installed it on Windows 7. I've manage to start it with the launch button from the game's library page. After checking the video options I've decided to play on 4:3 resolution 1024x768 because if I tried to play on higher resolution or widescreen the game crashes. This didn't bother me because my monitor can change in 4:3 mode. I didn't experienced any bugs when playing it except few crashes when I tried to Alt+Tab.
 Surprisingly the game ran better on Linux. The game official support is only for Ubuntu, so maybe that‚Äôs why I didn‚Äôt managed to launch the game directly on Manjaro. I didn‚Äôt bother to search for solutions before I try the Steam Play Compatibility tool. Running the game with latest available Proton 5.13-6, at the time, was good. Honestly, I think that the compile was too good. The game launched in its default 4:3 ratio without the need to manually adjust my monitor. It ran on both ratios with all resolutions but I chose to play on 4:3 ratio because the widescreen is just stretched 4:3. Even the lag was on the same places as I experienced the game for the first time back in 1999. It really lagged couple of times but I think that this is from the game itself and not from the Proton. No problems with Alt+Tab. The game crashed only ones when a Steam friend message me.
 I suggest to buy the Half-Life Complete bundle, when it's on sale.

Every now and then a game comes along that has such a significant impact on the gaming industry as to redefine a specific genre. While some genres remain relatively stable, few have seen as much innovation as that of the first-person shooter. This is probably because the genre is still fairly young, beginning with "Wolfenstein 3D" back in the day and then "Doom", which defined the genre and paved the way for other games which used the same formula. Most of these games were focused around navigating through corridors and shooting anything that moved with an assortment of weapons at your disposal. Sometimes keys would need to be acquired before moving on to the next area, usually through the deaths of powerful monsters holding or guarding them.

- Redefined The Genre :

Half-Life redefined the genre by doing things differently. Instead of mindlessly gunning down wave after wave of monsters, the game makes you think by impeding your progress through the application of several clever and dangerous puzzles instead of the usual locked door and key system that Doom started. In Half-Life, players are required to think on their feet and react quickly to enemies, which can teleport in randomly as well as blockade themselves in areas with lots of cover. Couple this with an intriguing story that is engaging and unfolds as you play without ever being truly revealed and you have on your hands the science fiction phenomena known as Half-Life.

- Another Normal Day In Black Mesa :

The Half-Life story begins with Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist and graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It is just an average day for the scientist, despite coming into work a little late. Today is the day he is scheduled to help the scientists in the research lab test a pure sample of some hazardous material of unknown origin. Upon setting the material in the test chamber however, things go horribly wrong, and the energy funneled into the material triggers a catastrophic "resonance cascade" event that not only destroys the lab, but opens a portal to another world that draws the attention of unfriendly aliens. Having survived the destruction of the labs, Freeman must make his way through the ruined Black Mesa complex in the midst of an alien invasion and try to figure out how to put a stop to it. Complicating matters are the U.S. marines, which have been given orders to kill anyone found at the labs.

- Mystery :

The first game in what would become an extensive series in an epic science fiction story, little tidbits as to what actually is going on are revealed as you play, leaving the player to discover the story as he or she progresses through the game. The end result is that several facets are still open to interpretation as the story is never fully revealed to Dr. Freeman (and thus, you, the player). Possibilities as to why the aliens are invading are hinted at, but never revealed, even as you face the mastermind behind the invasion at the end of the game. And then there is the enigmatic G-Man, who can be found behind the scenes occasionally as you make your way through the game. It is clear that he has had a hand in the events leading up to the resonance cascade, though exactly how or why is never revealed. There are many theories regarding the whole story behind the Half-Life series of games, and speculation among gamers of this popular series is rampant, leading more credence to the game's status as one of the legendary ones.

so basically i played this game because i wanted to play the other half-life games, but instead of making me excited for half-life 2, i became a lot more hesitant to start playing it. 

one of my main problems with this game is that the combat is very clearly split into two parts - a good part, and a bad part. when youre fighting the alien enemies, you can use the super-sonic speed that youve been given and its actually quite a bit of fun. when youre fighting the human enemies, however, the best strategy is to stand as far away from them as possible, since they literally cant hit you if youre too far away, but you can hit them. this leads to boring segments where you hide behind boxes until youre far enough away that you can shoot them without getting hurt. any attempt to take it fast paced will end up with you dying and it just isnt very fun at all.

my next big problem is that when i started playing it, i expected there to be a great story that comes with it, but this is only really partly true. there really are no characters, only blank slates that you run into during your time in the facility. the main character has no personality, which is fine on its own, but combined with the 0 other characters you actually makes it seem hard to care about the story aspect of the game. the most well developed character in the game isnt even a character, but rather the character of the government, which leads to the part of the story that i actually liked a lot: the way it tells the story. if youre not talking to a random scientist or some stupid security guard who tells you what to do and where to go, your main source of story telling is the environment. theres never an explanation (or at least one that i cared enough to listen to) about how anything happens or how it works, it's just there for you to see play out, which i really liked. this part is kind of a spoiler, but happens at almost the start of the game [spoiler] but the game never tells you how the "zombies" are made, it just shows you the head crabs and then later shows you the human with a head crab on its head. [/spoiler] There are many more examples of this kind of storytelling that i really like that i wont go over, but its pretty rare to see that in games.

all in all, it got me to finish it, which isn't very common tbh, but i think that mainly has to do with the fact that i wanted to play half-life 2 after.

This game has the same immersive value that it did when I was a much younger man. I'm now a 40-something, and I remember when this game was new and the Valve games cemented their legacy with a combination of great visuals, intuitive controls, and excellent storytelling. For me, it was one of the moments where the storyline value of your average Roberta Williams text-entry game on a 386 met the intensity of the FPS world brought into fruition by Apogee/Id. Here I am, reviewing it as a guy with a career and kids and my adult son and my teenager both played the Half Life games. The only reason I can see not to recommend this game emphatically is if you just have a distaste for the sci-fi dystopia genre or FPS games in general. And, to call it either of those things is reductive. It has a synergy I don't have the words to articulate. Play it.

Original Review: A pioneer in the FPS genre, Half-Life still holds up today. Except for On a Rail. 
And Xen. Fuck Xen.
But it's still a great game otherwise and I recommend you buy it.

Retrospective Review: I should go over what makes this game great.
The visuals, while somewhat dated, are great. The artstyle is semi-realistic, yet cartoony, and the animations nicely reflect this. The enemy variety is great, with annoying enemies to easy enemies, to thought-provoking enemies.
The levels are the most contentious part of this entire game, most of the campaign is solid. However a few chapters near the middle and end end up feeling stale. Not bad, just mediocre.
The deathmatch is rock solid though, no contest. And the modding support is second to none.

This was my very first 3d shooter game. I remember playing this as a 9 year old on my cousin's PC and I told myself this is the most realistic game I had ever seen. The most horrifying experience I ever had was encountering the alien possessed scientist for the first time and all I had was my pistol. It felt that I was actually holding my gun and I was fighting for my life. And I remember dying a couple of times.  Bear in mind, it was 1999 and the only games I was exposed to was Super Mario and Contra. 

After playing for the first time, I had dreams about this game. I thought about this game all the time during breakfast, school time, homework and at bed. I didn't have a computer like my cousin's so I told myself when I would grow up, I will get a job and buy myself a computer with Half Life and that's it, I will be settled for life. Again bear in mind, I was 9 at that time.

Fast forward, 20 years later, I download this and play it, and my impressions are this (and I am trying to be unbiased while having my nostalgia goggles off ), the graphics and gameplay mechanics are way too outdated, the shooting is mediocre and I can kill that alien scientist with my eyes closed. So if you got into gaming very late, played all the AC, Far Cry, GTA, all those  high budget AAA games and then playing this, and thinking "I don't get why this game is great", I get it, I feel the same way at times, its too outdated. Its amazing how the games have come so far, considering I once thought Half Life had the most "realistic graphics" ever.

So, would I recommend this game ? Hell, yes. 

Tbh, I'm just playing it for nostagia's sake, but as I play it, I can't help but feel some of the things this game did right that we don't see in today's games, the setting. the mood. the tone of the environment. Its just a mix of horror, anticipation,excitement, you have no idea whats going to happen in the next room, and it all happen in real time, in first person, in your perspective. No cutscenes, no in game movies. You don't see that many games do that today, and that is what makes me appreciate Half Life.
This game will still be forever in my heart as one of the best games ever made.
My cousin is no more. R.I.P. Thank you for introducing me to such a game and making my childhood bright, whether you intended it or not.

With loads to do, ammo to find, puzzles to solve, items to investigate and Aliens and Solider's to kill. This game still has it for me. If you don't mind classic Wolfenstein type graphics I know your love playing this. Have to say although the graphics aren't great, since the release and a few updates its not that bad, the game is very playable. Have fun guys life's to short not to enjoy every second.

A video game classic. How have you NOT played this game?

Unfortunately, I can only regard this game with respect to the extremely nostalgic memories I have of this game. Seeing this game for the first time in the 90s after playing DOOM for the last few years, just *blew me away!* Valve had the marketing term "soft-skin technology" that explained the smooth animations of its character's movements, particularly their mouths flapping during dialog, and it was incredible!

To this day, nothing can compare to playing mods on HALF-LIFE, particularly this one mod you may have heard of: TEAM FORTRESS CLASSIC. TFC was one of the first games I remember playing where, I'd start playing early in the evening - and 30 minutes later, the sun is rising outside. Good heavens! The *one more match* mentally hit me hard those nights. Back when us gamers were doing things on computers that have never been done before.

For the kids nowadays, I'm unsure if this game will be nearly as appealing as it is to me. There are some aspects of the game that will more than likely be frustrating for the younger generation of gamers. (I'm looking at YOU ladder physics!)

Old Nostalgy trip, taking you back to 1998.

The steam edition of the game nowadays, changes the menu of the game to what was modern when Steam released. Games like Counter-Strike 1,6 Standalone and Half-Life 2. I miss the old menu of Half-Life one. Even though you can mod it back to the game if you wish it. You know, just for that nostalgic feeling when game was released and you booted it up the first times you played through it.

Other memories I have for this game is that just like with Quake II, I did not have a 3D card in my computer.
So I had to run it in the beginning, in software mode on a computer that could barely run it. Sizing down the resolution window so it wasn't larger than most people's smartphones nowadays in size.

Then of course when I did get myself a Voodoo 2 3DFX card, I did play through the game properly again, including Opposing Forces. Writing this review though, I still never played through Blue Shift. However, I did mod the crap out of the game, mainly all the weapons. The game also has tons of single player missions crafted by fans. Downloading the Quake Army Knife editor (or QArK) it was super easy creating levels for the game. Including everything else that ran on the Quake Engine.

Last thing I do also remember as 1998 was a Pirates Paradise, a lot of people did not buy the games for PC, they just copied or cracked them to run without the CD. Which is also the entire reason Steam was created in the first place to prevent. But Half-Life had an immensely difficult copy protection to crack back then. I took a long time to be able to make a proper copy of it's CD that the game came on. I did it, eventually. But I was 14 at the time.
But then, I loved the game so much I did also buy it once I could afford it. When I got a little bit older =)
It was the collection with Opposing Force, Blue Shift and Counter-Strike 1,6 included.

So, let's with the game itself then:
Why was it so spectacular when it was released. It is mix of Duke Nukem 3D and Quake 2. So why? What made it unique? 

It was simply the games AI for NPC's in it. And the sense of realism in everything.
Unlike Duke and Quake, the game did not encourage you to just run and gun. It was more about learning how the aliens behave, think before you shoot. You really don't even need to kill everything that moves in it. It has puzzles based on physics, although a very rudimentary one at the time. Move boxes to get where you need to go. I loved the guns in the game, that at least tries to look like real world existing ones, unlike every other game that pretty tends to go crazy in that regard and you don't even know what it is your'e holding.
In Half-Life the Glock, the SPAS shotgun, the H&K MP5 and last but not least the 356 Magnum.
This game was first with that.

I mentioned the AI as one of it's main points, and it is because it was very easy to develop path findings for them, they were smart enough to interact with you and objects in the world in a manner no other First Person Shooter ever did before. They help telling the story in a way that no previous FPS ever has. It usually was either always you and the bad guys. Or like games like Myst, that didn't have any NPC's at all. Or it it had to be like games such as Pandora's Directive, Tex Murphy with pre rendered movies. Or strictly scripted evens such as Monkey Island point and click adventures had. There were no fluidity to the NPC's, they did not react to random events.

They did, in Half Life. The game begins in a tram, a sort of railway system. You can watch a lot of things they scripted for the AI there in the short moments fore the game really starts. Enjoy it, it will be the calm before the storm. The moments where the guard walks up to you when you leave the tram, is nothing special. He talk to you, he has a strict scripted event where he opens the door for you. Even though Half-Life is the first shooter game you ever saw such things. People, in the game. Interacting with you, talking to you. You can even hit the use button on him and he has more things to say. You can visit the kitchen later on and destroy the microwave, and the NPC's sitting there will react to it.
But here it get's more interesting, you can lead them, take them with you once the game starts and you're trying to reach the surface of the facility you're in. And let's say it's a scientist, they don't react well to danger. They will run and hide. Promptly refuse to follow you further with an outspoken reaction. They will help you open doors with the retina scanners etc. So will the guards. The guards will also fight together with you against opposition. Completely unheard of in any previous game before this was released.

The other thing that gave the sense of realism was it's environment. An science complex deep underground but it looked plausible. Believable. Until you get to Xen that is the game becomes more like it's old school predecessors. Xen a very small part of this game however. The Aliens home world.

The game itself was created in small parts together with ID software. How else did Valve get hold of Quake 2 code and was able to implement it in this heavily modified iteration of the ORIGINAL Quake engine. That back in the day did not even have 3D hardware support. So yes, Half-Life started out using the Quake 1 Engine. (Which is why you can use QArK to build maps for it) It's heavily modified to the part where it makes even Quake 2 feel outdated in comparison.

The game had 10 of 10 Graphics for it's time.
10 of 10 Sound design.
10 of 10 Game play.
The story of the main game was also quite long for it's time. Takes you about 8-10 hours if you have no idea where you're supposed to go or do. Took me 7 hours now to run through it.
And then of course the Multiplayer aspect that took the world with storm. The realistic weapons compared with the futuristic ones. The movement of the player, provided a quite different pace than Quake did.
Think, before you shoot mentality replaced run and gun.

It spawned ideas to a game pretty much everyone, even those who doesn't even play games have heard of.
Counter-Strike.

And CS wasn't even the first, but only one of many modified versions of Half-Life. The modding community is still strong today. Despite Half-Life 2's release with it's own Source Engine. Half-Life still has a place in a lot of peoples hearts.

However with a small warning for younger people who is used to modern graphics. This game has not aged very well and may give you a feeling of what all the fuss is about. Although, reading this review I hope it sheds some light on that.

This game is still a 10 out 10 in my book.

[h1] I left this game unfinished more than 15 years ago. But today, I finally finished Half-Life. [/h1]

[No spoilers but if you ever want to try this out for the first time without any prior knowledge or opinions about it, ignore this]

The farthest I've gone back in the day was "Blast Pit."After that chapter, everything was foreign to me. And when I was younger (and more impatient), I remember using a cheat code‚Äîwhich I have now forgotten‚Äîto skip everything and jump straight to "endgame" to see the ending. Even so, I vaguely remember some scenes of the first few parts. So I experienced most of the game for the first time.

Half-Life is an immersive first person shooter that offers more than just shoot 'em up gameplay. There's a lot of problem-solving to accomplish and platforming to perform. It also doesn't put you in a position where you always have to clear out your enemies. Sometimes you have to find an exit as quick as possible or stay away from certain rooms or areas. 

I seriously recommend going into this game blind if you're jumping into it for the first time, which means avoiding walkthroughs and playthroughs. Half-Life is highly enjoyable to experience for what it has to offer. The combat can be fast-paced, the jumpscares are still thrilling (for me, at least), and the constant thinking of how to get from one point to the other can be frustrating but rewarding once you get there. Some tasks can be challenging at certain points but the only times I really had to lookup stuff online was when I forgot what to do after a month-long or week-long break from playing. For every anxious moment the game throws at you, it also gives you those huge moments of relief and satisfaction once you get things done.

The story is simple enough to understand and doesn't need a lot of explanation. But even with its simplicity and straight-forward storytelling, it still managed to pique my interest. I will admit that the latter parts were a bit underwhelming. And I can't really say that the overall story was memorable. Nevertheless, Half-Life is worth playing even just for the narrative.

I don't necessarily know if this game pales in comparison to newer ones, because I also stopped playing video games around 13 years ago‚Äîalmost as long as the last time I played Half-Life. Returning to gaming at 30, I'm still impressed with 2000's era graphics of Half-Life. I'm aware that this is an updated version and there are recent remakes of this title. But what I'm trying to say is that it looks better than ever and feels just as fun as it was when I was younger.

With that being said, I'm glad that I revisited Half-Life and I'm highly satisfied to have finally finished it.

Fantastic game even after all this years. It was certainly ahead of its time. Other than its graphics the game has aged gracefully; I now understand why it earned its spot as a cult classic of PC.

Excellent story; the game manages to build a compelling atmosphere that is memorable. The story is told through gameplay, not cutscenes. Shooting and enemy AI have nothing to envy modern games; the gameplay overall still very solid. Movement feels a bit slippery, but it does not impact playability. The graphics hold up better that I expected, but this is where the game shows its age the most; the atmosphere and other details do make up for it.

The level design is organic and creative; plenty of subtle details. Most of the game feels like one big thing, even though you are constantly going to new zones. The puzzles are challenging; the game does not hold your hand; this is from back when you did not have a marker on the screen telling you what to do and where to go; you have to listen to the game to figure things out and move forward.

Half-Life is old; if you cannot stand "retro" games, then it will be too dated for your enjoyment; however, if you can change between modern and old games without issue, then it's definitively still worth playing.

[i] This next part assumes you've played the game [/i]

[spoiler] I particularly liked the assassin segments. The way they take place in these huge sprawling areas with tons of artificial corners for the assassins to hide behind, and the way the echoey nature of the areas provide both an advantage and a disadvantage. For one, you can easily hear any footsteps the assassins make, but it also means your own footsteps overlap, potentially confusing yourself. Even after you've taken out every assassin in the area, there's no real way for you to know, so you end up tiptoeing around the area with your finger jittering over your mouse waiting to get hit. It's great that in the second and last assasin section you're forced to go up on the catwalks yourself since the assassins can't get down, meaning that if you camped with explosives like I did, you have to switch up your playstyle. Half-Life isn't just a seminal masterpiece that has brought on an entirely new era of gaming, The formula of Run, Shoot, Think. Compounded by the interesting setting, the superlative gun-play and movement, the enemy design, and the confounding multi-faceted, nuanced, and multi-perspective story and lore, make Half-Life a game that has aged like a fine wine, a truly timeless piece that anyone who enjoys games should play. 

If it ended at that though, I wouldn't be writing this review.

Half-Life spawned an entirely new formula for making games that others have replicated countless times, it has influenced countless mods that would go on to become their own franchises, games, or have influenced others to make great games. 

If you play or have played any modern shooter, any story driven first person game, or a game that was based on the engines that facilitated Half-Life, its sequels, and its mods, you have this game to thank, it was the first true story driven shooter.

Its our obligation to recognize greatness when it is present, and this game oozes it in spades.

So, I recently reviewed Half-Life: Source, the absolutely ABYSMAL Source-run "remaster" of this excellent game. In turn, I'd like to give a review to the original, just to be fair.
Half-Life came out at a time where I had yet to exist. The benefit of Steam and the internet existing is that I don't have to miss out on all these old phenomena that were around when I wasn't alive yet.
Half-Life is one of those experiences that I was very happy to finally play for myself.
I do want to be clear - this game still has flaws. While I feel it isn't always right to judge a game by the standards of a different time, I do also believe that the ability of a game to age over time is important nonetheless. Graphically, Half-Life aged... not so well. Unfortunately, as I stated in my Half-Life: Source review, the official Valve "remaster" wasn't really so much of a "remaster" as it was an over-glorified port. That being said, nostalgia can come into play here. Some may not vibe with looking at every triangle on a model when they play a game. You may not like how pointy the G-Man's chin is. But to be honest, while the game's visuals haven't aged great, they aren't bad. 
Graphics aside, the gameplay is very nice. The running is a bit fast for comfort at times, but the physics engine and combat are very nice, especially considering the time that the game released. Some puzzles can be finicky sometimes, and while game-breaking glitches are something more common in Half-Life: Source, I still occasionally got soft-locked behind blast doors (which is intentional game design, to be fair to Valve here), and there was one point where I needed to supply power to a tram, and it still did not function even after enabling all sources of power (I reset my game save several times and it eventually worked out of nowhere). But this was one minor flaw in an otherwise stellar experience.
The story is simple. It's not overplayed, and it doesn't take the forefront. It gets the player invested while giving the gameplay the reigns and letting it do the talking. It sets up an amazing universe that the remainder of the games take place in, and I cannot recommend it more.
Play Half-Life.
And when you do, make sure it's this version and not the Source port.
P.S., while I praised the physics engine, the platforming is kind of bad. Get used to dying from a long fall. It's a good thing this is a first-person shooter.
An amazing experience, and a classic in video game history. Most definitely recommended.

Don't get me wrong, this game is really, really fun, but there's quite a list of things wrong with it. Imagine a game with fall damage, now times the fall damage taken from falling by 10, then times it by 69420 and you'll get about the fall damage you have in half life. Oh? You barely fell off a ledge? Time to remove 75% of your health! It's incredibly difficult in lots of situations, even on medium mode. It autosaves at some really bad times, and sometimes you might even get stuck in an infinite loop of reloading and dying (although uncommon it isn't unheard of). I would've been able to brush past all that and my review would've been a yes but the final nail on the coffin is how bloody hard it is to figure out what it wants you to do, you have to go through all these different possible solutions to finally get a result that moves you onto the next stage for the cycle to repeat. 4/10

I just can't get behind it, and this really pains me to say because I ABSOLUTELY loved HL2 and it's episode expansions (HL2 is also one of my favorite games of all time too, I played it like religiously on my old 360 when I was in 6th grade). I understand how revolutionary HL1 was for the FPS genre and I really respect it for that. But the game is really showing its age imo. I was really into HL1 when I first started it and played through the first few chapters (especially when you first got the HEV suit and that catchy theme started to play) but once I reached about close to mid way in, I just couldn't play it anymore.

Aside from the large and confusing environments (that barely give you any indication on where to go), the terrible platforming (I can't tell you how many times I died by falling off of a ladder because Gordon just wouldn't cling to it properly from a jump), that dreadful section with the green 3 tentacle monster (this part can burn in hell, the sneaking mechanics didn't even work properly), the terrible enemy placement (There's literally a section where you're going up on a lift and 3 soldiers begin to immediately shoot at you without warning, and you can't even properly take cover during this section. This was pretty much it for me.),and just the extreme difficulty in general (I was playing on normal and would get destroyed in most fights, and the fights I would survive I would be low on health. And I felt like the soldiers were just too op. Not only would they always be super alert to you to the point where you'll literally come around a corner and they'll fire at you instantly, but they would also hit you with perfect aim 90% of the time too. Hell, they can even one hit kill you with a grenade. They would also usually charge at you too and rush you. At that point, you would just have to pray and hope you'll kill them before they kill you.).

So yeah, I just couldn't get behind HL1. And that really saddens me because like I said above, I really loved its sequels.

I know what the thumbs say and how dare I say no to our Lord, but hear me out. 

This was a testing ground for a game that would later become Half-Life 2. You get context as to what is going on to catch you up for Half-Life 2, but that's about it. There are no interesting characters, the controls have a little slipperiness (likely trying to simulate how you can't just STOP walking in real life), and the gunplay got pretty boring afterward. 

It has 0 replay value, but if you want to know the story behind Half-Life, just pick up Black Mesa. From what I hear, it's a faithful recreation and the footage I've seen doesn't hurt my eyes if I look at it for more than 20 minutes. 

I guess it's cool that levels don't feel like levels. It's a big complex you run around in, scarcely seeing the outside except for a handful of times, and the loading screens are short enough. I want to like Half-Life 1, but I can't say I do. 

It's dated, so I'll give it some credit.

The original Half-Life trilogy will forever be my favorite set of games, and the first game really sets the tone.  What makes Half-Life such an amazing game is it's ability to tell a story with the environment itself instead of a traditional script.  Some of what you learn about Black Mesa is from the dialog you hear from scientists, security officers, and soldiers, but the majority of what you learn comes from just wandering around and observing the space.  Black Mesa is a real living facility.  Ultimately, with Half-Life valve created the ultimate dungeon crawler that no-one realizes is a dungeon crawler.

While it is really showing its age at this point, Half Life is a classic that keeps drawing me in with its brilliantly immersive atmosphere, memorable levels, unique weaponry, and satisfying gameplay.

There are admittedly some pretty frustrating aspects at times like slippery movement, a bad crosshair, ladders being annoying to climb, clunky platforming, getting stuck on terrain, tedious bosses, or dealing with annoying enemies.

In the beginning, for every one thing I liked, there was one thing I really despised. Even then, it still felt very satisfying to overcome a challenge that had me constantly reloading save files, though the game does badly grind to a halt when you spend too much time trying to beat a level.

However, the game has become far more enjoyable over time as I improved my mechanical skill and grew wiser in my playstyle, with most of my frustration fading away. 


Half Life is really at its best when you're immersed in the environment of Black Mesa and cruising through every challenge in your way, feeling like both a genius and a badass as you overcome your obstacles with a mix of strategy and skill. 

The weapons are really fun to use and are well balanced, with most of them feeling powerful in different circumstances. I also really like the variety in gameplay with various enemies that require different approaches, as well as puzzle solving, and platforming. You never really do the exact same thing for too long, before Half Life changes it up.



Even when you are just walking through Black Mesa, you're always travelling through areas in unusual ways, rather than just walking down hallways, shooting enemies. While the levels themselves are quite linear, the way in which you travel through them can feel less linear. This variety of gameplay and traversal really makes Black Mesa feel like a character within the game, as an oppressive, claustrophobic labyrinth, filled with danger.


Thanks to the solid variety throughout the game, I don't really get bored in Half Life, unless I am stuck retrying the same level.



Lastly, regarding the story of Half Life, while I don't find it particularly good, it was always compelling for me. The story is really carried by the brilliant way in which the game immerses you in its world and makes you live through the chaos. You aren't just witnessing the events that transpire, you're living through them.

Despite the barebones nature of the story, I felt like I was on an exciting rollercoaster ride and wanted to see what would happen next. This immersive storytelling, in combination with the atmospheric setting of Black Mesa, really invested me into a story and world that I would have otherwise never cared about. For what is such a basic story, the execution is remarkably good.




Half Life may not be for everybody, but for anyone who enjoys shooters I would recommend trying out this iconic, influential shooter and seeing what it has to offer.

Half-Life, a game 22 years old of writing, has a lot to be said about it, and a lot has already been said. If you somehow you haven't even heard of Half-Life or the series as a whole on a platform like Steam, then clearly you truly have been living under a rock, and have a hell of a lot to catch up on.

It's masterpiece of its time, but is extremely dated when playing it in the modern era. Obviously while graphics shouldn't define the gameplay and story of a game, it's very clear nowadays it's a game that when it came out, was revolutionary in the way it looked and acted. Even with that said, Half-Life is a game full of story telling, and people would happily argue it was a turning point for not just all story driven games, but the way a game should feel, act and play out. A timeline of games being Before Half-Life and After Half-Life. 

You can look anywhere on the Internet and see it is full of videos going over the vast and deep lore of the entire Half-Life franchise, speculations, anticipation for new games, lost projects, speedruns and so much more.

The game is less than ¬£10, and even though it may seem a smidge bit pricey for a 22 year old game, it's a must play to understanding a structural foundation for the games you love to play today.

One thing however, while the new Black Mesa game may look more promising to play, running on the Half-Life 2 source engine, with more up to par graphics, you must play the original first. The dialogue, references and general information will not make sense unless you play the original 1998 version.

Half-Life was a game that took the world's attention, and helped lay the foundations to the games you love and admire today.

Doom. Quake. Super Noah's Ark 3D. These are the games that defined shooters in the 1990's. In these games, you were running around, blowing up shit, usually with a vertically locked camera and extreme violence. The draw of these games was that they were new. In the 1980's video games were looked at as kids' toys with all the bright colors and the jump mans and all that jazz. But when Doom came out, the audience for gaming changed. Now it wasn't just your little brother running around and stomping on Bowsers or whatever, you were out there shooting guys in the face, blood everywhere. The thing you have to understand about these types of games, though, is that they weren't very subtle, and they weren't very pretty. They offered little in the way of plot and the levels often felt like labyrinthine mazes to navigate after all the shooting and the blood was over. The gameplay boiled down to shooting guys and then walking over their corpses until you got a key. Half-Life didn't do that. Half-Life gives you a goal within the first few minutes and makes it clear how hard it's gonna be to get there. Immediately you're thrown into combat encounters where you actually have to think about spacing, learn enemy attack patterns, and make every move count. Now, a modern gamer playing this game would be deterred not only by the graphics, but by the dated gunplay. I know that I certainly was at first. But the game honestly began to grow on me. While it takes a while to get used to, mastering Half-Life's combat is a deeply rewarding experience. In the beginning, you're put into the role of a scientist named Gordon Freeman whom no one really likes. You're seemingly always late, your coworkers talk down to you, and your job is to push a cart of magic alien stuff into a laser beam. But as the character of Gordon Freeman gets stronger, so too does the player. It's a game where you're constantly learning new things, having to navigate new scenarios, and getting new weapons in a supremely satisfying feedback loop. By the end of the game, everyone else in the facility that you're trying to escape from begs for your help and heralds you as a hero. This narrative connection to the protagonist is what makes Half-Life's sparse story so potent. It's truly a case of one man against the world, and you are going to die a lot in this game. But scraping by those tough combat encounters with only five health points remaining is tense and rewarding in a way not a lot of other games are, and I respect it for that. The final boss, while really mediocre, serves as a serviceable climax to the game. It's difficult to end video games, and throughout the game I felt like the quality just kept increasing. I was bored in the first few hours, but once I really got into it and learned the ropes of the combat and physics, I started to love it. Overall, I would recommend this game to anybody who loves shooters or is just curious to see how Valve started out. Peace and love, fellows and fellettes.

A half-life usually describes the decay of discrete entities, such as radioactive atoms. In that case, it does not work to use the definition that states "half-life is the time required for exactly half of the entities to decay". For example, if there is just one radioactive atom, and its half-life is one second, there will not be "half of an atom" left after one second.

Instead, the half-life is defined in terms of probability: "Half-life is the time required for exactly half of the entities to decay on average". In other words, the probability of a radioactive atom decaying within its half-life is 50%

First off let me say that I went into this game thinking: "I already know how the second game ends, but I'll play this anyways. What the heck. I got it in a bundle for 24 bucks, and it included ALL the others. Might as well start with the original".

Let me just say that I went in expecting something good. Maybe I had my expectations a little to high.
But this game is just amazing.
Can I say that it's one of the best games I've ever played? If you took away the nightmare that was Xen, then yes.
The thing I loved the most about Half-Life is how much variety and content there was in it. The beginning was a bit slow, but when things picked up, they REALLY picked up. Each area felt new and exciting. Every part from the labs to the above ground areas, even the monstrosity of game design that was the alien planet was an amazing place to be in. The amount of places that are in Half-Life were so numerous that it really felt like a long journey. And don't even get me started on the ingenious scripted events. Those were what carried the immersion for me. I would have been bored out of my skull watching the events that unfolded as cut scenes, but making them live and in front of you just made it so much better.
I only really have two things that ruined the game:
First is the fact that if you manually save instead of letting the game auto save, you can just kind of prance around and load the save game over and over before you end up beating the level. That was my own fault, but to new players, I'd recommend using auto saves until you reach Xen, then  save every 5 seconds. Trust me. [spoiler] Especially during the final boss [/spoiler].
Second, I looked up how to beat the game with walk through videos and guides. DON'T DO THIS AT ALL UNTIL YOU GET TO XEN. PLEASE don't look things up, I am BEGGING you. Once you reach the alien planet, use as many guides you can get your grubby little hands on, because it's by far the blemish on the finely polished car. Just take my word for it and try to figure stuff out for yourself.

This game is a classic for a reason. My experience with the original Half-Life started with the words "It came out in 1998, it can't be that good." and I was completely incorrect. While the scientists and security guards are more funny nowadays than immersive or realistic, I still enjoy the campy 'science voice' the VA uses for them (Coomer is of course a highlight). This game pretty much laid the foundations for every good first-person shooter following its release- both in narrative and gameplay- and this is for very good reason. You ARE Gordon, you can listen carefully to what the scientists have to say and try to save as many of them as possible (lol) or you could completely ignore them and shoot every scientist and security guard in the face mid-exposition dump and figure it out on your own. Everything you do in this game you do as yourself. Gordon never takes control away from you, there is never any text on the screen that tells you what to do, there is no minimap or compass or objective reminders, just "Hey that scientist said something about the generator before I got bored and shot him in the face, I'll head there". The design in Half-Life (and hopefully its sequel) is extremely refreshing to play in today's climate, and is really an extremely fun romp through a destroyed lab and a fun little apocalyptic scenario to boot. This is a must-buy for anyone who has not played it and certainly a library essential.

I carried a security guard through a decent amount of chapters. He was my best friend during those times of desolate tragedy at black mesa. Frequent stops to  vending machines, discussion of whether or not I saw his last shot, asking to buy me a beer. Good times.
             
After rescuing a few straggling scientists in office complex, I turned around to find my best buddy... Slaughtered, on the tiled floor, by a lone head crab.
                 
In an unstable and deteriorating mental state, I bombarded that bastard of a head crab with my shotgun, pistol and all of my grenades, until I was entirely out of fire power.
                 
After about a week, my nerves had been recovered to a point that I could continue and play the game again. As I reluctantly passed though chapter 6, I was being followed by a few scientists. I needed as much company as I could get to keep moving on. I'm not sure what I did, or what sort of fate this game had led me into, but I suddenly came to my senses, as all three of the scientists went off script and exclaimed "STAHP" in perfect unison, in the dead center of a hallway. That word was burning in my mind. I was having office complex flashbacks. These three were trying to tell me something. I immediately ran. Bolting so fast that the scientists eventually stopped following me, as I carelessly left them in the distance. Despite how many others where counting on my to get the the surface, I was heading back down. I just couldn't bare to continue.
             
Once I got back down to the offices, I found all of the tables, crates, and movable items I could find, and I made the most beautiful grave you could imagine. It might have just looked like some oil drums, crates and a small box for a headstone, but I'm sure my long lost security guard would have had the utmost respect and appreciation for our existing friendship. 
            
He never bought me that beer he said he would, he gave me something so much more. An emotion and depth to a game that so many new modern gamers will never get to experience. A connection, and story with an NPC, as such I had, with my beloved security guard.

*I cried*

This game deserves all the praise and high status it deserves, it's amazing. While combat itself is serviceable and overall just standard FPS combat (with some admittedly original and cool weapons), it's the story, the characters and the world building that make this game as awesome as it is. The fact that the game's "cinematics" and story moments are always from Gordon Freeman's perspective and you never let up control of him during these, gives HL that edge, the seamless trip from the Hazardous Materials lab all the way to the alien world of Xen is fantastic, it's a phenomenal game that anyone with a PC should play. While it does have some incredibly dull, slow, confusing and infuriating moments (mainly the "On a Rail" and Xen chapters) they still don't take away the fact that the rest of the package is a pure, unadulterated genius 90s shooter that has a lot more to it than meets the eye

I'm hesitant to write a review for this game, as, by current day's standards, it doesn't hold a candle to other games of its genre. However, even now, more than 20 years post the release date, Half Life's gameplay is solid. it has elements that one can still find in recently released games, and it is nice to see that this game, together with other titans of its time, has such a profound influence on what we know and love to play today.

It is not without its flaws. Disregarding the rather lackluster options menu and the aged graphics, the game does a bad job of explaining things. Sure, there are people who give you general directions, but at several points in the game i found myself aimlessly wandering the map looking for the correct action to perform. Specifically, the gate at chapter 7 with the gargantua, and in the subsequent chapter when you're required to crouch jump for the first time are really poorly explained. Lastly, long jumping received no explanation either.

Despite these flaws, Half Life is still a decent game. You can't go wrong with this, especially since it is OFTEN on sale for less than ‚Ç¨2.
