Half life is an iconic game that you should play. You will be enthralled by the story and by the subtle dialog and story hints that are dropped throughout the game. For its release date, it is one of the best games made. Sure its aged a bit, but I don't think that a game from 1998 can not be aged. Just the fact that this game is super hard, and there is a large variety of guns makes it to where you don't get bored, even if you have a short attention span like me. 

A couple of issues with the game
Sometimes it's difficult to tell if your shots are actually hitting the enemy, but that can be blamed on the old age of the game.
On a rail is just not a fun chapter in my opinion. It's just being on a minecart track while trying not to die for way too long of a time.

A couple things I like
The puzzles are usually clear enough that even if you're stuck, once you figure out what to do you can't believe you didn't think of it before. There is a little inconsistency of what you can destroy and when you are able to smack through a door.

Overall, this game is awesome, and I give it a 9/10

SPOILER FREE:

I had put off playing this game for a long time. I was born after its initial release, and the only Valve titles I'd played were Portal and Portal 2. One day, I had a hankering to play a singleplayer game, having just finished a second playthrough of Dishonored 2, and I had picked Half-Life and it's entire series as part of the Valve Complete Pack two summers ago.

The nostalgia is lost on me, so I have no connection to Gordon Freeman, Barney, or any other characters from the series. Having said that, My experience with Half-Life was most similar to my first watch of Terminator, the Wrath of Khan, and Akira, and not because they're all 90s sci-fi pieces. Rather, I began to see the game's influence throughout everything I've played since. Weapons were familiar to me; small pistol does less damage than big pistol, enemies run from grenades, etc.

What I cannot overstate is how gracefully this game has aged. Enemies feel intelligent and alive; they duck for cover when grenades are thrown, they warn their friends when they spot you, and I even had a particularly smart one (though it could have been by chance) bait me into a room full of his friends. This game's difficulty is ideal. I'm new to Half-Life, but I'm no casual FPS player, either. I found myself regularly rationing ammo and health, checking every corner, and breaking every box in search of HEV batteries, but at the same time, enemies are not so punishing that you resort to shooting their toes from behind cover or manipulating their AI to kill each other. I found each encounter different from the last, and each environment forced me to take a different approach. I might take my time skulking around the outskirts of a warehouse with a revolver to pick off a couple baddies before going gung-ho into the fray with an assault rifle. I may have just acquired a new weapon, and want to try it out. Half-Life's combat allows you to be creative, and to discover your own stories in its loose narrative.

That being said, Valve's inaugural title has not lost its old school charm. Scientists and security guards are lovingly adorable, and I found myself taking every opportunity to keep them out of harm's way, only for them to run scared from a single grunt and abandon me. Enemies amusingly explode into a shower of gibs when killed. The technical limitations originally imposed on Half-Life's 1998 development streamline the gameplay more than you might imagine. When walls are made of flat textures, a hidden vent or some exposed pipes are a clear path forward rather than  a cryptic hint towards what might come ahead. The rudimentary modeling and textures have been utilized to the fullest though. Each area is distinct, memorable, and atmospheric.

I would be lying, though, if I didn't talk about my issues with Half-Life. I found myself underwhelmed by the lack of narrative, and likewise by the anticlimactic finale, though Half-Life is not a game one plays for its story. The soundtrack is sparse and at times cliche. I also found myself overstrafing, given that Gordon Freeman scampers along the ground at full clip regardless of how fast I might like to go. I found myself whizzing through dazzling environments when I would have rather been taking in the view.

Half-Life is a real gem, and you are doing yourself a disservice by not playing it, especially if it's already in your Steam library (which it probably already is). While some aspects are obviously dated, given that while our protagonist can stick to a ladder like a spider monkey, he can barely sneeze a grenade more than a couple inches, you will not be bored by this one-of a kind experience.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I had been wanting to play Half-Life for a long time now. This game is highly regarded in the gaming community as a classic FPS and I finally got the chance to play it.

 As a first person shooter, Half-Life immediately distinguishes itself with its gameplay mechanics. The shooting feels great, the movement is very characteristic and takes a while to get used to, and mastering bunny hopping and long jumps/crouches takes time. There are many weapons available that are unlocked throughout the game as well as many different types of enemies and encounters.

 Every area (until the last few chapters) is well thought-out, with hidden paths and secrets as well as challenging enemies. Every time you progress in this game you are presented with new puzzles you have to solve and this helps keeping the gameplay fresh and fun. You will also encounter NPCs scattered through the levels, some can help you defeat enemies or unlock storage rooms with loot, while others can help you open security doors and access new areas. 
 What's great about Half-Life is the way you have to approach the maps. I quickly found out that traversing them requires some skill in the mechanics taught in the optional tutorial level. Sometimes, it's the quick mash of these different movement mechanics that get you to that special hidden room.

 The enemies in Half-Life are varied, some human and some alien. Human enemies are mostly the same, with a few exceptions, while alien enemies are vastly different from each other. Some are quick, jumping parasites while others are big armored tanks. There are also a few "boss" enemies which can't be defeated by conventional means - in these cases you have to either escape safely or used the environment against them. Most enemies were fun and fair, with some being a bit boring or annoying (like the Tentacles and the flying aliens). I also found the enemy AI to be good, knowing when to hide, when to attack and forcing you out of cover by throwing grenades. Alien and human enemies will also fight each other which makes sense in terms of the story.

 About the plot: if you're wanting to get into this game only because you heard positive things about the storytelling, think twice. This being the first Half-Life game, it barely contains any story at all. Most of the plot is told through visual means, with rare occasions where NPCs will refrain from spouting their usual standard lines (most of which have been turned into memes) to add a bit to the story. I personally found the plot to be interesting, but poorly laid out, and that disappointed me a bit (that said, the game's final moments are great and I'm excited to play the sequels).

 The only negative thing I have to say about Half-Life is that the last four chapters are terrible. I couldn't believe how boring and frustrating the game became. The interesting maps and routes were gone, the enemies were annoying, and the final boss was a complete joke. Thankfully, it only lasts for a bit until it's over, and the ending is great.

 The online community is also still active as I was able to find populated servers to try out the multiplayer aspect of the game.

 In conclusion, I recommend playing this game if you're curious about it and enjoy a good FPS with bits of good storytelling. The gameplay is solid, the mechanics are great and aside from poor graphics and the final levels, Half-Life is a phenomenal, unique shooter that is worth playing.

I was going to just write a little reference from Half Life with a recommendation but I think game has highlighted something really important for myself as a gamer and the gaming industry as a whole.

I've never experienced a game like this before and it goes to show just how generic modern gaming has become. Valve's attention to detail and open minded approach to level design allows for some of the most creative and original experiences I have ever known.
Despite the game being 22 years old, I was amazed by how advanced it felt with its imaginative solutions to challenges. This kind of gameplay is something I have always thought was the future of gaming, so it came as a shock to find that a classic title had achieved this many years ago. To put it in the most simple explanation - If you think of a solution, there's a chance it might actually work; so try shooting things and pressing buttons!

Upon finishing my playthrough, I have realised just how mind numbing modern titles are; it feels like the simple formula that so many developers follow now has shut my mind off to being creative with my thinking when it comes to approaching new challenges. 

At various points during the game, I was reminded of the puzzles of the Zelda series - particularly Ocarina of Time, and the gunplay of the original Doom titles, which was a clear indication to me that Valve understood the good gameplay mechanics that made Zelda and Doom so addicting and unique and then took it further with the extra power of computer hardware that was available at the time.  From seeing this clever formula in action, I feel that being given the opportunity to think outside the box is something that more developers need to explore.

The combination of unique and interesting story with sandbox yet varied gameplay is an experience like no other and I highly recommend this as a game for everyone to try at some point in their life because I am yet to have played anything like it.

Half Life 1 is by no means perfect, and there were moments of frustration as the game showed its age - however I did play on hard difficulty mode which is something I do not recommend unless you are ok we having to regularly quicksave and re-attempt. Probably one of the biggest issues is the parkour can be very annoying sometimes but it can also be really fun. Oh and also, there is no sprint -_-

The game requires you to think about the situation rather than running in and gunning down everything (on hard 1 v 1 can be death) so don't always rely on weapons. You can manipulate the environment to help you and stealth is often an option although this is not always possible.

So there is my review and it took me way too long to write but I think that this message is something really important for the future of the industry. Thank you very much if you've taken the time to read it and I wish you the best of luck if you decide to begin this journey, you've bought yourself a rewarding challenge! 

And for those of you who are still undecided - play this game and you too can become a fellow scientist ;)

Oh and one last thing, I was on the fence about buying [b] Black Mesa (remaster/remake of Half Life) [/b] over the original version and I'm glad I bought this first instead. Knowing some of the levels are changed in the remake and that a lot of the flaws of the original version [spoiler] especially Xen [/spoiler] are fixed makes Black Mesa look even more appealing!

After over 20 years, I was surprised how much the original Half Life held up. Before playing, I had come to the conclusion that Half Life wasn't worth playing and assumed there was no reason to play it over the remake, Black Mesa. However, after playing, I've decided that Black Mesa isn't so much a remake of Half Life as it is a re-imaging. As a result, both are great and deserve to be played. So, what exactly makes the original Half Life worth your time to play in 2021? First, the game-play has aged very well. There are some clunky aspects, most notably the occasional platforming the game forces you through, which can be frustrating. Despite that, the gun-play is solid, there's a lot of weapon variety and every weapon has a purpose. (Excluding the pistol, which, while very useful in the beginning of the game, sadly becomes useless as it progresses.) That being said, you can obviously get good gun-play from any other modern game today. What really sets Half-Life aside from other games is the story. It was a revolutionary story at the time and changed the way people thought of narratives in video games. Before Half-Life, narrative-based games where always text based or used cut-scenes to convey story. Half Life changed that. The player always has control of the protagonist, Gordon Freeman, throughout the entire game. The story is entirely optional, you can kill anyone you like and completely ignore it. (Which in it of itself actually improves the narrative as it allows Gordon Freeman to be a greater vessel for the player.) But for those willing to look, a very rich narrative is in store, one that you are given the option to experience through dialogue and general observations of the world around you. What also sets Half-Life apart from other games is the setting. Most of the game takes place in the Black Mesa research facility, with the exception of the last four chapters. Despite this, the facility always has to offer you interesting locals and new enemies.
In conclusion, Half-Life's combination of good gun-play and a complex but completely optional narrative are what sets it apart from modern shooters. Also, the OST is pretty kick-ass. That's why it's worth your time to play in 2021. It may not be pretty to look at but what's beneath the surface is definitely worth playing.

[h1] Review [/h1]
Before I start, I will say that I'm making this review for the consumer, not to make a constructive review for Valve since this game is already 22 years old (as of the time I'm writing this) and Valve has improved their games by a long mile ever since. I know Black Mesa exists but if you want the full 1998 experience, you could play this game. Trust me, it's worth your time.

[h1] Gameplay / Structure [/h1]
For a game in 1998, it has surprisingly held up well to today's standards and I can see how it has influenced modern day First-Person Shooters. The gun-play is simple, rigid, and responsive, you can switch weapons easily, and enemy AI is good. The marines' AI is especially impressive for its time since they behave like actual marines (i.e. retreating, throwing and timing grenades, and also ambushes). Shooting all of your enemies with your standard full-autos / shotguns won't always work since some of them will act like bullet sponges. Usually they respond differently depending on the types of enemies. Companion A.I. is kind of wonky as they will sometimes stop mid-way or block your path, but it isn't a big problem since you will navigate the game all by yourself.

Design-wise, the levels are good and they aren't maze-like or brain-dead simple as you can navigate some of the levels with ease. Objectives can be a little difficult to work on your own if you don't pay attention as the game doesn't have any way-points, arrows or memos. So you might need to rely on the environmental design to traverse. But sometimes, it's difficult to figure that out by yourself so you might find yourself stuck in some areas. There are also a few times where geometrical bugs can get you stuck as the game loads or if you went in a secluded space. Enemy placement can be overwhelming and frustrating at times [i](looking at you, helicopter...)[/i] so you will need to stock up for the big parts in the game. 

Xen is decent at best although a bit awkwardly designed. You might need some walkthrough guides to traverse and platforming here can be wonky. It's also shorter (an hour) than the Black Mesa parts but it doesn't drag on too far. 

[h1] Graphics / Aesthetics [/h1]
The world-building and atmosphere is phenomenal for its time. The huge complexes and rooms reminds you of warehouses you would often find inside factories but in a more sci-fi fashion. Outside areas and Xen are okay I guess, nothing more to say there. The pixelated textures and skyboxes aren't that impressive now but it helps bring out the vibrant yet oppressive atmosphere you're playing in the game. The particle effects and liquid physics are actually pretty impressive for its time, and there are some physics involved but it mostly involves some boxes.

Enemies are cleverly designed and are easily distinguishable. The cloned scientists and guards can be a bit immersion-breaking at some times but I wouldn't mind it. Sound-design is also great although low-quality (as expected), and it complements the world around you.

[h1] Story [/h1]
It's pretty straight-forward and simple. You are a scientist and things go to hell in the Black Mesa complex so you fight bad guys and stuff like that. I won't spoil anything but there are also some pretty interesting lore behind the environments and situations you walk in, including the enemies you fight. 

[h1] Overall [/h1]
This game served as a landmark for all the modern FPS games to come. Its immersive environments and tightly-packed gameplay is a big strength for a game. Although it doesn't come without its flaws, it's still great enough to play the game. I wouldn't really play the campaign again for long but it's your choice. I think it's a "one-time" experience for me since I don't want to experience the frustrating parts again, but you can always speed-run the game if you want. It's a solid game worth your time and you won't be disappointed.

Shrek is a 2001 American computer-animated fantasy romantic comedy film loosely based on the 1990 fairy tale picture book of the same name by William Steig. Directed by Andrew Adamson and Vicky Jenson in their directorial debuts, it stars Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy, Cameron Diaz and John Lithgow as the voices of the lead characters. The film parodies other fairy tale adaptations, primarily aimed at animated Disney films.[6] In the story, an ogre called Shrek (Myers) finds his swamp overrun by fairy tale creatures who have been banished by the corrupt Lord Farquaad (Lithgow) aspiring to be king. Shrek makes a deal with Farquaad to regain control of his swamp in return for rescuing Princess Fiona (Diaz), whom Farquaad intends to marry. With the help of Donkey (Murphy), Shrek embarks on his quest but soon falls in love with the princess, who is hiding a secret that will change his life forever.

The rights to Steig's book were purchased by Steven Spielberg in 1991. He originally planned to produce a traditionally-animated film based on the book, but John H. Williams convinced him to bring the film to the newly-founded DreamWorks in 1994. Jeffrey Katzenberg began active development of the film in 1995 immediately following the studio's purchase of the rights from Spielberg. Chris Farley was originally cast as the voice for the title character, recording nearly all of the required dialogue. After Farley died in 1997 before the work was finished, Mike Myers stepped in to voice the character, which was changed to a Scottish accent in the process. The film was intended to be motion-captured, but after poor results, the studio decided to hire Pacific Data Images to complete the final computer animation.

Shrek premiered at the 2001 Cannes Film Festival, where it competed for the Palme d'Or,[7] making it the first animated film since Disney's Peter Pan (1953) to be chosen to do so.[8] It was widely praised as an animated film that featured adult-oriented humor and themes, while catering to children at the same time. The film was theatrically released in the United States on May 18, 2001, and grossed $484.4 million worldwide against a production budget of $60 million. Shrek won the first ever Academy Award for Best Animated Feature and was also nominated for Best Adapted Screenplay. It earned six award nominations from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA), ultimately winning Best Adapted Screenplay. The film's success helped establish DreamWorks Animation as a prime competitor to Pixar in feature film computer animation, and three sequels were released‚ÄîShrek 2 (2004), Shrek the Third (2007), and Shrek Forever After (2010)‚Äîalong with two holiday specials, a spin-off film, and a stage musical that kickstarted the Shrek franchise. Although plans for a fifth film were canceled prior to the fourth film's release,[9] the project was revived in 2016 and has since stalled, with production and a potential release date getting pushed back.[10][11]

Truly a very unique and interesting pc classic that revolutionized the first-person shooter genre. I love the tension overall, and sense of dread and uneasiness from the presence of enemies at times, it's perfect for this game specifically. Unlike other single-player fps games like Doom or Metroid Prime you aren't playing as a trained soldier or marine of sorts, you're playing as Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist who probably has never held a gun before in his life. This isn't a "run and gun" kind of shooter, but more so a puzzle shooter that requires you to think as if you were in Gordon's situation in real life, which definitely can make the game a little difficult as I feel it does not do a very good job of getting the player into that mindset with the saves you can use over and over. The game admittedly goes very downhill in the Xen chapter and everything after it. Let's not talk about the on a rail chapter too, that chapter was shit. Other than these discrepancies, the game is great and something any fan of the first-person shooter genre should experience.

If you haven't yet played this game and consider yourself to be a fan of FPS style games, then you owe it to yourself to give probably the most influential FPS game of all time a shot. Right up there with other masterpieces such as Halo: CE, Goldeneye, or Doom, Half Life innovated the genre.

Now, that is what pretty much anyone will say about this game, and I'm only about halfway through. I think that this common assessment of the game has held up so far, and it is quite interesting to play one of the founding fathers of the modern FPS. With that being said, however, I definitely would call this game very dated. It has aged poorly (especially on controller) and lacks the fluidity of newer releases (or anything not made in the 90s). Comparing the overall movement, gunplay, and feel of the game, I would say a game like Halo CE blows it out of the water. Where Half Life excels from what I've seen is level design, narration, and puzzle solving aspects. 

I would definitely recommend this game for 99c during a sale, but so far I don't think its quite as good as it is praised for. Its awesome for a shooter from 1998, but in 2020 it can feel like a slog to play through at times.

Even if I haven't beaten this game yet, I can wholeheartedly say that I enjoy it.  Having not played it back in '98, however, I feel like I have some unique perspective on Half-Life.  The storyline is very well thought out in my opinion (Keep in mind I am currently on Chapter 17, so impressions are subject to change).  The gameplay, however, does get a bit tedious in some areas.  Especially on Interloper, where there are often many enemies around corners that must be killed at once.  If you end up at a bad spot at one point, you will probably have to load an earlier save.  This is mostly a problem with Interloper specifically, however.  Any trouble you may have with Half-Life will come from the fact that it is difficult.  Genuinely difficult.  I've been playing on the Easy difficulty, and the enemies still give me some trouble.  But I like that.  This game doesn't hold your hand in any way, which is a breath of fresh air from a lot of games that spoon-feed things like gameplay mechanics and story through cutscenes and interactive tutorials, which, while nice, can often become annoying.  Half-life lets you figure things out for yourself, which in my opinion, is great. 

One thing I discovered, however, is that Half-Life actually has a server browser with several deathmatch servers.  All of these are completely unpopulated except for two.  I joined one and managed to rack up 200 kills, but in the end, found it very tiresome to get beamed by people with a Tau cannon and Gluon Gun.  The multiplayer is overall very unbalanced, and not the most fun.  For that reason, I cannot recommend it to anyone.  

So in short, while I would say that the singleplayer Half-Life experience holds up, the multiplayer experience does not.

EDIT 12/31/20: I just beat the entire game!  It ends on a cliffhanger, which I found to be a bit frustrating, but overall, I was still hooked all the way.  I still recommend this game, even after all these years.

The first time I've learned about Half-Life was from an interview with Valve that I read in a polish gaming magazine from June 1998. The way that the game was described left a very strong impression on me: from the elaborate AI through the importance of storytelling all the way towards the focus on realism of the world and the situation. Half-Life seemed like a project that could inject a much needed dose of innovation to the FPS genre and from that point onward I couldn't wait to play it myself.

The game did not only deliver on its promise. It wiped the floor with all the other shooters at the time and brought everyone's attention to how much more can be done in action games. It stood as a landmark achievement that, much like DOOM in the early 90s, inspired a large number of clones and copycats while it's overall structure influenced many FPS games in the future.

There's not much to say about this first entry today, 22 years after its initial release. People who haven't been there at the time will probably not fully understand just how important that title was when it came out. Not many games manage to have such an influence on the industry for years to come. For me it'll always be very nostalgic to look back at how it all started.

Foundational to FPS games. Iconic.

The game that took the genre to a whole new level. Even now, 22 years later, it still manages to impress, with obvious thought put into each and every environment, puzzle, and combat scenario. The relative lack of hand-holding makes you feel that much more accomplished when you figure out how to defeat a boss, or outwit a group of particularly tough enemies when you're low on health. It's a wild ride that almost never lets up.

Of course, seeing as how they were making things up as they went, there were bound to be a few missteps.  Jumping and climbing is terribly imprecise, which makes the final few stages on Xen kind of infuriating. You'll occasionally get stuck on objects for no reason and have to do some finicking to get free. And the last boss, for lack of a nicer way to say it, sucks. Unbelievably difficult and unintuitive, I definitely got hung up on him longer than any other section in the game. Oh, and the plot is mostly background noise, but at least it had one.

Good for a nostalgia trip, or, if you're a first-timer like me, a reminder of how big a leap this was for first-person shooters, and how much we've built upon it since then.

Half-Life is an amazing game!  The level design is wonderful; the chapter Surface Tension in particular is fantastic, and a classic FPS level.  This level design was quite immersive in 1998, and it still holds up today.  The story isn't anything too original, but the way in which it's presented without the use of cut-scenes or loads of exposition is simply outstanding.  The enemy A.I. is quite intelligent, and respond to the player in a realistic and believable way.  The human soldiers in particular are very smart, being able to flank the player, and lob grenades organically.  This game is also extremely well paced; intense firefights compliment smart environmental puzzles like a fine wine.  The weapons you acquire are also fun to use.  The MP-5 and .357 Magnum are great and useful weapons, and the Crowbar is iconic.  The scientific/experimental weapons are fun to use, the Gluon Gun being one of my personal favorites.  And, besides the frustrating Xen levels, the campaign in Half-Life overall is awesome and unique!  Half-Life is considered to be one of the best and most influential FPS games of all time, and it's acclaim is well deserved!  Half-Life is one of my favorite games of all time, and a must play FPS game.  Whether is be 1998, or 2020, Half-Life is a timeless classic.

Some people over exaggerate how good this game is and leave out some major flaws. What once was a masterpiece in the late 90's is now a decent and often meme-able piece of history in video gaming. Half Life is not at all a bad game, it's brillant for sure. The platforming is not very good and often is the worst part about this game, the difficulty spikes up a bit when you go against these very tanky, bullet spongy enemies, the levels can get super confusing and navigating them can also get annoying and frustrating. These are all issues that have not stood well against the test of time. 
But the story, the fun gameplay, the sound design, the music, it's very coordinated and enjoyable. You can still get a kick out of it till this day, there is always something there for each type of player. It's a classic, it really did pave the way for more story-based shooters. If you don't have this game in your library, you can't be called a Valve fan.

[h1]Half-Life[/h1]

Is a classic first person shooter, running on the GoldSrc Engine, developed by Valve Software, published by Sierra entertainment on November 1998.

In Half-Life the player fill in the shoes of Dr. Gordon Freeman, 27 years old theoretical physicist late for his first day of work at Black Mesa Research Facility. He gets in the Hazardous Environment Suit, the experiment goes wrong, Resonance Cascade happens. Soon enough the first day on the job turns into Gordon's fight for his life during a cataclysmic event.

Over the course of the Black Mesa incident Gordon will acquire a large arsenal of military grade armaments, experimental weapons and tools. From the humble Glock and trusty crowbar, to the exotic crossbow and destructive Gluon gun. There're aways a good weapon for your situation you are in. And what are weapons for if not killing things? throughout Black Mesa you will encounter no shortage of hostiles from all sorts of Xen fauna, HECU and black ops, there's good variety of enemies for the time, and they interact and with the player in different ways. However the threat is not only found in enemies, but the hazardous environment of Black Mesa is in itself a danger, sure the HEV suit does a lot of heavy lifting for Gordon, but it won't save you from dissolving in a pool of acid of getting crushed by the collapsing facility debris.

In terms of controls, Gordon is fast, his air control is insane, and the movement is good and responsive, however I've seen complaints about Gordon feeling ''slippery'' this is a Golds thing that comes from its Quake origins, you keep part of your momentum when you stop running, it doesn't bother me at all it is a tiny thing, but I see how it could bother someone else.
When it comes to soundtrack, it is rather shy, but when it kicks in its pretty iconic and fits well with the energy and situation the player is in.

Valve keeps Half-Life up to date, so the game runs flawlessly on a fresh install ''out of the box'' on modern systems and hardware. It doesn't need any mods for it to run properly which is a god send when it comes to older titles such as this one, most publishers just slap a DOSbox on their games and call it a day like Bethesda did with Quake.

Half-Life is one of the first FPS games to make the jump from disconnected abstract maps chained in a episodic format to a fully story driven game. While I appreciate the simplicity and merits of its predecessors like Quake, Half-Life would go on to raise the bar and set a new standard in terms of quality, not only for gameplay but for environmental story telling and writing, both aspects that were yet unseen for the FPS genre of the time.

a instant classic that would change the way FPS games are designed forever. It's influence and success would cement Valve as a gaming landmark and give birth to future iconic games and franchises equally successful such as Counter-Strike, Portal and Team Fortress.

It is for this and many more reasons I consider Half-Life to be a Master Piece.

This was a long time coming. I never played Half-Life before, so one day I decided to fire it up and play because it has a decent modding community. Instead of replaying the same classic Doom mods over and over again forever. This was a fun 90‚Äôs cinematic first person shooter. It‚Äôs not as ‚Äúcinematic‚Äù as other shooters are today like Call of Duty but it is 90‚Äôs FPS cinematic. Unlike some of my favorite FPS games which have little to no story at all focusing entirely on gameplay.

The games story is primarily focused on a scientist named Gordan Freeman who needs to deal with a group of interdimensional aliens attacking a research facility called Black Mesa after they accidentally open a portal connecting their dimension to earth. From there things take a turn and become more and more complicated.

SLIGHT SPOILERS - [spoiler]At first it's just the scientists, security guards, and fighting off the aliens. Then the military shows up, it turns out that they were there to help cover up the experiments at the Black Mesa research facility. And by cover up I mean destroy any traces of the project by killing the aliens and the facilities guards and staff which includes you. You need to fight them off as much as you need to fight off the aliens. You fight your way through the facility dealing with soldiers and aliens as you go and the whole time there‚Äôs some mysterious man in a suit wandering the facility. You eventually go to the alien home world and kill the alien leader. It ends on a cliffhanger for Half-Life 2 where that mysterious man (whose nickname is The G-Man) hires you for a job by putting Freeman in stasis until the second game.[/spoiler]

Although the story isn‚Äôt why this game is popular. The games community wouldn't become lore nuts until Half-Life 2. Because the story isn‚Äôt all that special. This game was famous at the time because of its focus on realism. Half-Life came out in 1998 before that the most popular FPS game was Doom that was released in 1993. In Doom you go to a few different locations but none of the environments felt like real spaces. They felt like geometry that was hastily slapped together to somewhat imitate a real space. But prioritizing giving the players a fun playground to shoot their way through. In Half-Life the Black Mesa Research Facility feels like a real space. Unlike the starting military base in Doom for instance I can actually picture someone coming to work there. Another example is pickups, in Doom pickup items such as health and guns would float about an inch or two above the ground. In Half-Life ammo and health kits will be sitting on tables and shelves instead to make it more immersive. One more example is the story, like I said Half-Life is a cinematic first person shooter. Having a cohesive story in a FPS was new at the time. With Doom having next to no story at all.

Usually when I hear someone say ‚ÄúYou should play this game from the 90‚Äôs it was revolutionary for its time because of the graphics‚Äù I cringe. Because 90‚Äôs games had this weird thing where they were prioritizing making the whole thing look good over making it play well. As opposed to the original Doom which looks kind of ugly without modding it at least, but still plays very well. (Although that's probably subjective) One example that I like to use to make this point is Shenmue, a game that was famous for its time for looking good that looks terrible by today's standards. The gameplay isn‚Äôt very good either, because it‚Äôs just you doing a series of mundane chores and errands for the townspeople. The only reason why that game still gets so much praise today is because the people who played it years ago on the Dreamcast have nostalgia goggles on. It's the same for a lot of older games too and I appreciate that era of gaming because it helped bring the gaming medium into a league of its own. Computer games started to be something for everyone instead of just being a niche hobby for kids.

But it also means that a lot of older games didn‚Äôt age all that well thanks to improved technology. I think that may be why I never played Half-Life until now because I thought it would probably be a product of its time thanks to its focus on realism and in some ways it is. You can definitely tell that the game was made in the 1990‚Äôs but overall it's still a solid first person shooter. The beginning of the game starts out as a bit of a survival horror game with Gordan Freeman being armed with only a pistol and his famous and trusty crowbar. But eventually you get more weapons such as a shotgun, an assault rifle, and grenades. From there the game focuses on action shooting, platforming, and some light puzzle solving.

The shooting feels half-good. What I mean by that is that the guns you get are pretty decent and feel good to fire. You do get quite a few different weapons by the end of the game, 14 to be exact. But the guns I used the most were the MP5 submachine gun with an under barrel grenade launcher, the assault shotgun, and the colt python .357 magnum. Side note, I didn‚Äôt know you could mount an M203 grenade launcher on an MP5 SMG. The more you know I guess ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

The other half of the shooting isn‚Äôt that good. Most of the enemies will be using projectile weapons and most of the time if one of them starts shooting at you they WILL hit you unless there‚Äôs some cover between you and them. Basically if you can't see them they can't shoot you and if you can then they can. No amount of tactics or strafing side to side will stop every bullet from hitting you. (Not all the enemies use ‚Äúbullets‚Äù but you get what I‚Äôm saying) Some of the levels drag out for a little too long and the last few levels weren't all that good because of a massive difficulty spike. Also there‚Äôs quite a bit of platforming and I don‚Äôt like platforming in FPS games and I know I‚Äôm not alone in this. The AI was probably good for its time but by today's standards not so much. There‚Äôs some sections where the player needs to escort an NPC somewhere usually to unlock a door and the path finding is terrible. There‚Äôs a reason that what's seen as the gold standard for AI in an FPS game is F.E.A.R not Half-Life.

This was a fun game despite the age and rust. You can even bring the game up to a modern resolution thanks to Valve updates on Steam. Pro tip! When you first boot up the game go into the options menu and go to video. Then select "Widescreen" and "1080 x 720" Then go to mouse and disable auto-aim. The audio balancing could use some tweaking too. Go into the audio tab, turn MP3s up to maximum, and turn Sound Effects down a tic. It can be hard to hear characters talk thanks to the old and scratchy audio. Which is a problem in a story driven game with so subtitles.

Half-Life mixed up its enemy variety, weapon variety, and location variety in a way that gives it some really good pacing. Enough to keep me playing from start to finish and I enjoyed it enough that I can see myself playing it again in the future. Even though I still didn‚Äôt like it as much as classic Doom. I can‚Äôt wait to dive into the modding community for this game but first I have some expansion packs to play first, GG.

As someone who has never played any of the Half-Life titles, the very positive rating on Steam and the praise for the series online gave me very high expectations for this game, and I'm afraid I was a bit disappointed.

Don't get me wrong, there was lots I did like about the game. I found the story and universe to be excellent, and the mechanics were quite fun, for the most part. It was very exciting to find and use new weapons, especially as they moved farther and farther away from traditional weaponry. The game also had a lot of good level design, and there were lots of areas with multiple paths and lots of secrets, which was pretty cool.

There were a number of issues that prevent me from recommending this title though:
[list]
	[*]The visuals in this game are extremely dated. Textures are low quality, models are very blocky and have low detail, and the UI is small and hard to see. This alone didn't ruin the experience for me as I knew this would be the case going in, but they still leave a lot to be desired.
	[*]The momentum in this game was very frustrating and took almost the entirety of the game to get used to. You accelerate very quickly, and all of the movement feels as though it's on ice, as you continue to slide after releasing the keys. Given that there is a fair amount of platforming required in this game, this was pretty infuriating, and I often found myself sliding all over the place.
	[*]The game is pretty punishing. It's very easy to take damage very quickly, and it often seems a bit too unforgiving. The explosion radius is often much larger than it looks, and explosions do a lot of damage. Additionally, falls that seem harmless do a surprising amount of damage, and it is very easy to get killed by fall damage (which makes the previous point about the momentum worse as well). There were also a number of areas which contained hidden enemies or dangers that were very difficult to avoid, which made it feel like mandatory damage.
	[*]Most of the levels were very well designed and I had no issues, but I wasn't a huge fan of the ending of the game. I found it too difficult to determine what I should be doing or where I should be going. Based on what I've seen elsewhere though, the final chapters are generally considered to be the worst part of the game.
[/list]

I must give this game the credit it is due. When it came out, it was very revolutionary, and it had a huge influence on many of the games we play today. However, it hasn't aged well, and the outdated visuals, the frustrating momentum, and very unforgiving nature of the game make it difficult for me to recommend. If you're picking it up for nostalgia or you'd like to play a piece of gaming history, then I'd say go ahead, but I wouldn't recommend this title otherwise.

Story: Nothing, like any other when it comes to visual storytelling. This first person shooter establishes a story of an unremarkable individual, Gordon Freeman. Gordon, the scientist and research associate finds himself working in a government funded facility. Black Mesa, associated with their questionable ethics. Gordon is ordered to volunteer on a groundbreaking scientific research mission. Unfortunately, the scientists are filled with pride, and they are too stubborn to take consideration of a possible catastrophic event. Despite their efforts of tuning their scientific equipment to safety, unforeseeable consequences came. This caused extra-dimensional aliens to manifest around the Black-Mesa facility, caused by the infamous anti-mass spectrometer. Gordon lost the people he knew, his associates, co-workers, friends and family. In spite of all of this, Gordon is confident enough to maneuver through the ruins of the infamous facility, with the aid of the cutting edge HEV suit, and his impeccable intellect.

Graphics: The visuals may appear archaic, but does not get in the way of the game-play. Graphic wise, It is comparable to Quake (1996) because it is technically a modification of it. The lighting, shading, textures have aged well, but not in quality. The three dimensional assets on the other hand, have not aged very well. The characters are walking sock puppets asking you to leave them alone repeatedly.

Music: Kelly Bailey, game's composer established an interesting soundtrack. I have my criticisms about it. Kelly seemingly taken many samples from many libraries, and remixed them to his own liking. The mixture of symphonic orchestra and electronic blends seamlessly with the theme, reflecting the industrial nature of Black-Mesa and Freeman's will to survive.

Game play: The game lends you good controls on your character, such as mouse, strafing, crouching and most importantly, jumping. The weapons feel just right and satisfying compared to "boomer shooters". It is unfortunate the mouse is not set up adequately, either the sensitivity if too high or too low. Sometimes, your mouse registers "janky" inputs. The level design is intelligently thought out, as Black-Mesa is put together in a realistic portrayal compared to Quake's abstract and psychedelic environment.

That is all I got to say for today, go away now.

Half Life: if anything you recognize the name.

Introduction:

Half Life is close to the level of Doom when it comes to importance. At the time Half Life was cutting edge and introduced the new concept of level design that makes sense. Gone were the days of Romero's (admittedly fantastic) "abstract . . . design". Half Life was story driven, to be story driven and taken seriously, the setting had to seem real. It brought together it's spatial sense with aggressive action and interesting enemy designs. It had a simple story, but one that works well over the length of the game. Let's get into it, shall we?

1. Black Mesa

The setting; an X - Files - esque secret laboratory, both a government sponsored place of science, and a military bunker working with the unknown. It's a simple plot, but never had a plot of this magnitude been told in a video game. Before this, the only memorable shooter characters were Duke Nukem and Caleb from Blood. Throughout the game, you explore this facility, which is arguably a character itself. Journeying through Black Mesa reveals the questionable ethics of what had been going on there. It also features plenty of memorable scripted sequences and unique looking levels. All of this is shown to you in an unbroken first person perspective with no loading screens or breaks. 

2. Gameplay

Half Life has aged decently well in this case, the gameplay hasn't really fundamentally changed from Quake or Quake II, but the solid base is still there, this time with much more interesting weapons (not to devalue the Quake games, they have fantastic weapons in their own right) and the scripted sequences that really make the game immersive. These aspects really suck you in, so let's go over the weapons.

The crowbar, everyone know this one. The crowbar is your melee last resort and tool for breaking crates and vents.

The handgun, a pistol modeled after the Glock 17 of our own world. This is your bread and butter pistol, using the same ammo as the MP5 that comes later and stays a reliable long range weapon, It also stays useful for dealing with pesky headcrabs.

The Shotgun, and absolute classic. Definitely not realistic, as the alt fire (mouse 2 by default, every weapon has one) fires two shells at once, despite it having only one barrel. Great workhorse weapon for the Alien Slaves and a certain enemy I don't want to spoil.

The SMG, an MP5 that will probably be you main weapon. It's a little weird that it has a grenade launcher, but it's still a great weapon.

I'm going to stop here and I won't cover the enemies for the same reason: there's a lot of them and I don't want to spoil them as they're a lot of fun. Expect plenty of explosives and maybe even some "science" weapons.

3. Conclusion

Half Life is a great game, not perfect, but there is little for me to say that others haven't covered to death. Buy it an make sure to go into the options and turn off the HD model pack as they change the art style too much (use after your first playthrough, then see if you like them).

So finally, I do recommend Half Life, it really is special.

So here we are, where it all started for Valve, the original Half-Life, is it as amazing as everyone claims? Let‚Äôs find out.

Pros:

1. Good Graphics for a 1998 release, the visual style is very nice and charming to look at even today, character models also look good for the time as do weapons, and visual effects.

2. A very well built atmosphere with the survival horror aspect and each environment really adds to the atmosphere as a whole. You‚Äôll explore many labs, production factories, and even go outside the complex, and with the well built atmosphere in each area, you really feel like you‚Äôre there.

3. The Story at first is intriguing as you are left wondering what is happening and want to know more and this only continues as it builds up towards the end.

4. This game does something rather revolutionary for the FPS genre with the way it tells its story as during "cutscenes" if you will, you have the ability to move freely in the world while everything happens, meaning that gameplay isn't broken up during story moments, while this was technically already seen before in GoldenEye 007 for Nintendo 64, Half-Life does it better as you're given more freedom in the environment then GoldenEye and Half-Life is fully voiced acted as opposed to being subtitles only as seen in GE. Really nice innovation that Half-Life brought to the table here.


5. The gameplay has a good balance between your typical action that you‚Äôd expect and solving puzzles to proceed. Puzzles are well varied and take some thinking to solve, it‚Äôs a nice break from the action.

6. The weapons in this game are really awesome, from the 9MM Glock to the SMG, to the Shotgun, Magnum and the Crossbow and explosives. You have a pretty healthy arsenal of weapons here and each weapon feels unique and like they serve their own purposes with strengths and weaknesses. The sounds they make feel great and they're fun to use. My favorites have to be the Shotgun, SMG and Magnum, those 3 seriously pack a punch. Not once in this game do you feel like your weapon selection is lacking.

7. The enemy types you encounter are vast and quite varied. You‚Äôll fight Headcrabs, Zombies, Marines, Assassins, Bullsquids, Barnacles and more. Each enemy feels distinct in how they combat you and one must plan out different ways to deal with each one effectively, having multiple enemy types is always a good thing, especially when they‚Äôre done well like they are here.

8. The G-Man, I don't think anything else needs to be said about why this is a pro

9. Despite each character really only having 2 or 3 voice actors, the voices are charming if a bit cheesy at times.

10. The difficulties are very well balanced. The higher you go the more damage you take obviously and enemies take a bit more, and health pickups give you less health overall, but you never feel like it‚Äôs unfair. Half-Life on hard is a well designed challenge which is great as some shooters like to artificially increase difficulty.

11. While there isn‚Äôt much of it, the music in this game when it is present is quite good. It ranges from atmospheric ambience to heavy hard hitting rock that pumps you up for a big fight.

12. very good as the game is more focused on survival horror as you make your way through the Black Mesa Laboratory while aliens and various other creepy creatures invade the place, armed with only a limited amount of supplies and a crowbar, you have to really preserve your ammo to survive. I love the first hour or 2 of this game and I wish the rest of the game retained that horror feel.


Cons:


1. A few of the chapters in the game suffer from feeling either rushed or just being too long. The biggest offender and probably best example of this goes to On A Rail, it speaks volumes that nobody really likes this chapter as it's incredibly tedious and drags on. The chapter mainly boils down to using a monorail, having to stop a few moments later to either remove an obstacle or take out enemies and then repeating the process around 4 times or so, it gets old quick.


3. Some enemies in the game can feel a bit too bullet spongey which at times can make the game feel a bit unfair. The biggest offender of this is probably the Ichthyosaur as they take so much damage to kill and since they‚Äôre only really found underwater, this means the only 2 weapons that are really viable against them are the 9MM and the Crossbow as those are the only 2 that enable you to shoot underwater. Most enemies, even some that take more abuse than others, often only take more because they tend to actively avoid your gunfire such as the Marines, focused fire on them is enough to deal with them. But the Ichthyosaur doesn‚Äôt do this,


4. On the topic of enemies, one issue with this game is the hitscan problem. For those unaware: hitscan is a feature in games that essentially means if enemies have a line of sight on you, they will hit you, meaning they aren‚Äôt projectile based. Now of course this is common place in many shooters, especially back in those days, but in Half-Life at times it feels like you‚Äôre getting sniped and because of the hitscan, enemies can feel tougher than they should and often you can be punished for someone you cannot see. Just minor things like that can be a tad frustrating,
                                                                
4. Some sections in the game are a bit poorly designed to put it blunt, obviously this is more forgivable as it was Valve‚Äôs first game but it‚Äôs worth bringing up as a flaw. Some examples of this include sections where it is impossible to avoid taking damage although this is sorta mitigated by you getting health pickups but it doesn‚Äôt excuse it. Others can be enemies that can easily ambush you and you not being able to do anything about it without knowing beforehand that it‚Äôs going to occur, just things like that.

5. Xen, this whole chapter deserves it's own con because man it's just terrible and even Valve themselves admit to it's shortcomings. The novelty of being in the alien world wears off quite fast and the levels and tasks you have to do are just really boring and feel cobbled together. Top that off with a pretty annoying and tedious Final Boss and it's easy to see why even the most hardcore of fans stop playing when they reach Xen

6. The Decision to make Gordon Freeman be a silent protagonist while acceptable back in 1998, is honestly just plain bad by today's standards. Having him not talk is supposed to make you feel immersed into the levels and atmosphere but if anything I find it takes me out of the experience because you have all these characters talking to you like you're best buds are like you've been there for a while yet Gordon doesn't utter a single word in response, and due to cutscenes always being in first person, you don't even get to see him express emotion.




So with that said that‚Äôs mainly all I have to say about Half-Life. What do I think overall? I think the game is honestly a pretty great time, it has a lot of good things about it, although some things do miss the mark a fair bit, making the game a bit flawed in the grand scheme of things. I think while the game is great, I feel it is a bit overrated as I feel a section of it‚Äôs fans are blinded by all the positives and only sing the praises while ignoring the pretty obvious flaws on display. But hey it‚Äôs still a solid time and I‚Äôll be honest: on my first playthrough I didn‚Äôt enjoy it much but on a 2nd playthrough you do get to appreciate it a lot more. 


So I‚Äôd recommend this game if you are interested, it‚Äôs only 10 dollars normally and goes on sale often for far less than that so really what‚Äôs stopping you from trying it? The only thing I‚Äôll say is don‚Äôt go in expecting this masterpiece and listen to the hype as you may be disappointed like I originally was, but if you go in expecting a fun classic shooter, that‚Äôs exactly what you‚Äôll get.

Half-Life is one of the best games of all time. Even though it came out before I was born and the graphics are dated, this is still my favorite singleplayer game. Half-Life treads the line between Quake-style boomer shooters and Halo-style modern shooters. It retains some things from the former, such as running fast and having many weapons, while requiring tactics like Halo to succeed (at least when played on hard mode). One thing important to remember about Half-Life is that it expects you to play smart and observe your surroundings. In an earlier part of the game, you find a flooded room with a broken ceiling light. There is a vent that you need to crawl through to continue, however, the wires from the ceiling light are touching the water, causing you to take damage when you touch it. If you're playing smart, you might ask, "how could I turn the light off?" instead of just tanking the damage. The one downfall of Half-Life (ignoring Xen) is its graphics, as they encourage the player to lobotomize themselves and just shoot, like other older shooters.

Half-Life Review
Nothing half-assed about it--this has to be the finest shooter ever crafted.
Jason Bates
By Jason Bates
Updated: 13 Apr 2020 9:26 pm
Posted: 26 Nov 1998 3:00 am
You've got to hand it to these guys. Valve Software is a start-up, a relative unknown, with no track and, really, no business making such a mighty game. But mighty it is, the best single player shooter I've ever played.
It will be hard for some--mainly those who haven't played the game--to put their finger on exactly what everyone is raving about. There's nothing exceptional about the engine--it's a heavily modified version of Id Software's Quake. Its genre, the first-person shooter, has nearly been beaten to death. Its design couldn't be simpler: get some guns, run, shoot, jump; no laborious cutscenes or misplaced RPG elements here.

How many times have you shot at a monster only to have it either grimace at you blankly, perhaps firing off a few tepid shots, or slouch and drool while you pick off his comrades? Well, not here. The teams of soldiers you'll fight in Half-Life have to be the toughest, most convincing enemies yet seen in an action game. Where other opponents grunt incomprehensibly, these guys actually yell stuff relevant to the combat, such as "Fire in the Hole!" or "Look out!" as the grenades go flying. Then they actually try to get away from your grenades. And what's more, they also throw grenades at you.

Grenades might sound like a simple little thing to add to a game, and perhaps it is, but it adds such an extra dimension to the monsters' combat ability that it's almost like playing a whole new genre. Strafe, fire, strafe, fire just simply doesn't work every time. But in every other game, monsters either attack hand to hand, with area affects, or most commonly, with linear shots. It doesn't matter if they're shooting lasers, M-16s, or dollops of hot blue manna, it all comes in a straight line, and it all can be dodged. But change the angle of attack, and it's a whole new game. One little detail--one huge difference.

But that's just part of the appeal of Half-Life's enemies; unlike other games, they also cooperate. Teamwork, for monsters in other games, is if they all happen to be in the same room shooting in the same direction. Here, the infantry squads will split up, trying to hit you from several sides while one guy keeps you pinned or lobs grenades. It's surprising how entertaining well-implemented artificial intelligence can be, and it's probably worth it to play Half-Life just to fight its infantry. There could be a whole game based on nothing but fighting Half-Life's infantry.

Wait, there's more. How many times have you cleaned out one filthy, gory techno-dungeon, only to find yourself at a door that obviously leads to yet another, even filthier, techno-dungeon? How realistic is it to have obvious entrances and exits to levels--and what is a "level" anyway? An archaic holdover from Dungeons & Dragons? A convenient way of breaking up the game world so it can be loaded into memory?

Half-Life does away with the arbitrary concept of levels. Instead the world feels like a continuous whole, with small pauses and loads when you move from one area to another. This does create some problems when monsters are placed too close to the transition between mini-levels and you inadvertently strafe from one area to the other, accidentally triggering a load screen. But this problem aside, Half-Life's mini-levels create a more flowing and realistic game world, and so a more immersive one.

And freed from the stereotypical notion of levels, the designers were free to experiment with a wide variety of environments, logically linked and fun to explore. Every room isn't another corridor or another slime-filled dungeon. There are labs and warehouses, monorail stations and gun bunkers, missile silos and parking garages. The bulk of the action takes place in a deep underground military base called the Black Mesa Facility, but it is not confined there. You'll scale a canyon cliff and scamper through a military base. You'll ride weird monorails and climb through pipes full of waste. Virtually every location in Half-Life is interesting and unique.

This variety makes you want to keep playing Half-Life all the way through. How many times have you gotten half way through another game, only to say to yourself, "Eh, I've probably seen it all. If I keep playing, there will only be more monsters, with more guns, more hit points and more grubby levels." This is decidedly not the case with Half-Life.

Carefully crafted for the single player experience, every encounter in Half-Life is a new challenge, nearly every room throws out something you haven't seen before, every sound is a worrying cue that something horrible is about to happen. The sheer number of hand-scripted events and little scenes keeps the action moving, giving you a reason to keep playing, if only to see what could possibly happen next. I haven't had so much fun playing a game in years. I have not been frightened by a game in years. I have not dreaded corners like I have dreaded corners in this game in years. Half-Life is a superbly ambient game.

Is the game perfect? Of course not. Some of the elevators have a horrible sticking problem, and the ladders can be awkward to use. Occasionally the game chokes when a huge explosion happens. But these are minor problems.

Slightly more serious is the character of Gordon Freeman, who is rather flat and dry. I realize that the mood and feel Half-Life is very somber, very much in the mold of The X-Files, and a wisecracking Duke Nukem type wouldn't have worked. As a scientist and a specialist trained to deal with hazardous materials, Freeman is the right kind of character to serve as the story's alter ego, but his near total lack of personality--as far as I can recall, he never says anything in the game--leaves a little to be desired. Still, you could make a case that giving him a personality could actually detract from your ability to identify with the character. And certainly, the use of cut scenes or any of the other crude crutches of computer game storytelling would have detracted from the relentless pace of the game and the freedom and control you have over your character.

Internet play is more troubling. There's a built-in server list that works kind of like Gamespy, letting you find free servers quickly, which is a classy touch, but the matches themselves feel laggier than Quake. More to the point, it's obvious that Valve spent all its time and energy perfecting the single player experience, and so as far as deathmatches go, Half-Life's is just that, a standard deathmatch. But who cares? You shouldn't be buying this game to play deathmatch.

Really, my biggest problem with Half-Life was some of the level design, particularly in the middle stages of the game. Here the tension seriously sags, as you are forced to wander around some dreadful tunnels looking for switches in retro-gaming land, as jumping puzzles, switch hunts, and all the tedium of a dozen other games returns in force.

Pacing is important in an action game, since you want to break up the intense, heart-pounding shootouts with some stretches of creeping caution, even moments of relaxed calm. But in my view at least, too many of the middle levels rely on jumping puzzles, instant death traps, and almost sheer rote exploration via the save/load buttons.

However, once you get past the sewers, a seemingly interminable rail train puzzle, and the dreaded, obligatory underwater maze--once you fight your way back out into the open area where you have to mix it up with the camo guys again, the game perks up considerably, and some of the final levels in the military base are truly some of the greatest single player levels ever made.

-- Jason Bates

I think this game is decent, there is a lot about it I dislike though. Keep in mind that I played on, I think it's called Medium or Normal mode. A big problem with this game is your limited resources, yes I know there is a lot of guns in this game which you obtain in like the middle of the game. I just feel that I try to reserve the greater weapons like the Rocket Launcher or the other powerful weapons. I mainly use the shotgun, the pistol, the revolver and the Assault Rifle. Which I feel like I am always running out of ammo and never seem to find them. I also have a big complaint over the amount of Alien Controllers toward the end of the game. Like I said ammo Is a big problem and this is how it affected the gameplay in this situation. I had a decent amount of ammo in the shotgun toward the end of the game and not a lot of ammo in the long range weapons, here's the problem. The Alien Controller likes to attack from far away, which the using the shotgun doesn't help very much with enemies that attack from long range. I also have an issue with the Alien Controller spawning because when I defeat an Alien Controller magically a few more spawn which I feel like is useless to keep trying to kill them but they get really annoying and do a decent amount of damage, Their spawning usually catches me off guard and I get shot and with limited supplies such as health and ammo, I just keep dying and dying and dying. This gets really repetitive and annoying. This is where I gained less interest in this game and I was already too far into the game to give up so I just was mainly focused on beating the game even though I wasn't having fun. I do think this game is difficult which I love difficult games, but this is different. The enemies aren't that hard to beat it's just the resource management. There is some great things about the game I really like, I really like the story line in this game and I love the, I guess you can call cut scenes although they happen when you are playing the game, such as scientists being killed by something random, which is out of your control. I like how the game does have places where you can take a break and relax after fighting a bunch of enemies, these are the places where you actually get to heal up and get ammo. I really like the unique weapons and enemies which usually will not pop up in other games. The soundtrack and iconic sounds in this game is amazing. I still do recommend this game, for this game to be released in 1998 is impressive, It definitely can live up to today's standards. Thanks for reading.

Valve's first game, which became one of the best FPS ever created. Half-life is over 20 years old, but it is still an excellent game, being better than several more recent games. In the game we control Gordon Freeman, a scientist (who knows how to use weapons), that upon arriving at his workplace, Black Mesa Research Facility, witness an opening of a portal that releases dangerous creatures that will put everyone's life at risk. That's where the game begins. As a great FPS game, we can move around, jump, shoot, crouch, push objects (albeit in a rather strange way) and we can also make actions, such as clicking a button, turning a valve, etc. The ambience of the game is excellent, both the indoor and outdoor areas.  Gordon is speechless during the entire game, however, we will meet other humans, scientists, security guards (who are helping us) and soldiers (who have orders to kill us). The variety of weapons is huge, we have the iconic crowbar, pistols, shotguns, grenades, mines, crossbows, rocket launchers, ray guns and weapons that the creatures use. Talking now about the creatures, the variety is also huge, the famous headcrab, the Vortigaunt, the blind but extremely dangerous Tentacle and many others that we find throughout the game. Each enemy requires a certain strategy, or not, it will depend on you. The game also contains some puzzles, some easier, others more difficult. The only problem I had was sometimes that Gordon just got stuck (it happened about 3 times), and I had to go to another save. Half-life is an old game, but it is still a great game that is very worth playing. The game deserves 9.8 / 10.

So Half-Life is my favorite piece of media, but this game wasn‚Äôt my gateway into it's vast universe. Half-Life 2 was, and while that game has very similar design principles and thematic ties, it‚Äôs completely different from it‚Äôs predecessor. My first and fondest memories of this series is connecting with 2‚Äôs fleshed out cast of characters, and how fascinating and developed the world and the lore is.

Half-Life couldn‚Äôt afford to have those things. In fact, I‚Äôd argue it‚Äôs a way less consistently good game than it‚Äôs sequel. Modding it is easy, and that‚Äôs the main reason why I mess with it so much. It‚Äôs more of a sandbox to me than a game. But every time I actually go to pick it up, I‚Äôm reminded that it‚Äôs high points are just the best in the entire series, and to understand why is to understand what makes this game so unique.

Many of the things that fans and critics claim Half-Life pioneered was actually done before it. Blood‚Äôs combat, in my opinion, is just as sophisticated and nuanced. And sure, while that game lacked a really good presentation for its story, relying on cheap cutscenes and loveable edge factor, Half-Life wasn‚Äôt the first to evolve past those things. Quake 2 and Unreal were among the first games to realize the FPS genre‚Äôs potential for immersive storytelling, respectively casting their protagonists as a space marine on a cohesive warpath and a prisoner ironically freeing an alien race from subjugation. And sure, those are simple stories with few moral qualms, but Half-Life wasn‚Äôt the first to evolve past that either. System Shock juxtaposed the player's human ingenuity and imperfection with the efficiency of technology, a cyberpunk metaphor for the battle of player vs. designer. Valve was no doubt inspired by all of these games, since those elements were carefully weaved throughout their product. Alone, they make the game a classic, but the ideas captured with those tools are what makes it a masterpiece.

Half-Life places you in the shoes of Gordon Freeman, who is simultaneously a combination and rejection of every game protagonist that came before him. The sequel highlights the fact that Gordon is not a soldier, or a gunslinger, or an action movie hero, nor is he an everyman that people can reliably look up to. Valve‚Äôs employees have stated that Gordon was intended as a blank slate; a faceless avatar. But like with all fiction, some of the creators‚Äô true feelings tend to slip through the cracks.

See, games back then, and especially now, are obsessed with the idea of escapism. Publishers and players want the biggest worlds, the most options, and the best character builds, totally separated from our reality. They paid for the experience and set aside the time, and so it should be their fantasy. So isn‚Äôt it fascinating that Valve, despite crafting such an acclaimed, intricate world, made Gordon Freeman into someone fatally flawed, totally devoid of their own free will?

From the few details we‚Äôre given in the game, Freeman is the type of person who‚Äôs smart enough to graduate from MIT with a PhD in theoretical physics, and work at the Black Mesa Research Facility- a place that, on the surface, seems to be any aspiring researcher‚Äôs dream job. Like much of the demographic at the time, he's an aging young man, perhaps a bit geeky given the books in his locker, with an interest in the more intellectual aspects of our world and his whole life ahead of him. But all Gordon does is follow the orders of old, tired scientists who get irritated whenever he tries to get their attention. Despite his implied intelligence, and his earned academic and career achievements, he's reduced to little more than a grunt for a line of samey, unknowable individuals, even though they are the only people that share his same passions. And despite living through the most cataclysmic event in human history, he is still the spineless pawn, neither his previous life or his new one meaning zilch in the face of a new reality. Resonance Cascade or not, his fate is determined as soon as he steps on the tram to work in the morning.

All this might seem like I‚Äôm reading too far into a silly action game, but Valve‚Äôs decisions were deliberate. Strong themes of subjugation, manipulation, and loss of agency are wrapped within this conspiracy-fueled world, which is webbed with as many lies, half-truths, and unknowns as there are tripmines. They could have given Gordon a voice to reason with the world around him and solve his dilemmas like a typical story. Or, if they were truly committed to making him a power fantasy, he could conceivably go home, smoke a stogie, and get laid after the credits like every other cookie cutter mother fucker. But they didn‚Äôt. In fact, no matter what you do as him, the game will always chastise you in some cruel, ironic way. Those grunts that killed twelve dumb scientists, with not one of them fighting back? If you kill them, you‚Äôre just as bad as they are; if you let them live, you‚Äôve proved their point. Half-Life is a game that only offers simple solutions to complex problems: Run, Think, Shoot, Live, or fail. In this way, it's aim is not to be truly immersive or escapist, but to confront the player's real, human element and emotionally shake it to the core.

I suspect that Valve saw a lot of themselves in Gordon Freeman, perhaps too much of themselves. They were all clearly brilliant people with then-untapped potential, held back in some way or another. Game dev and professional creative arts can be sobering, stifling white collar experiences; office jobs are the birthplace of escapist interactive experiences, after all. Seen in Half-Life is a belligerent combination of ideas, coming from young, aspiring creatives and experienced software engineers clashing with each other, many of them foreign to what it takes to ship a game. In most cases, this would kill a new team, but Half-Life is a rare example where everyone involved decided that the product they had and the people that they were should be seen, heard, and experienced in the most engaging and fun way possible. Ex-law firm secretary Marc Laidlaw, while crafting meticulous sci-fi epics, writes Black Mesa‚Äôs office staff and the bureaucratic G-Man with noticeable contempt. Sound designer and composer Kelly Bailey is terrified and self-deprecating in interviews, and in the OST his guitar quietly lies behind well chosen, but heavy samples. Artist Ted Backman‚Äôs creatures use sexual imagery with the intent to terrify players. Level designers John Guthrie, Dario Casali, Dave Riller, and Brett Johnson (among others) redefined the art while regrettably using cheap ideas under crunch. Alongside Gabe Newell, gaming messiah that has apparently earned the ability to say and do what he wants, none of them want to talk about the series‚Äô first entry anymore.

When I was 15 years old and first played this, I was oblivious to these kinds of things, and just accepted it as a game in black and white terms: the good and the bad, the innovative and the crude. As a young man, I‚Äôve realized that it is a revolutionary, powerful piece of ‚Äúvent art‚Äù made by extraordinary people trying to find their place in life, and Valve at their most raw, ugly, and vulnerable. I'm glad that their effort won 50 GOTY awards, since I can't see a near future where a mainstream title will have the balls to say what it did.

Half-Life 2 onward masked Gordon by giving him what he might have wanted in the first game: A huge world; a guard that was an actual friend; a scientist that respected them; a scientist who resisted authority; a totally evil military force; coworkers you could hate; a friend you could love. Though Freeman was still a silent, spineless pawn, it was all given to him, instead of having to reason it out on his own. And while Alyx is on the cusp of revealing that they were all just pawns, too, Half-Life will stand on its own by having said the same thing, in a more concise, vicious, relevant, and hard-to-swallow way.
