Playing the original Half-Life game was a really unique experience for me. I did not played this game at launch, but even several years later I feel that the immersion of the story is present, and the originality and greatness of the gameplay for that era makes this game certainly valuable. The story is solid and it makes for an incredible foundation for what would be the next release in the saga, Half-Life 2. The dialogues between characters generally contain useful information that is necessary throughout story, but even with it, certain puzzles and scenarios can often feel confusing and sometimes daunting.

The gameplay is rather solid and even though many things have changed in modern games regarding player movement, this title standardize most of the keybinds that are still used to this date. Player movement, as I said, can feel slippery and you might even have the feeling that Gordon is extremely light. Even though this is no longer common in new titles and can feel somewhat weird, you get use to this fairly easily and even though it is noticeable, it is generally not going to feel like a limitation when playing. Furthermore, you might also encounter with situations where you are glitched and you need noclip in order to continue with the story. This happened to me a couple of times but it does not make the game unplayable.

I find no point on criticizing the graphics of this game from a modern point of view, they are obviously dated and this is totally understandable of a game this old, but back in the day I know that they where outstanding. However, there is an option in-game to enable "High Definition Models", which increase the number of polygons in many models, and replaces some textures for higher resolution ones. This significantly improves the visual aspect of many items.

There are a lot of weapons to try throughout the story. Since you unlock them progressively, you will probably have the change of trying many weapons before beating the game, and since it is very common to run out of ammo,  sometimes you will also be forced to use weapons you do not necessarily like.

The soundtrack is impressive. Not only the soundtrack itself, but the moments in which some tracks are played. You will often find a good-timed track starting to play in precise moments creating memorable scenes. Personally, one of my favorite scene/soundtrack piece is in the Chapter 12 "Surface Tension", when you get into a drain hatch and when you start seeing the end of the tunnel, the classic Valve theme starts playing.

I totally recommend this game; regardless of the clear limitations due to the game's age I think that this game deserves an shot if you have not played it yet. It will make you understand how far we have come in every single aspect: Artificial intelligence, gameplay, graphics, level design, etc. It is also able to exhibit the the beginnings of this game genre and you will quickly understand why was this game that influential and important to trace a path of how will many games be made from that moment on.

Half-Life deserves all the praise it has gotten (and still gets). However, if you just glance at most of the reviews here, I doubt some of them can explain why. The vast majority are either high on nostalgia or blindly hate modern games and subscribe to the "old but gold" belief (which isn't always true as some old games didn't age well or weren't good to begin with).

So I'll be one of the few reviewers that will attempt to explain in detail why Half-Life 1 is so freaking awesome.

First, let's look at the story. A top secret military facility named Black Mesa conducts an experiment that results in the teleportation of aliens to Earth (and a consequent invasion). The US government, trying to hide the truth, sends the military to wipe out not only the aliens, but also all the employees of Black Mesa. You play as Gordon Freeman, one of those scientists trying to survive. I don't know; some people loved the story but to me, it wasn't anything special (and it's not why HL1 is loved anyway). But whatever your views on the story, you should appreciate the fact that IT DOES NOT TAKE CONTROL FROM YOU TO TELL IT. The story was written to fit the gameplay, whereas modern games do the opposite. I dread playing some modern games today because you have to listen to or sit through a scripted event before you regain control (and their stories aren't that good anyway). HL1 does have a couple scripted events you need to watch, but they are few, don't overstay their welcome and actually tell you "Well s**t is about to get real". So if you don't care about the story, then rest assured you don't have to.

Now on to the gameplay. Remember when I said the story does not take over control from you? Well you can play HL1 at your own pace. Level design is linear, but not the "tight corridor" linear. It give you enough room to move about and it encourages and rewards exploration. Regards the latter, modern games don't give the incentive to explore for the so-called "secret collectibles", you get nothing more than an achievement. In HL1, when you find a secret area, it rewards you with health, power, ammo and weapons. Now that's an incentive.

The game also does not treat you like an idiot. You have the general idea of trying to escape and trying to repair the damage done but you also have to listen to the dialogue from the scientists and security guards as to what you're to do next, and even if you don't listen, there are hints in the environment telling you where to go and what's your next move (like signs and printed warnings). No objective list, no map markers, nothing. Just go there or shoot something and see what happens. I like it. And usually when I got stuck somewhere and saw a walkthrough telling me what to do next, I genuinely feel like I ruined the experience of figuring out, like I thought "How did I not see that?" So please, if you get stuck somewhere, resist the temptation of looking up a walkthrough of where to go and what to do. Trust me, YOU WILL KNOW. Modern games, on the other hand, started bringing "to-do lists". Fine. Then it started bringing up maps with the objective mark. Eh, I can live with it. Then compasses telling you where to go. Okay, okay I'll figure it out. Now the marker is on the center of the screen. Great, there's no incentive to explore or use your head. And you no longer take the time to appreciate the environment because your eyes are fixated on the objective. Thanks a lot modern gaming! If 10 year olds could beat the game back in 1998, then why do we need all those crap telling us where to go?

Now on to the AI and difficulty. This is the one of the most well-coded AI and difficulties I have even seen. Do you want to know how good AI and difficulty is in a game? Ask yourself this: will quick-saving break it? Because in HL1, though you can quick-save, that still will not address the enemies and obstacles you need to overcome. In other words, there is no artificial difficulty like in modern games. You see, modern games try to rely on checkpoint placement to try and make the game more difficult. What it does is just make things more frustrating because it's really just relying on your endurance for difficulty rather than their own ability to try and kill you. Not so with HL1. HL1 is like, "Oh you're gonna save there? LMAO, we're still here buddy. That ain't gonna help you." All enemies require certain tactics to defeat them, even on the Easy difficulty. And if you think quick-saving makes the game too easy (which IMO it doesn't), then you don't have to save. So to developers, let us quick-save where we want. And if you think that will ruin the game, then you just need to code it better.

And the gunplay. Every weapon has it's use. I think this solidifies the idea that less=better. HL1 doesn't have a lot of weapons by modern standards, but they all have a purpose. I rather have a game that has less weapons but all have a purpose than a game that has 100 weapons but you use only 5 at most. And this is coming from a gun-nut who appreciates weapon variety in games, as long as all (or most) have a use.

Now on to the bad. Obviously, graphics have aged poorly even with HD models enabled. Speaking of the HD pack, I don't see the hate around them. It makes the models a little more pleasant to look at. My problem is that it replaces the MP5 with an M4 carbine AND IT STILL USES THE PISTOL ROUNDS FROM THE PISTOL. With the MP5, I understand as it uses 9mm bullets, but not with a rifle.

As for the human enemies (i.e. the Marines), they are one of the strongest enemies in the game (even stronger than most aliens). They require a lot of bullets to take down (though this can be attributed to their body armor). But remember when I said all enemies require tactics and the AI is well-coded? You will see this with the Marines. They won't stand out in the middle of the open with no sense of self-preservation. No, they will act and co-ordinate like a team. It's almost as if they're like the military (oh wait). If you are in cover, they will flush you out with grenades. If you do enough damage, they will retreat. If you run away to recuperate, they won't blindly chase you (though they sometimes will), they will wait in ambush for you when you come back. I know I was going to talk about the bad, but the bad thing about the Marines is that added to all these, they are bullet sponges. Even shotguns sometimes make them tickle. But for some strange reason, firefights with them are some of the best parts of the game.

I spoke a lot about this game and I'm sure I missed some (or even a lot) of other good things, but I just wanted to explain why this game is so awesome to me, and how modern games still struggle to reach even close to HL1. This game is a masterpiece. After playing this, you will never look at other shooters the same again.

Half-Life is alright... it is product of it's time. The graphics are aged, dialog and storytelling is bad and the VO is not great.
Graphic wise, this game was made a long time ago, so old graphics are to be expected. However some of the textures and lighting just don't quite work, and often ruin the sense of immersion.
Dialog and Storytelling are the main issues with this game. You have to stand right up to the people talking to even hear them, and often you wont even know they are telling you something, meaning you have no clue what to do in the story or why you are doing certain tasks (such as going to lambda station).
This issue leads into the VO. Clearly, Valve was only just getting the hang of things and their studio hadn't been able to get in "New" recording tech. And that is noticeable in this game.
Often I found myself bored and wondering "When will this game end???", and whenever i think that, something is wrong.
So, for these reasons, I don't believe I would ever play Half-Life again. However, if you have played other Half-Life games and want to see where it started like i did, I would recommend it, as at least you have that sense of curiosity to keep you going.
Half-Life gets a 4/10.

Well, let's see, we have a good one here folks. Half Life was valve's debut title, but this is no rushed, poorly made, mess of a game, no, not at all. Half Life is one of the most revolutionary and fun shooters that I have played in a good while, and while it's graphics are dated, I still recommend it over Black Mesa because of the map layouts feeling better with more comfortable enemy AI. This game is so good in fact, that a twitch series parodying this game blew up and now my profile pic is from that series. While that series uses Half Life: Source, I do not recommend that version since HL: Source was clearly rushed with many bugs and glitches. Overall, it takes a while to get used to this game, but when you do, it feels like an adrenaline rush of an adventure. Now before I go, I do want to mention the combat in this game. The combat in Half Life feels great, but not everybody will like it. The combat in Half Life uses strategy- wait, wait stop, stop walking away.
When I say strategic, I mean that the combat has you revisiting encounters to see what works and what doesn't, and while it sounds boring, it's what makes the game shine. The combat in Half Life is better than any other fps I've played with it's over powered, but low ammo weapons like the "Tas Cannon" and "Gluon Gun", to the more simple weapons, like a machine gun that also fires grenades, or an alien that you shove your hand into, which makes you able to shoot smaller aliens that are like little homing missiles. This game is crazy, and while people poop on the ending area, Xen, I got past it pretty quick, and while it was boring at times in Xen, the rest of the game was one of the best fps games I have ever played.
I absolutely recommend this game, and it's only $10, but wait for the summer sale, so you can get the half life complete bundle for about $17 or less. Half Life Complete includes: (Half Life, Half Life: Source, Half Life: Blue Shift, Half Life: Opposing Force, Half Life Deathmatch, HL: Deathmatch Source, Half Life 2, HL2: Episode 1&2, etc.)

Half-Life is a gem of the videogaming history that puts you in the shoes of Gordon Freeman, a physicist who, following an accident during an experiment in the Black Mesa Research Facility, must survive an alien invasion and stop it.

I'm not going to lie, I never played an Half-Life game before. However, I constantly heard about how great the series was and decided to give it a shot. What do I have to say? The game still holds up in 2020 (it came out in 1998) and has got a beautiful story.

The puzzles aren't easy and they do require some thinking before doing anything. Nothing in the game's world is put randomly, and even the small detail can make the difference. The same thing applies for the fights, thank to its complex AIs. You have to pay attention to your enemies and the game will not hesitate to punish you if you stay in a safe spot for too long.

I'd easily give this game a 8/10. The graphics, for the time it was created, were good and, generally speaking, is still able to excite and entertain even today. Great job, Valve!

This game is a classic... of sorts. It's an important historical milestone, like star wars. Also like star wars this isn't the original version. the UI is different, most of the stuff that I remember causing me grief is still here, most of the stuff I liked is gone. This is the "Special Edition" of Half life, that retains many of the bugs of the original: invisible walls, janky physics that will get you stuck mid loading screen, jerky motion, dumb AI... However you do get some of the improvements of the modern era: widescreen resolution (that you could get in the original just as easily), simplified soulless UI, HD models that are less detailed than the originals. 

The game is a fun romp, through Black Mesa. The people in charge of this project, particularly the level designers are clearly talented and excel at something that .... few modern games do well, environmental storytelling. It also has some non-environmental storytelling, and no unskippable cutscenes. Instead you have unskippable tedious sections. "host_framerate 0.09" bind that to a button, trust me. 

The platforming is surprisingly good. At least not nearly as infuriating as in BMS. Except the launchpads trigger in a very janky way, are totally unreliable, and the cases where you would need them always have some time pressure which makes this doubly more infuriating. Obviously this could've been fixed years later... It wasn't but at least you have an M4 instead of an MP5. 

The later half of the game: xen, is thankfully less than half of the game. It's tedious, but mercifully short and to the point. A virtue that BMS lacks. 

The combat is highly reliant on level design. This is great in most cases, because the level design in the main half of the life (pardon the pun), is actually not bad. Despite the fact that marines are hitscanning grenade spamming gods, they can be cracked just like a puzzle. It's run think shoot. If that's your jam, I'd advise you to play Deus Ex, but this is an acceptable introduction to the genre of shooters where brain is as important as brawn. 

This game isn't ideal, but not by any means terrible. You can't legally obtain the masterpiece that this version is based upon, but it is nearly as good as the old game. If you have disposable income and want this exact game because you want to experience **half life** this is the best legally available version. If not, and you simply want to try half life... you're better off without it. This game pioneered the genre of run think story driven shooters, but its execution is extremely rough. It has a remarkable atmosphere and some jank that you either love or hate. If you do, this version is doubly infuriating because that delicate nostalgia is tampered with... if not, you will feel that this game is about as polished as a brick wall, and you will feel cheated. This game's rough edges are atoned for by the retro atmosphere, despite its very modern formulaic approach. it is unfortunate, but it lacked the creative genius of Warren Specter, and the technological finesse of John Carmack. What it had instead, was much better, but has become so prolific that better, more polished implementations of this very formula suffuse the modern gaming markets. It's not at all terrible, but not a solid recommendation. It's still WAY better than Black Mesa Source, so I would encourage you to play this instead of that. 

P.S. On Linux, I would recommend using the native executable, for the fonts. The performance deficiency is barely noticeable, and while I did have tentative success running Brutal Half life, it crashed very frequently. I would advise not using Steam Play unlike Black Mesa Source.

Oooh, i get to be a contrarian! Yay!

In all seriousness, I would enjoy Half Life. I might enjoy it a lot... if not for the unintuitive level design and interaction.
I can't count the number of times I've lost my damn mind stepping onto something which looked safe, but wasn't (even though it seemed identical to another safe thing) and when I failed to reach a platform or latch onto a surface because I wasn't doing the right keyboard shuffle when I hit it.

When you get past all these little complaints... it just feels like a shooter game. Granted, it's enjoyable, but I don't see what's particularly special about it.
I'm sure it was really good for it's time, but it's probably like Star Wars or most cartoons: it's only truly enjoyable if you grew up with it, and I didn't. I heard there was a fan-based remake of this game, and I'm sure I'd love it to death. But not right now, my forehead is bruised from slamming it against the keyboard so many times.

Half-life (symbol t1‚ÅÑ2) is the time required for a quantity to reduce to half of its initial value. The term is commonly used in nuclear physics to describe how quickly unstable atoms undergo, or how long stable atoms survive, radioactive decay. The term is also used more generally to characterize any type of exponential or non-exponential decay. For example, the medical sciences refer to the biological half-life of drugs and other chemicals in the human body. The converse of half-life is doubling time.

The original term, half-life period, dating to Ernest Rutherford's discovery of the principle in 1907, was shortened to half-life in the early 1950s.[1] Rutherford applied the principle of a radioactive element's half-life to studies of age determination of rocks by measuring the decay period of radium to lead-206.

Half-life is constant over the lifetime of an exponentially decaying quantity, and it is a characteristic unit for the exponential decay equation. The accompanying table shows the reduction of a quantity as a function of the number of half-lives elapsed.

Half-Life is an absolute classic. It's right up there with Doom, Quake and Blood as one of the most influential FPS games ever made. Half-Life 2 (and Half-Life: Alyx!) would go on to continue Half-Life's legacy of innovation.  

That being said, it's got some 90s jank, for sure. Maybe I'm just bad at the game, but I get killed by doors more often than I'd like to admit, and some scripting sequences have a tendency to kill me too LOL. I won't even talk about how jank ladders are...

Although I never played Half-Life when it first came out, I still find this game to be pretty darn appealing. Although it's an old school first-person, shooter, it manages to hold up for the most part. If you are a fan of sci-fi/horror you will more than likely appreciate this game. 

I find the controls are for the most part fluid. It very much reminds me of Doom controls in terms of how speedy your character moves around the environment. That being said, the most frustrating part of this game also include the controls in terms of the jumping mechanics and especially going up and down ladders. Despite these flaws, I was still able to obtain much enjoyment from the game.

The enemies in this game are pretty basic sci-fi horror tropes but they do provide a little bit of variety. Being a fairly old game, it doesn't feel incredibly intoxicating when you kill your enemies but despite how old it is, it still provides some pleasure when killing the various foes you encounter throughout your journey.

All in all, I loved the game's story-concept and most of the gameplay. Although I think it would be difficult for younger gamers to appreciate the old-school look and mechanics of the game, it can, with time, still be appreciated as the masterpiece it was and still is.

I'm sure some folks will write me off as just being bad at the game, or being too stupid to comprehend how amazing it is for a game that came out in 1998, and make other such excuses to invalidate my opinion. I've played more than enough old games to know what I'm talking about. If I gave it some more effort and gave it a second playthrough, then sure, maybe I'd end up loving it, it's happened before. But much like other important games from the 90's, this one takes a tremendous amount of effort to have fun with. I respect this game for what innovations it brought to the table, but the number of times I groaned and said "Fuck I hate this game" while playing it started to add up to the point I can't heartily recommend it to newcomers without adding a thick air of caution. Half-Life is a good experience and a great history lesson. The innovations it presents are taken for granted now (Barring needlessly minute AI programming that the player will likely never see in-game, such as programmed scents). The game is fun but definitely suffers from the poor shooting mechanics of Goldsrc (That later carried over to Source games). Guns feel floaty and non-impactful, some of the puzzles can be annoying. enemy AI is well-designed but fairly simplistic, and the difficulty is very inconsistent from moment-to-moment. There are definitely things that die-hard fans will defend as essential pieces of the experience, but to the average gamer they are simply annoyances.

Half-Life is an important part of FPS history, and that's where it's main value lies now, but it is still [i]fun[/i], even if that fun is at times bogged down by frustrating level design or mechanics. The fast paced, run and gun gameplay is addictive, and the weapons are fun to use and experiment with. The story and moment-to-moment scenes of interacting with the Black Mesa staff are enjoyable. The dialogue is humorous and the game knows when to be terrifying when it needs to. 

All in all I would recommend playing through it on medium difficulty and understanding the hype. If you're really interested in Half-Life, Black Mesa is a much more enjoyable experience but it would be wise to experience the original first. The Opposing Force expansion greatly improves on many aspects of this game by streamlining the experience and adding many more interesting weapons while cutting out the crap that plagued the first game. If you enjoy this title, I strongly recommend that one. 

4/5, a piece of history that has not aged well in many parts, but despite that, holds up strongly for pure fun factor.

One of the best games of the 90s that launched Valve into the current juggernaut that's taking mine and your money to this very day. This will forever be one of my personal favorites up there with its sequel.

You're immediately placed in the role of a guy running late for his job. Instead of hurrying you into the action like other shooters preceding it, Half-Life starts with a slow tram ride intro that masterfully sets the scene and takes you into the heart of this mysterious underground research lab, Black Mesa, which is something akin to Area 51.

You'll pass through security checkpoints, get suited up, maybe blow up a casserole, and take in the atmosphere this game creates around you, before putting you in a frantic escape situation when your experiment goes awry.

Valve really wanted to make the game feel like a continuous narrative, where you never leave the POV of your character for cutscenes, mission breaks, etc. Each area connects directly from the previous, making Half-Life feel like it has a sprawling contiguous map, even though short loading screens help hide the map breaks.

The graphics definitely look like a product of 1998. You'll encounter flappy muppet mouthed scientists and security guards all throughout the facility, all speaking in the same couple of voices. Valve is no stranger to overusing the same few skins and voice actors, and that is a trend that carries over into Half-Life 2.

Enemy AI was groundbreaking for the time. Marines can dynamically coordinate with each other and their tactics are not easy to predict. There's a wide variety of enemies here ranging from your basic alien fauna, the enslaved vortigaunts and alien grunts, the US marines sent in to "hush up" the situation, and a course, zombies.

Though NPCs are mostly generic, there is one character you'll notice "observing" your progress from time to time. It's the enigmatic GMan, whose purpose in all this remains unexplained to this day.

Towards the end of the game you are teleported to a parallel world known as Xen where the final confrontation takes place, and many people rightfully recognize it as the most poorly aged and out of place portion of the game. There are a few sections that could've been trimmed (namely the On a Rail chapter) but overall the game is very well paced and it's clear Gaben and crew knew how to keep the player interested and pushing forward. 

This is a classic shooter and you owe it to yourself to play it at least once. It works flawlessly on modern systems. If you absolutely can't get past the graphics, look up Black Mesa which is an unofficial remake and does a pretty good job of what it sets out to do, though it's no replacement for the original.

Half-Life is a great game. Easily one of my favorite games of all time and I only started playing it this year. The main game is great. I love running through the halls of the Black Mesa Research Facility and blasting aliens and HECU grunts. The only parts of the game I could really do without are On A Rail and the majority of Interloper. Xen in general was kind of an anticlimactic disappointment after the downright amazing game before it. When you start playing Xen, you wish you were back in the Black Mesa Facility and that feeling never goes away even after you defeat Nihilanth. Speaking of Nihilanth, I found the fight to be way too easy. Nihilanth does next to nothing except for use cheap attacks that can kill you even if you're at full health. I would've preferred a much more interesting fight for a final boss but when it was over, there was still a great sense of accomplishment. Everything before Xen is great but Xen itself is mediocre. I love this game to death and the online multiplayer adds to that. The multiplayer is very fun and I'm online most days due to the multiplayer. I've replayed the campaign for a second time partially and I'm loving it all over again. Valve made an excellent product when they released Half-Life. It's just too much fun to stay away from for long.

In short, 8.5/10 would highly recommend regardless of whether or not it's on sale. I'd say $10.00 is way too low for Half-Life. I would've gladly paid more for it.

This is a completely revolutionary fps for the time, but yes it has aged quite a bit. Firstly the graphics aren't to hot and the bullets feel kind of weird. Also I heard that valve won a prize for making the smallest aiming reticle possible. And while I'm sure some of this sounds bad if your willing to look past these issues you got a great game. The story is captivating except for around the middle were it feels like your kind of just going down a never ending tunnel of tasks. But the first 6 and the last 4 chapters are awesome because there able to tell so much story without any crazy cutscenes. And the selection of weapons are out standing for the time considering each gun has there pros and cons. And there are multiple ways of going after and enemy and you kind of pick your own play style. The world is massive and lively the story (for the most part) is stellar the shooting and graphics are kind of meh but it's all worth it. Definitly reccomend this game to a person willing to let go of issues like un modern graphics and game design to experience a classic gem valve has made changing PC fps for ever.

Okay, so we all know about Half-Life. Being Valve's debut title and setting the standard for FPS games of today.
But I'll blab about it anyway.

Dr. Gordon Freeman: Theoretical Physicist, is late for work at Black Mesa; a research facility that specializes in portal technology. After donning his HEV (Hazardous EnVironment) suit, He proceeds to Anomalous Materials to preform an experiment with his fellow scientists; where they accidentally cause a resonance cascade, which rips open a portal to Xen: A dimension home to a bunch of aliens that start pouring in, leaving the staff and Gordon to defend themselves.

Things get worse when the HECU (Hazardous Environment Combat Unit) arrive. They're the military's cleanup crew you see? But not only are they're here to exterminate the aliens, But also terminate anyone associated with the project to prevent public panic, Their primary target: Freeman himself.

So now we got the scientists and security team left helpless, the aliens invading Earth, The HECU trying to eliminate both factions, and Gordon is stuck in the middle initially trying to escape the facility, then finding the lambda team to contain the situation, finally heading to Xen to end the invasion once and for all.

But first he needs to make his way through the damaged facility, use an old rail system, traverse an abandoned waste disposal plant, then head to the surface where the HECU are waiting for him. Luckily for Gordon despite being a science guy, He's pretty handy with guns, Loads of guns. Plus a crowbar.

Now as for the gameplay, it's what you expect: You shoot things, reload if needed, gather ammo and health, repeat. But you also do some platforming here and there as well as vent-crawling. However despite it being influential story-wise the game itself is kinda mediocre, It's not godawful, only serviceable. For example the machine gun (either an MP5 or M4 with the HD pack turned on) is an absolute bullet hose, where the redeeming factor is its grenade launcher. not all guns are bad mind you, but that's the one people tend to bring up. Moving on, you can have NPCs follow you (scientists to open doors with eye-scanners and security guards to aid you in combat) albeit the AI is a bit derpy.

Finally there's the HEV suit, at a glance it's just a fancy looking hazmat suit, but it's a fancy looking hazmat suit that's awesome! Not only does it administer morphine when at critical health to keep you going, it can be used to traverse unsafe locations of course, but also act as an armor of sorts against the many enemies you come across. It even comes with a flashlight!

While Half-Life is a bit slow in the beginning where it might turn some people off and some parts can be frustrating to the point of save-scumming, It's still playable and being updated to this day along with its expansion packs, but I'll cover those later. 

In conclusion, Mr.Freeman: Run. Think. Shoot. Live.

This game STILL influences over 20 years later and is STILL one of my top 10 games I've ever played. This review is for those who wonder whether they should play this post-2020. 

The one thing that keeps me coming back to Half Life time and time again is the AI and  level design. This game doesn't have cut scenes but instead puts you into dire situations and in unconventional environments (gun fight while descending a cliff). You are almost always on the brink of death and forced to think about how you can use your environment and current ammo to your advantage. This game celebrates creativity and never has you wondering "will the game let me do this?" instead the game says "go for it". For example... imagine this scene which represents only 30 seconds of gameplay:

I am out of heavy ammo, low on health, and just got out of combat. I cut a turn and see the path ahead is the top of a dam. It looks like I will need to cross it. To the right of that dam is a huge body of water and a lighthouse stands in the middle of it. I start sprinting along the top of the dam to get to the other side. When I reach the center, I hear what sounds like a helicopter's blades. Suddenly a helicopter appears over the horizon. Helicopters, in this game, don't go down easy and I currently don't have the means to destroy it. The helicopter begins shooting at me. The first bullets miss and land 10 ft in front of me but the trail of bullets quickly climb towards me. I'm wide open and completely exposed. In panic, I make a sharp right and dive 200ft off the dam into the water to escape the gunfire. The gravity of the fall puts me several feet underwater and I hear something snarling down here. I look down to see a piranha/shark-like creature with jaws open wide and coming at me fast. At the same time, the helicopter's bullets begin to rain down from above. The bullets are slowed down slightly by the water but I still get hit. I start swimming as quickly as possible to the lighthouse and see a ladder I can climb. I get bit by the shark-like creature as I climb up the ladder. Finally I find myself in a control room with a big red button where I can catch my breath. The helicopter circles the lighthouse and manages to hit me through some windows, I quickly push the red button and hear something underwater opening. Which means, now I'll need to go back underwater and face the shark/dodge the helicopter to find that open hatch in order to escape. I dive back into the water.

And that's just 30 seconds of gameplay. You could approach that same situation in a number of different ways, this is just how I experienced it. That's how the whole game is. It's a thrill ride from start to finish. Go in blind, don't look up anything online for help and experience this game fresh. I wish I could go back and experience this one again for the first time.

TLDR:  Rail-shooter that once set a standard and is now showing its age.

I remember when Half-Life spilled onto the scene twenty years ago. At the time, people were still arguing the supremacy of Quake vs Duke Nukem vs Doom for the king of the FPS heap. Then in stumbled a new game, sometimes dubbed the "thinking man's FPS" and the genre was never the same again.

I got it on Steam mostly on the nostalgia factor; I sank so many hours into it back in the day I wanted to see if still measured up. Taken in isolation and compared to the games of its day, I think it did all right ... but as one would expect it has ceded ground to newer and better shooters since then.

Half-Life is the story of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist at Black Mesa, a top-secret research facility where scientists are monkeying with stuff they shouldn't be. As usual, that kind of nosiness doesn't end well. A dimensional gateway opens, flooding the facility with all kinds of beasts and it's then up to the player to help Freeman save the day. You'll find a crowbar to defend yourself, then plenty of other guns and goodies along the way. Eventually, the military will show up to rescue everyone ... I mean, "rescue" everyone and things get more complex.

Gameplay is straightforward, with a default WASD/mouse movement scheme, L/R clicks to attack and alternate attack. The controls are ... adequate. Certain objects--such as wheels and switches--can be interacted with to open doors, raise or lower water levels, move cranes out of the way of rail tracks, etc. The game pretty much has one path you can follow so if you find yourself unable to advance, you'll have to look for some of these items. Some advancement requires puzzle solving; for example, the Blast Pit requires the player to find and turn on the oxygen and fuel lines to fire a test rocket--though to get to those, you have to sneak past a blind but very powerful mob that can basically one-shot you. Just don't make a sound. Generally speaking, the puzzles add depth and tension to the game, though some are aggravating. Far too many points in the game require pinpoint running and jumping and I'm glad that (aside from platformers) modern games have largely left that trope in the dirt.

Enemies are varied and have their own behaviors. The most basic alien animals will simply charge. Humans will fire and seek cover. Some of the more exotic aliens present their own challenges. A handful of big ones are all but bulletproof, forcing you to find other ways to evade or defeat them.

The game's ambiance is pretty decent; before the disaster you'll see scientists and security going about their daily tasks, discussing experiments and other happenings at Black Mesa. After, you'll find their bodies, or see them getting attacked and eaten. Those that live often offer to help Freeman by opening doors or providing clues about how to get around certain mission objectives, and so on. You can ask security guards to follow you and they will do a decent job of attacking enemies for you (though the guards don't last too long). Consoles will randomly explode, radio messages about what's happening can be heard, and you'll come across the military fighting the monsters, in some places giving you the choice of running through while everyone's distracted or just killing them all.

One nice aspect is that because the game is older, it runs well on just about any modern machine, with a small footprint and virtually no disc space.

Having said all that, the game feels dated because, well, it is. Textures and shading are some of the most glaring examples. For all the NPCs you'll see, there are like three models for scientists and one for security guards, and all are pretty angular, even on higher resolutions. The game will sometimes load new areas and even on a powerful PC, will freeze in the middle of a hallway for five seconds with the word "LOADING" on the screen. While the sound is mostly good, it's limited. Each enemy tends to make one or two sounds, repeated over and over. There are only a handful of military "radio static" message patterns, all of which sound like dull squawks. Again, dated.

This game is also a fair bit harder than modern shooters. Maybe I was just younger with faster reflexes when it first came out but I remember back in the day HL being one of the only shooters where I felt the competitive multiplayer was more forgiving than the single-player game. Even on easy mode, it is very simple to get shredded in by enemies in HL, or fall to your death, get electrocuted, run into industrial fans, fry yourself in radioactive goop, etc. There are a lot of ways to die in every area and most players will find them.

My biggest gripe is about the controls which feel sloppy and uncontrolled. Simply tapping the AD keys (even holding Shift for "slow" movement) can send you flying to the side. Great when strafing to avoid combat. Bad during precision jumping sequences, which this game has aplenty of and the jumping, especially in places where you can't get a running start, feels very inconsistent.

Half-Life is a good game and a good throw back. I don't think most people will find as sharp as today's best shooters--in appearance, content, or interface--but if you can pick it up for a couple bucks, it's still worth playing.

Pros
- Nostalgia! Can still be fun, after all these years
- Minimal install, runs well on just about any modern machine

Cons
- Anyone who grew up on modern shooters is probably going to find it unforgiving
- Graphics, sound, and controls dated

Final Score: 6.5/10

It's hard to say anything that hasn't already been said about Half-Life.  A seminal work in the evolution of the FPS genre, this game didn't invent things so much as combine a lot of good ideas into a great, polished package.  Continuous, fixed perspective (i.e. no cut-scenes to interrupt the flow or deliver plot), environmental storytelling, light puzzle-platforming, and strategic enemy AI were not new, necessarily, when this game came out; Half-Life just does (most) of this consistently well.  Add a popular and active modding scene that pumped out amazing content, much of which went on to become full-fledged games of their own (Counter Strike, Day of Defeat, Natural Selection), and it's no wonder this game holds such a special place in many a gamer's heart.

It's not without flaws: some platforming is a little aggravating, the combat is alright by today's standards, and the last portion of the game ("Zen") is a departure in quality.  Even so, I can't help but look back fondly on this game, even the blemishes.  At least a bit of that is nostalgia, but there's plenty of games that I hold nostalgia for yet can't bear to play again because of how poorly they've aged.  This is a game I can easily come back to over the years and still have a fun time with.

If you're interested in experiencing some of the roots of the modern FPS genre, or are just looking for a quality game that will run out-of-the-proverbial-box on a potato, you're in for a good time.

[h1]A truly iconic game, a must-have for fans of FPS games.[/h1] (spoiler-free)
I wasn't at all into shooter games, before my boyfriend introduced me to the Half-Life franchise. At first, due to my lack of experience in shooters, I disliked this game and found it boring. And so it happened, I abandoned it for a year or so. After coming back, I fell in love with this game and am insanely proud it's my first PC FPS game.

The graphics are obviously not perfect as for today's standards, but to me they give that retro vibe which I haven't experienced back in 1998 due to my age. That too, you can play using the HD models (changeable through settings).
The story told is quite tragic, but at the same time is adventurous and thrilling. The player's goals change as the game progresses, which doesn't let the gameplay get boring. Puzzles are also available.
There are no cutscenes in the game, the story is told by the environment and npcs, causing you to carefully listen and observe. Sadly for me (non-english speaker) there are no subtitles available.
The silence of Gordon Freeman throughout the game really lets all your emotions and feelings to be freely expressed, without you having to play as a personality that's not yours. Your personality becomes Gordon's personality.
The game is amazingly optimized for modern pcs, on my old non-gaming laptop the game ran pretty smooth, only rarely experiencing framedrops in intense scenes.
The game does indeed have flaws, but they're minor and can be reasoned by the limitations of the time it was made in.

I have a lot to say about this game, but I'll start off with: 
-
Interesting and deep story line + many fire fights and some puzzle elements = Very fun even for a first game by Valve. (For those who didn't know, Half-Life is the first game Valve ever made) And to people who are confused as to which version of this game to buy if you haven't played already, get this 1998 release version. Half-Life Source is only VISUALLY better. The source version has some more game breaking bugs than the original 98 release which is disappointing and can at times ruin the experience if you're not aware of it while playing. Not to say this version is perfectly bug free, but it's the best stable version there is.
-
Side note: Most people must have at least *heard* of Half-Life. Who doesn't know about Gordon Freeman and his trusty Crowbar? He is an iconic character to me. Idk about you but even though he's a silent protag, the game gets the messages across mostly well.
-
This game in my personal opinion is great for those who are into first person shooters, and like solving some puzzles on the side. Because there's some sections where you can get stuck if you're either not paying attention or are not careful. I've gotten stuck plenty of times trust me. Overall, I'd say experience Half-Life if you haven't already.

I‚Äôm not sure how much I have left to say about [i]Half-Life[/i].

I write a [i]Half-Life[/i] comic, see ‚Äì a mightily expensive bit of fan-fiction (if this opens me up to charges of bias, I apologise; hopefully the game‚Äôs reputation can supersede them). So professionally it‚Äôs taken up a lot of my imaginative space for the past five years, a period of time in which, for most other people, [i]Half-Life[/i] was more or less dead. Almost everything I‚Äôve had to say has been poured into that comic and there‚Äôs still a few years left on it. Perhaps even another five. I‚Äôm conscious of wearing myself out.

At the same time, it‚Äôs important to stay rooted in [i]Half-Life[/i] so I don‚Äôt risk straying too far from the franchise that kick-started the whole endeavour.

And so roughly every couple of years I revisit the series to check in with the characters and world. It runs the risk of tedium, but luckily for me [i]Half-Life[/i] is still as playable and entertaining as ever.

[h1]DOCTOR FREEMAN THE PRUH-FESH-UH-NL[/h1]

A watershed moment for the first-person shooter, [i]Half-Life[/i] would instil in Valve the belief that in order for the series to go forward, it would consistently need to reach the heights of the game that started it all. A tall order, but one they have proven time and again they‚Äôre capable of meeting.

Revisiting it last week, I was reminded of how I experienced [i]Half-Life[/i] as a 10-year-old (11?) kid. I was so enthralled with the prospect of being hapless theoretical physicist Gordon Freeman that I‚Äôd effectively role-play specific sequences. It was a way of corralling the narrative to fit my desires ‚Äì a testament to the relative elasticity of Valve‚Äôs design, the potency of the game‚Äôs immersive setting, and, clearly, an early warning sign as to my latent obsessive tendencies.

When the tram came to a stop outside the Anomalous Materials lab where Freeman works, I‚Äôd keep shift pressed down from the moment the door opened to the eventual test chamber disaster. I knew Freeman was late, but I didn‚Äôt imagine him running through the steel corridors like a madman; I wanted him to be a professional. (Now I crouch-jump through the lab and hop on tables when characters are speaking, studiously turning my back on them.)

And when a certain crucial decision had to be made, I‚Äôd walk Doctor Freeman to the end of the tram to gaze into the colourless void in mock contemplation. (Now I make my choice the moment it‚Äôs available for me to do so, checking off another completed playthrough.)

I had more time then. Now I‚Äôve got other, more adult things to be getting on with.

Like writing comic-books based on video-games.

[h1]LEGACY[/h1]

Valve‚Äôs achievement was, and remains, monumental. With its tale of science-gone-awry unleashing interdimensional chaos on a top secret facility, there was nothing unique in and of itself about [i]Half-Life's[/i] story. But in terms of the way that story was [i]told[/i], in immersing players in its smartly realised setting and placing them at the heart of the unfolding drama, they created something unforgettable.

Its story was a simple one, but it changed the way developers approached how they thought about storytelling ‚Äì especially in the domain of the first-person shooter.

It changed the way I thought about them, too.

The moment you push the crystal into the beam and split the world, I get chills. As arcs of green energy lash angrily across the chamber and glittering particles of light materialise above, drawn to the crystal like a moth to the flame, I am reminded of what it was like to experience [i]Half-Life[/i] for the very first time. And in doing so, I am reminded of how what came next shaped who I am today.

I didn‚Äôt know it when I was a kid, but Gordon Freeman‚Äôs mishap would resonate far beyond Black Mesa, rippling through time and space and giving birth to a cast of characters I‚Äôve been proud to spend a good chunk of my adult life with.

It‚Äôs impossible to experience [i]Half-Life[/i] without them. I‚Äôm grateful for that.

And here I am now, nearly 800 words in, having only planned to write a short piece about how [i]Half-Life[/i] still holds up today. But you‚Äôve read enough about that. You already [i]know[/i] that. The Resonance Cascade left a sizeable dent, impossible to ignore, secure in its legacy ‚Äì an inflection point, from Freeman‚Äôs dim prospects as a theoretical physicist to the very shape of the first-person shooter. And to my professional life as a writer.

Twenty years later and apparently I still have plenty to say about bloody [i]Half-Life[/i]. I don't know whether or not I should be embarrassed about that, but at least the 11-year-old (10?) me would've been happy.

In a way, I'm still pressing down shift.

despite coming out in 1998, this game is still amazing. although yes, I did enjoy Half life 2 more, it's still impossible to criticize this game. time has not been kind to the 1990's graphics and low resolution and blocky models, but there is still some satisfaction in blasting through the countless obstacles (with the occasional help of noclip). I would recommend disabling blood and gibs via the parental control in the options, as things can get rather violent at times. every chapter of the game has multiple mini-bosses which you have to fight using not only locations on the map (such as electro-frying a gargantua), but also cooking headcrabs, houndeyes, bullsquid, and everything under the sun with half life's weapons. even though the gravity gun didn't exist yet, and some today call this game's guns rudimentary, it's still impressive. even if you like modern graphics or better weapons, if you want to blast some HECU marines, aliens, or even your own allies, then spend some money and get ready to mind-blow your friends with this game! (not being sarcastic, BTW)

Just gonna be honest. I enjoyed the first hour or two of the game, seeing the infamous black mesa that is referenced so often in newer half life games. But over time the gameplay gets stale and frustrating. It gets progressively more difficult, to a point at which you have to reload saves continuously in order to perfect your play. health is so scarce that if you complete an area but lose a tiny amount of health, chances are you are going to restart it in order to do it without losing health. From the exceptional reviews i was assuming the game would still hold up, even for a new player in 2020. And it did, for a little while. Older games typically revolve around the save and reload mechanic, allowing them to make exceptionally difficult levels that you can brute force your way through, but its just not fun or immersive when compared with the modern style of game. The graphics aren't great but when i finished the game the graphics were not what left a sour taste in my mouth. Instead, the slippery movement and the bullet sink enemies left me feeling frustrated and bored. Levels which involved platforming were so annoying because whenever gordon moves it feels like he is sliding about an ice rink. Intro:

Released in 1998 for the PC, Half-Life runs on the GoldSrc engine, which is a heavily modified version of the Quake engine. This game is well known for pioneering story-telling in video games. Video games before Half-Life had very simple stories, usually written at the back of the box. Games like DOOM focused mainly on the gameplay, leaving story as an after thought. Half-Life aimed to change this, and it succeeded tenfold. 

Gameplay: 

Half-Life is a typical late 90's shooter. You have your roster of guns and can carry all of them (as soon as you obtain them), you move quickly and therefore, combat is very fast paced. If you aren't an old-school FPS player, then I recommend playing the game on Easy if you've never played it before, as the higher difficulties can prove to be quite brutal. 
The gunplay feels great, with a wide variety of weapons to choose from, and almost all of them serving some sort of purpose throughout the campaign. (i.e. pistol for picking off headcrabs and barnicles, shotgun for tankier enemies, magnum and crossbow for long range etc.). There is also a wide variety of enemies. Early on, you will be fighting aliens and zombies,  but later in the game there will be marines and assassins, as well as more difficult alien enemies, each with their own quirks to spice up gameplay. In the end, it feels like a game of chess, as each gun serves a different purpose and is good against different enemy types. One issue I have with the gunplay is that it this game has no bullets, but instead, hitscan weapons, meaning there is no way to dodge the projectiles fired by marines and some aliens like the vortigaunts. Overall though, gameplay is very satisfying. 

Level Design: 

Level design, for the most part, is fantastic. The game has 18 chapters total, and each chapter is split into multiple levels. The transitions between levels are smooth and fast on modern machines, and hardly break the immersion of gameplay. Some levels also have very well designed arenas to combat enemies in. 
That said, this game is extremely linear, but I'd say this works in its favor, as it aims to tell a story in a fully interactive environment. Control is never taken away from the player, and the introductory 2 chapters are completely devoid of combat. This makes for an extremely memorable experience, not seen in many games nowadays, which tend to overuse cutscenes and feel more like movies than actual games. 
The only part of the level design I did not enjoy, were the Xen levels (During the last quarter of the game), which feel very rushed and barren compared to the rest of the game. If you don't particularly care about the story, I might go as far as suggesting you skip these levels, as they are mostly just platforming, with small combat sections in between. (The first Xen chapter can literally be beaten in about 5 minutes during normal play)

Story: 

The story follows Gordon Freeman, a young theoretical physicist who works in the Black Mesa research facility. One day however, an experiment he is a part of goes horribly wrong, opening an inter-dimensional portal to a border world known as "Xen". Aliens from said world start flooding our world, and soon the entire research facility is overrun by them, and it is up to Gordon and his fellow scientist to find a way to close the dimensional rift before it is too late.
Throughout the entire plot, Gordon does not utter a single word, nor does he have any background other than the theoretical physicist part, meaning he is the perfect vessel for the player. Want to be a complete psychopath and slaughter everyone in your path, including your fellow scientists? The game lets you do that. This is one huge advantage that other games of this time period or later don't have, be it due to essential NPC's or morality in-game choices.  
I will not spoil the ending (though most people most likely already know it by now), but I will say that for newcomers to the series, the story becomes very interesting the further you go, mostly because of a mysterious figure you will be seeing throughout the game known as the "G-Man". 
The story itself isn't anything groundbreaking, but it's the way it is presented to the player which makes it memorable. As mentioned before, you are always in control, and therefore, feel like a part of the game world. 

Graphics: 

Graphically, this is the game's weakest aspect. The graphics have aged horribly, and textures are upscaled and heavily pixelated. Models are also quite low-poly, especially if you aren't using the HD models (can be toggled inside the options). Some people may enjoy the graphics style due to its retro charm, but most may be put off by it. On the bright side, the game  fully supports modern resolutions and can be played in 1080p (And I think even 4K, but I was unable to test it) and at 60 FPS. 

Sound: 

This game has brilliant sound design. From environmental echoes, to amazing gun sounds and the occasional music that plays during combat, fitting perfectly with both the atmosphere of the game and rythm of the combat. Voice acting on the other hand, however, isn't that great, and some voice lines are quite low quality. 

Verdict/Conclusion: 

Half-Life pioneered story-telling in video games. Not only does it perfectly incorporate its story into the gameplay, never even once taking control away from the player, but it is also extremely satisfying with its gunplay. The story, although nothing spectacular, is strengthened by the fact mentioned above. Graphics have a neat retro feel to them, but may be off-putting for most. Level design is stellar, and outside of the few ending chapters, it has great pacing and combat sequences, as well as memorable set-pieces. Sound design suffers only from poorly recorded voice lines here and there, but overall does a great job to immerse the player and have guns sound like they truly pack a punch. Overall, this game gets a 10/10 for me, as it is one of the most influential games of all time, and should be in any FPS enthusiast's library.

Movement is like sliding on butter, the game tries to autoaim your gun for you and fails miserably, some enemies will happily one shot you, some enemies are unkillable, movement in the air is nearly impossible and incredibly inconsistent, environmental cues trigger without warning and will one shot you. Put these all together, and you get every level in the game, the final boss with this is amplified to such an aggravating extent. Games that are hard to be difficult, like Cuphead and Dark Souls have fleshed out systems that only sometimes toss you for no reason. This game, a normal game, tosses you every few minutes. I attribute most of this to how old it is, and that's okay - it just was not a fun game for me.

[h1]Even more than 20 years after its release Half-Life is still among my personal Top 5 best games of all time. It‚Äòll be very difficult for me to describe this game without using superlatives in every sentence. [/h1]

Before i played Half-Life at some point during 1999, i already had brief experiences with earlier 3D shooters. I knew what Doom was, had briefly played Golden Eye and Duke Nukem 3D on a friend‚Äòs N64 and even had few Botmatches in Unreal. They were all good fun, but compared to Half-Life seemed downright unimpressive all of a sudden. Half-Life was the game that ultimately converted me into a dedicated FPS fan until today and it was the first game that completely sucked me in with its atmosphere and cinematic approach. At least in terms of overall gameplay, pacing, story-telling and building atmosphere, i still compare every fps to the Half-Life series to this day, particularly the first game.

To speak about the story is somewhat redundant at this point, because i guess EVERY gamer knows about the basic premise of Half-Life. But to sum it up shortly: You play as 27 years old physicist Gordon Freeman, who works at the Black Mesa Research Facility, located deep within the deserts of New Mexico. One morning you play a crucial role in an experiment with a strange and seemingly extraterrestrial material, which goes horribly awry. The experiment opens up various portals to another dimension and as a consequence Black Mesa and the surrounding desert are flooded with foreign creatures intend on killing everyone and everything. As Gordon, your one and only goal is to make it out of the research facility alive and escape the chaos surrounding you.
The story itself is as basic as every other fps from throughout the 90s. It is basically a combination of the plots of Doom and Quake (extraterrestrial beeings attack through portals after experiment went wrong) and Unreal (protagonist tries to escape from a desperate, live-threatening situation after severe accident). What sets Half-Life apart from the likes of Doom and Quake and really made it raising the bar for fps game design (along with Unreal to be fair), is not the story itself, but how it was told. There were no cutscenes and no screens full of explanatory text. You were witnessing the whole plot from Gordon‚Äòs eyes, never leaving this perspective and never being pulled out of the gameworld by seperate levels like in doom or quake. All you could see and hear the whole game through were the world, events and characters immediately surrounding you, and so you piece together the big puzzle by just paying attention to the things happening around you as you try to escape. The level design is so much more believable and immersive than in other fps of that time and this approach to world-building and storytelling is half-life‚Äôs biggest accomplishment and makes it the first action-movie that you yourself play the lead role in. Ever wondered how John McClane must have felt during ‚ÄûDie hard‚Äú, or Ellen Ripley during ‚ÄûAliens‚Äú? Go try Half-Life and you‚Äòll get the idea...

To be honest, the rest of Half-Life wasn‚Äôt that revolutionary even in 1998. I consider it to be pointless (and also a bit unfair) to discuss all the aspects of the game in great detail in 2020 and compare them to the recent standards of modern fps games. Just like the first Doom, Half-Life has maintained a status as sort of a timeless classic (rightfully so!!!) and the only way to get a somewhat objective, unbiased, nostalgia-free opinion on the game is to read a review from around the actual time of half-life‚Äôs release. But to avoid stirring up unrealistic expectations, it should be mentioned that grafics, controls, gunplay and sound were only slightly above average, if at all, at that time. Even the soundtrack, which for me personally is still among the best and most enjoyable video game soundtracks ever composed, sounds admittedly a bit dated nowadays, so it is somewhat forgivable if younger players fail to see the importance and impact this game had on the industry back in the late 90s and early 00s.
But between the releases of Doom in 1993 and Call of Duty 4 Modern Warfare in 2007, Half-Life has been THE most defining first person-shooter for almost 10 years straight. Fortnites, Battlefields and PUBGs come and go, but Half-Life will always be there in some form or another, even if we still have to wait for a conclusion to it‚Äôs story arc 13 years after the release of Half-Life 2 Episode 2 and the series basically being a living corpse (thx anyways valve for HL: Alyx, but that‚Äôs not what we hardcore Half-Life fans want *coughHL3cough*). The first Half-Life is one of those very rare games i‚Äòd say that not only fps enthusiasts but absolutely every gamer, from the super mario fans to the world of warcraft devotees, from the call of duty fanboys to the indie game worshipers, from the filthy console peasants to the glorious pc master race, from the 16 years old gamer girl to the 50 years old video game veteran, has to try at least once. What the Beatles‚Äò ‚ÄûSgt. Peppers lonely hearts club band‚Äú-album was for Rock- and Pop music, Half-Life 1 is for the FPS genre.

Playing this in the modern era (or at least, in the era I'm currently writing) may actually do this game a few favors. Mechanically, it's sound; it's an FPS on a PC, without radical movement concepts to wrangle. To be fair, there is annoying platforming sequence that tests the limits of jumping in a first person perspective. To its credit, it feels tacked on and doesn't make up a bulk of your interaction with the world. You'll often be shooting at things and using environmental puzzles to advance. Said puzzles are intuitive enough where you'll often know what to do without needing a guide, but not so obvious or repetitive where it feels like filler. 

Where this game has aged the best may be in its atmosphere. It's a special sort of isolated, haunting experience to play a game where you don't really know what the world is capable of. This title doesn't have to carry the weight of decades of spin-offs, sequels, one-shot comics, and the litany of other expanded universe bloat that current shooters suffer from. The primitive character models buoy the unease of uncovering an otherworldly mystery. There's an almost Lynchian aesthetic.

I don't have anything really new or insightful to say that hasn't been said.

Kind of a slow start but it picks up about a quarter of the way in. The action's rather good when you encounter it. I found Half-Life packed with a surprising amount of environmental puzzles, many of which were easy enough to understand but the in-game physics made them frustratingly clunky to execute. I see what the developers were going for but a few obstacles came across as obtuse. For example, some enemy vehicles you can destroy while identical others you strangely can't. I also got stuck on a particular level because I didn't know you had to duck-jump onto a box; why not just add one more knee-high box to the pile? Overall though, Half-Life still became addictive in its gun-battling and its (mostly) clever level design. I can understand why it was so groundbreaking in its day.

You've got to hand it to these guys. Valve Software is a start-up, a relative unknown, with no track and, really, no business making such a mighty game. But mighty it is, the best single player shooter I've ever played.
It will be hard for some--mainly those who haven't played the game--to put their finger on exactly what everyone is raving about. There's nothing exceptional about the engine--it's a heavily modified version of Id Software's Quake. Its genre, the first-person shooter, has nearly been beaten to death. Its design couldn't be simpler: get some guns, run, shoot, jump; no laborious cutscenes or misplaced RPG elements here.

The weapons aren't spectacular either, just your usual array of realistic modern firearms and a few alien gadgets with some new twists. The creatures in some respects are fairly standard, and many of the levels have been done before. Taken separately, no particular element in Half-Life shines above the rest, nothing makes or breaks the game.

No, the real secret is that Half-Life is truly the sum of its parts. It takes every element in this oh-so-predictable genre, re-examines it, improves it, and then meshes it with the rest to create a constantly surprising, internally consistent, and always entertaining game.

Here are some examples. How many games have you played where health packs, armor, ammo and guns are simply lying around as if some Power-Up Santa Claus had emptied the contents of his pack on the floor? You can almost hear the level designers saying to themselves, "Okay, a health pack would be a good item to put in this otherwise empty room."

In Half-Life, weapons and ammo are taken from dead soldiers or other logical places, like a weapons locker. Armor isn't lying around in the form of glowing icons or leather helmets--instead, you're wearing a battery-powered hazard suit, but since it's a fairly standard bit of equipment in this secret base, power outlets are conveniently scattered throughout the complex. Doing this makes the game world feel all that much more real. The more real it feels, the more the player is sucked into the game. This is called suspension of disbelief, and while few game developers seem to be aware of it, Valve is and they make it work for them, over and over.

How many times have you shot at a monster only to have it either grimace at you blankly, perhaps firing off a few tepid shots, or slouch and drool while you pick off his comrades? Well, not here. The teams of soldiers you'll fight in Half-Life have to be the toughest, most convincing enemies yet seen in an action game. Where other opponents grunt incomprehensibly, these guys actually yell stuff relevant to the combat, such as "Fire in the Hole!" or "Look out!" as the grenades go flying. Then they actually try to get away from your grenades. And what's more, they also throw grenades at you.

Grenades might sound like a simple little thing to add to a game, and perhaps it is, but it adds such an extra dimension to the monsters' combat ability that it's almost like playing a whole new genre. Strafe, fire, strafe, fire just simply doesn't work every time. But in every other game, monsters either attack hand to hand, with area affects, or most commonly, with linear shots. It doesn't matter if they're shooting lasers, M-16s, or dollops of hot blue manna, it all comes in a straight line, and it all can be dodged. But change the angle of attack, and it's a whole new game. One little detail--one huge difference.

But that's just part of the appeal of Half-Life's enemies; unlike other games, they also cooperate. Teamwork, for monsters in other games, is if they all happen to be in the same room shooting in the same direction. Here, the infantry squads will split up, trying to hit you from several sides while one guy keeps you pinned or lobs grenades. It's surprising how entertaining well-implemented artificial intelligence can be, and it's probably worth it to play Half-Life just to fight its infantry. There could be a whole game based on nothing but fighting Half-Life's infantry.

Wait, there's more. How many times have you cleaned out one filthy, gory techno-dungeon, only to find yourself at a door that obviously leads to yet another, even filthier, techno-dungeon? How realistic is it to have obvious entrances and exits to levels--and what is a "level" anyway? An archaic holdover from Dungeons & Dragons? A convenient way of breaking up the game world so it can be loaded into memory?

Half-Life does away with the arbitrary concept of levels. Instead the world feels like a continuous whole, with small pauses and loads when you move from one area to another. This does create some problems when monsters are placed too close to the transition between mini-levels and you inadvertently strafe from one area to the other, accidentally triggering a load screen. But this problem aside, Half-Life's mini-levels create a more flowing and realistic game world, and so a more immersive one.

And freed from the stereotypical notion of levels, the designers were free to experiment with a wide variety of environments, logically linked and fun to explore. Every room isn't another corridor or another slime-filled dungeon. There are labs and warehouses, monorail stations and gun bunkers, missile silos and parking garages. The bulk of the action takes place in a deep underground military base called the Black Mesa Facility, but it is not confined there. You'll scale a canyon cliff and scamper through a military base. You'll ride weird monorails and climb through pipes full of waste. Virtually every location in Half-Life is interesting and unique.

This variety makes you want to keep playing Half-Life all the way through. How many times have you gotten half way through another game, only to say to yourself, "Eh, I've probably seen it all. If I keep playing, there will only be more monsters, with more guns, more hit points and more grubby levels." This is decidedly not the case with Half-Life.

Carefully crafted for the single player experience, every encounter in Half-Life is a new challenge, nearly every room throws out something you haven't seen before, every sound is a worrying cue that something horrible is about to happen. The sheer number of hand-scripted events and little scenes keeps the action moving, giving you a reason to keep playing, if only to see what could possibly happen next. I haven't had so much fun playing a game in years. I have not been frightened by a game in years. I have not dreaded corners like I have dreaded corners in this game in years. Half-Life is a superbly ambient game.

Is the game perfect? Of course not. Some of the elevators have a horrible sticking problem, and the ladders can be awkward to use. Occasionally the game chokes when a huge explosion happens. But these are minor problems.

Slightly more serious is the character of Gordon Freeman, who is rather flat and dry. I realize that the mood and feel Half-Life is very somber, very much in the mold of The X-Files, and a wisecracking Duke Nukem type wouldn't have worked. As a scientist and a specialist trained to deal with hazardous materials, Freeman is the right kind of character to serve as the story's alter ego, but his near total lack of personality--as far as I can recall, he never says anything in the game--leaves a little to be desired. Still, you could make a case that giving him a personality could actually detract from your ability to identify with the character. And certainly, the use of cut scenes or any of the other crude crutches of computer game storytelling would have detracted from the relentless pace of the game and the freedom and control you have over your character.
