[h1]HOW THE FUCK IS THIS GAME CONSIDERED EVEN REMOTELY GOOD[/h1]

THE GAME THAT STARTED IT ALL
Back in the 1990s, First Person Shooters were nearly all identical in design philosophy, with your game either being Doom, or a Doom clone.  Every new FPS had the same formula, with its own stylistic changes, Doom was a Sci Fi game with light horror elements, Duke Nukem 3D was a ode to 80s action flicks, and Quake, while being in 3D, was just Doom with a darker tone. That is in no means a diss to these games, they are all great games from this time period, and my profile picture is Duke Nukem right now for crying out loud, but it was the truth. FPS games hadn't had a real major change in terms of gameplay, and by 1998 it was getting old. You can only go so far rehashing the same type of game before it gets old, and it was very true for the Doom type shooters. 

And this is where our savior GabeN steps in.

Back in 1996 two former Microsoft developers Gabe Newell and Mike Harrington formed their own Game studio in Valve, and quickly  began work on Half-Life. Releasing in 1998 it was a huge success, surpassing anyone's expectations.  Critics praised it to the sun, and the consumers came out in droves to buy it. Very few game developers can make as big an impact with their first game as Valve did with Half-Life. For example iD software,  the developers of the father of FPS games Doom, started out with the mediocre Commander Keen, a Mario clone for PC, and the successful, but not majorly so Wolfenstein 3D before they got to Doom. Even Nintendo, the most iconic game company of them all, took over a decade to release a hit game, and that is without mentioning the near 90 years before they were making Video Games. But what made this game so huge?

It may seem hard to believe now, but Half-Life was mind blowing in 1998. This was a FPS game with a great story, great graphics (at the time), and groundbreaking gameplay. The games story seems rather simple today, but back in 1998 this was revolutionary. Remember that this was a time before stories were common in games. Most games, especially first person shooters, would have only the bare minimum of a story, for example Doom's story is basically just Demons break through a portal from hell to a human colony on Mars, and to even know that you would need to read the manual Doom shipped with. I still don't even know what Quake 1's story is supposed to be about, if there even is one. Half-Life did things completely different, by opening the game with a bit of a slow burn tram ride into your work, the Black Mesa Research Facility. Once you get off the train you are met by a Security guard, who may or may not be Barney Calhoun who brings up your running late. You soon run into a scientist who tells you that they are waiting for you in the test chamber in perhaps one of the most unsettling ways possible, which is an excellent use of foreshadowing. Before you head there you must go to your Locker room and grab your HEV suit, and maybe blow up some guys microwave casserole on the way. You arrive at the test chamber shove some alien rock into a machine and then everything goes to utter shit, with you briefly teleporting into an alien world, and return with Black Mesa overrun with aliens, and utter carnage. I won't spoil anymore, as there are a few more twists throughout the campaign that it is best you don't know about if you don't know already. 

The gameplay in Half Life is pretty standard, with a collection of your standard FPS weapons, such as the Pistol, Revolver, Shotgun, Assault Rifle (complete with a scarface style grenade launcher attachment), and a somewhat unique weapon in the crossbow. But before you get any of these, you start with a trusty Crowbar, which has in turn became an iconic part of not just half-life, but Valve as a whole. It's a slow burn to get these weapons, and you don't want to overuse them when you do get them as ammo is limited, so it is best to use the right weapons for the right enemies. There are some more unique weapons in the game as well, but it is best to let you discover those yourself in my opinion. 

The enemies in Half Life are all quite iconic now, with the Headcrab, Valves own version of the Alien Facehuggers, the 'Zombies' which are human corpses take over by said headcrabs, Vortigaunts, which are a really unique alien who can shoot orbs and teleport and an array of others, many of which are best encountered going in blind. 

As you progress through Black Mesa you will come across many scripted events that allow the game to tell its story without forcing you out of the gameplay once which is something that even to this day is unique and quite awesome. 

The graphics were great at the time, but didn't age very well looking back, which is too be expected when returning to a game from over 20 years ago. 

And if that isn't enough to sell how damn important this game is, release this is the game that the original Counter-Strike was a mod for, and also the game that Team Fortress Classic was a mod for. Both games Valve scooped up and started selling physically with Half-Life in a bundle that lead to this very platform, Steam, created so Valve could keep Counter-Strike and any other games they make up to date easily. 

Now no game is perfect and let me get this clear to end this review their are some decently large flaws with this game which boils down to 2 things. The platforming sections, which aren't terrible, but don't really fit in either, and the elephant in the room, the last 2 hours of the game. The platforming is easy to excuse as at the time it wasn't bad and was pretty decent, but it is the section of the game that has aged the worst, the last 2 hours of the game on the other hand, were lackluster even for 1998 standards, and Gabe Newell himself has stated it is the one thing he wish he could change in a Valve game. There are also a few other sections that haven't aged well, most notably the section on a rail, where you need to take an annoying raid on a kart, but aside from these 3 problems, the game has aged very well. 

Overall I 100% recommend you play this game, preferably before you play Half-Life 2 which has aged a bit better,  as for $10 normally and as low as  $0.99 on sale it's a no brainer,  where you can't go wrong. I also strongly advise you stay far away from Valve's official Source port of the game Half-Life Source with the exceptions being if your buying the Valve Complete Pack or play Gmod and really want OG Half-Life materials.

Finally got around to playing this "classic" from 1998, and wow... just wow... what an utter disappointment.

I'd say this game aged poorly, but I have doubts it was any good to begin with.  While not the worst game I've played, not by a long-shot, it is still not something I'd recommend.

The first issue I had where the movement controls.  I've played arena shooters so I know what a fast running speed fells like.  However, it feels like Gordon is wearing roller skates in this game.  Combine that with the precision platforming, (yes in a FPS), and you have a formula for frustration.

The game also has some lousy signposting even for 1998 standards.

Then you have the enemies who do insane amounts of damage, especially at later levels, on even the easiest difficulty.  The hit detection can be wonky at times.  (Died on time to an enemy soldier despite me having his head right in my cross-hairs and firing full bore at nearly point blank range.) 

I lost count of the number of times I rolled my eyes at a cheap death.  It got boring.

I really tried to like this game.  I wanted to love it, but I can't.  It got so bad that in order to just finish it I activated cheats, I was so fed up.

I doubt I will ever replay this, and have no idea how this became a "classic."

I've never played the half-life series and always heard good things about them, but I didn't have the consoles growing up so I never played them. Playing this in 2020, I enjoyed it, reminded me of simpler times. But I wasn't particularly wowed by it. Or at least not enough to understand the hype around the series. Looking at other shooters of the time, South Park 64, Quake II, Tom Clancy's Rainbox Six, Dark Forces II, it really was impressive. I remember the graphics from Dark Forces and Rainbow Six, so Half life did shine among them I'm sure.

The game was fun, the story was lacking, the long line from start to finish being mostly seemless was nice. That said, while little details like microwaving the soup until it explodes, the vending machines, little bits of dialogue saying hi to Freeman... all that was nice, but I felt there was a distinct lack of story. I only knew that I was Gordon, I was going into work for something. Then I go press a button because someone told me and all hell breaks loose. Then for some reason we're the ones who HAVE to go and do a bunch of stuff. I guess it's because Gordon's the only one with the hazard suit on? Or because he's the only scientist who hits the range and gym? I'm not sure. But putting that aside, when there was small bits of exposition it was barely enough to tell you a vague objective and I often was doing puzzles because I saw them and figure'd I just needed to do it, not because anyone explained why. I did the whole rocket-kills-the-alien puzzle without having any idea WHY I was doing it and it was only after the alien died that I realized that I was doing that to open up the hole to travel some more. Then, the game ends in the way that it does and we're left with no particular answers or clues as to why this strange person is giving us a portal home or what they really want. Is it the mystery that got people intrigued? I don't understand. I hope that by playing the second game I'll get it some more, but while the first half-life is fun, and was unique in some ways, it just seems like a solid game to me and something to inspire a million decadeslong memes about half-life 3 never ever. I guess I'll learn more later.

"If you thought all action games were the same..."

"...Think again."
- Half-Life Box.

Absolute Poetry and the best way to describe the game. 

Half-Life isn't your Brother's quake, it isn't your papa's Doom, and it surely isn't your granddad's Wolf 3d. Half-Life is something else. The enemies are dangerous, always present, and their tactics always change. You can't just go in and shotgun a marine, then move on. No, because you will waste a lot of ammo on one of them, and by the time they are down, about 3 others have probably dog-piled you. You need to use every one of your weapons to their full effect, and find creative uses for all of them, in order to not only kill your enemies, but to also flush them from cover and into your gunfire. They know how to use their weapons like professionals (Because they're mostly army grunts), and you are nothing but a lonely scientist. What are you going to do to fight them?

Answer: Superior Intellect.

Because of this, Half-Life is an incredibly unique and fun action FPS which is doubtlessly timeless. While many prefer HL2, I will always have a soft spot for Half-life. And hey, if you are reading this review, then you can thank Half-Life for putting Valve on the map, and subsequently making Steam. So, there's that!

Half-Life is daunting, challenging, and tough as hell. But remember:

Run.
Shoot.
Think.
Live.

This game isn't perfect. But I think the experience as a whole makes up for it's shortcomings. First, I'll get to what I don't like about this game.
Half-Life has a big departure from classic FPS level design. Instead of a maze shooter where you find switches/keys to progress in the level, Half-Life's formula is relatively linear. Although this isn't necessarily bad, the game will feel very dumbed-down to someone who is used to Doom and Build engine games. There are a few levels that are a bit more open, but they all usually are long, boring, or tedious. 
But besides that (and a couple glitches), I had a lot of fun playing this game. I think the weapons are fun, the mechanics nice to mess around with, the enemies enjoyable to battle, and the story interesting to think about. I think if you're a fan of classic FPS's, you should play this game if you haven't already. Even if you aren't usually one to play first person shooters, check this one out.

7 / 10. Painstakingly tedious.

Half-Life is one of those games that are so known that it's kind of impossible to say something bad about. The nostalgia googles are on and no-one's keen on taking them off.

Dubbed "one of the three titans" (alongside Unreal Tournament and Quake III: Arena), this was a must play at the turn of the new millennium. The internet cafes were crowded with people playing the titans and also other less mentioned games (like Delta Force or Rainbow Six). The thing is... everyone played multiplayer (death match) and mostly the mods: Wanted, Opposing Force, Counter-Strike. Almost no one would play single player.

I remember asking people in the day if the single player experience was any good, but most players told me they either hadn't played it or that is wasn't all that great. As someone who hasn't played the single player experience back in the day, I can surely say that playing this game decades later is a whole different experience that it would have been in '99.

Visually, the game looks great for the time it came out. It has it's distinct look and feel but after finishing the game, I do feel that a lot of elements were inspired by games that were happening in that time frame, especially Action Quake II (which is funny as Counter-Strike would become the spiritual successor), Unreal (the Xen levels) and Duke Nukem as far as some panels and details go.

What I find particularly weird is that later iterations and mods (DM, CS) would bring more improvements which were never back-ported. I really wonder why they didn't take the time to keep all games at the same level of detail.

The sound is generally bad. I understand that positional sound was a great thing at the time, but for the most time you can't really understand what anyone's saying. The sound options don't have any effect on the game. Music is nice but it's so rare that you'll probably miss it. I found myself actually listening to external music because everything was too bland.

Gameplay is where the mishmash comes in. Controls are dated. Very clunky, needing very high coordination for some areas. Some jumps require perfect timing. Climbing and descending stairs was never a strong point, but that fall damage really hurts (you get less damaged from enemies than from the fall damage).

The first 3rd of the game is really good. You feel engaged. Everything is done and detailed in a perfect manner. After this point, the game quickly comes to a crawl because every 5 minutes you'll encounter precisely engineered annoyances. Every step you take you'll get shot, jumped-at, exploded, stalked, etc. It becomes so tedious that a typical player would just consider it's not worth the effort. Everything is scripted to be against you. If this game was made today, I would say that developers purposely made the game hard, but that was the way of thinking for the time.

The puzzles are so prevalent that I feel this game is a Puzzle game with Shooter elements and not the other way around. And everything lacks detail. You either get it or look up a walkthrough. Hints are rarely introduced and there isn't any map or general guidelines.

There's a handful of bugs which sometimes can stop the player's progress. Saving is plentiful. Save scumming is essential. You don't take too many steps without the need to reload. All these traps and forced difficulty really play a toll on your nerves and overall opinion.

Balancing is mostly ok, but sometimes munition is lacking. A third of the game I couldn't find any magnum ammo. The Xen levels are the worst offender. The Hive Hand would be your main choice and it slows everything to a crawl (shoot, miss, wait for reload, repeat). Some weapons are introduced too late and some items are too abundant (there's not too many uses for the tripmine).

Enemies are not too diverse. Some of them, like the soldiers, are overpowered (grenades every few steps, with pinpoint accuracy). There's not such thing as stealth. Every enemy knows where you are. There's no point in having a silent crossbow if the enemy shoots you before you even have the time to target them. Scripted events make enemies invulnerable. Also there are some triggers that never get disabled (and always spawn new enemies).

Overall the experience is ok, but with a lot of highs and lows. Playing it in short sessions is the key to beating the game.

As I was saying earlier, this game would have been a great deal in it's day, but it doesn't stand the test of time. It's all down to personal tastes, but I feel that this game is just ok, that very rare mainstream ok game. Looking back at Shooters made in the second half of the '90s, I dare say Half-Life wouldn't have even been on my top-choices list.

Very good game overall. Some sections are a bit lackluster like the parkour sections and the final few chapters but I'd say that the rest of the game is a magical experience. If you've never played the game before I'd definitely suggest purchasing it.

There is a reason why this game rivals other first-person-shooter games of the 90's, such as Doom, Quake, and Duke Nukem, and that reason is the incredibly immersive storytelling; most other games will force exposition dumps upon the player - but not Half-Life! Instead of having to sit through boring exposition and dialogue you have no interest in, Half-Life tells a story with its incredibly immersive world, a world that few other games can rival. The game is one, long journey - no filler, no wasted time, no annoying interruptions, and certainly no times where you are forced to deal with situations in specific ways, which brings me to my next point: freedom; Half-Life is an extremely linear game, which completely contrasts what I just stated about it being linear, but that is where you are wrong! - the linear environments and level designs allow for a well-tailored experience that was built in a fashion that every single weapon (even the weak pistol) is useful. The sheer amount of weapons and options combined with the freedom the player has in using them lends itself to pure freedom for the player in combat, thus giving it some of the greatest combat, if not THE greatest combat, in any FPS game ever made! The game is perfection and has aged like a fine wine in both the game-play and story department, with the tiny exception of ladders (which are clunky nightmares), so I absolutely insist on anybody reading this to buy this game if they are interested!

A great start to a great franchise. Can't believe how well the first couple of Half-Life games hold up. The atmosphere in each game is gorgeous, engrossing, and irreplaceable. It's a distinct style that only Half-Life could pull off. I'll miss the veterans who worked on this game; it's clear those lost influences have impacted the direction of modern Half-Life, for better or worse. But I will always be grateful for the world this introduced, and the influence it has had on the games that came after, the developers it spawned. If you can't tell, I really really really like this game. A lot. Play it. I don't think you'll regret it. This is playable history for an entire industry.

[h1]Made the FPS genre better[/h1]
Before Half-Life, the FPS genre had almost non-existent storylines that appeared as a paragraph at the end of episodes like in Wolfenstein 3D, Doom, and Quake outside of being mindless shooters. Half-Life pushes the stereotype by forcing you to use tactics for dealing with your targets as well as solving physics puzzles. To incorporate the story, this game puts you into the mind of Gordon Freeman. Everything you see, Gordon sees. You commute to his job, talk to the scientists, and overheard the soldiers plans while still being Dr. Freeman.

(No spoilers, and this is an actual review intended for those not familiar with Half-Life)

This game was revolutionary, and a must-play for anyone who is interested in video game history. That said, I think the point of Steam reviews is more about if the game is worth playing on its own merits, and imo this one hasn't really held up super well. There's some things that are still great in modern day, like the atmosphere and sound design (although the actual sound quality is about what'd you expect from the game's era). However, to be honest, I don't think those just looking for a game to have fun in and don't really care about history and 'playing the first Half-Life' and such will get much out of this.

This game has some serious flaws, some of which I've heard even the most die-hard fans acknowledge, and others that apparently are a hot take from me for whatever reason. I think most people agree that the last two chapters are pretty lackluster in terms of level design, as well as some other bits throughout. In general, this game has a lot of 'where the hell am I supposed to go' moments, which can be pretty frustrating, though I can forgive that since to be completely honest I am the sort of person who gets easily lost in both games and real life. (In other words your mileage may vary)

I think the gunplay is this game is generally pretty crappy by modern standards. And I don't mean crappy as in just mediocre, like in Half-Life 2, I mean actually annoyingly bad. My most hated weapon in particular is the MP5 (or the M4 if you're using the HD pack [which don't by the way because it sucks]). Every bullet seems to go left or right and anywhere but what you're aiming at, and not like in Counter Strike or other games where it's an actual pattern you can control. It's just basically unusable, which sucks since you kinda have to use it unless you want to have a very hard time getting through certain sections. Only a few of the weapons have any power to them, due to floaty, dated looking animations. 

The AI is generally pretty good, a bit too good aim-wise in my opinion. You can get pixel-sniped in this game pretty easily, which is especially annoying during some of surface sections. Other than this though you will definitely feel like you're fighting formidable foes throughout the game. Soldiers especially have very complicated scripting in certain areas that make them behave more like real-life soldiers. They will flank, lob grenades, and get to cover to gain the upper-hand. The AI is overall is challenging, but mostly fair.

As many will say and I will agree with is that this game is world-class in storytelling and atmosphere. It starts very slow, setting up the world and events that play, before thrusting you into survival-scavenge mode. I don't have many criticisms here, except that a more robust 'level' (or chapter) select probably would have been helpful, like was done in the sequel. The game generally keeps you immersed very well, with an optional but fairly helpful tutorial level. 

This is a minor nitpick, but I'm generally not a big fan of games have a quicksave feature over more optimal checkpoints, as personally it takes me out of the world because I'm worrying about whether I should save now or wait or whatever. Also, the voice acting, while very funny and something I love to quote to friends, is kinda bad. It's not really the voice actors as much as it's the writing; again though it's pretty funny and honestly one of the parts of the game I cherish. 

In summary, while the game definitely is very important and has very real high points, I don't think someone who doesn't already have an alternative motivation to get through the game is likely to enjoy it nearly as much as people like to say. If you've never played a Half-Life game, to be honest I would recommend skipping this one and its expansions, and just start at Half-Life 2. The sequel is a much better all-around game, and retcons a lot of stuff anyways so it doesn't matter that much to be out of the loop. If you're into older games and somehow haven't played this however, you may be into it.

So much has been said about this game that it hardly feels worth even reviewing, but in spite of the fact that I've been immersed in Half-Life lore and fandom from a young age as a PC gamer and FPS fan, it's only been recently that I've actually picked up the game and played it, so please consider this a review for the benefit of people who may have heard a lot about Half-Life but just haven't gotten around to it yet.

The one thing that everyone praises about this game above all else is the way that it seamlessly marries story and gameplay, and I have to say it lives up to the hype.  The game is well-structured and paces itself so that the story unfolds at around the same pace that the mechanics do.  It all flows pretty naturally, beginning with Gordon Freeman as a humble scientist and following him as he adapts to a bizarre situation and becomes something much bigger than he was before, and this whole time the level design organically teaches you the game's basic mechanics and encourages you to use them to get better at the game at your own pace, so you never feel like you're being left behind but it also never feels like you're having your hand held either.  The story is rarely if ever intrusive, meaning that you can enjoy the depth of Half-Life's story at your leisure if you please or you can just treat it like a fun shooter and ignore the story entirely.  It's up to you.

The gameplay isn't without its quirks.  There's a lot more platforming than one would expect, a product of the age in which Half-Life was developed.  If you're not accustomed to platforming in first-person it may take some getting used to.  Crouch-jumping also doesn't feel quite as smooth as it is in more modern games, but with practice you'll get the hang of it.  There were only one or two moments where the platforming felt intrusive and out-of-place and they were generally short enough to be forgiven.

Some friends I've spoken to take umbrage with the inventory system in Half-Life, preferring the more conventional weapon-swapping system in which you use the scroll wheel to cycle through weapons, whereas here the scroll wheel cycles through a menu that you have to pick a weapon from.  At first this seems like a bizarre choice even for the time, but on reflection I actually quite like this system, because it adds an extra second of panic when you're trying to swap weapons in combat and that works really well with the story.  Gordon Freeman is not a trained soldier, he's a scientist who happens to have a suit of power armor on; he's not trained to deal with the stress of combat and that's reflected in that extra second of clunkiness you'll get when you switch weapons.  Sure it's not the smoothest design, but Gordon isn't a smooth fighter, at least not until the events of Half-Life 2 when he's got more combat experience under his belt.

If you absolutely must play this game unspoiled then you can stop reading here assured that I thoroughly recommend Half-Life as a classic shooter with an excellent narrative focus and solid gameplay that still holds up today.  Give it a download, play it through, hunt for some secrets, download some mods, play the Deathmatch mode, have fun.  It's well-worth the ten bucks Valve is charging for it these days and it's certainly worthy of your time.



So spoiler time then: I hate this game.  I'm serious, I fucking hate this game.  Specifically I hate the last few levels, after Gordon teleports to Xen.  If you have friends that played Half-Life you've probably heard them say that the Xen levels are terrible and they really are.  I was having a ton of fun shooting zombies, sneaking around military personnel and alien invaders, and letting the levels challenge me to figure out the best solutions myself in real time.  Then Xen happened, and the entire dynamic of the game changed.  Lower gravity, heavier emphasis on platforming, more numerous and increasingly annoying enemies, really difficult to find ammo, confusing level design, and a constant sense that you have no idea what the game wants from you.

To be clear, I think I would have liked Xen if the game had done a better job of setting it up, but as it stands it comes right out of nowhere and leaves me utterly gobsmacked at how fundamentally opposed to the core design of Half-Life it really is.  I think I know what they were going for: Xen is supposed to be the point where Gordon steps into an utterly unknown world and has to survive on his wits and intuition, but instead what it feels like is my asshole friends stopped Highlander right towards the climax and put Highlander 2 in instead.  And then punched me in the gut.

I was so utterly repulsed by Xen and so frustrated with how bullshit the enemies and level design were at this point in the game that I actually stopped playing.  I will never finish Half-Life.  Why should I?  The game's ending is plastered all over YouTube and the sequel has been out since 2007.  I know what happens, and I know that there's a better game in my library waiting for me to play it.  Why would I waste my time with this crap?

Despite all of my revulsion for the penultimate chapters of the game, however, my recommendation stands, because at its core Half-Life is still a five out of five classic shooter with a well-deserved reputation as an innovator in the market which the industry continues to use as a design template to this day.  It just so happens that right towards the end its five star score to drops down to a two star.  I know that's harsh but I'm trying to give an honest review based on my experience with the game.  Maybe you won't find the Xen levels as offensive as I did and that's fine with me; do enjoy them at your leisure, but you've been warned.

Would've made this game a thousand times better if they had either cut out the platforming or at the very minimum, removed Lambda Core, cause boy howdy that level is the bane of my entire existence.
"Go through this level that consists of unlabeled portals that don't tell you what they do or where they lead to, just jump in and pray to god you don't get fucked!" is the real catchy slogan for that level, not to mention that there are parts in the alien levels that really get on my nerves as well.
I see why it's considered a classic, but it has some real irritating flaws that should've been ironed out before being released.
Overall, I'd say it's a 6.5/10. It's all right, but really knows how to grind my gears.

What more can be said about this game, Valve is like an unstoppable force of quality and the first time people realised that was with this game. This is seriously the first real attempt at " Story Driven Video Games" Half life was a game changer that anyone practiced in the game industry knows about and likes. Half life gets its reputation deservedly, and many many games like to take inspiration from it, like listening to a war veterans stories and writing a book about it. 

The game generally was instrumental in its release era, it threw tons of interesting puzzles and ideas at you and told you to get used to them, you spent a long while trying to find a solution and when you do it feels great, the plot is serious and interestingly original, gordon freeman has a great design, a great feel to him, like he deserves to be where he is and know s how to operate things like the energy weapons. The alien and enemy designs are fun and creative, the atmosphere can scare talibans out of their bomb vests. The underwater parts were frightening and pisspants thriller. The gunplay is solid and satisfying, the Nihilanth Boss fight is god teir with its level design and the ending is god damn wonderful.

There is no such thing as perfection, however, and there were some small issues i have to nitpick, sadly.
The flashlight kinda sucks, its lighting is weird in a way that its more like a concentrated beam of light than a torch, its better than the Opposing Force expansions goggles but still, the AI is clunky, bots that you need to progress need alot of handholding to get where you want, the enemies are really solid for the most part, except for the occasional steph curry perfect grenade throws and those aliens that shoot homing missiles that hit you through walls and stuff. The Xen Climax was also pretty unfair and clunky, i think it was Interloper with the fucking platforming bit that forced you to fly up in the air and inevitably die from fall damage, fuck interloper.

Get this game with the valve bundle to get every valve game. The Half life series is legendary and no valve-made half life game has failed to amaze the time it was released, who the fuck knows WHATS gonna happen after Alyx but considering Half lifes roots as one of the best gane series of all time, all we can do is patiently wait for the next video game revolution

Back in 1998, Half Life 1 was released, It was ground-breaking. It won a lot of awards. But does the game still hold up? Yea I'd say it does.

However, there are some certain part that have aged. This game being released in 1998, does really show. 
-The Graphics are.. well obviously has aged quite badly. This isn't really fair though as this was of course back in 1998.
-The Movement is pretty janky, You feel pretty slippery and often times you'll accidentally fall of platforms from said slippery movement.
-The weapons are alright, They certainly do a some decent amount of damage.
-The gameplay is wonderful, I had a lot of fun playing this game. It could kill a decent amount of hours.
-The story is pretty alright. It's not too complicated and very simple.
-The music is incredible, I really really love the music. It fits the game nicely, and is really enjoyable.

Overall, If you have a few buck to spare. I'd recommend you buy this game. Like a lot of Valve games, It's pretty cheap on sale.

Honestly, it doesn't really hold up for me. I played through this game because I was interested in knowing the story before starting half life 2, since I got that game during a sale. The story for this universe is very cool and knowing what happens in half life is useful but the gameplay was infuriating. I can recognize that this game was amazing for the time, especially in terms of realism and story-building, but the actual experience of going through this game was like pulling teeth. Enemy placement is designed in such a way that you WILL take damage no matter how cautious you are, enemies will spawn behind you and they will hide behind corners lying in wait. I had to resort to saving constantly because you have to make sure you have enough health to make it to the next health station and some areas REQUIRE you to know what is about to happen or you will take damage from something.

TL;DR: Story is worth knowing, actual gameplay experience is agonizing. Read about what happens then play Half Life 2.

I can‚Äôt help but feel I‚Äôm missing out on something because every single positive review seems to be talking about a completely different game than the one I played. I should specify this is a review of the first 3 hours of the game (I couldn‚Äôt bear it any further) from someone who is completely new to the series, unconcerned with its legacy. 

The graphics and overall presentation hold up fine. They would obviously be considered dated by today‚Äôs standards but they‚Äôre pleasant, if unremarkable, and don‚Äôt break immersion.

The issue with Half-life is... well... everything else. 

The level design is shockingly bad from both an aesthetic and functional perspective. The muted greys of the facility are repetitive and boring and the game somehow fails to make a secret underground nuclear(?) military research base novel in any way. If vents turn you on you‚Äôll be hard as diamonds by the end of this game because the sheer amount of them is staggering. There are puzzles I suppose (I stacked a crate!) but the strongest puzzle is ultimately going to be finding a reason to continue playing. Few if any of the puzzles are engaging or challenging and feel more akin to busywork. 

The layout is twisting and bizarre to the point of having nothing in common with any real life building whatsoever. Its so shockingly so that it constantly breaks immersion and provides no sense of progression. It feels as if the player is merely tossed around different parts of some massive sprawling purgatorial corridor, never gaining a sense of whether they‚Äôre closer or not to the end goal (escape?).

Of course this would not be a complete non-issue if the shooting was the focus and the setting was just an excuse to get the to meat of the game (e.g. mario 64). However that‚Äôs not the case- clever storytelling through gameplay and environment are often touted as a major draw of the half life series. There are certainly instances of this - learning the military is in fact not there to help as you watch scientists gunned down from above, or seeing some poor soul dragged into a vent in the distance, foreshadowing the arrival of (yet more) headcrabs. But these instances are here and there and aren‚Äôt interconnected in any interesting way. 

Furthermore the actual meat of the game (Puzzle solving, FPS gameplay) is‚Ä¶ passable at beast. The shooting is OK. I didn‚Äôt expect much and it delivered wholesale on that expectation. The guns are generic dollar store military weapons and feel underwhelming to shoot.

There‚Äôs very little in the way of mechanics or movement to learn, and the dominant strategy ultimately comes down to simply running past most enemies (the most pleasant way to play the game on hard). On the rare occasion however, the game flips the script and you‚Äôre stuck between hordes of vortigaunt and the exit hoping you don‚Äôt get insta force-lightninged to death while you wield the worst shotgun known to gaming history. Obviously this is 1998 so I‚Äôm not expecting current day AAA levels of feedback and tuning in the gunplay, but compared to something like Doom or even Marathon Half Life‚Äôs gunplay can‚Äôt hold a candle and feels phoned in.

The movement is clunky and has some weird kind of inertia to it. This wouldn‚Äôt be a problem in your average FPS but the game is filled with an outrageous amount of platforming over instant death pits (Sometimes several in a row) meaning you‚Äôll be restarting at the same checkpoint over and over unless you‚Äôre save scumming s.t.a.l.k.e.r. style. Another weird design choice in this vein is crouch jumping. It‚Äôs unclear to me why crouch jumping is so heavily implemented in the game. It feels janky and adds nothing whatsoever. Why not just let Freeman jump higher? 

The ladders make me want to blow my brains out. 

I can‚Äôt say whether the story picks up later or not but the beginning has nothing to offer. The silent protagonist is a theoretical physicist who works with highly dangerous alien materials. This seems novel, and a welcome change from the characters that seem typical for the genre. But nope. Half life is just an cool man who kills aliens and doesn‚Äôt afraid of anything. 

On hard the difficulty is inconsistent, ranging between easy (most segments with the soldiers) to extremely punishing (office with the vortigaunts), and the game rarely finds a way to slowly build up difficulty or create a skill curve. 

There are some novelties in this game, and those occur when the puzzles mesh with the combat, like leading superior numbers of enemies past a room filled with turrets while you dash behind the boxes to avoid getting shot. This is good fun and I imagine this is what made the game a hit, but for every one of these moments there‚Äôs another level segment filled with god awful platforming, crate stacking, and vents. 

I‚Äôd give it a 2/5 at best. There were things to like about it and it‚Äôs clear the game was hugely influential but poor design choices and underwhelming FPS gameplay middle this title and prevent it from holding up alongside other FPS classics.

Oh man, where do i start? This game is incredible in so many ways! For starters, it blends puzzle horror and action elements beautifully and everything is very well paced. Never are you too scared, too stressed, or too worked up. It's quite amazing how the devs managed to strike such a good balance, they've hit the nail on the head! 
Often times you'll find yourself doing very interesting and fun enviromental puzzles, or going through small airvents cluttered with all sorts of diffrent creatures, or gunning down Marines with grenades, shotguns, crossbows, fuck it, even crowbars, if you're an absolute masochist!
The game also heavily rewards you for exploring and taking your time to search through every nook n' cranny and smashing every box you can find. the rewards are pretty basic, but often time much needed.
The difficulty is never really an issue, because the game is fair and rather forgiving, however, sometimes when doing risky jumps and manuevers it can be a little frustrating, atleast in my experience, although i might just be bad at fps platforming. either way, nothing deal breaking, just a bit of a incovinience

Overall, if you haven't played this game before for whatever reason, do yourself a favour and pick it up, even if you're a pussy like i am, i guarantee you'll be able to pull through even with all the Headcrabs popping out of vents, and Headcrab Zombies bursting through walls, you'll get used to it eventually, and come to expect it

Consider this review from  a newer generation of gamers, I've grown up with call of duty as my first person shooter, and for a game that come out 22 years ago, it puts the fps' of today to shame. I've played a few of them, and if you're anything like me, you have too, maybe you're even pretty good at it. Great. Now take everything you have learnt from those games, and bin it. This game is nothing like any first person shooter I've ever experienced. Firstly, the AI are MUCH MUCH smarter than you think, it makes you realize how dumbed down current fps' are to appeal to mainstream audience. Then, you come to the actual game play, this is not a game where you can deploy one tactic throughout the entire game, the enemies flush you out, they make you move, and are tactical. You're not some overpowered person destroying everything in your path, you have to be super efficient with the way you use the environment and your arsenal of weapongs.  I played this game on easy difficulty and I found it fairly difficult, so if you're new to this, might want to consider the difficulty. The game had so into it that at times, I suddenly had an urge to pee (just like you do when you used to play hide and seek as a kid). It's all round just incredible, the gameplay has a lot of variety too it, the story has you hooked, and once you get the hang of it, you're going to enjoy it too. But holy **** is it scary at first, maybe its the old graphics, the demonic looking monsters, or the eerie sounds, but I found it scary. Still, all adds to the experience, and if you're looking for a different kind of fps, this is something to give a go. Now I'm off to half life 2.

Visuals are audio are very dated, but this is forgivable due to the game's age and interesting storytelling. The only issues that are rather unforgivable would be the lackluster combat and inconsistent movement mechanics, but these aspects are most definitely improved upon in the later entries to the series.

Half-Life is one of the most important FPS ever, which makes it one of the most important games of any genre. Only Doom is more important than it, and MAYBE its successor, Half-Life 2. I played it a lot in the early 2000s, both this and its revolutionary mod, Counter-Strike.

This game, together with Goldeneye 007 for the Nintendo 64, changed FPS evolution, with a greater importance to narrative, and eliminating the stage structure. No more strong superheroes such as in Doom or Duke Nukem 3D: we now have Gordon Freeman, a scientist on an ordinary workday. The whole story is presented from his (or your) point of view, with no cutscenes.

Because there are no stages, the game happens in large, continuous ambients, with a brief loading between areas. However, it is incredibly linear, with few deviations along the way (usually to solve a puzzle that allows the player to continue the game later). This means that there is little backtracking, which is rather nice.

Like most shooters, there are a number of interesting weapons in the game, some of them very creative. Enemies are simple at first, even a little monotonous; later on they become smarter and stronger, as they use more elaborate strategies to kill you. However, the most important aspects of the game are the environment and the gameplay. Contrary to other games at the time, the player is not supposed to shoot everything on sight; instead, he/she must solve puzzles, advance with caution, and face 3D platforming in first person (although these moments are not that interesting, since movements are a little slippery).

Half-Life is a game with a much less archaic gameplay than the first FPS; however, being this a genre that has undergone so many changes over the years, many players may still consider this one a little dated. In fact, some of its cons are still quite noticeable, such as the already mentioned platforming (especially at the end of the game), graphics that have not aged very well (they were very good at launch, but not fantastic), and some episodes that are a little monotonous.

I recommend buying this game. It is worth the full price, which is not too high. Obviously, try to buy it during a sale (Steam often offers it at a high discount).

Some tips that can help those playing for the first time:
- configure the mouse to your taste, increasing its sensitivity accordingly;
- as the game is very linear, it doesn't have many secret areas, so do not waste time looking for them;
- save often, and especially before a platforming segment. Jumping in this game is very tricky;
- watch out for smarter enemies, as they really ambush you. Moving around to protect yourself is a good strategy.

What can I say? It's Half-Life. Almost every FPS game released after this game owes something to it.

Unlike many other historically important shooters, such as Doom or Quake, Half-Life's gameplay holds up pretty well in comparison to today's FPS fare, probably because it was so influential that other games since have simply followed its example. The gunfights are an addictive mix of frenzied improvisation and tactical planning, and the game's pacing is excellent (at least up until the unfortunate Xen chapters, which murder the pacing somewhat in its final 20% or so.)

In any case, this game is well worth the $2 it goes down to on sale. The question, then, is which version to buy; the original (as I am reviewing here), the Source port, or Black Mesa. Half-Life: Source is pretty much the same game but with the tradeoff of better box physics in exchange for more bugs and costing five times as much. Black Mesa is a totally different game, and not really my cup of tea; for my money, you should experience the original before deciding whether to try Black Mesa's reimagining.

I'd recommend this game to anyone with an interest in first-person shooters, past or present. It holds up, and for as little as it costs, you're not taking much of a risk on whether you enjoy it or not. Try it out!

For many years I've heard people rave about Half Life and how amazing it is. When I was younger, I didn't have a computer to play games on, so I never got the chance to play Half Life, and to find out for myself why it is such a beloved game to so many people. Then one day I saw the announcement trailer for Half Life Alyx and found out that Valve was letting people play Half Life for free in the months leading up to the release of Half Life Alyx and decided it was time to find out what was so special about this game. Starting out, I didn't really know what Half Life was about or what to expect from it. All I'd ever seen of it bits of a speedrun done at GDQ. I had no idea what I was about to get into. 

You play as a scientist  Dr. Gordan Freeman who works in a top secret military facility called Black Mesa. Your day starts with a science experiment, but during the experiment, something goes horribly wrong, causing aliens from a different dimension to invade Black Mesa. Your job is find a way to deal with this issue, using an ever growing arsenal of weapons to progress through Black Mesa to stop this alien threat. Once I started playing, I legitimately couldn't stop. I beat the game in 15 hours, and I think I put in half that time on the first day I started playing. All the weapons feel amazing, and you acquire them at regular intervals throughout the game, which gives you new and interesting ways to defeat your foes. Are you gonna lay down a tripwire to stop the enemy, toss a grenade at them, use your rifle, or just shotgun them in the face? The game is pretty easy at the beginning, but the difficulty ramps up as you progress, with the game throwing more difficult enemies and areas at you forcing you to get better at dealing with enemies while managing your ammo and keeping your health up. Some areas in the game gave me more trouble than others, but I didn't find this frustrating at all. I just kept adjusting my strategy until I found the one that worked. 

In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game enough. If you like first person shooters, enjoy games with a good story, and haven't played this game yet, what are you doing? Buy it. Right now. In no world do you ever regret buying Half Life. This game is a masterpiece and it does everything right. 

Thanks for reading, and Valve, please make Half Life 3.

Half-Life on release was a monumental game, with cutting edge graphical capabilities, revolutionary storytelling, and fast paced thrilling gameplay which established the now beloved valve software as a major player in the games industry. But if you think that this game has aged like anything but fine wine, you are wrong. as someone who hadn't played half life up until recently, I can confidently say that this game holds up remarkably. Everyone who enjoys FPS games should play this game at least once all the way through. The gameplay is fast paced, and requires a degree of thinking that will keep you on your toes. the storytelling is phenomenal and immersive, never taking you out of the shoes of Gordon Freeman as you watch events unfold around you. The soundtrack is great, though if I were to have one complaint about the whole game I wish the soundtrack would have kept playing a bit longer. I understand that it helps immerse you in the atmosphere by only having the soundtrack play occasionally during regular gameplay, but I feel that specifically during boss fights letting the music linger a while longer would be beneficial to the atmosphere. If you don't own this game already, but it. now. it's exceptionally priced, especially if you buy it as a part of one of the many bundles it's included in.

Half Life is an FPS game from the late 90s that, surprisingly, hasn‚Äôt aged all that poorly, given its age. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, the game looks and feels old, but it is still a fairly enjoyable experience. 
The only real problems I had with it are as follows:
The game will often ask the player to complete platforming challenges, and those can be really frustrating at times, given how slippery your character is when moving at his default speed.
Fall damage is way too high, you can lose more than a quarter of your max HP by falling from heights that usually would not even damage you in other games.
Climbing/Descending ladders can feel incredibly awkward.
The path ahead is not always clear. The game almost never directly tells you where you need to go, and while I do appreciate the lack of handholding, finding yourself in a situation you have absolutely no idea where to go or what to do will not be a rare occurrence, specially in the later parts of the game.
The music in the game might glitch out if you find yourself loading saves often.
The quality of the audio in general is bad, most sound effects and voices sound like they were recorded with a shitty Xbox 360 mic. I‚Äôve seen older games with better audio.
The final boss is not particularly good, since you are forced to rely on a very inconsistent mechanic to get the final hit. 
The game might be a bit too lengthy. While the game will constantly put you in interesting scenarios, the overall simplicity of its gameplay might get you burned out by the end.
Those problems aside, the game can still be pretty fun. The gunplay is decent and the puzzles are well thought out in most cases. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who might be interested in checking out what might be the most influential game in the PC gaming industry.

ADVICE FOR PEOPLE WHO WANTS TO ENJOY THIS GAME.
I know this game might look ugly to you because of how outdated it is, but it's not fully the fault of its age,
- I recommend you to turn the resolution to 640x480 on 4:3 aspect ratio, this really helped me because playing on 16:9 makes your movement more inaccurate and makes you prone to falling off platforms, and the lower resolution helps masks the game's textures that were not meant for modern displays.
- If you have a CRT Monitor, I suggest you dusting it off and plugging it in to play games like these, or any game really, not only is it aesthetically pleasing, the graphic translates better on CRT as it is its intended monitor to work with.
- The game is kind of hard, especially on the harder difficulty, I suggest you to bind some of your keys to quick save and quick load, for example
Bind p "save quick"
Bind o "load quick"
- Be creative with the game, half life won tons of awards for a reason, the gameplay is really flexible, there are multiple ways for you to tackle a single enemy, shotgun to the face, bounce grenade off of the walls, use tripmines and lure them over with a pistol shot, etc.
I hope this helps because I know how it feels playing this game without knowing these beforehand, it feels bland and wonky. I hope this helps you to understand how the game was meant to be played and how to enjoy it in a today.

In all honesty, the game is not perfect. Even for a game released in 1998, it has problems. The game can drag on when your just walking and WALKING and walking. Something I never had with Half Life 2,  besides the beginning. Though, in all honesty, this might be the best game of 1998. And yes, I know Ocarina of Time was released the same year.

There is no cutscene. You are always in control. When a character is talking, you can walk around and do just about whatever you want. Also, speaking of control, youre never held back. You can kill anyone you want. And, it's satisfying. Truly, it is! If you're bored and want this guy whose been talking for 3 minutes dead? Pull out that gun, kill him. There is never something holding you back in this game, and I LOVE it. Also, not only that, but after you fight someone for a while and finally get that bullet that kills him, it is truly more satisfying than Half Life, because one thing that is truly rare is that they made the enemies, specifically the soldiers, have the same amount of health as you. It's not like every other game ever released, when usually the starter enemy is a lot weaker than you. That's because your both people. And, once again, I LOVE it. 

If this game was released today with good graphics, it can still be great. Except for the glitches. There are tons of glitches I encountered the game. Actually, sadly, this is one of the glitchiest games I have ever played. I've seen multiple cutscenes about to start, and then the NPC disappears. Guns don't work and you have to kill yourself just for them to work. 

Overall, it's not a perfect game. Half Life 2 is MUCH better. But, this is without a doubt still a great game.

Overall, this is an excellent game, it looks very good and has a great story. But as this is my first time playing, and I've never watched a walk through before, I had no idea what happened in the game apart from the very basic premise. 

My main gripe, which is in my opinion a big one, is that for a new player like myself with no prior knowledge of the game, playing it and progressing can be difficult at times. Sure, some of the puzzles I should've guessed, but other ones I had absolutely no idea what to do or where to go and would have to consult with a Youtube video to find out what to do next. The game doesn't really seem to give you any pointers, just leaves you on your own to get frustrated at what on earth do you have to do to advance.
For me, this does ruin the game quite a bit as instead of just enjoying playing through the story and completing the puzzles I am frustrated and lost. I'm sure this might be partly to do with the fact that I don't really play story-style games, but nonetheless I think that is a serious flaw of the game.

If you enjoy sci-fi, adventure and action and don't mind getting frustrated often, this is the game for you.

If you're just looking for a chilled out sci-fi or adventure game that is easy to follow, Half Life is probably not going to be as good of an experience as people rave about.

For me, I still enjoy the game, not as much as I was expecting but I am still enthusiastic to play it.

The Half-Life game series is arguably the most influential in the PC gaming industry. It starts in 1998, most of the popular games at the time were Quake and Doom. In those games you play as super soldiers. Super hero-like characters with powerful strength. When Half-Life came out, you literally spawned playing as ‚Äúman on his way to work‚Äù. It was a new concept compared to any other game, and even more relatable to the player. You didn't have super-strength, you didn't have mind-control. You were a normal scientist with a hazard suit. The suit, named HEV suit or Hazardous Environment Suit. It was the only real power that the main character, Gordon Freeman had at his disposal. It's a suit that's not meant for war, simply working in hazardous environments. 

	When you start the game, you are greeted with a long train ride to your workplace. You are Gordon Freeman, a man with a PhD in Theoretical Physics. Along the train ride, you witness the advanced AI. You see NPCs (Non Playable Characters) at work, at break and interacting with each other. Having normal human conversations, such as ‚ÄúDo you know who ate all the doughnuts?‚Äù And generally complaining about work environments or equipment failures. 

	You work at Black Mesa Research Facility, a government facility located in the New Mexico desert. It's a top secret facility working on all sorts of super cool futuristic technologies. A massive underground facility with housing, amenities and even their own TV and news entertainment. They have a small security force that works all over the facility to protect it from any failed Frankenstein-like experiments.

	When you arrive at your train stop, you are greeted by a friendly security guard who lets you out of your train and warns you that you are late to work and they are soon going to start a big experiment. Once freed from the train car, you enter the lobby of Sector C. You are then greeted by NPCs who tell you that you are late and must go to the test chamber. Once you have put on the HEV Suit and arrived at the test chamber, you begin the experiment. As predicted, it goes very wrong. You unintentionally create a portal to another planet prompting the native species to invade earth.

	Fighting your way through the facility, you learn that the military has been ordered to cover up everything. They do this by eliminating everyone associated with the failed experiment. When the military fails, the CIA special forces are there to do the same thing. They are even ordered to eliminate the leftover military forces who originally failed. All while this is happening, the player is mysteriously stalked by a man known as The G-Man. A tall pale man in a blue suit carrying a black leather briefcase. Nothing is really known about him and how he relates to the main game, but it's speculated that he plays a major role.

	I rate Half-Life 10/10. It is an absolute perfect RPG with an engaging story. Although at the time it took them 6 years to release Half-Life 2, I was not born yet so it did not affect me! I got to play the half life series back to back and I enjoyed every bit of it! I‚Äôve bonded with many friends over the Half-Life series and even the games based off of Half-Life such as the Counter-Strike series, HL Deathmatch, Ricochet, Day Of Defeat and Gary‚Äôs Mod. All great games that originally started with Half-Life, a game about a man who had a bad day at work.

I bought this when it came out on CD-ROM, and played the game to death in my late teens.  It still has legs, the puzzles are a lot harder than I remember and the levels are challenging without feeling too repetitive.  The atmosphere really draws you in, and the tension just never lets up.  No such thing as an 'easy' enemy either, even the most basic monster can be deadly if your health is under 40.  Look, it's dated in terms of graphics obviously, but don't let that deter you - you'l hardly even think about that once you're about 6 levels into the game.  It's easy to see the roots of the modern Wolfenstein in this game, as well as other shooters such as Prey.  Heck pretty much outside of Doom and Quake, HL is the most influential FPS of all time.   I never really got into Counter Strike, and I'm not a multi-player guy, so for me, I cannot comment on those aspects of the game.  But as a solo player in 2020, HL is well worth your time and money.

Since Half Life is a classic game that many gamers make a pilgrimage to play it pains me to say this but I've never played a more annoying and needlessly frustrating game in my life. With games like Dark Souls or Bloodborne where being challenging is apart of the experience, Half Life is difficult with the sole purpose of being a throne in my side. I'm currently at Surface Tension, and stuck in that room with like a million trip mines. Every step I take I blow up out of nowhere. This game autosaves at some of the most inconvenient times, it's so easy to die to the point a damn ball point pen could kill you, it has the most clunky controls I've ever seen (I acknowledge that it was made it 1998 but I've played games of the NES with tighter controls) if you fall six inches off the ground you lose half your health, ECT. I'm not even having fun playing Half Life anymore. I'm just playing it to be done with it so I can uninstall it and never look at its stupid, smug logo ever again.
